title: Question 1

children: A 67-year-old man is evaluated because of a 2-year history of multiple scaly spots on the forehead, cheeks, ears, and hands. The lesions are asymptomatic but unsightly. Medical history is unremarkable except for significant lifetime sun exposure and several painful, blistering sunburns as a child.
The lesions are thin and have a rough, sandpaper-like quality when palpated. Representative lesions on the hands are
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The usual presentation of actinic keratosis is a poorly defined, erythematous, scaly “sandpaper” macule that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of older persons with fair skin.
Extensive actinic keratoses require “field therapy” to adequately treat the extensive precancerous lesions; this can be achieved with topical fluorouracil.
Topical fluorouracil (
Option C

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient with likely actinic keratoses. The usual presentation of actinic keratosis is a poorly defined, erythematous, scaly “sandpaper” macule that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas (e.g., face, dorsal arms, hands, legs, and upper back) of older persons with fair skin. Approximately 1% to 5% of actinic keratoses will develop into squamous cell cancers. This patient has extensive involvement, with a large number of lesions. Extensive actinic keratoses require “field therapy” to adequately treat the extensive precancerous lesions. When there are more than 10 (to 15) lesions, targeted specific lesion destruction is often inadequate, so it is preferable to treat the entire affected area. This can be achieved with topical chemotherapy creams, such as fluorouracil, imiquimod, or ingenol mebutate; however, a randomized clinical trial demonstrated that fluorouracil is the most effective treatment. Topical fluorouracil is applied once or twice daily and causes erythema, blistering, and necrosis with erosion, followed by re-epithelialization. The process may take from 4 to 6 weeks. The prevention of additional actinic keratoses with sun avoidance and sun protection is an important therapeutic principle. Use of fluorouracil cream can reduce the number of new actinic keratoses that develop over the subsequent 6 to 24 months and reduce rates of new lesion growth, need for targeted lesion-specific treatment, and number of lesions overall.
Cryotherapy (
Option A

) with liquid nitrogen is also a treatment option for actinic keratosis, but it is used when there are individual or just a few lesions. It would not be a good choice in this patient with multiple lesions.

A randomized clinical trial compared fluorouracil cream, 5% imiquimod cream, methyl aminolevulinate photodynamic therapy, or 0.015% ingenol mebutate gel in the treatment of actinic keratosis in a White population. At 12 months, 5% fluorouracil cream was the most effective of four field-directed treatments. For this patient, fluorouracil would be preferred to photodynamic therapy (
Option B
) or imiquimod cream (
Option D

references: Jansen MHE, Kessels JPHM, Nelemans PJ, et al. Randomized trial of four treatment approaches for actinic keratosis. N Engl J Med. 2019;380:935-946.

title: Question 2

children: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening muscle weakness. She has end-stage kidney disease. Due to a recent family gathering, she was not adherent to her low-potassium diet. She has not been dialyzed for 3 days.
Vital signs are normal. Examination reveals diffuse muscular weakness of the lower extremities.
Serum potassium
level is 8.0 mEq/L (8.0 mmol/L) and blood
glucose
is 114 mg/dL (6.3 mmol/L).
ECG shows tall, peaked T waves.
Intravenous (IV) calcium gluconate is administered. Emergent hemodialysis is planned for later today.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?

In patients with significant hyperkalemia, intravenous calcium gluconate stabilizes the myocardium by lowering the threshold potential and is usually administered acutely to decrease the risk for arrhythmias.
In patients with end-stage kidney disease, intravenous insulin and glucose will lower serum by shifting potassium intracellularly.
The most appropriate additional treatment for rapidly lowering this patient's serum potassium level is intravenous (IV) glucose and insulin (
Option A

). She has end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) and presents with muscle weakness, hyperkalemia, and peaked T waves on ECG. Signs and symptoms are related to adverse effects of serum potassium on skeletal and cardiac muscle cell membranes, including muscle weakness and cardiac conduction and rhythm abnormalities. IV calcium gluconate stabilizes the myocardium by lowering the threshold potential and is usually administered acutely to decrease the risk for arrhythmias; however, calcium does not have any effect on serum potassium levels. The appropriate treatment for reducing serum potassium quickly in this patient with ESKD and hyperkalemia is both insulin and glucose given intravenously to rapidly shift potassium intracellularly. Insulin effectively drives potassium into cells by increasing activity of the Na
/K
ATPase pump in skeletal muscle. Glucose is given to counteract potential hypoglycemia associated with insulin therapy.
High-dose loop diuretics, such as furosemide (
Option B

), and thiazide diuretics increase kidney potassium loss, particularly when combined with saline hydration, in patients with normal kidney function or mild to moderate kidney failure. However, this effect is not immediate, and furosemide would be ineffective in this patient with ESKD.
IV sodium bicarbonate (
Option C

) raises the serum pH and leads to a shift of potassium into cells as part of the buffering process. However, it has not been shown to be an effective or predictable method for producing a hypokalemic response, especially in patients with ESKD.
Definitive treatment of severe hyperkalemia, unrelated to reversible transcellular shift, must include removal of potassium from the body. Patiromer (
Option D

) and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate are effective in binding potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and effectively lower potassium. However, hemodialysis is the treatment of choice in patients with severe hyperkalemia and oliguric kidney disease; this patient has no need for patiromer therapy.

objective.__html: Treat hyperkalemia using intravenous glucose and insulin.

references: Liu M, Rafique Z. Acute management of hyperkalemia. Curr Heart Fail Rep. 2019;16:67-74.

title: Question 3

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated because of a 7-month history of tingling and numbness involving the right index finger, thumb, and adjacent palm associated with recent onset of reduced grip strength. Sensory symptoms are worse at night.
On physical examination, there is right thumb abductor weakness and thenar eminence atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show median nerve sensorimotor denervation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Carpal tunnel syndrome presents as wrist pain that may radiate to the forearm and hand; paresthesia and weakness of the first three fingers and thenar eminence (median nerve distribution) may be present.

Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome who have active denervation on nerve conduction studies and have muscle weakness and atrophy on clinical examination should undergo decompression surgery to prevent irreversible motor weakness.
Decompression surgery (
Option A

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient with carpal tunnel syndrome. Carpal tunnel syndrome develops from increased pressure within the carpal tunnel causing median nerve compression. Diagnosis is usually established based on history. The syndrome presents as wrist pain that may radiate to the forearm and hand; paresthesia and weakness of the first three fingers and thenar eminence (median nerve distribution) may be present. Symptoms are often worse at night and with repetitive wrist motion. Risk factors include obesity, female sex, hypothyroidism, pregnancy, and connective tissue disorders. Although keyboard use has been suggested as a risk factor, it has not been confirmed by studies. Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome who have active denervation on nerve conduction studies and have muscle weakness and atrophy on clinical examination should undergo decompression surgery to prevent irreversible motor weakness. Uncontrolled pain and sensory symptoms can be another indication for surgery, but in the absence of motor weakness and active denervation, conservative measures to treat pain and control paresthesia should be attempted first.
Topical or oral NSAIDs, such as naproxen (
Option B

), are no more effective than placebo in managing symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome. Furthermore, in this patient with evidence of motor denervation, a trial of conservative treatment before decompression surgery may result in irreversible motor weakness.
Conservative treatment, such as nocturnal neutral wrist splinting (
Option C

) and glucocorticoids may be appropriate therapy for mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome, but only if the patient has no evidence of weakness, atrophy, or active motor denervation on nerve conduction studies.
In patients with mild disease, oral glucocorticoids such as prednisone (
Option D
) can be effective, but glucocorticoid injections are preferred to minimize systemic glucocorticoid side effects.

objective.__html: Treat carpal tunnel syndrome with decompression surgery.

references: Faktorovich S, Filatov A, Rizvi Z. Common compression neuropathies. Clin Geriatr Med. 2021;37:241-252.

title: Question 4

children: A 41-year-old man has a 9-month history of nausea, vomiting, early satiety, and postprandial bloating. His only other medical problem is chronic shoulder pain, for which he takes daily ibuprofen.
Vital signs are normal. The abdomen is distended, with epigastric tenderness without guarding or rigidity. A succussion splash is heard.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying include nausea, vomiting, early satiety, bloating, postprandial fullness, and abdominal pain.
In all patients with symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying, the initial diagnostic test is upper endoscopy to exclude gastric outlet obstruction.
The most appropriate management is to perform upper endoscopy (
Option D

). This patient has symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying, which is characterized by nausea, vomiting, early satiety, bloating, postprandial fullness, and abdominal pain. A loud succussion splash is associated with retained air and gastric fluid. It is auscultated with the stethoscope over the upper abdomen when the patient is rocked or the abdomen is palpated. Delayed gastric emptying can be due to either a mechanical gastric outlet obstruction or gastroparesis. Gastroparesis is a neuromuscular disorder of the gastrointestinal tract. It is most commonly idiopathic, but other common causes are diabetes, drugs, and surgery. In this patient, the use of ibuprofen could have caused peptic ulceration with outlet obstruction due to inflammation and/or scarring. In all patients, the initial diagnostic test is upper endoscopy to exclude gastric outlet obstruction. Once a structural cause for symptoms has been excluded, a test to assess gastric emptying (such as gastric scintigraphy, wireless motility capsule, or radiolabeled carbon breath test) is performed. Gastric scintigraphy is used most commonly. Once delayed emptying is confirmed, additional testing may be required to determine the underlying cause of the gastroparesis.
Only after mechanical obstruction is ruled out would gastric scintigraphy (
Option A
) be a reasonable test to evaluate for gastroparesis. If scintigraphy is pursued, the 4-hour study is preferred over 90- or 120-minute studies due to increased diagnostic accuracy.
A proton pump inhibitor, such as lansoprazole (
Option B
), might be used in this patient if a pyloric ulcer is diagnosed as the cause of mechanical outlet obstruction, but its use would be premature until a diagnosis is established.
Treatment of gastroparesis focuses on prokinetic drugs, such as metoclopramide (
Option C

), and avoidance of medications that impair gastric motility, such as opioids and anticholinergics. Pyloric botulinum toxin injections, pyloroplasty, and gastric electrical stimulation have been used as well. Treatment with any of these modalities would be premature until a diagnosis is established.

references: Lacy BE, Cangemi DJ. Controversies in gastroparesis: discussing the sticky points. Am J Gastroenterol. 2021.

title: Question 5

children: A 34-year-old woman is seen in follow-up for major depressive disorder. She has persistent symptoms despite cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Her PHQ-9 score was 14 before she started CBT and is now 9, indicating mild depression. After discussing the benefits and harms, it is decided to initiate sertraline. The patient is taking no other prescription or over-the-counter medications.
Physical examination is normal.
For which of the following conditions is this patient at most risk?

Serotonin syndrome can develop in patients taking any selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, bupropion, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors, alone or in combination with other prescription medications (such as opioids and triptans) or over-the-counter medications (such as dextromethorphan).
Findings unique to serotonin syndrome are shivering, hyperreflexia, myoclonus, ocular clonus (slow, continuous, horizontal eye movements), and ataxia.
The patient is most at risk for serotonin syndrome (
Option D

) due to the recent initiation of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) sertraline. Serotonin syndrome can develop in patients taking any SSRI or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), bupropion, or monoamine oxidase inhibitors, alone or in combination with other prescription medications (such as opioids and triptans) or over-the-counter medications (such as dextromethorphan). Symptoms usually develop within 24 hours of initiating therapy or a change in dose, or of initiating an interacting drug. Serotonin syndrome may be mild, with symptoms of anxiety, tremor, restlessness, or diarrhea, or may present with high fever, muscle rigidity, and cognitive changes. Findings unique to serotonin syndrome are shivering, hyperreflexia, myoclonus, ocular clonus (slow, continuous, horizontal eye movements), and ataxia.
Typical symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (
Option A

) include hyperthermia, dry skin and mucous membranes, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and mydriasis. Anticholinergic toxicity is most likely to occur following treatment of depression with a tricyclic antidepressant, not an SSRI.
Malignant hyperthermia (
Option B

) is a reaction to certain classes of drugs, including inhaled anesthetics (halothane and others) and depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (succinylcholine and decamethonium). It causes markedly increased intracellular calcium, increased cellular metabolism, and sustained muscle tetany. Severe muscle rigidity, masseter spasm, hyperthermia (core temperature up to 45 °C [113.0 °F]), cardiac tachyarrhythmias, and rhabdomyolysis usually manifest quickly when susceptible patients are exposed to a triggering agent. This patient has not been exposed to the implicated drugs.
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (
Option C

) is an idiosyncratic reaction resulting from administration of antipsychotic agents and certain antiemetic agents, or withdrawal of antiparkinsonian dopaminergic medications. It is characterized by muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, altered mental status, and autonomic dysregulation. This syndrome often occurs when drug treatment is started or after rapid dose escalation. The patient is not taking medications associated with this syndrome.

objective.__html: Assess the risk for developing serotonin syndrome.

references: Malcolm B, Thomas K. Serotonin toxicity of serotonergic psychedelics. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2021.

title: Question 6

children: A 28-year-old man is evaluated for a testicular mass recently discovered by his wife. He also notes the recent onset of cough and lumbar back pain.

An inguinal orchiectomy reveals a testicular seminoma. Tumor staging is performed, and distant metastases are discovered. He will be treated with highly-emetogenic cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent this patient's nausea and vomiting?

text.__html: Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and glucocorticoids
Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine
Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and medical marijuana

children: The major risk factor for nausea and vomiting in chemotherapy regimens is the emetogenicity of the chemotherapy agent being used.
For patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy, the combination of serotonin antagonists, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine are guideline recommended.
This patient should receive the combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine (
Option C

). Delayed nausea and vomiting are defined as symptoms occurring at least 24 hours after receiving chemotherapy, a sequela that can significantly affect a patient's quality of life. The major risk factor for nausea and vomiting in chemotherapy regimens is the emetogenicity of the chemotherapy agent being used. Highly emetogenic chemotherapy is associated with greater than 90% risk of emesis if appropriate prophylactic medications are not given. High-dose cisplatin is highly emetogenic. Serotonin antagonists like ondansetron or palonosetron are very effective in preventing acute nausea and vomiting but have less impact on prevention of delayed-onset symptoms. Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine have been shown to help with delayed nausea and vomiting. The combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine has been shown to significantly decrease breakthrough symptoms and is recommended by American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) guidelines.
Benzodiazepines, such as alprazolam (
Option A

) or lorazepam, are anxiolytics that may help with anticipatory nausea, vomiting, and anxiety related to treatment. However, these drugs can cause significant sedation and would not be helpful in preventing delayed nausea and vomiting. Anticipatory nausea and vomiting occur as a conditioned response in patients who experienced severe nausea and vomiting during prior cycles of chemotherapy. Anticipatory nausea and vomiting may be precipitated by sensory cues such as the room where chemotherapy is delivered, or by the travel route taken for treatment. The best prevention for anticipatory nausea and vomiting is selection of the most appropriate antiemetics and dosages for the chemotherapy that is to be delivered.

ASCO guidelines recommend adult patients who are treated with an anthracycline combined with cyclophosphamide should be offered a four-drug combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine. A combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and glucocorticoids alone (
Option B
) may be insufficient to prevent delayed nausea and vomiting in this patient receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy.

ASCO guidelines state that the evidence remains insufficient for a recommendation regarding treatment with medical marijuana for the prevention of nausea and vomiting in patients with cancer who receive chemotherapy or radiation therapy (
Option D

). Evidence is also insufficient for a recommendation regarding the use of medical marijuana in place of the tested and approved cannabinoids, dronabinol and nabilone, for the treatment of nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy or radiation therapy. Dronabinol is approved as rescue nausea medication in patients with breakthrough symptoms despite adequate prophylaxis. This patient's prophylaxis effectiveness has not yet been tested, so dronabinol would not be appropriate at this time.

references: Hesketh PJ, Kris MG, Basch E, et al. Antiemetics: American Society of Clinical Oncology clinical practice guideline update. J Clin Oncol. 2017;35:3240-3261.

Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient's anemia?

Patients with anemia of inflammation have a hemoglobin level of 8 to 10 g/dL (80-100 g/L) and a peripheral blood smear showing a normochromic, normocytic anemia associated with an elevated serum ferritin level, low serum iron level, and a reduced total iron-binding capacity.
Anemia of inflammation does not usually require treatment other than that of the underlying illness.
This patient has anemia of inflammation, which does not usually require treatment other than that of the underlying illness (
Option D

). Chronic infections (tuberculosis or osteomyelitis, malignancies, and collagen vascular diseases) are usually associated with anemia of inflammation. Pathogenesis of anemia of inflammation is multifactorial, likely resulting from enhanced immune response. Inflammation leads to increased levels of inflammatory cytokines, which lead to altered erythropoietin production and responsiveness. Increased production of peptide hepcidin by the liver causes decreased iron absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and decreased iron release by macrophages, resulting in a state of iron-restricted hematopoiesis. No laboratory test is commercially available for measuring hepcidin levels. Peripheral blood smear may be normal in patients with anemia of inflammation or, over time, may show microcytic hypochromic erythrocytes, such as in iron deficiency. Typically, anemia of inflammation is characterized by a hemoglobin level greater than 8 g/dL (80 g/L). Because of erythrocyte underproduction, reticulocyte count is typically low for the degree of anemia. Serum iron level is initially normal but decreases over time. Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is low, and serum ferritin level is typically elevated.
Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs), such as darbepoetin alfa (
Option A

), may improve anemia of inflammation but are associated with thrombosis and other effects that impede safe use. Their use has been limited to patients with other concomitant indications for ESAs, such as anemia of kidney disease. Treatment of the underlying inflammatory condition typically improves the anemia.
Intravenous iron (
Option B

) is indicated for patients undergoing dialysis who have large iron requirements or for patients with celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, or those who have undergone resection of the stomach or small bowel, for whom oral iron may not be adequate treatment. These patients typically require parenteral iron. This patient does not have iron deficiency and has no indication for parenteral iron therapy.

As ferritin levels increase with inflammation, identifying concomitant iron deficiency in these patients is sometimes difficult. However, most patients with serum ferritin levels greater than 100 ng/mL (100 µg/L) and saturation (serum iron/TIBC x 100) greater than 20% are usually considered to have adequate iron stores. In addition, TIBC in iron deficiency tends to be elevated and not decreased. Iron replacement (
Option C
) is unlikely to alleviate the patient's symptoms because she is not iron deficient.

references: Weiss G, Ganz T, Goodnough LT. Anemia of inflammation. Blood. 2019;133:40-50.

title: Question 8

children: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for an acute, persistent nosebleed from the right nares. Nose bleeds have been recurrent since the start of winter and use of the central heating system. She reports no recent trauma and has no personal or family history of bleeding disorders. She takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Blood is dripping from the right nares.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
First-line therapy for minor epistaxis is nasal compression for 5 minutes; other first-line treatments include application of vasoconstrictors, nasal packing, and nasal cautery.
The most appropriate treatment is nasal compression (
Option B

) for 5 minutes. Most episodes of epistaxis are anterior and occur in the Kiesselbach plexus, which is the vascular watershed area of the nasal septum. Common local causes are nose picking, trauma, irritants (such as medications, low humidity, foreign bodies, or rhinitis from viral infections or allergies), tumors, septal perforations, vascular malformations, and telangiectasias. Common systemic causes are thrombocytopenia, bleeding disorders, and use of anticoagulants (including antiplatelet therapy). The patient should be advised to use petrolatum to prevent drying of the nares. She should also be advised to use a home humidifier.

Other first-line treatments for epistaxis include application of vasoconstrictors, nasal packing, and nasal cautery. If the bleeding is not controlled with nasal compression and a bleeding source cannot be verified due to the briskness of bleeding, nasal packing should be performed. If the bleeding is controlled enough to perform nasal rhinoscopy, the clot can be removed and the bleeding source identified. The next step is often the use of topical vasoconstrictors, such as oxymetazoline or phenylephrine. If bleeding persists, chemical (silver nitrate) or thermal cautery can be performed after a topical anesthetic is applied. However, only one side of the septum should be treated at any one time to limit the risk for septal perforation.
Intranasal budesonide (
Option A
) has no role in epistaxis. In fact, intranasal glucocorticoids may cause epistaxis. Therapies, such as administration of phenylephrine (
Option D

) or oxymetazoline spray for vasoconstriction, are beneficial for acute epistaxis after the source of bleeding has been identified. Intraoperative topical phenylephrine has been linked to sudden death and some experts recommend against its use.
Anterior packing of one or both nares (
Option C
) should be performed if nasal compression cannot stop the bleeding and anterior rhinoscopy cannot identify a source of bleeding (often due to active bleeding obscuring underlying mucosa).

references: Tunkel DE, Anne S, Payne SC, et al. Clinical practice guideline: nosebleed (epistaxis) executive summary. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2020;162:8-25.

title: Question 9

children: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for chronic left knee pain. It is worse with walking and improves with rest. He has 25 minutes of morning knee stiffness.

On physical examination, BMI is 32. Left knee examination reveals a small effusion without redness or warmth. Crepitus and tenderness to palpation are present along the medial joint line. Knee radiographs reveal medial tibiofemoral compartment joint-space narrowing and sclerosis along with small medial osteophytes.
Which of the following is most appropriate initial management?

Guidelines for the management of osteoarthritis (OA) strongly recommend exercise and weight loss for knee OA; other strongly recommended therapies include self-management programs, tai chi, use of a cane or a tibiofemoral knee brace, oral and topical NSAIDs, and intra-articular glucocorticoid injection.
Weight loss and exercise (
Option D

) are indicated for this patient with knee osteoarthritis (OA). OA is a chronic progressive multifactorial disorder of maladaptive cellular repair responses to joint stress. It affects all the tissues of the joint and is characterized by cartilage and meniscal degradation, subchondral bone changes (bone marrow lesions, subchondral sclerosis), and osteophyte formation. This patient's knee pain suggests tibiofemoral knee OA, a diagnosis supported by the presence of medial joint-line tenderness and radiographic findings of medial tibiofemoral compartment joint-space narrowing. The strongest risk factors for OA are advancing age, obesity, female sex, joint injury (caused by occupation, repetitive use, or actual trauma), and genetic factors. Obesity, in particular, is the most important modifiable risk factor for knee OA. Several trials have demonstrated that weight loss and/or exercise programs can relieve pain and improve function, similar to the benefits of NSAID use. In long-term studies, sustained weight loss of approximately 6.8 kg (15 lb) has relieved symptoms. The 2019 American College of Rheumatology/Arthritis Foundation guideline for the management of OA strongly recommends exercise and weight loss for knee OA. Other strongly recommended therapies for knee OA include self-management programs, tai chi, use of a cane or a tibiofemoral knee brace, oral and topical NSAIDs, and intra-articular glucocorticoid injection.
The 2019 American College of Rheumatology guidelines recommend against chondroitin sulfate (
Option A
), as well as combination products that include glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, in patients with knee and/or hip OA.
Studies regarding glucosamine sulfate (
Option B

) in the management of OA have had contradictory results. After several favorable smaller studies, a trial sponsored by the National Institutes of Health showed no effectiveness in reducing pain, and the 2019 American College of Rheumatology guidelines strongly recommend against its use.
Tramadol (
Option C

), a partial opioid with fewer adverse effects and less addictive potential than pure opioids, may be considered in some patients in whom other analgesics have not relieved pain. Nonetheless, concerns about the potential for adverse effects of tramadol continue. The 2019 American College of Rheumatology guideline recommends against non-tramadol opioids, such as oxycodone, in patients with knee, hip, or hand OA; use can be considered in limited circumstances when no other alternatives exist.

references: Kolasinski SL, Neogi T, Hochberg MC, et al. 2019 American College of Rheumatology/Arthritis Foundation guideline for the management of osteoarthritis of the hand, hip, and knee. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2020;72:220-233.

children: A 68-year-old woman is referred for evaluation by an addiction specialist for alcohol use disorder. She has no history of encephalopathy, gastrointestinal bleeding, or ascites. Her only medication is naltrexone.
Vital signs are normal. There is no evidence of encephalopathy, jaundice, petechiae, ecchymoses, or ascites. Splenomegaly is present. Laboratory evaluation reveals a
platelet count
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Upper endoscopy should be performed on all patients with cirrhosis to assess for the presence of varices.
Nonselective β-blockers (propranolol, nadolol, carvedilol) are first-line agents in the primary prevention of bleeding in patients with moderate and severe esophageal varices.
The most appropriate management is upper endoscopy to evaluate for esophageal varices (
Option D

). Portal venous hypertension develops in the setting of advanced cirrhosis due to obstruction of blood flow caused by intrahepatic fibrosis, the development of regenerating liver nodules, and increased intrahepatic vascular resistance. Hypersplenism, often also associated with thrombocytopenia, further increases flow within the portal vein, exacerbating portal hypertension. Complications of portal hypertension include gastroesophageal varices, ascites, and hepatic encephalopathy. Esophageal varices are enlarged vessels within the lumen of the lower esophagus that provide extrahepatic pathways of blood flow from the portal circulation to the systemic circulation. Over time, esophageal varices enlarge and may spontaneously rupture, leading to bleeding and possible death. Upper endoscopy should be performed on all patients with cirrhosis to assess for the presence of varices. Management of varices in patients with cirrhosis depends on the size of the varix and whether the cirrhosis is compensated. Although patients in the early stages of cirrhosis may be asymptomatic, metabolic encephalopathy and portal hypertension leading to ascites and gastroesophageal variceal disease indicate decompensated cirrhosis and a poor prognosis.
Patients with asymptomatic thrombocytopenia due to hypersplenism do not typically require treatment. Platelet transfusions (
Option A
) may be required in actively bleeding patients and before certain procedures associated with a high risk of bleeding. Platelet counts greater than 100,000/µL (100 × 10
/L) do not increase bleeding risk. Counts between 50,000 and 100,000/µL (50-100 × 10
/L) do not require treatment and are adequate for surgical procedures, although 100,000/µL (100 × 10
/L) is desirable for neurosurgery. Platelet counts between 30,000 and 50,000/µL (30-50 × 10
/L) must be corrected before surgical intervention, and counts less than 10,000/µL (10 × 10
/L) are associated with risk of spontaneous bleeding.
Nonselective β-blockers (propranolol [
Option B

], nadolol, carvedilol) are first-line agents in the primary prevention of bleeding in patients with moderate and severe esophageal varices but should not be given empirically. There is no evidence that β-blockers prevent de novo formation of varices. Endoscopic variceal ligation is preferred when patients have contraindications to β-blockers or are unable to tolerate these medications.
Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (
Option C

) is indicated for recurrent variceal hemorrhage when β-blockers and variceal ligation fail, but it is not used to prevent the first episode of bleeding. TIPS also improves survival more than large-volume paracentesis in patients with refractory ascites.

objective.__html: Diagnose variceal disease in cirrhosis with upper endoscopy.

references: Garcia-Tsao G, Abraldes JG, Berzigotti A, et al. Portal hypertensive bleeding in cirrhosis: risk stratification, diagnosis, and management: 2016 practice guidance by the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases. Hepatology. 2017;65:310-335.

Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment?

Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin for 7 days or levofloxacin for 5 days for uncomplicated infections, 10-14 days in complicated infections) are the only oral agents recommended for empiric outpatient treatment of pyelonephritis.

Patients with pyelonephritis who are acutely ill, hypotensive, nauseated, or vomiting should be hospitalized to receive intravenous fluids and empiric therapy with a fluoroquinolone, an extended-spectrum cephalosporin or penicillin, or an aminoglycoside.
Oral ciprofloxacin (
Option C

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient who has acute pyelonephritis. Pyelonephritis is associated with abrupt onset of fever, chills, sweats, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, myalgia, and flank or abdominal pain. Hypotension and septic shock may occur in severe cases. Urinary frequency and dysuria may precede pyelonephritis. Urine culture with susceptibility testing is required before initiation of empiric therapy. Outpatient management can be considered for patients with pyelonephritis who are medically stable and able to take oral medication. Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin for 7 days or levofloxacin for 5 days for uncomplicated infections, 10-14 days in complicated infections) are the only oral agents recommended for empiric outpatient treatment (except in pregnancy) because of the higher urine drug concentrations achieved compared with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Patients with pyelonephritis who are acutely ill, hypotensive, nauseated, or vomiting should be hospitalized to receive intravenous fluids and parenteral antibiotics. Empiric therapy for hospitalized patients is begun with a fluoroquinolone, an extended-spectrum cephalosporin or penicillin, or an aminoglycoside, and treatment is continued for 7 to 14 days with adjustments to the antibiotic regimen based on results of urine and blood cultures. Therapy can be completed with active oral agents if an adequate clinical response has been observed. Patients with bacteremia do not require longer treatment courses and may be converted to appropriate oral therapy when clinically stable. Persistent fever and unilateral flank pain despite adequate treatment suggest perinephric or intrarenal abscess and the need for imaging with kidney CT.
Ampicillin (
Option A
); first-generation cephalosporins, such as cephalexin (
Option B
); and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option D
) are no longer used for empiric therapy because of unacceptably high rates of resistance.

references: Johnson JR, Russo TA. Acute pyelonephritis in adults. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:48-59.

title: Question 12

children: A 39-year-old man is evaluated after fainting while waiting to buy concert tickets. Just before he fainted, he felt warm and diaphoretic. He recovered completely within 1 to 2 minutes.
On physical examination, pulse rate is 50/min; the remainder of vital signs and the examination are normal.
ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 52/min.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Suggestive features of vasovagal syncope include any of the “3 P's”: posture (occurrence during prolonged standing or aborted by lying down), provoking factors (e.g., pain or a medical procedure), and prodromal symptoms (diaphoresis, warmth, and pallor).
All patients with syncope should undergo ECG, but patients with uncomplicated vasovagal syncope do not require further investigation or specialist referral.
No further testing (
Option D

) is required for this patient with symptoms consistent with neurally mediated syncope (also known as neurocardiogenic or reflex syncope), the most common form of syncope. The underlying syncopal mechanism, termed the neurocardiogenic or vasodepressor reflex, is a response of vasodilation, bradycardia, and systemic hypotension, which leads to transient hypoperfusion of the brain. Neurally mediated syncope includes vasovagal syncope, which may be provoked by noxious stimuli, fear, stress, or heat overexposure; situational syncope, which is triggered by cough, micturition, defecation, or deglutition; and carotid sinus hypersensitivity, which is sometimes experienced during head rotation, shaving, or use of a tight-fitting neck collar. Suggestive features of vasovagal syncope include any of the “3 Ps”: posture (occurrence during prolonged standing or aborted by lying down), provoking factors (e.g., pain or a medical procedure), and prodromal symptoms (diaphoresis, warmth, and pallor). All patients with syncope should undergo ECG, but patients with uncomplicated vasovagal syncope do not require further investigation or specialist referral. This patient's bradycardia is likely a result of the vasovagal physiology, which can cause peripheral vasodilation, bradycardia, or both. Patients should be counseled to maintain adequate hydration and perform counterpressure maneuvers like crossing/flexing their legs or lying down if the symptoms recur.
Guidelines recommend against routinely obtaining brain imaging with either CT or MRI (
Option A

) in cases of syncope that do not involve objective focal neurologic findings. Bilateral carotid stenosis is a rare cause of syncope, and routine carotid duplex ultrasonography is not recommended. Unilateral carotid artery stenosis does not cause syncope. Typical manifestations of unilateral carotid artery stenosis include transient ischemic attack, amaurosis fugax, and stroke.
If structural heart disease is suspected, echocardiography (
Option B
) should be pursued. This patient's symptoms are compatible with neurally mediated syncope, and his history and ECG results do not suggest structural heart disease.
Prolonged electrocardiographic monitoring (
Option C

) with an ambulatory monitor, event monitor, or implantable loop recorder should be considered in selected patients with a probable arrhythmic cause; the choice of test is based on the frequency and nature of the syncopal event. Arrhythmogenic syncope might be suggested by sudden loss of consciousness without a prodrome, syncope in the sitting position, or history of cardiovascular disease. This patient's syncope is not arrhythmogenic, and electrocardiographic monitoring is not indicated.

references: Shen WK, Sheldon RS, Benditt DG, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/HRS guideline for the evaluation and management of patients with syncope: executive summary: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association task force on clinical practice guidelines and the Heart Rhythm Society. Circulation. 2017;136:e25-e59.

title: Question 13

children: A 63-year-old woman is evaluated for left calf pain that limits walking. She has peripheral artery disease and recently completed an exercise rehabilitation program with minimal improvement in her symptoms. She also has hyperlipidemia. Medications are aspirin and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Diminished left femoral, popliteal, ankle, and pedal pulses are noted. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a
left ventricular ejection fraction
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
In patients who can exercise, supervised exercise training has been associated with improved functional performance and is recommended for patients with intermittent claudication.
In the absence of heart failure, a therapeutic trial of cilostazol should be considered in all patients with lifestyle-limiting claudication.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient is the addition of cilostazol (
Option A

). In patients who can exercise, supervised exercise training has been associated with improved functional performance and is recommended for patients with intermittent claudication. Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor with antiplatelet and vasodilator activity, has been shown in randomized clinical trials to increase pain-free walking and overall walking distance in patients with claudication. Cilostazol is contraindicated in patients with heart failure or left ventricular ejection fraction less than 40% because cilostazol has a similar pharmacologic action to the inotropic drugs milrinone and amrinone, which increase mortality rates with long-term use in patients with heart failure. In the absence of heart failure, a therapeutic trial of cilostazol should be considered in all patients with lifestyle-limiting claudication.
Pentoxifylline (
Option B
) has no benefit for the treatment of symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) and should not be prescribed to this patient.
Ticagrelor (
Option C

) or another thienopyridine should be added to aspirin therapy in all patients after acute coronary syndrome and after coronary artery stent placement. However, there is no benefit in adding ticagrelor to aspirin in patients with PAD to treat vascular occlusion or reduce the risk for cardiovascular events.
Neither warfarin nor rivaroxaban should be initiated (
Option D

). In the absence of other established indications for warfarin therapy, the addition of warfarin to antiplatelet therapy for the treatment of PAD does not confer any clinical benefit and instead increases the risk for major bleeding. In the Warfarin Antiplatelet Vascular Evaluation trial, the combination of an oral anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy in patients with PAD was not more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone in preventing major cardiovascular complications and was associated with an increase in life-threatening bleeding. Evidence from the COMPASS trial demonstrated that aspirin (100 mg/d) plus low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg twice daily) was associated with improved major adverse cardiovascular and limb end points when compared with aspirin plus placebo in patients with coronary artery disease and PAD. Major bleeding, primarily gastrointestinal bleeding, was increased in patients assigned to receive aspirin plus rivaroxaban; however, fatal or critical organ bleeding was not significantly different between the groups.

objective.__html: Treat peripheral artery disease with cilostazol.

references: Gerhard-Herman MD, Gornik HL, Barrett C, et al. 2016 AHA/ACC guideline on the management of patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines. Circulation. 2017;135:e726-e779.

title: Question 14

children: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 4-month history of painful, progressively enlarging breasts. Puberty was normal. He takes no medications or illicit drugs.
Physical examination reveals symmetric tender gynecomastia but no other signs of feminization. Testicular volume is normal. Serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin level is normal,
luteinizing hormone
level is 5 mU/mL (5 U/L), and
total morning testosterone
level is 520 ng/dL (18 nmol/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
The initial evaluation of gynecomastia includes measurement of estradiol, total testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and β-human chorionic gonadotropin levels.
Unilateral, nontender, or fixed breast masses in a man should prompt an evaluation for breast cancer with a mammogram.
In addition to morning total testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and β-human chorionic gonadotropin levels, an estradiol level (
Option B

) should be obtained in this patient with recent onset of painful progressive gynecomastia and no clear cause identified on history and physical examination. Gynecomastia is the abnormal growth of large mammary glands in men causing breast enlargement. On physical examination, gynecomastia presents as a rubbery, concentric, subareolar mass. It is typically bilateral and may be tender if early in its course of development. Gynecomastia results from an imbalance in the testosterone-to-estrogen ratio. This imbalance may be caused by a low testosterone level or an elevated estradiol level. Associated conditions include obesity, substance use disorder, malnutrition, cirrhosis, primary or secondary hypogonadism, testicular germ cell tumors, adrenal tumors, hyperthyroidism, and chronic kidney disease. Because the total testosterone level is normal in this patient, an estradiol level must be obtained to check for any elevation.
Adrenal CT (
Option A

) is inappropriate in the evaluation of gynecomastia unless the estradiol level is elevated. If the estradiol level is elevated, testicular ultrasonography should be ordered before adrenal CT to exclude a testicular neoplasm. If the testicular ultrasound shows no neoplasms, adrenal CT should be ordered to exclude an adrenal neoplasm.
Gynecomastia is typically bilateral. Unilateral, nontender, or fixed breast masses should prompt an evaluation for breast cancer with a mammogram (
Option C
). This patient has bilateral and progressive gynecomastia over a relatively short period. Mammography is unlikely to be helpful.

Treatment of a specific cause of gynecomastia during the active proliferative phase may result in regression in size of the abnormal tissue. Selective estrogen receptor modulators, such as tamoxifen (
Option D

), aromatase inhibitors, and androgens (for men with hypogonadism) are commonly used medications. If gynecomastia is longstanding, regression (spontaneously or with medical therapy) is unlikely owing to fibrotic changes. In this scenario, plastic surgery referral may be the best option for cosmetic improvement.

references: Sansone A, Romanelli F, Sansone M, et al. Gynecomastia and hormones. Endocrine. 2017;55:37-44.

title: Question 15

children: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She has never been tested for HIV infection. She is asymptomatic and reports no known risk factors for HIV infection.

Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay is reactive. Subsequent HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay is negative, as is the result of HIV-1 nucleic acid amplification testing.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
The fourth-generation HIV antigen/antibody combination assay, which evaluates for the presence of HIV antibodies and the p24 viral nucleic acid protein, is recommended for initial HIV testing.

The preferred follow-up testing for a positive result on an antigen/antibody combination assay includes an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation assay and HIV nucleic acid amplification testing if the antibody differentiation assay finding is indeterminate or negative.
No further testing (
Option D

) is needed for this patient who does not have HIV infection. The CDC, American College of Physicians, Infectious Diseases Society of America, and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommend universal screening for HIV in all adults at least once. The fourth-generation HIV antigen/antibody combination assay, which evaluates for the presence of HIV antibodies and the p24 viral nucleic acid protein, is recommended for initial HIV testing. This patient's initial test was reactive, so further testing was indicated. The preferred follow-up testing for a positive result on an antigen/antibody combination assay includes an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation assay followed by HIV nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) if the antibody differentiation assay finding is indeterminate or negative. HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation assay can identify the presence of HIV-1 or HIV-2 antibodies in the serum; HIV NAAT can detect viral RNA and is used to detect HIV RNA during the antibody-negative “window” period of acute HIV infection. Despite her initial positive test result, both follow-up test results were negative; the appropriate interpretation is that her initial positive result on the screening test was a false positive. Although the recommended initial screening test has a reported specificity of 99.6%, in persons at low risk with very low pretest probability, the rate of false-positive results may still be significant. This asymptomatic woman should be reassured that the initial test result was a false positive based on her negative results on follow-up testing.
All persons who test positive for HIV should immediately be referred to a health care provider with HIV infection management expertise. However, referral and initiation of HIV therapy (
Option A
) is unnecessary for this patient, because she does not have HIV infection. The initial HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay revealed a false-positive result.
In patients with confirmed HIV infection, a baseline CD4 cell count guides opportunistic infection prophylaxis, but T-cell subsets (
Option B
) should never be used in diagnostic testing for HIV infection, because a reduced CD4 cell count is neither sensitive nor specific for HIV infection.
In patients with confirmed HIV infection, a baseline viral load (
Option C

) is used to monitor antiretroviral therapy effectiveness. Because this patient has no evidence of HIV infection, including a negative test for HIV nucleic acid (negative NAAT), measurement of viral load will not be helpful.

objective.__html: Interpret the results of fourth-generation HIV antigen/antibody combination testing.

references: Saag MS. HIV infection - screening, diagnosis, and treatment. N Engl J Med. 2021;384:2131-2143.

title: Question 16

children: A 79-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for an increase in
serum creatinine
level from 1.1 mg/dL (97.2 µmol/L) to 1.9 mg/dL (168 µmol/L). He was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia 4 days ago.

On physical examination, vital signs are stable. There are crackles noted in the left lower lung field. The bladder is not palpable. Urine output was 300 mL in the past 24 hours. Urinalysis findings, including microscopic examination, are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
Relief of urinary obstruction can reverse acute kidney injury and prevent chronic damage; therefore, timely diagnosis is essential.

Because of the lack of definitive symptoms on presentation, kidney imaging, typically ultrasonography of the kidney and bladder, should be considered for all patients with acute kidney injury to exclude obstruction.
Kidney and bladder ultrasonography (
Option D

) is indicated for this patient with acute kidney injury (AKI). Kidney and bladder ultrasonography is helpful in patients with a high pretest probability of urinary tract obstruction and in patients with AKI of unknown etiology. Because relief of obstruction can reverse kidney injury and prevent chronic damage, timely diagnosis is essential. Urinary obstruction can be asymptomatic and can be associated with no noted change in urine output. Because of the lack of definitive symptoms on presentation, kidney imaging, typically ultrasonography, should be considered for all patients with AKI, but most particularly when risk factors for obstruction are present. Medical history findings (including pelvic tumors or irradiation, congenital urinary tract abnormalities, kidney stones, genitourinary infections, various procedures or surgeries, and prostatic enlargement) should increase suspicion for obstruction.
Bladder ultrasonography (
Option A
), rather than kidney ultrasonography, can be done as a quick bedside procedure and may also diagnose bladder obstruction; however, it will not reveal hydronephrosis or kidney anatomy.
If the pretest probability of nephrolithiasis or malignancy is high, CT of the abdomen and pelvis would be the preferred test (
Option B
). However, the normal urinalysis and lack of pain make nephrolithiasis an unlikely possibility.
In obstruction, urine electrolytes are variable. In early obstruction, the urine sodium concentration and fractional excretion of sodium (FE
Na
) may be low, but in late obstruction, the urine sodium concentration and FE
Na
may be high, indicative of tubular damage. Therefore, the FE
Na
Option C
) is not helpful in evaluating for possible obstruction. Because of impaired kidney excretion of potassium, acid, and water, hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis and hyponatremia may also be present.

references: Ronco C, Bellomo R, Kellum JA. Acute kidney injury. Lancet. 2019;394:1949-1964.

title: Question 17

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-year history of irritable bowel syndrome characterized by daily abdominal pain and infrequent, lumpy, hard-to-pass stools. She has no family history of colorectal cancer or inflammatory bowel disease. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her symptoms persist despite her FODMAP (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) avoidance diet, psyllium use, and a trial of polyethylene glycol.
Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Patients with irritable bowel syndrome-constipation subtype may benefit from psyllium (soluble fiber) and avoidance of FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols); polyethylene glycol can be used for persistent constipation.
Lubiprostone, plecanatide, or linaclotide is recommended for patients with refractory irritable bowel syndrome-constipation subtype.
The most appropriate next step in management of this patient with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with predominant constipation is initiation of linaclotide (
Option D

). The Rome IV criteria for diagnosis of IBS require symptoms of recurrent abdominal pain at least 1 day per week for a period of 3 months, along with at least two of the following three criteria: pain related to defecation, change in stool frequency, or change in stool consistency. IBS can then be further subtyped as IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with predominant diarrhea (IBS-D), IBS with mixed bowel habits (IBS-M), or IBS unclassified. In IBS-C, more than 25% of the stools are hard and less than 25% are loose. IBS is more common in women, particularly those younger than 50 years. Alarm symptoms, including weight loss, fever, bloody stools, and family history of colorectal cancer or inflammatory bowel disease, are indications for additional evaluation. In contrast, low-risk patients with a diagnosis established by the aforementioned criteria do not benefit from extensive laboratory or endoscopic investigations. Patients with IBS-C are often initially advised to use psyllium (soluble fiber) and avoid dietary FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols). If constipation persists, polyethylene glycol often is used. Lubiprostone, plecanatide, or linaclotide may subsequently be recommended for refractory constipation. Linaclotide, a guanylate cyclase-C agonist, is a prosecretory agent strongly recommended by the American Gastroenterological Association for the treatment of IBS-C based on high-quality evidence.
Colonoscopy (
Option A
) is not indicated in the evaluation of this young patient whose symptoms meet criteria for IBS-C and who has no alarm features.
Eluxadoline (
Option B
) is an opioid agonist/antagonist approved for the treatment of IBS-D but not IBS-C.
Calprotectin (
Option C

) is a protein released by neutrophils, useful in the assessment of disease activity and response to treatment in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Calprotectin measurement might be considered in the initial evaluation of a patient with IBS-D but is unnecessary in patients with IBS-C.

objective.__html: Treat irritable bowel syndrome with constipation.

references: Ford AC, Moayyedi P, Chey WD, et al; ACG Task Force on Management of Irritable Bowel Syndrome. American College of Gastroenterology monograph on management of irritable bowel syndrome. Am J Gastroenterol. 2018;113:1-18.

title: Question 18

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 9-month history of cramping pain in the buttocks radiating to both legs but predominant on the right. Symptoms are aggravated by standing and walking up stairs and relieved with sitting or leaning forward. She has a 13-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Physical examination reveals normal lower extremity strength and sensation, normal reflexes, and intact peripheral pulses. No spinal tenderness is noted.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Clinical manifestations of spinal stenosis are progressively worsening low back or buttock discomfort and severe leg pain (often bilateral but can be asymmetric) that is minimized when the low back is flexed (leading patients to lean forward) and worsened with spinal extension (such as when standing and walking up steps).
Spinal stenosis (
Option D

) is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. Spinal stenosis results from narrowing of the spinal canal, usually due to degenerative arthritis of the spine that causes mechanical compression and ischemia of the lumbosacral spine nerve roots. Clinical manifestations of spinal stenosis are progressively worsening low back or buttock discomfort and severe leg pain (often bilateral but can be asymmetric) that is minimized when the low back is flexed (leading patients to lean forward) and worsened with spinal extension (such as when standing and walking up steps). Patients with chronic compressive myelopathy due to lumbar spinal stenosis may present with progressive leg weakness, spasticity, distal numbness, and bladder impairment. Diagnosis is supported by lumbar spine MRI. Notably, spinal stenosis may be incidentally detected in asymptomatic patients who have imaging for other reasons, and the degree of stenosis does not predict development of symptoms. Therefore, this finding alone does not require further evaluation in the absence of other signs or symptoms.
Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP) (
Option A

) is a potentially treatable autoimmune neuropathy. CIDP often presents with a progressive or relapsing symmetric proximal and distal weakness and sensory symptoms with diffuse areflexia. Its temporal course is often subacute with progression after 8 weeks of onset. This patient has normal reflexes, sensation, and motor strength. Finally, symptoms of CIDP would not change with changes in position.
Diabetic amyotrophy (
Option B

), also known as proximal lumbosacral radiculoneuropathy, is associated with subacute painful involvement of the lumbosacral plexus followed by resolution of pain and onset of marked asymmetric weakness with atrophy and weight loss. Presenting symptoms typically include acute, asymmetric, focal onset of pain followed by weakness involving the proximal leg, with associated autonomic failure and weight loss. This patient does not have weakness or muscle atrophy, autonomic failure, or weight loss.
Symptoms associated with spinal stenosis are sometimes termed pseudoclaudication because they worsen with ambulation and improve with rest, similar to claudication due to peripheral artery disease (
Option C
). However, vascular claudication symptoms do not tend to worsen with standing or improve with spinal flexion and is usually associated with diminished peripheral pulses.

references: Lafian AM, Torralba KD. Lumbar spinal stenosis in older adults. Rheum Dis Clin North Am. 2018;44:501-512.

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for the acute onset of a widespread, painful red rash associated with fever, weakness, and malaise. Her only other medical problems are mild psoriasis and asthma. She recently completed a course of prednisone for an asthma exacerbation. Medications are fluticasone-salmeterol inhalers and topical calcitriol.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F). Erythema is noted on more than 90% of her body.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe, potentially fatal inflammatory skin condition that is characterized by widespread erythema (early), scaling and exfoliation (later), and sheets of superficial pustules with erosions in about 30% of patients.
In people with preexisting psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis may be precipitated by withdrawal of oral glucocorticoids or excessive use of topical glucocorticoids.
This patient has erythrodermic psoriasis (
Option B

). Erythroderma is defined as diffuse erythema covering 80% to 90% of the body surface area. Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe, potentially fatal inflammatory skin condition that is characterized by widespread erythema (early), scaling and exfoliation (later), and sheets of superficial pustules with erosions in about 30% of patients. In people with preexisting psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis may be precipitated by withdrawal of oral glucocorticoids (or excessive use of topical glucocorticoids). Management includes hospitalization for supportive care and possibly nonglucocorticoid systemic immunomodulators. This patient has features characteristic of erythrodermic psoriasis, including a history of psoriasis, recent withdrawal of an oral glucocorticoid, extensive erythroderma, and fever.
Erythroderma may be secondary to a drug eruption (
Option A

) and presents acutely, usually within days to weeks, of a new drug exposure. A wide variety of drugs can cause erythroderma but the most common culprits are sulfonamide antibiotics, allopurinol, and anticonvulsants. This patient is not taking drugs commonly associated with cutaneous reactions, and she has a more plausible explanation for the acute onset of erythroderma.
Sézary syndrome (
Option C

) is a more aggressive form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma in which diffuse erythroderma characterizes the skin involvement and malignant T cells circulate in the blood. Most commonly, patients with Sézary syndrome develop erythroderma over weeks to months associated with generalized lymphadenopathy. The most common debilitating symptom is pruritus. The patient's acute onset of erythroderma and fever in the setting of psoriasis is not likely to be Sézary syndrome.
Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) (
Option D
) is typically a diffuse erythroderma resembling sunburn that involves both the skin and the mucous membranes.
Staphylococcus aureus
– and
Streptococcus pyogenes

–associated exotoxins result in cytokine production that can result in TSS. Staphylococcal TSS is associated with tampon use, nasal packings, surgical wounds, skin ulcers, burns, catheters, and injection drug use. Streptococcal TSS is associated with skin and soft tissue infection, particularly necrotizing fasciitis. This patient has no risk factors for toxic shock syndrome, and her clinical presentation is not compatible with the diagnosis.
