title: Question 20

children: A 39-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 9-month history of cough occurring during the day but especially at night. She has to clear her throat often. She has no postnasal drip, acid reflux symptoms, dyspnea, or wheezing. She has never smoked cigarettes and takes no medications.
Physical examination shows cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx. Chest radiograph is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Upper airway cough syndrome is the most common cause of chronic cough (>8 weeks' duration); other common causes of chronic cough include asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease, ACE inhibitors, and smoking.
Guidelines recommend initiating therapy for upper airway cough syndrome as the first management step in patients with undifferentiated cough syndrome.
The most appropriate treatment is diphenhydramine and pseudoephedrine (
Option A

). This patient most likely has upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), the most common cause of chronic cough (>8 weeks' duration). Other common causes of chronic cough include asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), ACE inhibitors, and smoking. UACS was previously known as postnasal drip syndrome, but the name was revised to include other etiologies that cause excess upper airway secretions. Symptoms of UACS include cough, nasal discharge, sensation of postnasal drip, or frequent throat clearing, although symptoms other than cough are not always present. The oropharyngeal examination in UACS may reveal cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx or visible mucopurulent secretions draining from the nasopharynx. Allergic rhinitis–associated UACS is optimally treated with intranasal glucocorticoids, whereas UACS resulting from nonallergic rhinitis responds best to first-generation antihistamines (chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine, diphenhydramine) and decongestants (pseudoephedrine).
GERD is also a common source of chronic cough. For patients with undifferentiated cough, a trial of empiric GERD treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), such as lansoprazole (
Option B

), is reasonable, but guidelines suggest first initiating empiric trials of therapy for UACS, then asthma. This patient does not have signs or symptoms of GERD for which a PPI would be indicated as initial therapy.

Asthma should be considered in patients with symptoms that do not respond to empiric treatment for UACS. Cough-variant asthma is diagnosed if spirometry and/or bronchial hyperresponsiveness testing results with an agent such as methacholine (
Option C

) are abnormal and symptoms improve with standard therapy for asthma, including inhaled glucocorticoids. For patients with undifferentiated cough without features or testing to suggest a specific diagnosis, empiric asthma therapy can be considered, but guidelines recommend this only after empiric therapy for UACS has been trialed.

In patients with normal findings on evaluation or failed empiric treatment for UACS, asthma, and GERD, the most reasonable next step is to exclude nonasthmatic eosinophilic bronchitis with sputum analysis for eosinophils (
Option D
) or exhaled nitric oxide testing. If test results are abnormal, therapy with inhaled glucocorticoids should be initiated.

references: Irwin RS, French CL, Chang AB, et al; CHEST Expert Cough Panel*. Classification of cough as a symptom in adults and management algorithms: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;153:196-209.

title: Question 21

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated because of a slowly changing mole above his ear. He recalls several blistering sunburns as a child and adolescent.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The lesion is
shown
. A complete skin examination reveals several seborrheic keratoses; some are irritated and inflamed. The patient also has a pigmented actinic keratosis on his forehead.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

In general, the ABCDEs of identifying characteristics can help diagnose melanoma, where “A” stands for Asymmetry, “B” for irregular Border, “C” for multiple Colors, “D” for Diameter greater than 6 mm, and “E” for Evolution or change over time.

All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied; the preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 2-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and to prevent sampling error.
This patient most likely has nodular malignant melanoma (
Option B

). In general, the ABCDEs of identifying characteristics can help diagnose melanoma, where “A” stands for Asymmetry, “B” for irregular Border, “C” for multiple Colors, “D” for Diameter greater than 6 mm, and “E” for Evolution or change over time. There are four clinical subtypes of melanoma: superficial spreading, lentigo maligna, acral lentiginous, and nodular melanoma. Risk factors include ultraviolet light (both chronic and intermittent blistering sunburns), genetics (family history, and
CDKN2A
and
CDK4

gene mutations), large number of nevi, dysplastic nevi, and fair skin. Nodular melanomas typically present as uniformly dark blue or black "berry-like" lesions that most commonly originate from normal skin but may also arise as amelanotic lesions with a pink hue, making diagnosis difficult. This patient has a small back nodule and a large, mainly pink nodule with some melanotic pigmentation, making the diagnosis easier. Nodular melanomas can also arise from preexisting nevi. All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied. The preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 2-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and to prevent sampling error. Poor prognostic factors include male gender, increasing age, increased tumor thickness (Breslow depth), ulceration, increased tumor mitotic rate, and head/neck/trunk locations.
Lentigo maligna (
Option A

) is a slow-growing in-situ melanoma most commonly seen on the head and neck of older, fair-skinned persons as a pigmented patch; it is caused by substantial cumulative sun exposure. It has a prolonged radial growth phase and can be present for many years before developing invasive, malignant vertical growth. After invasion, lentigo maligna is called lentigo maligna melanoma and is distinguishable from benign processes by positive ABCDE criteria.
Actinic keratoses (AKs) (
Option C

) are squamous cell precursor lesions occurring in sun-damaged areas. Pigmentation is occasionally present, but pigmented AKs behave in a manner identical to typical AKs, with rough and scaly surface features. They are usually small, measuring only 1 to 3 mm. In this patient with a large and enlarging smooth lesion, lentigo maligna melanoma is more likely.
Seborrheic keratoses (
Option D

) are brown, scaly, waxy papules and plaques that appear “stuck on” and occur in older persons. Although benign, they may be difficult to differentiate definitively from melanoma; atypical lesions are often biopsied. This patient's smooth nodular, darkly pigmented lesion arising from a preexisting nevus makes seborrheic keratosis unlikely.

references: Rashid S, Tsao H. Recognition, staging, and management of melanoma. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:643-661.

title: Question 22

children: A 63-year-old woman is evaluated after a recent diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The diagnosis was based on the presence of a large amount of monoclonal protein on serum electrophoresis and more than 10% bone marrow monoclonal plasma cells. She is asymptomatic. She takes no medications.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
Serum calcium
level is 11.2 mg/dL (2.8 mmol/L), and
total protein
is 9.2 g/dL (92 g/L).
Which of the following should be measured?
In clinical settings in which increased protein binding of calcium may occur, the serum total calcium level may be elevated without a rise in the actual serum ionized calcium concentration.
Ionized calcium measurement is indicated in asymptomatic patients with multiple myeloma and elevated total serum calcium.
This patient's ionized calcium level (
Option C

) should be measured. Her total calcium level is elevated, but she is without symptoms of hypercalcemia. Approximately 40% to 45% of the calcium in serum is bound to protein, principally albumin, although the physiologically active form of calcium is in an ionized (or free) state. In most patients with relatively normal serum albumin levels, the total calcium usually reflects an accurate ionized calcium fraction. However, in clinical settings in which increased protein binding of calcium may occur, the serum total calcium level may be elevated without a rise in the actual serum ionized calcium concentration. This may occur in patients with hyperalbuminuria (as may occur in those who are severely dehydrated) and in patients with a paraprotein capable of binding calcium (as occasionally occurs in some patients with multiple myeloma). This phenomenon is sometimes termed pseudohypercalcemia (or factitious hypercalcemia). If present, a normal ionized calcium level may indicate that the elevated total calcium level is the result of excessive protein binding and potentially eliminates the need for further evaluation for hypercalcemia. Ionized calcium measurement is indicated in asymptomatic patients with multiple myeloma and elevated total serum calcium.
A 24-hour urine calcium measurement (
Option A

) is indicated in the diagnosis of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH). FHH is an autosomal dominant condition and the most common type of familial hypercalcemia. In FHH, an inactivating mutation of the
CaSR

gene causes the parathyroid gland to perceive serum calcium concentrations as low, resulting in increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion and a higher serum calcium level. Simultaneously, the mutated
CaSR

in the kidney increases kidney resorption of calcium, leading to paradoxical hypocalciuria in the setting of hypercalcemia. This patient with multiple myeloma and a large amount of serum monoclonal protein likely has pseudohypercalcemia, and measurement of the ionized calcium level is the most appropriate diagnostic test.
25-Hydroxyvitamin D (
Option B

) is the storage form of vitamin D in the body, and its measurement is the most appropriate test for assessing vitamin D stores but will not help evaluate patients with hypercalcemia. Measuring both 25-hydroxyvitamin D and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is useful in further assessing patients with non–PTH-mediated hypercalcemia to assess for excess vitamin D production.
PTH testing (
Option D

) is indicated in patients with hypercalcemia to differentiate between PTH-mediated and non–PTH-mediated hypercalcemia. Measurement of PTH and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels may be indicated as part of this patient's evaluation, but only after true hypercalcemia has been established by measuring the ionized calcium. However, the primary cause of hypercalcemia in patients with multiple myeloma is not primary hyperparathyroidism but rather tumor-induced, osteoclast-mediated bone resorption due to cytokines released by myeloma cells.

references: Hussain A, Almenfi HF, Almehdewi AM, et al. Laboratory features of newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. Cureus. 2019;11:e4716.

title: Question 23

children: An 84-year-old man is evaluated because of dizziness and confusion 2 weeks after his furosemide dosage was increased. He has atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and postherpetic neuralgia. His other medications are rivaroxaban, benazepril, gabapentin, and metoprolol.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal without orthostasis. There is an irregular rhythm. The patient appears weak but has no localizing findings.
Serum creatinine
level has risen from 1.2 mg/dL (106.1 µmol/L) to 1.8 mg/dL (159.1 µmol/L); laboratory evaluation is otherwise unremarkable.
Which of the following most likely caused this patient's symptoms?

Twelve percent of patients in the United States older than 65 years take 10 or more medications each week, and adverse drug reactions in this population account for 10% of emergency department visits and up to 17% of acute hospitalizations.
This clinical presentation is likely the result of overmedication (
Option C

) in this patient with significant medical comorbidities and numerous medications. His diuretic dosage was recently increased, which likely led to volume depletion and in turn may have changed his kidneys' ability to metabolize renally cleared drugs, as suggested by the increase in serum creatinine concentration.

Polypharmacy is common in older patients. Although no consistent definition exists, the presence of more than five prescribed medications is commonly used. Twelve percent of patients in the United States older than 65 years take 10 or more medications each week, and adverse drug reactions in this population account for 10% of emergency department visits and up to 17% of acute hospitalizations. In addition, transitions of care, such as hospital discharge, are associated with an increase in the number of prescribed medications and medication reconciliation errors, leading to inappropriate discontinuation of essential medications.

Many medications on this patient's list could cause adverse reactions. Gabapentin can cause dizziness and weakness and needs to be dose-adjusted in the setting of kidney disease. A review of every patient's medications, particularly patients older than 65 years, should be a part of routine care to avoid polypharmacy and potential medication-related adverse events.
The absence of clinical findings of heart failure (lung crackles, edema) argues against acute heart failure (
Option A
) as the cause of this patient's recent symptoms.
Because this patient is elderly and taking an anticoagulant, he has an increased risk for intracerebral hemorrhage (
Option B
), but his symptoms and normal examination do not support this diagnosis.
Infection, especially pneumonia (
Option D

), should always be a primary consideration in patients older than 65 years with mental status changes and failure to thrive. However, in this patient with recent aggressive diuresis and no reported fever or focal infectious symptoms, a medication effect is a more likely cause.

objective.__html: Diagnose a medication-related adverse effect in an elderly patient.

references: Levy HB. Polypharmacy reduction strategies: tips on incorporating American Geriatrics Society Beers and screening tool of older people's prescriptions criteria. Clin Geriatr Med. 2017;33:177-187.

title: Question 24

children: A 68-year-old man is evaluated because of urinary frequency and urgency despite taking tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has no other medical problems and takes no other medications.

On examination, the prostate gland is modestly enlarged, smooth, and nontender. Urinalysis and prostatic specific antigen level are normal. Urodynamic studies and postvoid bladder volume determined by ultrasonography exclude bladder outlet obstruction.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
In men with lower urinary tract symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia, the recommended initial pharmacologic therapy is an α-blocker.

In men with persistent lower urinary tract symptoms despite treatment with an α-blocker and no evidence of bladder outlet obstruction, the addition of an anticholinergic drug is a reasonable next step.
This patient should receive an approved anticholinergic agent such as tolterodine (
Option D

), oxybutynin, darifenacin, solifenacin, fesoterodine, or trospium for his lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). LUTS can be grouped into irritative symptoms (urinary urgency with or without urinary incontinence, increasing daytime frequency, and nocturia) and obstructive symptoms (hesitancy, weak urinary stream, straining, incomplete voiding, urinary retention, and overflow incontinence). This patient was appropriately initially treated with tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the most common cause of LUTS in men. However, the persistence of symptoms, absence of bladder outlet obstruction on urodynamic studies and bladder ultrasonography, and presence of irritative symptoms points to overactive bladder as the diagnosis. Medical treatment is aimed at reducing involuntary detrusor contractions during filling of the bladder. Because no evidence of postvoid residuals was found, it is safe to initiate a trial of an anticholinergic medication, such as tolterodine, in this patient. The combination of the α-blocker (such as tamsulosin) and an anticholinergic agent (such as tolterodine) is more effective in treating LUTS than monotherapy with either drug.
Saw palmetto (
Option A

) is frequently used to treat LUTS secondary to BPH; however, the data on effectiveness is mixed. A Cochrane database review concluded that saw palmetto provided mild-to-moderate improvement in symptoms (like finasteride), but a subsequent, high-quality randomized controlled trial found no benefit. Efficacy data consistently demonstrates improved symptoms for patients with LUTS following treatment with an α-blocker.
Chronic use of the phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor tadalafil (
Option B

) has been shown to improve erectile dysfunction and LUTS. However, caution should be exercised with concomitant PDE-5 inhibitor and α-blocker use due to the increased risk of hypotension. Monotherapy with tadalafil may be a reasonable option in concomitant BPH and erectile dysfunction but in this case, an anticholinergic agent would be preferred add-on therapy to an α-blocker.
Testosterone therapy with testosterone gel (
Option C
) will not ameliorate LUTS but will likely worsen BPH. In addition, it may result in polycythemia, hypertension, and increases the risk for prostate cancer and cannot be recommended for this patient.
Transurethral resection of the prostate (
Option E

) is indicated for patients with medically refractory BPH-related voiding symptoms or with BPH-related complications. BPH-related complications include recurrent urinary tract infection, bladder stone, obstructive nephropathy, persistent hematuria, and urinary retention. This patient's LUTS are irritative, not obstructive, and surgery is not indicated.

objective.__html: Treat overactive bladder in a patient with lower urinary tract symptoms.

references: Lightner DJ, Gomelsky A, Souter L, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of overactive bladder (Non-neurogenic) in adults: AUA/SUFU guideline amendment 2019. J Urol. 2019;202:558-563.

title: Question 25

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for a 7-month history of insomnia. She has difficulty falling asleep and maintaining sleep. She is the primary caregiver for her 2 grandchildren following her daughter's recent death. Based on the STOP-BANG survey, she is at low risk for obstructive sleep apnea. PHQ-9 score is 3.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's insomnia?
Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is the most appropriate management for chronic insomnia in older adults.

Although cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, a short course of low-dose doxepin or a nonbenzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonist can be considered in patients who are unable or unwilling to receive CBT-I.
Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) (
Option B

) is the most appropriate next step in management. Insomnia symptoms are common in older patients, with up to 20% of adults older than 65 years meeting criteria for insomnia disorder. Prevalence is higher in women, especially those who are caregivers. Untreated insomnia has been associated with increased risk for depression, heart disease, and poorly controlled chronic comorbid conditions. Management should preferentially involve nonpharmacologic strategies. CBT-I is delivered in 6 to 10 sessions with a trained therapist and focuses on recognizing and eliminating behaviors that interfere with sleep. Studies support its efficacy in older adults, and it is recommended as first-line therapy by multiple guidelines.
Guidelines suggest against the use chamomile (
Option A

) for treatment of chronic insomnia disorder. A systematic review evaluated the efficacy and safety of valerian and chamomile for treatment of insomnia. There were no between-group differences in the critical outcomes of daytime functioning, insomnia severity, and sleep efficiency, and no differences in either daytime functioning or insomnia severity were found versus placebo.
Trazodone (
Option C

) is a serotonin modulator. Current guidelines suggest against the use of trazodone for treatment of chronic insomnia disorder. A systematic review reported no differences in sleep efficiency or rate of discontinuation due to adverse events between trazodone and placebo in patients diagnosed with chronic insomnia. Cardiac arrhythmias, including prolonged QT interval on ECG and ventricular tachycardia, have been reported with trazodone as well as orthostatic hypotension, serotonin syndrome, and withdrawal syndrome.

The American College of Physicians recommends that physicians engage in a thorough shared decision-making process to decide whether to add pharmacologic therapy. Although CBT-I is the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, a short course of low-dose doxepin or a nonbenzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonist such as zolpidem (
Option D
) can be considered in patients who are unable or unwilling to receive CBT-I.

objective.__html: Manage insomnia in an elderly patient.

references: Patel D, Steinberg J, Patel P. Insomnia in the elderly: A review. J Clin Sleep Med. 2018;14:1017-1024.

title: Question 26

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She feels well, has no medical problems, and takes no medications. Medical history is remarkable only for an episode of pyelonephritis treated with a 3-day hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics after the birth of her last child at age 42 years.
Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows trace leukocyte esterase, and two subsequent urine cultures reveal more than 10
cfu/mL of
Escherichia coli
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not require treatment.
Screening for and treating asymptomatic bacteriuria are indicated only in pregnancy and before invasive urologic procedures.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) does not require treatment (
Option D
). ASB is defined as the presence of at least 10

cfu/mL of a uropathogen from two consecutive voided urine specimens in women or one specimen in men. In all cases, local or systemic signs or symptoms of infection are absent. The prevalence of ASB ranges from 1% to 5% in healthy premenopausal women (2%-10% in pregnant women) to nearly 100% in patients with long-term indwelling urinary catheters. The bacteria responsible for ASB are the same as those associated with symptomatic infections of the urinary tract.
Escherichia coli

is the organism isolated most often. Evidence shows that treating ASB has no effect on the incidence of symptomatic urinary tract infections (UTIs), prevalence of bacteriuria, or survival. Screening for or treating ASB is not indicated in nonpregnant women or patients with diabetes mellitus, spinal cord injuries, or chronic indwelling urinary catheters. Treatment of these populations puts the patients at risk for drug adverse effects and increases the probability of antibiotic resistance. Screening for and treating ASB is indicated only in pregnancy and before invasive urologic procedures. Untreated ASB in pregnant women may be complicated by premature delivery, a low–birth-weight infant, or pyelonephritis. Untreated ASB in patients undergoing urologic procedures associated with mucosal trauma can increase the risk for postoperative UTIs and sepsis.

Antibiotic treatment is not required for this patient with ASB. Preferred agents for the treatment of cystitis include nitrofurantoin (5 days), trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMS) (3 days), and fosfomycin (1 dose). In geographic areas where TMS resistance exceeds 20%, an alternative agent should be selected. β-Lactam agents (including amoxicillin-clavulanate [
Option A

], cefdinir, cefaclor, and cefpodoxime proxetil, each 3-7 days) are considered acceptable alternative second-line therapies. β-Lactams, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, are not preferred for cystitis if other recommended agents are available, because they are less effective in eradicating infection.
Nitrofurantoin (
Option B
) is an excellent choice for cystitis but is not required in this patient with ASB.
Repeat urinalysis and urine culture (
Option C
) will likely provide similar results and may document the presence of ASB but will not help in managing this patient.

objective.__html: Manage a patient with asymptomatic bacteriuria.

references: Nicolle LE, Gupta K, Bradley SF, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the management of asymptomatic bacteriuria: 2019 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clin Infect Dis. 2019;68:e83-e110.

title: Question 27

children: A 75-year-old man is evaluated for 3 months of worsening exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and recent exertional chest pain that is relieved with rest.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 155/43 mm Hg, with rapid carotid upstrokes and collapse. A diminished S
, grade 2/6 early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, and displaced apical impulse are noted. Pulmonary crackles and elevated jugular pressure are present.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The characteristic murmur of valvular aortic regurgitation is a blowing diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left third and fourth interspaces with the patient sitting and leaning forward.
Severe aortic regurgitation may be associated with a Corrigan pulse in the carotid arteries (rapid, accentuated upstroke with a rapid decline), displaced apical impulse, and widened pulse pressure.
The most likely diagnosis is chronic aortic regurgitation (AR) (
Option A

). The characteristic murmur of valvular AR is a blowing diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left third and fourth interspaces with the patient sitting and leaning forward. This patient's physical examination is consistent with severe AR, as evidenced by a Corrigan pulse in the carotid arteries (rapid, accentuated upstroke with a rapid decline), displaced apical impulse, and widened pulse pressure. AR is generally asymptomatic for a long time (possibly decades) until signs and symptoms of heart failure develop due to cardiac remodeling from chronic volume overload. Angina also may manifest because of subendocardial ischemia related to increased wall tension or reduced coronary perfusion pressure from reduced diastolic pressures. Congenital valve abnormalities (such as bicuspid aortic valve), rheumatic heart disease, abnormalities of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta, prior infective endocarditis, or injury from prior radiation therapy may cause chronic AR.
Patients with an atrial myxoma (
Option B

) may present with constitutional symptoms related to interleukin production, embolic phenomena from tumor fragmentation, or symptoms referable to intracardiac obstruction (dyspnea, syncope). When mitral valvular obstruction is present, auscultatory findings are similar to those of mitral stenosis (mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex); however, findings may vary with position or be associated with an early diastolic sound, known as the tumor plop. This patient's findings do not support a diagnosis of atrial myxoma.
A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) (
Option C
) is a persistent fetal connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. The typical murmur of a PDA is a continuous “machinery” murmur that envelops the S

, making it inaudible; the murmur is heard beneath the left clavicle. A tiny PDA is generally asymptomatic and inaudible. Patients with a moderate-sized PDA may present with bounding pulses, a wide pulse pressure, left-heart enlargement and dysfunction, and, rarely, clinical heart failure. This patient's early diastolic murmur localized to the left sternal border is not compatible with PDA.
This patient's physical examination reveals no evidence of significant tricuspid regurgitation (
Option D
), such as a systolic murmur, jugular venous distention, large retrograde
v
waves, or hepatojugular reflux.

references: Akinseye OA, Pathak A, Ibebuogu UN. Aortic valve regurgitation: A comprehensive review. Curr Probl Cardiol. 2018;43:315-334.

title: Question 28

children: A 73-year-old man is evaluated for 2 days of widespread pruritic hives. Lesions last less than 60 minutes, but new lesions are continually appearing. He just finished a 7-day course of cephalexin for lower extremity cellulitis.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal; urticarial lesions are present on the face, neck, chest, flanks, and arms. There is no wheezing, mucosal lesions, or bullae.
Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?

Drug-induced acute urticaria should be treated initially with elimination of the underlying medication trigger, if possible, and with symptomatic relief with a nonsedating, long-acting second-generation H
-blocking antihistamine.
The patient should be treated with the histamine-blocking drug fexofenadine (
Option A

). He has acute urticaria (hives) that is most likely drug induced, given his recent exposure to cephalexin. Drug-induced acute urticaria should be treated initially with elimination of the underlying medication trigger, if possible, and with symptomatic relief with a nonsedating, long-acting second-generation H

-blocking antihistamine, such as fexofenadine. This patient has already completed his course of cephalexin and should be treated with fexofenadine for antihistaminic relief of the pruritis. If symptoms are severe or persist, adjunctive H
-blocking agents may be added, such as famotidine.
Intramuscular epinephrine (
Option B

) is reserved for patients with life-threatening angioedema that may compromise the airway or those in anaphylaxis. If this patient exhibited dyspnea, difficulty clearing secretions, lip or tongue swelling, or hemodynamic instability, administration of epinephrine would be indicated. In this patient without instability or wheezing, epinephrine is not indicated.
A short course (less than 10 days) of systemic glucocorticoids such as prednisone (
Option C

) may be helpful for patients with widespread or highly symptomatic involvement, or for those who do not respond to first-line therapy. Adverse effects restrict the use of systemic glucocorticoids to patients in whom second-generation H
-blocking antihistamines are insufficiently helpful. Topical glucocorticoids may be of some help in highly focal urticaria but are not practical for widespread urticaria, such as this patient has.
Topical antihistamines, such as topical diphenhydramine (
Option D
), are not recommended because they are ineffective and may result in contact dermatitis.

objective.__html: Treat a patient with drug-induced urticaria.

references: Khan DA, Kocatürk E, Bauer A, Aygören-Pürsün E. What's new in the treatment of urticaria and angioedema. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2021;9:2170-2184.

title: Question 29

children: A 27-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated during a routine visit. She has a 5-year history of schizophrenia treated with olanzapine. She was last seen 4 months ago. There is no family history of metabolic or cardiovascular diseases. Fasting glucose was measured 1 year ago, and complete blood count and lipids were measured 5 years ago; results were normal.
On physical examination, BMI is 27 and waist circumference is 81 cm (32 in).
Which of the following screening tests should be obtained?

text.__html: Lipid levels and fasting glucose measurement

children: Schizophrenia is associated with an increased risk for diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular disease, and obesity, and these coexisting conditions may be exacerbated by the metabolic complications of antipsychotic therapy.
In patients taking antipsychotic medications, fasting glucose should be measured every year, and serum lipids should be measured every 5 years.
Lipid and fasting glucose levels (
Option C

) should be obtained now. Schizophrenia is associated with an increased risk for diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular disease, and obesity, and these coexisting conditions may be exacerbated by the metabolic complications of antipsychotic therapy. Undertreatment of medical disease is also common in this population. Patients with pre-existing components of the metabolic syndrome are at highest risk. Routine periodic monitoring of metabolic parameters is recommended for patients taking any antipsychotic drug. Measurements of weight (and BMI), waist circumference, blood pressure, glucose level, and lipid levels are recommended at baseline when starting antipsychotic drugs. Weight should be measured at 4 weeks, 8 weeks, 12 weeks, and then quarterly. The other parameters should be measured at 12 weeks, and with the exception of lipids, should then be measured annually; lipid measurements are recommended at least every 5 years.

QT prolongation is typically mild with use of most second-generation antipsychotic drugs, but these drugs should be used with caution in patients with cardiac risk factors or taking other drugs that prolong the QT interval. Routine periodic monitoring with ECG (
Option A
) is not recommended. A baseline ECG is recommended at the time of drug initiation and after therapeutic drug levels have been achieved in patients with risk factors for QT prolongation.
Agranulocytosis is a complication of clozapine treatment, and monitoring of the leukocyte count for the first several months of therapy (
Option B

) is recommended. Agranulocytosis is less frequently associated with other second-generation antipsychotic drugs and occurs in less than 1% of patients taking olanzapine. Routine monitoring for agranulocytosis is not recommended for patients taking antipsychotics other than clozapine unless baseline leukocyte counts were low or the patient previously experienced an episode of agranulocytosis.
Second-generation antipsychotic drugs are associated with elevations of prolactin levels by direct blockade of pituitary dopamine receptors. Routine monitoring of serum prolactin levels (
Option D
) is not recommended, but measurement is indicated if the patient has symptoms of sexual dysfunction or galactorrhea.

objective.__html: Screen for metabolic syndrome in a patient taking antipsychotic medications.

references: Rognoni C, Bertolani A, Jommi C. Second-generation antipsychotic drugs for patients with schizophrenia: systematic literature review and meta-analysis of metabolic and cardiovascular side effects. Clin Drug Investig. 2021;41:303-319.

title: Question 30

children: A 36-year-old man with a 5-year history of ulcerative colitis is hospitalized with a 1-week history of fever, tenesmus, diffuse abdominal pain, and 12 daily episodes of bloody diarrhea despite use of oral glucocorticoids.
Stool culture for enteric pathogens and
Clostridioides difficile
assay are negative. He improves with intravenous glucocorticoid therapy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate maintenance treatment?
Glucocorticoids are appropriate for the treatment of severe flares of ulcerative colitis but should never be used for maintenance therapy.
Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (adalimumab, golimumab, and infliximab) are effective for induction and maintenance in severe ulcerative colitis.
The patient's symptoms are consistent with a severe flare-up of ulcerative colitis, which makes a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor such as infliximab (
Option B

) the appropriate choice to induce and maintain remission. Ulcerative colitis is an immune-mediated disease with a fluctuating course that is characterized by periods of remission and flare-ups of varying severity and extent of colonic involvement. Most patients have proctitis, but inflammatory changes often extend proximally in a continuous fashion and involve other segments of the colon. The presence of systemic symptoms, such as fever and tachycardia, as well as 6 to 10 daily bloody bowel movements, defines a severe flare. Because some of the symptoms of
Clostridioides difficile

and infectious colitis may mimic ulcerative colitis flares, it is highly recommended that these conditions be ruled out. In addition to the clinical assessment, fecal calprotectin, a protein found in neutrophils, is useful in assessing disease activity and response to treatment. Glucocorticoids are appropriate for the treatment of severe flares of ulcerative colitis but should never be used for maintenance therapy. TNF inhibitors (adalimumab, golimumab, and infliximab) are effective for induction and maintenance in severe ulcerative colitis and may lead to a favorable response within days. Although well tolerated, TNF inhibitors increase the risk for infection.
Thiopurines, such as oral azathioprine (
Option A

), are slow-acting agents recommended for maintenance but not for inducing remission of ulcerative colitis. Budesonide is a nonsystemic glucocorticoid that induces remission in flares of colitis, but only in mild to moderate cases. Oral mesalamine, an aminosalicylate, is commonly used for maintenance and may be used as a single agent to induce remission in mild to moderate, but not severe, colitis.
The small-molecule Janus kinase inhibitor tofacitinib (
Option C

) is effective as primary therapy in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and as secondary therapy when anti-TNF agents have failed. Tofacitinib is associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, cancer, blood clots, and death.
Vedolizumab (
Option D
) is effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, as well as in inducing remission when anti-TNF agents have failed.

references: Feuerstein JD, Isaacs KL, Schneider Y, et al; AGA Institute Clinical Guidelines Committee. AGA clinical practice guidelines on the management of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. Gastroenterology. 2020;158:1450-1461.

title: Question 31

children: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the office after her fourth emergency department visit for stage III heart failure over the past 6 months, resulting in a 2-day hospitalization on two occasions. She lives alone and lacks transportation. She is taking maximally tolerated, guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Home-based care includes primary care, nursing, social work, and therapeutic modalities delivered by way of home health services, telehealth services by physicians and allied health professionals, and the “hospital-at-home” model, defined as treatment by health care professionals in the patient's home for a condition otherwise requiring acute inpatient hospital care.
This patient with frequent exacerbations of chronic disease and subsequent emergency department visits would benefit from multidisciplinary home-based care (
Option B

). Home-based care includes primary care, nursing, social work, and therapeutic modalities delivered by way of home health services, telehealth services by physicians and allied health professionals, and the “hospital-at-home” model, defined as treatment by health care professionals in the patient's home for a condition otherwise requiring acute inpatient hospital care. Home-based care has shown benefit for COPD, heart failure, and cerebrovascular disease. Although evidence for mortality benefit is mixed, home-based care has been shown to reduce hospital admissions/readmissions and cost, improve patient satisfaction, and decrease the need for institutionalization. Other advantages include avoidance of hospital-acquired complications and improved preservation of functional status.

Hospice is a form of palliative medicine that delivers specialized interdisciplinary care to patients with an expected prognosis of 6 months or less. Hospice care can be provided to patients in multiple settings, including the home, skilled nursing facilities, and residential hospice homes. Hospice teams are skilled in managing the symptoms of advanced and terminal illness and improve overall satisfaction with care. Hospice care may be provided in the home and may ultimately be recommended for this patient. However, evaluation of prognosis and discussions regarding goals of care should precede the decision to pursue hospice care (
Option A
). Referral before such evaluation and discussions would be premature.
The effectiveness of nurse-led telephone-based care (
Option C

) for chronic diseases is mixed. Although telephone care is an important component of multidisciplinary home-based care, it is unlikely that telephone-based care alone will be able to meet all of this patient's care needs.
Placement in a skilled nursing facility (
Option D

) would require the presence of a need that could not be addressed in an independent living setting. The presence of an advanced medical condition alone is insufficient to justify the need for placement in a skilled nursing facility.

objective.__html: Manage a chronic disease using home care.

references: LaFave S, Drazich B, Sheehan OC, et al. The value of home-based primary care: qualitative exploration of homebound participant perspectives. J Appl Gerontol. 2021;40:1611-1616.

title: Question 32

children: An elderly man is found lying down and pulseless on a sidewalk by his neighbors. His down time is unknown. Bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated. Emergency medical services are summoned, arrive, confirm cardiac arrest, and diagnose ventricular fibrillation. A 200-J shock is administered through an automated external defibrillator.
Which of the following is the next intervention?

After every shock from an automated external defibrillator, it is necessary to continue cardiopulmonary resuscitation for 2 minutes, or five cycles of 30 compressions and two breaths, without stopping to assess the rhythm.
The next intervention is to continue chest compressions (
Option C

). After every shock from an automated external defibrillator, it is necessary to continue cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) for 2 minutes, or five cycles of 30 compressions and two breaths, without stopping to assess the rhythm. Although the postshock rhythm may be normal sinus, there can be pulseless electrical activity or ineffective cardiac output during this time. Chest compressions should be of adequate depth (>2 in) and at a rate of 100/min, allowing for full chest recoil.

Guidelines support the administration of epinephrine for cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm after initial defibrillation attempts have failed. In patients with a nonshockable rhythm, it is reasonable to administer epinephrine as soon as possible. In either situation, epinephrine can be administered every 3 to 5 minutes. Vasopressin can be used alone or with epinephrine, but vasopressin offers no advantage to epinephrine. If the patient with a shockable rhythm is unresponsive to defibrillation and epinephrine, an intravenous antiarrhythmic agent, such as amiodarone or lidocaine (
Option A
), should be considered. Administering lidocaine after the first shock is premature.
Routine administration of sodium bicarbonate (
Option B
), calcium, or magnesium is not recommended due to lack of benefit.

All interruptions should be kept to a minimum during CPR because any break can lead to a reduction in coronary perfusion pressure and worse outcomes. The length of time that providers can withhold CPR during defibrillator charging, shock, and postshock rhythm check can be more than 30 seconds. Therefore, CPR should be continued after every shock for 2 minutes as a first step; after that, a rhythm check should be completed (
Option D
). If the patient is still in a shockable rhythm, a second shock should be given, followed by 2 more minutes of CPR.

references: Panchal AR, Berg KM, Kudenchuk PJ, et al. 2018 American Heart Association focused update on advanced cardiovascular life support use of antiarrhythmic drugs during and immediately after cardiac arrest: an update to the American Heart Association guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation and emergency cardiovascular care. Circulation. 2018;138:e740-e749.

title: Question 33

children: A 52-year-old woman with a diagnosis of alcohol use disorder is discharged after her third inpatient admission for acute alcohol detoxification. Screening for depression and abuse of other substances is negative. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications. She is enrolled in an alcohol treatment program. The patient confirms that adherence to medications is difficult.
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment?

Both naltrexone and acamprosate are considered first-line therapy for alcohol use disorder, but naltrexone is administered by mouth daily (or monthly by injection) compared with three times daily administration for acamprosate.

Disulfiram is considered second-line treatment for alcohol dependence and should be used only in patients who have contraindications to or intolerance of first-line treatments (naltrexone or acamprosate).
This patient should receive naltrexone (
Option C

) for her alcohol dependence. Brief nonpharmacologic interventions are effective for patients with at-risk alcohol use, but more aggressive therapy, potentially including pharmacotherapy, is indicated in both alcohol use disorder and alcohol dependence. Naltrexone, an opioid receptor antagonist, has been shown to be effective in short-term treatment and in decreasing the frequency of relapse. Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor that causes an accumulation of aldehyde if alcohol is consumed, which results in vomiting, headache, and anxiety. Studies have been inconclusive on its efficacy in enhancing abstinence. It is considered second-line treatment for alcohol dependence and should be used only in patients who have contraindications to or intolerance of first-line treatments (naltrexone or acamprosate) and who have been fully counseled on the potential for symptoms if relapse occurs.

Both naltrexone and acamprosate are considered first-line therapy for alcohol use disorder, but naltrexone is administered by mouth daily (or monthly by injection) compared with three times daily administration for acamprosate (
Option A

); adherence to naltrexone may be superior, particularly a once-monthly injection. Ultimately, the choice between naltrexone and acamprosate should be directed by pharmacologic considerations, patient preference, and the presence of comorbidities.
Benzodiazepines, such as alprazolam (
Option B

), are recommended for use in acute alcohol detoxification, either for the prevention or treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Benzodiazepines do not have a role in the ongoing treatment of alcohol dependence. Patients with alcohol use disorder are at increased risk for benzodiazepine dependence. Additionally, concomitant use of benzodiazepines and alcohol can lead to sedation, respiratory depression, and death if relapse occurs.
Sertraline (
Option D

) is a selective serotonin receptor inhibitor antidepressant. Antidepressants and anxiolytics may play a role if an underlying psychiatric disorder is present but are not the primary treatment for alcohol dependence. The American Psychiatric Association recommends against the use of antidepressants in the treatment of alcohol use disorder in the absence of depression.

references: Reus VI, Fochtmann LJ, Bukstein O, et al. The American Psychiatric Association practice guideline for the pharmacological treatment of patients with alcohol use disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2018;175:86-90.

title: Question 34

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of fever, dyspnea, and anterior chest pain. Five other men were seen in the emergency department today with similar symptoms. All attended a baseball game 4 days ago and sat in the same stadium section.

Temperature is 38.7 °C (101.7 °F). The patient has hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea and is confused. Breath sounds are diminished. Chest radiograph shows bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and mediastinal widening.
Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
The rapid development of a septic state following a nonspecific prodromal flu-like syndrome is characteristic of inhalational anthrax.
Inhalational anthrax results in widening of the mediastinum and occasional bloody pleural effusions demonstrated on chest radiograph or CT scan.
The most likely infectious agent is
Bacillus anthracis
Option A

). Unusually severe illness; rapid increase in disease incidence; atypical clinical presentation; and uncommon geographic, temporal, or demographic clustering of disease outbreaks suggest a bioterrorism attack. The rapid development of a septic state following a nonspecific prodromal flu-like syndrome is characteristic of inhalational anthrax. Migration of inhaled spores to the mediastinal lymph nodes leads to tissue destruction and hemorrhage, resulting in the classic widening of the mediastinum and occasional bloody pleural effusions demonstrated on chest radiograph or CT scan. The diagnosis is confirmed by isolating the organism (commonly from blood cultures of patients with inhalational disease) or detecting its presence in tissue or fluid through polymerase chain reaction testing.
The Ebola (
Option B

) and Marburg viruses are the most likely viruses to be used as biologic weapons. In endemic areas, spread to humans occurs by vectors, contact with bodily fluids, or fomites. Aerosolization is a likely mode of terrorist dissemination. Symptoms of fever, headache, myalgia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and unexplained bleeding and bruising appear 2 to 21 days after exposure. Disease progression results in maculopapular rash, hemorrhagic diathesis, shock, and multiorgan failure. Mortality rates may reach 90%. Pneumonia with mediastinal widening is not seen.
Symptomatic infection with SARS-CoV-2 (
Option C

) is known as COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019). COVID-19 may present as an acute respiratory disease, which may be mild but can progress to severe viral pneumonia. The clinical presentation is an influenza-like illness with lower respiratory tract symptoms. Fever eventually develops in most symptomatic patients. Cough may be severe and nonproductive; myalgia, sore throat, and headache are common. Loss of taste and smell is a differentiating symptom. Although imaging is nondiagnostic and may appear normal, persons with COVID-19 who do have imaging abnormalities most characteristically have bilateral ground-glass opacities.
Yersinia pestis
Option D

) is endemic to the southwestern United States, where the population of reservoir rodents is dense, with transmission usually by flea bite. Plague typically consists of three clinical syndromes: (1) pneumonic plague, occurring with inhalation of bacteria (very rare); (2) bubonic plague, characterized by purulent lymphadenitis near the inoculation site; and (3) septicemic plague, a septic presentation that may arise from either of the other syndromes. The bipolar staining, gram-negative bacillus giving the appearance of a closed safety pin is practically pathognomonic for
Y. pestis.
Mediastinal widening is not seen with pneumonic plague.

references: Savransky V, Ionin B, Reece J. Current status and trends in prophylaxis and management of anthrax disease. Pathogens. 2020;9.

title: Question 35

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for 90 minutes of crushing anterior chest pain.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 93/65 mm Hg and pulse rate is 112/min. The patient is diaphoretic. Pulsus paradoxus is absent. Jugular venous distension is present. Lungs are clear. Heart sounds are distant without murmur. ECG shows 2-mm ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF and 0.5-mm ST-segment elevation in lead V
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
In the setting of an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction, the triad of hypotension, clear lung fields, and jugular venous distention suggests a right ventricular infarction.

Treatment of right ventricular infarction consists of aggressive volume resuscitation to optimize right ventricular filling (preload), intravenous vasopressors if hypotension persists, and urgent coronary revascularization.
In the setting of an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction, the triad of hypotension, clear lung fields, and jugular venous distention suggests a right ventricular (RV) infarction (
Option C

). RV infarction occurs in approximately 20% of patients with an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The diagnosis can be made by right-sided ECG, on which ST-segment elevation will be seen in leads V
and V
R. Treatment consists of aggressive volume resuscitation to optimize RV filling (preload), intravenous vasopressors if hypotension persists, and urgent coronary revascularization.
Cardiac tamponade (
Option A

) occurs when fluid accumulation within the pericardial space compresses the heart and impedes diastolic filling. Clinical signs of tamponade include tachycardia, hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevation of the jugular venous pulse. Pulsus paradoxus represents exaggerated ventricular interdependence and is a key clinical feature of cardiac tamponade. The ECG may demonstrate electrical alternans (related to a swinging motion of the heart within the pericardial fluid) or low voltage. Some patients may also have ST elevations in many leads, including RV leads. The absence of a paradoxical pulse and ST changes in the inferior leads is not compatible with cardiac tamponade.
Pulmonary embolism (PE) (
Option B

) can also present with chest pain, ECG changes, and hypotension. The chest pain of PE may be pleuritic. PE can also cause strain on the right ventricle with ST elevations in right-sided leads, and if the PE is sufficiently large, cardiac output may be impaired with resultant hypotension. However, PE is rarely associated with ST-segment elevations localized to the inferior leads. If the diagnosis remains in doubt, bedside echocardiography can often distinguish between RV infarction and PE; infarction will be associated with RV dysfunction, including hypokinesis or akinesis, and reduced RV ejection, among other findings.
A ventricular septal rupture (
Option D

) manifests as a new, harsh, holosystolic murmur; palpable thrill; and respiratory distress due to acute left-to-right shunting, pulmonary overcirculation, and biventricular failure 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction onset. It would be exceedingly uncommon for a patient to initially have a ventricular septal defect unless symptoms of chest pain were present for 1 to 3 days prior to presentation. In addition, the clear lungs on physical examination do not support the presence of pulmonary edema, which would likely be present with acute ventricular septal rupture.

references: Durko AP, Budde RPJ, Geleijnse ML, et al. Recognition, assessment and management of the mechanical complications of acute myocardial infarction. Heart. 2018;104:1216-1223.

title: Question 36

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-month history of postprandial fullness. She has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine and a remote history of adequately treated
Helicobacter pylori
infection.
Abdominal examination is normal. Vitiligo and absent vibratory sensation in the lower extremities are noted.
Hemoglobin
level is 10 g/dL (100 g/L) with a
mean corpuscular volume
of 114 fL. Result of stool antigen test for
H. pylori
is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Chronic autoimmune atrophic gastritis is an autoimmune disorder typically found in older women that leads to replacement of the normal gastric mucosa by intestinal metaplastic cells; patients typically have low vitamin B
levels and macrocytic anemia.
Goals of therapy for autoimmune atrophic gastritis include prevention of pernicious anemia and iron deficiency with vitamin B
supplementation and iron replacement.
This patient has a medical history, clinical manifestations, and physical findings that support the diagnosis of chronic autoimmune atrophic gastritis (CAAG) (
Option A

). CAAG is an autoimmune disorder that leads to replacement of the normal gastric mucosa by intestinal metaplastic cells. The disease is more common in women older than 60 years and presents with nonspecific symptoms that affect the gastrointestinal tract and nervous system. Abnormal vibratory sensation and proprioception may develop due to degeneration of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord. Patients typically have low vitamin B

levels and macrocytic anemia (pernicious anemia), but younger persons with earlier disease may present with iron deficiency. CAAG is commonly associated with chronic thyroiditis and autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, Addison disease, and vitiligo. Diagnosis may require a combination of clinical, serologic, and histologic information. Parietal cell antibodies are sensitive but also may be found in other autoimmune conditions; conversely, intrinsic factor antibodies are highly specific but not sensitive. Upper endoscopy reveals atrophic and polypoid changes, although abnormalities may not be present in the early stages. CAAG is a precancerous condition that increases the risk for gastric adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine tumors. Goals of therapy for autoimmune atrophic gastritis include prevention of pernicious anemia and iron deficiency with vitamin B

supplementation and iron replacement, along with surveillance for gastric neoplasm. Screening upper endoscopy with gastric biopsy is recommended in the setting of pernicious anemia. Otherwise, there are no universally accepted surveillance protocols for gastric neoplasm in chronic atrophic gastritis, and endoscopic surveillance should be considered on an individual basis.
Erosive gastropathy (
Option B

) can result from exposure to medications and toxins, including NSAIDs, iron, and alcohol. Ischemia and portal hypertension are additional causes. Although erosive gastropathy may result in gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia, it rarely causes clinically significant bleeding. Erosive gastropathy is not associated with other autoimmune disorders or vitamin B
deficiency.
Abnormal gastric motility has been described in CAAG, but the absence of nausea, vomiting, and early satiety and the presence of vitamin B
deficiency make gastroparesis (
Option C
) a less likely diagnosis.
Helicobacter pylori
infection (
Option D
) may be concomitant with CAAG and should be treated if present, but a negative result on a stool antigen test makes the diagnosis unlikely.

references: Gupta S, Li D, El Serag HB, et al. AGA clinical practice guidelines on management of gastric intestinal metaplasia. Gastroenterology. 2020;158:693-702.

title: Question 37

children: A 37-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 4-week history of progressive neck and left forearm pain and weakness. There has been no trauma, and the patient has been otherwise well.

Physical examination reveals 2/5 strength in the left biceps and absent biceps and brachioradialis deep tendon reflexes. MRI of the cervical spine shows compression of the left C6 nerve root from a herniated disk.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Most patients with cervical radiculopathy symptoms have pain and sensory symptoms; these patients can be offered conservative management with rest, analgesics, and physical therapy.

In patients with cervical radiculopathy, surgical intervention is generally indicated in patients with progressive neurologic symptoms resulting from a defined anatomic abnormality to preserve and avoid permanent loss of function.
This patient should be referred for surgical evaluation (
Option D

). She has clinical and imaging evidence of cervical radiculopathy and significant progressive weakness in the affected arm that correlates with her disk herniation. Surgical intervention is generally indicated in patients with progressive neurologic symptoms resulting from a defined anatomic abnormality to preserve and avoid permanent loss of function. Most patients with cervical radiculopathy symptoms have pain and sensory symptoms; however, they do not have associated motor symptoms or only have minor motor symptoms. These patients can be offered conservative management with rest, analgesics, and physical therapy and do not need neuroimaging. Seventy-five percent of these patients have symptom improvement with these conservative measures.

In the absence of progressive motor deficits, a conservative approach, such as analgesics and rest, is indicated because most patients experience improvement in symptoms without more aggressive imaging or intervention. Oral and topical NSAIDs are considered first-line pharmacologic therapy for neck pain. Because of its favorable side-effect profile, acetaminophen is also frequently used, although its effectiveness is not clearly established. Muscle relaxants such as cyclobenzaprine are more effective than placebo for treatment of acute neck pain associated with muscle spasm. Acetaminophen and cyclobenzaprine are not appropriate in the management of weakness caused by radiculopathy (
Option A
Cervical collars are discouraged because they may be associated with a longer recovery period, and opioids should be avoided because of their abuse potential (
Option B
Local glucocorticoid injections with triamcinolone (
Option C

) may provide faster pain relief, although long-term outcomes are similar to those with conservative therapy. This option would not be appropriate in the management of weakness caused by radiculopathy.

objective.__html: Treat cervical radiculopathy with neurologic deficits.

references: McCartney S, Baskerville R, Blagg S, et al. Cervical radiculopathy and cervical myelopathy: diagnosis and management in primary care. Br J Gen Pract. 2018;68:44-46.

children: A 72-year-old woman is evaluated for a progressive asymmetric hand tremor. She also reports difficulty with buttoning clothes, smaller handwriting, and softening of her voice. She takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is increased tone and a resting tremor in the right upper extremity. Repetitive alternating movements are slow and decrementing. Gait is normal. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment score is within the normal range.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
The diagnosis of Parkinson disease requires the presence of bradykinesia and at least one other cardinal feature (resting tremor, rigidity, or postural instability).
In addition to bradykinesia and resting tremor, rigidity, or postural instability, asymmetry of symptoms and absence of early dementia and early falls support the diagnosis of Parkinson disease.
This patient most likely has early Parkinson disease (PD) based on her clinical examination findings and does not require additional diagnostic testing (
Option D

). Diagnosis of PD is clinical. It requires the presence of bradykinesia (in this patient, the decrements in speed and amplitude of repetitive movements) and at least one other cardinal feature (resting tremor, rigidity, or postural instability). In addition, asymmetry of symptoms and absence of atypical features, such as early dementia and early falls, are consistent with the diagnosis of PD. In the absence of atypical features in her history or physical examination, additional testing is usually not necessary.
A dopamine transporter scan (
Option A

) can confirm degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic terminals in PD and differentiate between PD and essential tremor in patients in whom the diagnosis cannot be made on clinical grounds, which is not the case in this patient. The sensitivity of this expensive test, however, is not superior to that of expert clinical assessment. Conventional neuroimaging is not mandatory in patients with a typical clinical presentation and no red flags. However, it is common to perform MRI of the brain to rule out such structural abnormalities as hydrocephalus, diffuse vascular disease or mass lesions that may present with parkinsonism.
Lumbar puncture (
Option B

) and subsequent analysis of cerebrospinal fluid is used in the diagnosis of central nervous system infections and can be helpful in the diagnosis of demyelinating diseases, central nervous system tumors, Guillain-Barré syndrome, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Recent efforts to develop specific biomarkers for PD are underway and include assays to measure α-synuclein in cerebrospinal fluid, but the clinical utility of this test remains unclear.
In patients younger than 40 years with symptoms of parkinsonism, Wilson disease should be ruled out by measuring serum ceruloplasmin as well as 24-hour urine copper level (
Option C

). Wilson disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that causes accumulation of copper in the liver. The accumulation of copper can result in sudden liver failure and Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia due to the sudden release of copper from hepatocytes. Neurological changes can be seen in patients with Wilson disease (tremor, early-onset PD, dystonia). Kayser-Fleischer rings can be seen on slit-lamp examination of patients with Wilson disease and neurologic findings. This 72-year-old woman with typical features of PD without red flags does not require testing for Wilson disease.

title: Question 39

children: A 71-year-old man is evaluated because of a 2-day history of right elbow pain after carrying a heavy briefcase during an extended business trip. The pain radiates to the wrist. Ibuprofen provides partial relief.

On physical examination, temperature is 36.6 °C (97.8 °F). The lateral epicondyle is tender without erythema. There is normal elbow range of motion and no joint swelling; resisted wrist extension provokes pain.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Lateral elbow tendinopathy is characterized by pain located over the lateral elbow but may also radiate to the dorsal forearm; tenderness over the lateral elbow and pain with resisted wrist extension are characteristic examination findings.
Lateral elbow tendinopathy is managed by limiting pain-inducing activities.
This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with lateral elbow tendinopathy and should be advised to limit pain-inducing activities (
Option A

). Lateral elbow tendinopathy (previously called lateral epicondylitis), or tennis elbow, is induced by repetitive wrist extension (e.g., prolonged computer use, racquet sports). Symptoms also can be caused by excessive strain on the wrist extensor tendons, as can happen with lifting or carrying a heavy object. Pain is located over the lateral elbow but may also radiate to the dorsal forearm. Tenderness over the lateral elbow and pain with resisted wrist extension are characteristic examination findings. Increasing evidence suggests elbow tendinopathy is a chronic tendinosis with disorganization and neovascularization of the tissues, instead of an acute or chronic inflammatory process as traditionally believed. Because the primary mechanism of injury appears to be mechanical strain, and repetitive use of injured tissues diminishes healing, primary treatment is avoidance of activities that cause pain and continued injury to the affected area. Braces may be useful when exacerbating activities cannot be avoided, and counterforce bracing, which alters the mechanical strain on the elbow tendons, may be helpful. With rest, pain usually subsides, although resistance exercises also may be beneficial. Other conservative measures include ice and topical or oral NSAIDs, which may provide short-term symptomatic relief. Symptoms usually improve over 3 to 4 weeks unless re-injury occurs.

Imaging, including MRI, is not necessary for diagnosis if the patient has clinical findings consistent with lateral elbow tendinopathy. MRI may be indicated if this patient had atypical findings or did not respond to initial treatment. If there is a history of trauma, evidence of restricted range of motion, or suspected joint pathology, plain radiography is the imaging modality of choice. CT scan (
Option B
) is rarely, if ever indicated.
Surgery (
Option C

) is indicated only for refractory cases of elbow tendinopathy. Patients should first be treated with appropriate conservative measures (rest, ice, bracing, NSAIDs). The risks of surgery would be warranted only if this patient had not responded to all nonsurgical therapies.
Glucocorticoid injections, such as with triamcinolone, with or without lidocaine (
Option D

), may temporarily improve symptoms, but data do not support long-term benefits. Additionally, some evidence shows that glucocorticoid injections may lead to increased risk for recurrence. Associated risks (hyperglycemia in patients with diabetes mellitus, infection) must also be considered. Glucocorticoid injections cannot be justified in this patient who has not received an adequate trial of conservative therapy.

references: Urits I, Markel M, Choi P, et al. Minimally invasive treatment of lateral epicondylitis. Best Pract Res Clin Anaesthesiol. 2020;34:583-602.

Other than a BMI of 17, today's physical examination is unremarkable. Complete blood count is normal, and testing for cystic fibrosis and HIV infection is negative.
Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?

children: Common variable immune deficiency is the most common cause of severe antibody deficiency.
The onset of common variable immune deficiency is usually between the ages of 15 and 25 years, and a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections with encapsulated organisms, such as
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and
Haemophilus influenzae
, as well as giardiasis are common.
This patient likely has common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), and serum levels of IgG, IgA, and IgM should be measured to begin evaluation (
Option C
). The onset of CVID is usually between the ages of 15 and 25 years, and a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections with encapsulated organisms, such as
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and
Haemophilus influenzae

, as well as giardiasis are common. Patients with CVID have a higher incidence of autoimmune disorders, particularly autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, pernicious anemia, and rheumatoid arthritis, as well as disorders of the gastrointestinal tract leading to diarrhea and malabsorption. A higher incidence of CVID exists in those of northern European ancestry, and there is a familial predisposition to selective IgA deficiency and malignancies. If serum IgG and IgA or IgM levels are low, the antibody response to protein- and polysaccharide-based vaccines should then be assessed. If IgG levels are very low (<200 mg/dL [2 g/L]) or undetectable, assessment of vaccine response is not necessary because antibody levels are predictably absent. Therefore, the first step in the evaluation of patients with suspected CVID is measurement of serum immunoglobulin levels.
Flow cytometry (
Option A

) can detect the absence of B cells or B-cell subsets, which may support the diagnosis of an underlying primary humoral deficiency. However, the first step in evaluating this patient is measurement of immunoglobulins because CVID is the most common cause of severe antibody deficiency in children and young adults.

Defective cell-mediated immunity is typically suggested by the occurrence of severe or prolonged infections with common viruses, opportunistic intracellular pathogens, or fungi. Cutaneous delayed-type hypersensitivity is an in vivo test of cellular immunity. The test measures the ability to react to an intradermal injection of an antigen to which the patient has been previously exposed, such as
Candida
Option B

). A positive response suggests normal cellular immunity, but a negative response may have many causes and does not establish the diagnosis of impaired cellular immunity. A negative response is usually followed up with flow cytometry and functional assays. This patient's clinical presentation does not suggest an isolated defect in cell-mediated immunity.
Total hemolytic complement (
Option D

) should be measured whenever a complement deficiency is suspected. A low total hemolytic complement level is seen with classical and terminal complement pathway deficiencies. Complement deficiencies involving the early components of the complement system are associated with autoimmune disorders, most specifically systemic lupus erythematosus. These patients may have recurrent infections caused by encapsulated organisms, such as
S. pneumoniae
or disseminated
Neisseria
infections. Deficiencies in the terminal components of the complement system are associated with recurrent
Neisseria
infections.

references: Lee TK, Gereige JD, Maglione PJ. State-of-the-art diagnostic evaluation of common variable immunodeficiency. Ann Allergy Asthma Immunol. 2021;127:19-27.

title: Question 41

children: A 45-year-old man has a 3-year history of limiting exertional dyspnea. He has no risk factors for cardiac or pulmonary disease and no other symptoms.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: Oxygen saturation
is 97% with the patient breathing ambient air. BMI is 35. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Hemoglobin level is normal. Chest radiograph, ECG, spirometry, and echocardiogram are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
Cardiopulmonary exercise testing can be helpful if the cause of dyspnea remains elusive following completion of standard testing.
Cardiopulmonary testing can also support the diagnosis of deconditioning as a cause of dyspnea.
Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (
Option A

) should be performed next. If the cause of dyspnea remains elusive following completion of standard testing, cardiopulmonary exercise testing can be helpful. It can also aid in the evaluation of patients with multiple potential causes of dyspnea. Cardiopulmonary exercise testing involves continuous monitoring of ECG, blood pressure, respiratory rate, pulse oximetry, and other parameters in addition to more sophisticated measurements of oxygen consumption, carbon dioxide production, and work output. Cardiopulmonary testing narrows the differential diagnosis of dyspnea by identifying the physiologic basis for the patient's symptoms. It can also support the diagnosis of deconditioning as a cause of symptoms.
Chest CT (
Option B

) is used to evaluate lung lesions and other chest pathology, including interstitial, pleural, or mediastinal disease. U.S. Preventive Services Task Force guidelines also recommend lung cancer screening with low-dose CT for patients aged 50 through 80 years who have no symptoms of lung cancer and at least a 20-pack-year smoking history and who are current smokers or have quit within the last 15 years. This patient has few symptoms to suggest pulmonary disease, and he has a normal pulmonary examination, oxygen saturation, and chest radiograph. In addition, he does not meet the criteria for lung cancer screening.
For undifferentiated dyspnea, obtaining a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal pro–B-type (NT-proBNP) natriuretic peptide level (
Option C

) may be reasonable to help differentiate cardiac from pulmonary causes of dyspnea. In this patient with a normal physical examination, chest radiograph, spirometry, ECG and echocardiogram, a BNP NT-proBNP level is unlikely to be helpful. In addition, BNP and NT-proBNP levels are reduced in patients with an elevated BMI.

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as a resting mean pulmonary artery pressure of 25 mm Hg or greater measured during right heart catheterization. The initial symptoms of PH are nonspecific, often consisting of exertional dyspnea and fatigue. If PH is suspected, transthoracic echocardiography should be performed, as it allows an estimation of pulmonary arterial systolic pressure and assessment of both right and left heart size and function. Right heart catheterization (
Option D
) confirms the diagnosis of PH and is typically an essential component of the diagnostic evaluation. This patient's echocardiogram was normal, and right heart catheterization is not indicated.

objective.__html: Evaluate dyspnea with cardiopulmonary exercise testing.

references: O'Donnell DE, Milne KM, Vincent SG, et al. Unraveling the causes of unexplained dyspnea: the value of exercise testing. Clin Chest Med. 2019;40:471-499.

children: A 67-year-old man reports a several-day history of light-headedness with rest and activity. The symptoms can be abated by lying down. His only other medical problem is mild-severity Alzheimer disease treated with donepezil.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 137/88 mm Hg and pulse rate is 47/min.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Sinus node dysfunction can cause sinus or ectopic atrial bradycardia (rate <50/min), sinoatrial exit block, sinus pause (>3 seconds), sinus node arrest, tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome, chronotropic incompetence, or isorhythmic dissociation.
Medications such as β-blockers or parasympathetic nervous system stimulants (e.g., donepezil, neostigmine, and pyridostigmine) are the most common reversible cause of sinus node dysfunction.
Because this patient's episodes of sinus bradycardia correlate with lightheadedness, he likely has sinus node dysfunction (
Option D

). Sinus node dysfunction can cause sinus or ectopic atrial bradycardia (rate <50/min), sinoatrial exit block, sinus pause (>3 seconds), sinus node arrest, tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome, chronotropic incompetence, or isorhythmic dissociation. Symptoms of lightheadedness (most typical), near-syncope, syncope, or confusion are manifestations of hypoperfusion. Sinus node dysfunction can be caused by degenerative fibrosis of the sinoatrial node or be related to other myocardial disease processes. Medications such as β-blockers or parasympathetic nervous system stimulants (e.g., donepezil, neostigmine, and pyridostigmine) are the most common reversible cause of sinus node dysfunction. Permanent pacemaker implantation is the most appropriate treatment for symptomatic sinus node dysfunction with documented bradycardia not caused by treatable factors.
If impulse generation is faster in the atrioventricular (AV) junction than the sinus node rate, an ectopic junctional rhythm (
Option A

) will be seen on ECG. Ectopic junctional rhythm is characterized by lack of P waves before the QRS complexes, but retrograde P waves may be buried within QRS complex or occur after the QRS complex deforming the ST segment or T wave. Sinus node impulses are inhibited by the retrograde conducted P waves. This patient has P waves prior to each QRS complex, excluding the diagnosis of ectopic junctional rhythm.
In second-degree AV block (
Option B

), only some P waves conduct to the ventricles.
