Mobitz type 1 second-degree (Wenckebach) AV block is characterized electrocardiographically by a PR interval that progressively prolongs until a beat is dropped, resulting in grouped beating. Mobitz type 2 second-degree AV block is typified by intermittent nonconducted P waves with unchanging PR intervals. This patient has no evidence of nonconducted P waves, excluding the diagnosis of second-degree heart block.

The transient absence of sinus P waves on ECG defines sinus node pause or sinus node arrest. The pause may last from 2 seconds to several minutes and is the result of an alteration in discharge by the sinoatrial node pacemaker. This patient's ECG shows a regular sinus bradycardia without evidence of sinus pauses or arrest (
Option C

references: Sidhu S, Marine JE. Evaluating and managing bradycardia. Trends Cardiovasc Med. 2020;30:265-272.

title: Question 43

children: A 49-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is evaluated in the emergency department for a 36-hour history of nausea and vomiting associated with severe abdominal pain radiating to his back.
Temperature is 38.4 °C (101.2 °F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 110/min. The abdomen is distended, and epigastric tenderness to palpation is present.
Which of the following is the best predictor of severe disease in this patient?
Risk factors for severe pancreatitis include age older than 55 years, medical comorbidities, obesity, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome.

Hypovolemia is a risk factor for acute pancreatitis–related morbidity, which can be identified by a serum blood urea nitrogen level greater than 20 mg/dL (7.14 mmol/L), hematocrit level greater than 44%, or elevated serum creatinine level.
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (
Option A

) is the best predictor of severe disease in this patient with acute pancreatitis. He has abdominal pain with characteristic features, including acute onset, epigastric location, and radiation to the back. Serum amylase and lipase levels are usually elevated at least three times the upper limit of normal. Risk factors for severe pancreatitis include age older than 55 years, medical comorbidities, obesity, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome. Hypovolemia is also a risk factor for morbidity, which can be identified by a serum BUN level greater than 20 mg/dL (7.14 mmol/L), hematocrit level greater than 44%, or elevated serum creatinine level. BUN is the most reliable routine laboratory study to predict mortality. For every 5.0-mg/dL (1.79-mmol/L) increase in BUN during the first 24 hours, the age- and sex-adjusted odds ratio for mortality increases by 2.2 (95% confidence interval, 1.8-2.7).
Serum lipase (
Option B

) or amylase levels should be used only to diagnose acute pancreatitis; they do not provide any value in terms of predicting the severity of acute pancreatitis. In addition, they should not be used to monitor the patient's progress during hospitalization because the levels generally do not correlate with clinical improvement or decline.

Patients with acute pancreatitis should undergo transabdominal ultrasonography to assess for gallstones and biliary duct dilation. Transabdominal ultrasonography is preferred over CT because it has a higher sensitivity for detecting gallstones, avoids the risks of intravenous contrast material, and is more cost-effective. Although less useful for assessing the biliary system, CT may be indicated if the diagnosis is in question or clinical symptoms are not improved within the first 48 hours (especially because abdominal air can limit ultrasonographic visualization of the pancreas). Peripancreatic edema (
Option C
) blurs the margins of the pancreas on CT and signifies pancreatic inflammation. However, this finding is not a marker of the severity of acute pancreatitis.
Fever and leukocytosis may be seen in acute pancreatitis and are usually a part of the cytokine cascade. Neither temperature (
Option D
) nor leukocyte count is an independent marker of severity in acute pancreatitis.

objective.__html: Identify acute pancreatitis prognostic risk factors.

references: Crockett SD, Wani S, Gardner TB, et al; American Gastroenterological Association Institute Clinical Guidelines Committee. American Gastroenterological Association Institute guideline on initial management of acute pancreatitis. Gastroenterology. 2018;154:1096-1101.

title: Question 44

children: A 68-year-old woman reports a 5-year history of bilateral lower extremity discomfort associated with brown coloration and edema. One year ago, she developed a small ulcer below the right medial malleolus.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 32. Ankle-brachial index is normal. Ankle edema, dilated veins, thin hyperpigmented skin, and a healed ulcer below the right medial malleolus are noted. There is no erythema, tenderness, or warmth.
Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
Manifestations of chronic venous insufficiency include edema, varicose veins, skin hyperpigmentation, stasis dermatitis, cellulitis, and ulceration.
The initial management of chronic venous insufficiency includes walking and multilayered compression bandages or knee-high compression stockings.
This patient has chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and the best management is walking exercise and multilayered compression bandages or knee-high compression stockings (
Option D

). Walking and ankle flexion exercises are inexpensive, safe, and effective treatment for nonulcerated chronic venous insufficiency. These interventions activate the calf-muscle "venous pump" to move lower extremity venous blood proximally. Multiple randomized trials have demonstrated the benefits of long-term compression therapy in patients with CVI with associated edema, ulcer, or eczema. Before starting compression stockings, patients with weak pulses or risk factors for atherosclerosis should have ankle-brachial index measurements because compression therapy is contraindicated in patients with peripheral artery disease. CVI results from persistent venous hypertension caused by venous incompetence or occlusion. It is commonly seen in older persons, those who are overweight, or those with previous conditions (thrombophlebitis, trauma) in which the lower extremity venous system may have been damaged. Manifestations of CVI include edema, varicose veins, skin hyperpigmentation, stasis dermatitis, cellulitis, and ulceration (such as in this patient, who has a healed ulcer on the right medial ankle). Diagnosis is usually made based on history and examination alone, but duplex ultrasonography can be helpful in unclear cases or when planning surgery. Medications should be reviewed because certain drugs (e.g., dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) can exacerbate dependent edema.
CVI-related edema is due to increased hydrostatic forces, not hypervolemia. Loop diuretics, such as bumetanide (
Option A

), are rarely effective unless there is an associated hypervolemic state. Inappropriate use of diuretics, especially in the elderly, can lead to electrolyte disturbances, orthostatic hypotension, and falls.
Antibiotics, such as doxycycline (
Option B

), can be used in CVI when there is evidence of secondary infection. Because CVI causes lower extremity erythema, it is frequently confused with infection. However, cellulitis is usually acute, erythematous, unilateral, and associated with pain and possibly systemic symptoms. This patient's stable bilateral brown pigmentation without acute changes or signs of infection is more consistent with CVI.
A topical glucocorticoid, such as hydrocortisone (
Option C

), is indicated for patients who manifest findings of stasis dermatitis such as erythema, oozing, or vesiculation. Mid-potency topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone butyrate 0.1% or hydrocortisone valerate 0.02%, are typically used. This patient has no findings to suggest stasis dermatitis, and topical glucocorticoids are not needed. For dry itching skin, topical petrolatum is recommended.

references: Stücker M, Münter KC, Erfurt-Berge C, et al. Multicomponent compression system use in patients with chronic venous insufficiency: a real-life prospective study. J Wound Care. 2021;30:400-412.

title: Question 45

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated in the office for 3 days of fever, dysuria, urinary urgency, slow urinary stream, and perineal pain associated with cloudy urine. He does not report nausea or vomiting. He is not sexually active.

The patient appears acutely ill but stable. Temperature is 38.8 °C (101.8 °F); all other vital signs are normal. Rectal examination reveals a tender, boggy prostate. Laboratory results show leukocytosis, pyuria, and bacteriuria. Urine and blood cultures are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric treatment?

Recommended empiric outpatient treatment of acute bacterial prostatitis in men without risk factors for sexually transmitted infection should begin with either trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or a fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin.
A single dose of ceftriaxone plus doxycycline is indicated for uncomplicated acute bacterial prostatitis in patients at risk for sexually transmitted infections with
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
or
Chlamydia trachomatis
; generally, men younger than 35 years are at risk for infection with these organisms.
This patient with likely acute bacterial prostatitis should begin empiric treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option D

). Oral fluoroquinolone antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) are also effective treatments for acute bacterial prostatitis but should not be used if recent genitourinary instrumentation was performed, because most
Escherichia coli

strains are now resistant to fluoroquinolones. Acute prostatitis most commonly results from an ascending urethral infection, although bacterial cystitis or epididymo-orchitis may be an underlying source of infection. Patients most often present with fever; chills; malaise; nausea and vomiting; dysuria; urinary urgency and frequency; and pain in the lower abdomen, perineum, and rectum. The onset of symptoms is typically rapid. On physical examination, the prostate is tender and tense or boggy. Blood and urine cultures should be obtained, and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started. Gram-negative bacillary organisms, including
E. coli
Serratia
species, and
Klebsiella

species, are the most common causative agents in patients with uncomplicated acute bacterial prostatitis who are at low risk for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The course of therapy is typically 2 to 4 weeks; some experts recommend up to 6 weeks.
Ampicillin (
Option A
), which was an alternative therapeutic option for prostatitis, can no longer be recommended as empiric therapy because of the high rate of resistance among community-acquired microorganisms.
A single dose of ceftriaxone, 500 mg intramuscularly, plus doxycycline (
Option B
) is indicated for uncomplicated acute bacterial prostatitis in patients at risk for STIs with
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
or
Chlamydia trachomatis

. Generally, men younger than 35 years and older men who engage in high-risk sexual behavior are at risk for infection with these organisms. These patients may also have concomitant epididymitis and urethritis. This patient is 66 years old and not sexually active; therefore, he does not require coverage for possible STIs.
Treatment with a carbapenem, such as meropenem (
Option C
), should be reserved for patients who require hospitalization.

references: Gill BC, Shoskes DA. Bacterial prostatitis. Curr Opin Infect Dis. 2016;29:86-91.

title: Question 46

children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for a 4-month history of snoring and daytime somnolence. His bed partner reports the recent onset of gasping and loud snorting following a period of not breathing.
BMI is 34. Neck circumference is 18 inches. The soft palate is low-lying. Polysomnography discloses an apnea-hypopnea index of 38/hour.
Weight loss is recommended.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Obstructive sleep apnea is defined by upper airway narrowing or collapse resulting in cessation (apnea) or reduction (hypopnea) in airflow despite ongoing efforts to breathe.
Continuous positive airway pressure should be considered first-line therapy in any patient who has obstructive sleep apnea and associated symptoms, particularly excessive daytime sleepiness.
The most appropriate treatment is continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) (
Option B

). Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is defined by upper airway narrowing or collapse resulting in cessation (apnea) or reduction (hypopnea) in airflow despite ongoing efforts to breathe. The severity of OSA is measured using the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), calculated as the sum of apneas and hypopneas divided by total sleep hours. An AHI of 5 to 15 indicates mild OSA, an AHI of 16 to 30 indicates moderate sleep apnea, and an AHI of more than 30 indicates severe OSA. It is estimated that 24% of men aged 30 to 60 years and 9% of similarly aged women have OSA (AHI of at least 5/hour). CPAP should be considered first-line therapy in any patient who has OSA and associated symptoms, particularly excessive daytime sleepiness. Optimal positive airway pressure therapy may have salutary effects on the cardiovascular diseases associated with OSA. Suboptimal adherence to CPAP is common in clinical practice, and rates of discontinuation are high. Therefore, objective monitoring of use and periodic follow-up are important to ensure adherence.
Bilevel positive airway pressure (
Option A

), which delivers separate inspiratory and expiratory pressures (the gradient is referred to as pressure support) to augment alveolar ventilation, is not first-line therapy for OSA without a hypoventilation syndrome.
A hypoglossal nerve stimulator (
Option C

) approved for use in OSA has been shown to improve the AHI in some patients. Implanted in the chest wall, it synchronizes with the respiratory cycle to contract the tongue muscles during inspiration. It is expensive, and those patients most likely to benefit from this treatment are yet to be determined.
Nocturnal oxygen therapy (
Option D
) alone is inadequate to prevent complications associated with OSA because it does not correct upper airway obstruction, which is the primary problem related to oxygen desaturation.

references: Kent D, Stanley J, Aurora RN, et al. Referral of adults with obstructive sleep apnea for surgical consultation: an American Academy of Sleep Medicine clinical practice guideline. J Clin Sleep Med. 2021.

title: Question 47

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for his third episode of calcium oxalate kidney stones. He has recurrent stone formation despite adherence to increased fluid intake, resulting in a daily urine output of more than 2500 mL, and a low-sodium diet.
A 24-hour urine collection shows normal calcium, uric acid, and citric acid levels but high urine oxalate.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

text.__html: Increase dietary calcium and start low-protein, low-oxalate diet
Increase consumption of rhubarb, peanuts, spinach, beets, and chocolate

children: Patients with recurrent calcium oxalate stones and hyperoxaluria will benefit from a high calcium diet, which will bind oxalate in the gut and prevent its absorption and ultimate filtration at the level of the kidneys.

In patients with recurrent calcium-containing stones and hypercalciuria, a thiazide diuretic is recommended to reduce urinary calcium excretion, increase calcium reabsorption in the kidney, and therefore reduce the amount of calcium available in the urine to form stones.
An increase in dietary calcium and initiation of a low-protein, low-oxalate diet (
Option C

) are indicated for this patient. He should also maintain a low-sodium diet. He most likely has recurrent calcium oxalate stones due to hyperoxaluria. Furthermore, oxalate binds to urine calcium as it is eliminated by the kidneys, which results in calcium oxalate stone formation. With a high-calcium diet, the calcium binds to oxalate in the gut and prevents its absorption and ultimate filtration at the level of the kidneys.
In patients with recurrent calcium-containing stones and hypercalciuria, a thiazide diuretic such as chlorthalidone (
Option A

) is recommended to reduce urinary calcium excretion, increase calcium reabsorption in the kidney, and therefore reduce the amount of calcium available in the urine to form stones. However, this patient's 24-hour urine collection findings suggest that hyperoxaluria is the causative factor for stone formation, not hypercalciuria.

Because citrate prevents calcium crystal formation, low urine levels are associated with increased stone formation. Citrate excretion is decreased in the presence of metabolic acidosis, as occurs with chronic diarrhea and distal renal tubular acidosis. Alkalinization of the urine with citrate may help prevent recurrent kidney stones. This patient has normal urinary citrate; thus, potassium citrate is not needed (
Option B
). The use of citrate to alkalinize the urine may cause calcium phosphate stone formation.

Enteric hyperoxaluria is caused by increased gastrointestinal absorption of oxalate, whereas secondary hyperoxaluria is usually caused by increased intake of oxalate-rich foods such as rhubarb, peanuts, spinach, beets, and chocolate. This patient likely has secondary hyperoxaluria, and dietary restriction of oxalate-rich foods would decrease this patient's risk for recurrent calcium oxalate stones. Increasing the consumption of rhubarb, peanuts, spinach, beets, and chocolate (
Option D
) will likely worsen his condition.

objective.__html: Manage recurrent calcium oxalate stone formation.

references: D'Alessandro C, Ferraro PM, Cianchi C, et al. Which diet for calcium stone patients: A real-world approach to preventive care. Nutrients. 2019;11.

title: Question 48

children: A 34-year-old man is evaluated because of subacute worsening of nontraumatic chronic low back pain. Last night, he developed paresthesia over the inner thighs and perineum, and he could not urinate this morning. He has no other medical problems.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is bilateral foot drop, saddle anesthesia, and absent lower extremity reflexes.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

Classic clinical findings of cauda equina syndrome include acute low back pain, radicular pain, and bilateral leg weakness; other associated findings may include perineal sensory symptoms; bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction; and decreased or absent distal reflexes.
Urgent neuroimaging with MRI and surgical treatment offer the best chance of avoiding permanent neurologic damage from cauda equina syndrome.
This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with cauda equina syndrome (CES), and an urgent MRI (
Option D

) should be obtained. CES is an uncommon but potentially catastrophic condition caused by compression and ischemia of some or all of the 18 descending nerve roots that make up the cauda equina, with resulting neurologic impairment. Causes may be benign (such as degenerative changes, disk herniation, spondylosis, and other structural abnormalities of the spine; infection; or bleeding) or malignant (with multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and prostate cancer being the most commonly associated cancers). Classic clinical findings include acute low back pain, radicular pain, and bilateral leg weakness. CES may be associated with perineal sensory symptoms; bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction; and decreased or absent distal reflexes. However, not all of these features present early in the syndrome. For example, pain is the most common early symptom and may precede other neurologic findings; bowel and bladder dysfunction are usually late manifestations and do not occur in all patients. Urgent neuroimaging with MRI and surgical treatment offer the best chance of avoiding permanent neurologic damage.

CT myelography can show compressive myelopathy when MRI is not feasible but often does not reveal the cause of compression. Additionally, this type of imaging may be difficult to arrange emergently and is problematic in patients with allergies to contrast dyes or impaired kidney function. CT without myelography (
Option A
) will not be helpful in this patient with potential cauda equina compression due to the limited ability to visualize the nerve roots.
Evaluation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) obtained through a lumbar puncture (
Option B

) has no role in the evaluation of suspected cauda equina syndrome or cord compression. It is possible that sudden clinical deterioration may occur in patients with complete subarachnoid block when CSF pressure below the block has been reduced by the lumbar puncture. Lumbar puncture will be required to introduce contrast if CT myelography is performed, and neurosurgical input is often recommended.
Plain radiography (
Option C

) may be considered to evaluate for ankylosing spondylitis or vertebral compression fracture. When malignancy is suspected, plain radiography in addition to measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is the recommended management. If results of these initial tests are negative and significant concern remains, MRI should then be obtained.

references: Long B, Koyfman A, Gottlieb M. Evaluation and management of cauda equina syndrome in the emergency department. Am J Emerg Med. 2020;38:143-148.

title: Question 49

children: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-month history of fatigue and constipation. More recently, she has experienced polydipsia and polyuria. She has no other medical problems.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
Serum albumin
level is 4.5 g/dL (45 g/L),
calcium
level is 11.4 mg/dL (2.9 mmol/L), and
phosphorus
level is 2.2 mg/dL (0.71 mmol/L). Complete blood count, anion gap, and kidney function are normal.
Which of the following should be measured next?
Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in the outpatient setting, and the first step in diagnosing hypercalcemia is to determine the parathyroid hormone level.
In patients with hypercalcemia, an elevated or “inappropriately” normal parathyroid hormone measurement is diagnostic of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in the outpatient setting, and the first step in diagnosing hypercalcemia is to determine the parathyroid hormone (PTH) level with an assay for intact PTH (
Option D

). If the PTH level is high or “inappropriately” normal, primary hyperparathyroidism is the diagnosis. If the PTH level is suppressed, a search for other entities that cause hypercalcemia must be conducted. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically caused by a solitary parathyroid adenoma. Because PTH enhances kidney phosphate excretion, low or low-normal serum phosphorus concentrations support the diagnosis.
Calcitonin (
Option A

) is secreted by thyroid parafollicular C cells. This serum level is elevated in patients with medullary thyroid cancer or C-cell hyperplasia. Calcitonin tends to lower the calcium level, but the effect is weak and relevant only in pharmacologic amounts. Measurement of serum calcitonin is not indicated in a patient with hypercalcemia.

One of the ways in which PTH increases the serum calcium level is by upregulation of the 1α-hydroxylase enzyme, which stimulates conversion of vitamin D to its most active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. This form of vitamin D increases the percentage of dietary calcium absorbed by the intestine. Body stores of vitamin D are assessed by measuring 25-hydroxyvitamin D, which has a long half-life. Measurement of this patient's 25-hydroxyvitamin D and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels (
Option B
) may be appropriate after measuring serum PTH, particularly if the PTH level is suppressed; however, this should not precede measurement of serum PTH.
Ionized calcium measurement (
Option C

) is not necessary if the serum albumin or corrected total calcium levels are normal, there are no acute acid-base disorders, or there is no evidence of paraproteinemia, such as multiple myeloma (anemia, kidney injury, low anion gap). In most clinical situations, measured calcium levels depend on the amount bound to albumin, which may be affected by nutrition and acid-base status. When albumin concentration is low, ionized calcium measurement or corrected total calcium calculation is required to accurately assess calcium levels. This patient's albumin level is normal, and she has symptoms of hypercalcemia; ionized calcium does not need to be measured.

references: Insogna KL. Primary hyperparathyroidism. N Engl J Med. 2018;379:1050-1059.

title: Question 50

children: A 22-year-old woman on a university cross-country team is evaluated for recent onset of cough, chest tightness, and shortness of breath occurring shortly after training and continuing for 30 minutes. Symptoms are worse in cold weather.
Physical examination and office spirometry are normal. After exercise,
FEV
decreases by 15% from baseline.
Which of the following inhaled agents is the most appropriate treatment?
Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) is an acute, measurable airway obstruction that occurs in response to exercise; a decrease in FEV
of greater than 10% within 30 minutes of exercise is diagnostic of EIB.
Initial pharmacologic therapy for exercise-induced bronchoconstriction can include administration of either an inhaled short-acting β
-agonist, such as albuterol, or low-dose budesonide-formoterol, 15 minutes before exercise.
The most appropriate treatment is inhaled low-dose budesonide-formoterol before exercise (
Option B

). This patient has features of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), which is acute, measurable airway obstruction that occurs in response to exercise. EIB is common in patients with asthma, and some patients only experience symptoms after exercise. Precipitating symptoms include exercise in cold, dry air, such as during winter; exposure to high levels of trichloramines in swimming pools; and inhalation of airborne particulates and ozone. A decrease in FEV
of greater than 10% within 30 minutes of exercise is diagnostic of EIB. Initial pharmacologic therapy can include administration of either an inhaled short-acting β

-agonist (SABA), such as albuterol, or low-dose budesonide-formoterol, 15 minutes before exercise. Nonpharmacologic approaches to prevent EIB include gradual warm-up before intense exercise and using a mask over the nose and mouth to warm and humidify air during cold weather.
An inhaled glucocorticoid, such as beclomethasone (
Option A

), can be added daily whenever SABA therapy is used at least daily or when symptoms are not well controlled. An inhaled glucocorticoid alone immediately before exercise is not effective in preventing EIB.
Inhaled long-acting β
-agonists (LABAs), such as salmeterol (
Option C

), which provide sustained airway dilation with just once- or twice-daily dosing, are an important tool for asthma treatment when added to inhaled glucocorticoid therapy, improving control and decreasing the risk for asthma exacerbation. However, single-agent use of LABAs is not recommended because of the increased risk for asthma-related death when they are used without a simultaneous controller medication, such as an inhaled glucocorticoid.
Long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMAs), such as tiotropium (
Option D

), provide sustained airway dilation. When added to therapy in patients with asthma that is not controlled with inhaled glucocorticoid/LABA combination therapy, tiotropium has been shown to improve lung function and reduce exacerbations. For patients with significant adverse effects from LABAs, a LAMA can reasonably be substituted. However, there is no substantial evidence that LAMAs instead of LABAs should be the first choice for long-acting airway dilation in patients with asthma. There is no evidence that a LAMA, as a single therapeutic agent, is effective in preventing EIB.

references: Cloutier MM, Dixon AE, Krishnan JA, et al. Managing asthma in adolescents and adults: 2020 asthma guideline update from the national asthma education and prevention program. JAMA. 2020;324:2301-2317.

title: Question 51

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-day history of abdominal cramping and several days of nonbloody, watery diarrhea. Six other people developed similar symptoms after drinking unpasteurized milk 2 days ago contaminated with
Salmonella braenderup.
She has no other medical problems.
Temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8 °F). The abdomen is nontender with active bowel sounds.
Leukocyte count
Oral hydration therapy is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Nontyphoidal
Salmonella
serotypes are the most common bacterial cause of foodborne illness in the United States.
In young healthy persons with mild
Salmonella
gastroenteritis, the illness usually resolves without antibiotic therapy; antibiotic therapy is associated with prolonged asymptomatic fecal shedding with no decrease in duration of diarrhea.
This otherwise healthy and stable patient has acute diarrhea consistent with mild
Salmonella
gastroenteritis, which requires no treatment (
Option D
) at this time. Nontyphoidal
Salmonella

serotypes are the most common bacterial cause of foodborne illness in the United States. Infection usually results from ingesting fecally contaminated water or food of animal origin, including poultry, beef, eggs, and milk. Contact with infected animals (including pet reptiles, amphibians, and poultry) is a less common mode of transmission. The incubation period is usually less than 3 days, resulting in an inflammatory diarrhea, sometimes associated with fever and abdominal pain. In young healthy persons, such as this patient, the illness is usually self-limited and resolves without antibiotic therapy. In this population, antibiotic therapy is associated with prolonged asymptomatic fecal shedding with no decrease in duration of diarrhea. Antibiotics are typically reserved for patients with more serious illness (including severe diarrhea requiring hospitalization, bacteremia, high fever, or sepsis) and those at high risk for severe complicated invasive disease (including infants; patients aged ≥50 years; or those with prosthetic materials, significant atherosclerotic disease, or immunocompromising conditions).
Campylobacter

-associated gastroenteritis is usually foodborne, often secondary to undercooked poultry. The incubation period is about 3 days. Symptoms may include fevers, chills, diarrhea (watery or bloody), and crampy abdominal pain. Postinfection complications may include Guillain-Barré syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, intestinal perforation, glomerulonephritis, erythema nodosum, hemolytic anemia, or reactive arthritis. Azithromycin (
Option A
) is the preferred empiric treatment option for
Campylobacter
gastroenteritis, considering increasing rates of quinolone resistance for this bacterium.
Vibrio parahaemolyticus
is the most common
Vibrio

species to cause gastrointestinal illness, usually after consumption of undercooked oysters and other shellfish. The incubation period is about 2 days; typically reported presenting symptoms are diarrhea (may be bloody), fever, nausea or emesis, and crampy abdominal pain. Septicemia may develop in patients who have liver disease and may lead to secondary necrotizing skin infections. Severe noninvasive gastrointestinal illness may be treated with doxycycline (
Option B
). This patient does not have infection with a
Vibrio
species and has no indication for doxycycline.
Treatment of an initial
Clostridioides difficile
infection is dictated by disease severity, with nonsevere disease treated with fidaxomicin (preferred) or oral vancomycin (
Option C
). This patient does not have
C. difficile
infection, and vancomycin is not indicated.

references: Shane AL, Mody RK, Crump JA, et al. 2017 Infectious Diseases Society of America clinical practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of infectious diarrhea. Clin Infect Dis. 2017;65:e45-e80.

title: Question 52

children: A 45-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated during a routine wellness examination. His mother recently died of metastatic colon cancer. She was diagnosed with colon cancer 5 years ago at age 69 years; there is no other history of familial polyps, colon cancer, or other cancer diagnoses.
Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate colorectal cancer screening strategy for this patient?

Appropriate screening strategies for colorectal cancer in average-risk individuals include colonoscopy every 10 years; high-sensitivity guaiac fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test every year; DNA-fecal immunochemical test every 1 to 3 years; CT colonography every 5 years; flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years; and flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years plus fecal immunochemical testing every year.
Colonoscopy every 10 years (
Option B

) is the most appropriate colorectal cancer (CRC) screening strategy for this patient at average risk for colorectal cancer. Evidence from cohort studies demonstrated that colonoscopy reduces CRC-related mortality. Colonoscopy every 10 years is the longest screening interval of all recommended colorectal cancer screening tests. Harms include bleeding and perforation, both risks increasing with age. Other acceptable screening strategies include high-sensitivity guaiac fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test every year; DNA-fecal immunochemical test every 1 to 3 years; CT colonography every 5 years; flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years; and flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years plus fecal immunochemical testing every year. The most appropriate CRC screening strategy is the strategy the patient is most likely to adhere.
Colonoscopy every 5 years (
Option A

) is an appropriate screening test and interval for patients at increased risk for CRC. Patients at increased risk have a family history of CRC diagnosed in a first-degree relative at younger than 60 years or with two or more first-degree relatives at any age. In these patients, CRC screening should begin at age 40 years or 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative at diagnosis, whichever comes first. This patient has average risk for CRC and screening every 10 years with colonoscopy is appropriate.
CT colonography (
Option C

) screening for CRC should be performed every 5 years in average-risk patients, rather than every 10 years. There is no direct evidence that CT colonography reduces CRC mortality. CT colonography requires the same bowel preparation as colonoscopy. Abnormal colonography results must be followed up with colonoscopy.
Fecal immunochemical screening (
Option D

) should be performed annually, rather than every 5 years. Evidence from a single large cohort study documents a reduction in CRC with annual screening. Testing can be done with a single stool specimen but does not require bowel preparation. Abnormal results must be followed up with colonoscopy.

objective.__html: Screen for colorectal cancer with the most appropriate strategy.

references: Davidson KW, Barry MJ, Mangione CM, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for colorectal cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2021;325:1965-1977.

title: Question 53

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a progressive 7-month history of postprandial bloating and early satiety that now occur daily. She has no alarm features to suggest ulcer, inflammatory bowel disease, or cancer.
Abdominal examination reveals minimal epigastric tenderness to palpation without a succussion splash. Bowel sounds are normal. Result of a stool antigen test for
Helicobacter pylori
is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
In the evaluation of dyspepsia, guidelines recommend routine use of upper endoscopy only in patients aged 60 years and older to exclude malignancy.
Patients with dyspepsia who test positive for
Helicobacter pylori
should receive eradication therapy; if the test result is negative or
H. pylori
eradication fails to relieve the dyspepsia, proton pump inhibitor therapy should be pursued for 4 weeks.
A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) such as lansoprazole (
Option B

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient with dyspepsia. The diagnosis of dyspepsia may be challenging, as symptoms overlap with other gastrointestinal disorders, including gastroesophageal reflux disease, gastroparesis, and
Helicobacter pylori

infection. The American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) defines dyspepsia as predominant epigastric pain for at least 1 month. Other symptoms, such as early satiety, nausea, and vomiting, also may be present. The diagnosis of functional dyspepsia requires negative results on upper endoscopy and other tests for organic diseases. Given the low incidence of malignancy and with consideration given to the cost-effectiveness of evaluating dyspepsia in younger adults, the ACG and the Canadian Association of Gastroenterology (CAG) have jointly recommended routine use of upper endoscopy only in patients aged 60 years and older to exclude malignancy. The ACG/CAG guidelines recommend against routine use of upper endoscopy in patients younger than 60 years with dyspepsia, even in most patients with alarm features (weight loss, anemia, dysphagia, and vomiting) because these features poorly predict organic structural pathology, such as malignancy, peptic ulcer disease, or esophagitis. Consideration of endoscopy at a younger age is reasonable for patients at higher risk of malignancy, such as those with childhood years spent in a region where gastric cancer is endemic (Asia, Russia, and South America) or those with a positive family history.
Management of dyspepsia is directed at treating the underlying cause. The first step includes the “test and treat” strategy. Patients who test positive for
H. pylori
should receive eradication therapy. If the test result is negative or if
H. pylori
eradication fails to relieve the dyspepsia, an empiric trial of a PPI should be pursued for 4 weeks.
No evidence supports the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, such as duloxetine (
Option A
), in the treatment of dyspepsia.
In patients without evidence of
H. pylori
infection who are unresponsive to PPI therapy, prokinetic therapies (such as metoclopramide [
Option C
]) or tricyclic antidepressants (such as nortriptyline [
Option D
]) can be tried.

references: Moayyedi P, Lacy BE, Andrews CN, et al. ACG and CAG clinical guideline: management of dyspepsia. Am J Gastroenterol. 2017;112:988-1013.

title: Question 54

children: A 36-year-old man is evaluated for ventilator-associated pneumonia in the ICU, where he was transferred 3 days ago for respiratory failure owing to Guillain-Barré syndrome.
Temperature is 38.6 °C (101.4 °F). Pulmonary examination reveals scattered rhonchi. Flaccid weakness is present in the arms and legs. Bronchoalveolar lavage culture grows methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
. The isolate is susceptible to vancomycin, daptomycin, linezolid, and tigecycline. He is allergic to vancomycin. Chest radiograph shows right middle and lower lobe infiltrates without effusions.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Empiric ventilator-associated pneumonia regimens include coverage for
Staphylococcus aureus
or
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
and other gram-negative bacilli.
Daptomycin is bound by surfactant, and it is not effective in treating pneumonia.
The most appropriate treatment is intravenous linezolid (
Option B

) for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP notably accounts for approximately 20% of hospital-acquired infections and complicates 10% of ventilation episodes. Empiric VAP regimens include coverage for
Staphylococcus aureus
or
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
and other gram-negative bacilli. In this patient with methicillin-resistant
S. aureus

(MRSA) VAP and an adverse reaction to vancomycin, alternative therapy must be used. Linezolid is an oxazolidinone drug with bacteriostatic activity against gram-positive aerobic bacteria, including MRSA and vancomycin-resistant enterococci, and it has performed well in randomized controlled trials compared with vancomycin for pneumonia. The pharmacokinetics of linezolid in the lung are favorable, and it is an excellent alternative to vancomycin for treating MRSA. An important side effect of linezolid is myelosuppression, notably thrombocytopenia. Weekly complete blood counts should be obtained in patients treated with linezolid.
Daptomycin (
Option A
) is effective in treating staphylococcal bacteremia and right-sided infective endocarditis, in addition to skin and skin structure infections. It is equally effective for methicillin-sensitive
S. aureus

(MSSA) and MRSA infections. Although daptomycin is no more effective than β-lactams for treating MSSA infections, it may be a useful alternative to vancomycin for treating MRSA infections in patients with fluctuating kidney function or for isolates with a relatively high (≥2 µg/mL) vancomycin minimum inhibitory concentration. Daptomycin is bound by surfactant, however, and it is not effective in treating pneumonia.
Telavancin (
Option C

), oritavancin, and dalbavancin are analogues of vancomycin and are used for complicated skin and soft tissue infections. Telavancin is also approved for the treatment of VAP when other alternatives are not available. The incidence of hypersensitivity cross-reactivity with vancomycin is unknown, and alternative antibiotics should be used in the setting of an adverse reaction to vancomycin.
Tigecycline (
Option D

) is not approved for hospital-acquired (or ventilator-associated) pneumonia. An FDA warning reported increased mortality rates among patients treated with tigecycline in randomized controlled trials of patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia. Consequently, tigecycline should not be used for treating VAP.

objective.__html: Treat ventilator-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia in a patient allergic to vancomycin.

references: Kalil AC, Metersky ML, Klompas M, et al. Management of adults with hospital-acquired and ventilator-associated pneumonia: 2016 clinical practice guidelines by the Infectious Diseases Society of America and the American Thoracic Society. Clin Infect Dis. 2016;63:e61-e111.

title: Question 55

children: A 37-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-month history of diminishing libido. He has no additional symptoms. Puberty was normal. He fathered one child 4 years ago. He drinks two beers weekly and takes no medication.
Secondary sex characteristics, testicular size, and BMI are normal. Depression screening is negative. His 3
PM
total testosterone
level is 200 ng/dL (6.9 nmol/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?

text.__html: Serum luteinizing and follicle-stimulating hormone levels

children: In the evaluation of male hypogonadism, initial morning measurement of a patient's total testosterone level should be performed; if results are abnormal, a second confirmatory morning measurement should be obtained.

If low testosterone is confirmed with two morning measurements, serum luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone measurements are indicated to differentiate primary from secondary hypogonadism.
Obtaining a morning (8:00 to 10:00
AM)
serum total testosterone level (
Option B

) is the most appropriate next diagnostic test for this patient with decreased libido. Male hypogonadism is a clinical syndrome that results from failure of the testes to produce physiologic levels of testosterone and a normal number of spermatozoa caused by disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-testicular axis. Specific symptoms of hypogonadism in the adult male include decreased morning and spontaneous erections, mastodynia, gynecomastia, decreased need for shaving, and/or decreased axillary and genital hair. According to Endocrine Society guidelines, an initial morning measurement of a patient's total testosterone level should be performed to assess for hypogonadism; if results are abnormal, a second confirmatory morning measurement should be obtained before additional testing is begun. This recommendation is based on many studies showing that variability in testosterone levels from day to day or diurnally is common, with morning total testosterone levels being the most accurate in indicating a patient's androgen status.
Many free testosterone assays (
Option A

) are grossly inaccurate and thus are not currently recommended to diagnose hypogonadism, unless the assay measures free testosterone by equilibrium dialysis. In addition, this patient has no risk factors for altered sex hormone–binding globulin levels (obesity and older age), which would make a total testosterone level less reliable. Therefore, he has no need for a free testosterone assessment.
A repeat 3
PM
total testosterone measurement (
Option C

) is not indicated. Because of the daily variability of testosterone levels, including diurnal variation, morning testosterone measurements are indicated as the most accurate representation of the patient's hormone status.
If low testosterone is confirmed with two morning measurements, serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) measurements (
Option D
) are indicated. Low or normal LH or FSH levels reflect secondary hypogonadism. However, a diagnosis of hypogonadism has not yet been confirmed in this patient.

references: Bhasin S, Brito JP, Cunningham GR, et al. Testosterone therapy in men with hypogonadism: an Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2018;103:1715-1744.

title: Question 56

children: A 79-year-old woman has gram-negative sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure caused by acute respiratory distress syndrome. Mechanical ventilation is indicated. She has advanced Alzheimer dementia and lacks decision-making capacity. She does not have an advance directive. Her only living relative is her adult daughter, who is having trouble making a decision about mechanical ventilation.
Which of the following can be suggested to the patient's daughter as an appropriate basis for her decision?

text.__html: What the daughter feels is correct

children: Surrogates have ethical and legal obligations to make decisions based on the patient's known wishes.
If a patient's wishes are unknown, surrogates should make decisions based on the patient's health care-related values, goals, and preferences (substituted judgment), if known.
The most appropriate recommendation is to ask the patient's daughter what decision the patient would make if she were capable (
Option C

). In the case of a patient who lacks decision-making capacity, a surrogate must guide the decision making. If the patient has an advance directive, the person named in that document is the most appropriate (and legal) surrogate. In the absence of this, many states stipulate a hierarchy of surrogate decision makers (for example, the patient's spouse, followed by an adult child, and so forth). Clinicians should be aware of legal requirements for surrogate appointment in their state. In this patient's case, her adult daughter is the most appropriate surrogate. Surrogates have ethical and legal obligations to make decisions based on the patient's known wishes. If these are not known, surrogates should make decisions based on the patient's health care-related values, goals, and preferences (substituted judgment), if known.
Decisions based on the patient's best interests (
Option A

) should be reserved for situations in which there are no previously expressed oral or written statements of preferences or values from the patient. Family members and physicians may have divergent opinions on what is in the patient's best interests, which may not correlate with what the patient would want.
A surrogate should not make decisions based on his or her own values, preferences, or what he or she feels is the correct course of action (
Option B
) because these views may differ from those of the patient.
A surrogate should not make a decision based solely on what the physician recommends (
Option D

) because the recommendation may be at odds with what the patient wishes might be, if known. A physician recommendation that includes all reasonable options along with expected benefit and harms might be reasonable if the patient's wishes are not known and a decision will be based on the patient's best interests.

objective.__html: Manage surrogate decision making in a patient without an advance directive.

references: Sulmasy LS, Bledsoe TA; ACP Ethics, Professionalism and Human Rights Committee. American College of Physicians ethics manual: seventh edition.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 57

children: A 23-year-old man is evaluated for colon cancer risk. Colon cancer was recently diagnosed in his 50-year-old mother. Colon cancer was also diagnosed in his maternal grandmother at age 67 years and his maternal uncle at age 40 years. The patient is asymptomatic.
Physical examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

text.__html: Flexible sigmoidoscopy and stool DNA testing

children: Lynch syndrome follows an autosomal dominant inheritance and should be suspected when the “3-2-1-1-0” rules are met: (at least) three family members with Lynch-related cancers, in two generations, with one family member a first-degree relative of the other two, at least one member affected before age 50 years, and no familial polyposis.
This patient should be referred for genetic counseling (
Option B

). He has a family history meeting the Amsterdam criteria for Lynch syndrome, an inherited cancer syndrome. It is characterized by germline mutations in the mismatch repair genes or the epithelial cell adhesion molecule gene, which leads to increased risk for neoplasia of the colon and other organs. Lynch syndrome was previously known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer; that name is no longer used because the syndrome is associated with polyps and because it may present as extra-colonic cancer. Lynch syndrome follows an autosomal dominant inheritance and should be suspected when the “3-2-1-1-0” rules are met: (at least) three family members with Lynch-related cancers, in two generations, with one family member a first-degree relative of the other two, at least one member affected before age 50 years, and no familial polyposis. Diagnosis of Lynch syndrome is confirmed if tumors are confirmed histologically and tumor tissue from a family member shows evidence of microsatellite instability or loss of mismatch repair protein expression.
Flexible sigmoidoscopy and stool DNA testing (
Option A

) or fecal immunochemical testing are insufficient for screening for colon cancer in patients with suspected Lynch syndrome. In this patient, colon cancer screening should be accomplished by full colonoscopy.

When a Lynch mutation is identified in a family, testing of first-degree relatives should be performed and surveillance instituted. Family members first should be referred to a genetic counselor who is skilled at appropriate data collection, pedigree analysis, and pre- and posttest counseling for possible germline mutation testing based on the tumor genetics previously identified (
Option C

Screening colonoscopy should be initiated between age 20 and 25 years (or 2-5 years before the age of diagnosis of the earliest familial cancer, if earlier) and repeated every 1 to 2 years. Waiting for colonoscopy until age 35 years (
Option D
) is inappropriate.

objective.__html: Recommend genetic counseling for a patient for risk for inherited cancer.

references: Sinicrope FA. Lynch syndrome-associated colorectal cancer. N Engl J Med. 2018;379:764-773.

title: Question 58

children: A 59-year-old woman is evaluated for a recently self-discovered breast mass. Diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound examinations are normal. All previous mammograms have been normal. She has never had a breast biopsy.
On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm, nontender mass in the right upper outer quadrant. There are no other abnormalities, including lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Mammography is the initial test performed in most patients aged 30 years or older with a breast mass; ultrasonography is preferred in women younger than age 30 years.
Negative ultrasound or a normal mammogram in a patient with a discrete breast mass does not rule out malignancy and requires further evaluation to characterize the nature of the breast mass.
This patient should undergo core needle biopsy of the mass (
Option B

). Mammography is the initial test performed in most patients aged 30 years or older with a breast mass. For patients with a focal abnormality noted on clinical examination or mammogram, targeted ultrasonography can clarify the size of the mass, determine whether the mass is solid or cystic, and identify the margins as smooth or irregular. Ultrasonography is the preferred initial method of evaluation for women younger than 30 years, in whom mammography has low sensitivity due to dense breasts. It is also the test of choice in pregnant patients. Approximately 10% to 20% of palpable breast cancers are not detected by mammography or ultrasonography. Negative ultrasound or a normal mammogram in a patient with a discrete breast mass does not rule out malignancy; therefore, this patient requires further evaluation to characterize the nature of the breast mass. Core needle biopsy, with ultrasonographic or stereotactic guidance (when detectable on imaging), provides excellent tissue sampling for pathology, and if malignant, for hormone receptor status. It is the test of choice for most palpable, solid lesions. This patient with a palpable, firm breast mass but negative imaging results should undergo palpation-guided core needle biopsy.
Breast MRI (
Option A
) would likely better define the breast lesion, which was not visualized on mammography and ultrasonography, but would not replace the need for tissue diagnosis in this patient.

The interval for follow-up imaging after a benign breast biopsy is controversial, with recommendations ranging from 6 to 18 months. Changes in the physical examination or imaging findings of a previously diagnosed breast mass during surveillance should prompt reevaluation and biopsy. This patient does not yet have a diagnosis of a benign breast mass; therefore, returning in 18 months (
Option C
) for repeat mammography misses the opportunity to diagnose a potential breast cancer at an early, possibly curable stage.
A surgical biopsy (
Option D

) is performed when the core needle biopsy is technically challenging because of the location of the lesion, when atypical hyperplasia is seen on core needle biopsy specimens, or when the pathology and imaging findings are discordant. This patient has no indication for a surgical biopsy currently.

objective.__html: Evaluate a breast mass in a postmenopausal woman.

references: Salzman B, Collins E, Hersh L. Common breast problems. Am Fam Physician. 2019;99:505-514.

title: Question 59

children: A 34-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a head injury. He reports worsening headache, nausea, and vomiting 90 minutes after hitting his head in a fall from the top of a 6-foot ladder.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is no scalp laceration, bruising over the mastoid processes, or fluid draining from the nares. The general neurologic examination is normal. Glasgow Coma Scale score is 15/15.
Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step in management?

Guidelines suggest a noncontrast head CT in patients with traumatic brain injury who have had no (or very brief) loss of consciousness or posttraumatic amnesia but have a focal neurologic deficit, vomiting, severe headache, physical signs of a basilar skull fracture, Glasgow Coma Scale score lower than 15, coagulopathy, or a dangerous mechanism of injury, such as ejection from a motor vehicle or a fall from a height of more than 3 feet.
This patient should have CT of the head without contrast (
Option B

). The American College of Emergency Physicians and the CDC have published guidelines for management of mild traumatic brain injury (TBI). Their recommendation is to consider a noncontrast head CT in patients with TBI who have had no (or very brief) loss of consciousness or posttraumatic amnesia but have a focal neurologic deficit, vomiting, severe headache, physical signs of a basilar skull fracture, Glasgow Coma Scale score lower than 15, coagulopathy, or a dangerous mechanism of injury, such as ejection from a motor vehicle or a fall from a height of more than 3 feet. These findings have nearly 100% sensitivity for identifying patients with clinically important findings but low specificity. This patient sustained a TBI with a dangerous mechanism of injury several hours ago and has developed symptoms (worsening headache and vomiting) mentioned in the guideline. Therefore, noncontrast CT of the head is indicated. A finding of parenchymal, subdural, or epidural hemorrhage requires emergent neurosurgical evaluation.
In the setting of acute head trauma, head CT without contrast is preferable to head CT with contrast (
Option A
) or brain MRI (
Option D

) because of its lower cost and wider availability. Contrast administration aids in the assessment of certain malignant and vascular lesions of the brain but adds nothing to the evaluation of acute head trauma. Head CT without contrast is also very sensitive for detecting skull fracture or acute hemorrhage, and a CT scan generally requires shorter examination times than a brain MRI requires, both important factors in the evaluation of a patient with acute head injury and symptoms of potential deterioration.
Biomarkers, such as levels of tau protein (
Option C

), are being studied as an aid in the diagnosis and assessment of mild TBI. Tau protein levels have been found to be significantly elevated over baseline when measured 1 hour after concussion and remain elevated for as long as symptoms persist. Measurement of tau protein and other biomarkers are not ready for clinical practice, and importantly, will not replace neuroimaging as the gold standard test to detect intracerebral bleeding.

objective.__html: Evaluate traumatic brain injury with CT of the head.

references: Silverberg ND, Iaccarino MA, Panenka WJ, et al; American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine Brain Injury Interdisciplinary Special Interest Group Mild TBI Task Force. Management of concussion and mild traumatic brain injury: a synthesis of practice guidelines. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 2020;101:382-393.

title: Question 60

children: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized for urosepsis. On admission to the hospital, his blood pressure was 92/58 mm Hg despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, intravenous fluid resuscitation, vasopressors, and ultimately glucocorticoids. His vital signs stabilize 2 days later, but he is oliguric, and his
serum creatinine
level has increased from 0.8 mg/dL (70.7 µmol/L) to 2.2 mg/dL (194.5 µmol/L). Serum electrolytes are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

text.__html: CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Measurement of serum and urine osmolality

children: In patients with acute kidney injury, pigmented (muddy brown) granular casts and tubular epithelial cells will establish the diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis.
Ultrasonography of the kidneys and bladder should be obtained for suspected bladder outlet obstruction or when the underlying cause of acute kidney injury is unclear.
The most appropriate initial test is urinalysis with microscopy (
Option D

). The diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) is based on increased levels of serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). Physical examination focuses on volume status, signs of systemic illness that might impair kidney function, and evidence of urinary obstruction (such as a palpable bladder or flank pain). Laboratory evaluation includes BUN and creatinine concentrations, electrolytes, complete blood count, and assessment of the urine (urine indices, urinalysis, and microscopic evaluation of the urine sediment). In patients with AKI, pigmented (muddy brown) granular casts and tubular epithelial cells will establish the diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and help distinguish it from prerenal azotemia (normal urinalysis or hyaline casts), antibiotic-associated interstitial nephritis (mild proteinuria, leukocytes, erythrocytes, leukocyte casts, eosinophiluria), acute glomerulonephritis (proteinuria, dysmorphic erythrocytes, erythrocyte casts), and intratubular obstruction (crystalluria or Bence-Jones proteinuria).
CT of the abdomen and pelvis (
Option A

) is unnecessary and costly, removes the patient from the ICU, and exposes the patient to unnecessary radiation. Ultrasonography of the kidneys and bladder should be obtained for suspected bladder outlet obstruction or when the underlying cause of AKI is unclear.

Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is defined as a sustained elevated intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) associated with new organ dysfunction. ACS occurs in the setting of abdominal surgery, trauma, hemoperitoneum, retroperitoneal bleed, ascites, bowel obstruction, ileus, and pancreatitis. It can also occur from capillary leak with concurrent massive fluid resuscitation. Increasing IAP causes hypoperfusion and ischemia of the intestines and other peritoneal and retroperitoneal structures, leading to hemodynamic, respiratory, neurologic, and kidney impairment. Renal vein compression and renal artery vasoconstriction cause oliguric AKI. ACS is diagnosed by measuring IAP; measurement of bladder pressure (
Option B
) with an indwelling catheter is the standard methodology. There is no compelling indication to perform IAP measurement before obtaining a urinalysis in this patient.

Ethylene glycol intoxication causes AKI from intratubular precipitation of needle-shaped calcium oxalate crystals, which can be seen on urine microscopy. Ethylene glycol should be suspected in a patient with a history of ingestion and whose laboratory studies demonstrate an increased anion gap metabolic acidosis and osmolal gap. This patient's history of urosepsis and hypotension adequately account for his AKI and his electrolytes are normal, excluding an anion gap metabolic acidosis. Measuring serum and urine osmolality (
Option C
) to calculate the osmolar gap is unnecessary.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute tubular necrosis as cause of acute kidney injury.

references: Levey AS, James MT. Acute kidney injury.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 61

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for an episode of aphasia and right-sided weakness that occurred 7 hours ago and lasted 3 hours. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia treated with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin and low-dose aspirin.

All physical examination findings, including vital signs, are unremarkable. Head CT, ECG, prolonged telemetry monitoring, and echocardiogram are all normal. CT angiogram shows 70% stenosis of the left internal carotid artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to reduce this patient's risk for stroke?
Carotid endarterectomy for critical carotid artery stenosis is highly effective in reducing the risk for recurrent stroke in the immediate poststroke period.

With symptomatic carotid stenosis, the risk for recurrent stroke is 1% per day for the first 2 weeks after a stroke or TIA; therefore, the greatest benefit of carotid endarterectomy is gained when the procedure is performed early.
This patient should be referred for urgent endarterectomy of the left internal carotid artery (
Option A

). He has had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) consisting of aphasia and right-sided weakness due to symptomatic high-grade carotid stenosis. The risk for recurrent stroke is approximately 26% over the next 2 years. Carotid endarterectomy is highly effective in reducing the risk for recurrent stroke in the immediate poststroke period. With symptomatic carotid stenosis, the risk for recurrent stroke is 1% per day for the first 2 weeks after a stroke or TIA; therefore, the greatest benefit is gained when the procedure is performed early.
Carotid stenting (
Option B

) would be inappropriate for this patient. Clinical trials have shown that for the outcomes of stroke, myocardial infarction, and death, stenting and endarterectomy are not significantly different. However, stenting poses a greater risk for perioperative stroke than does endarterectomy. Therefore, it is not recommended as a primary intervention for symptomatic carotid artery stenosis. In patients who are considered high risk for carotid endarterectomy, such as those with major cardiac comorbid conditions, stenting is an alternative.
Prasugrel (
Option C
) is a P2Y

receptor blocker used as an antiplatelet agent. Prasugrel may cause significant, sometimes fatal, bleeding. It is contraindicated in patients with active pathological bleeding or a history of TIA or stroke. Clopidogrel, another P2Y

agent, has a role in medical therapy for patients who cannot take aspirin. However, antiplatelet agents generally provide only a marginal benefit compared with surgery in reducing the risk for stroke in the acute period after a stroke or TIA caused by symptomatic high-grade carotid stenosis.

Anticoagulation in the context of acute stroke has been associated with increased mortality rates and poorer neurologic outcomes. Long-term anticoagulation with a direct-acting anticoagulant, such as rivaroxaban (
Option D

) or warfarin, is beneficial only in patients whose stroke is caused by atrial fibrillation or another source of cardiogenic embolism. Because this patient's stroke probably resulted from his high-grade carotid stenosis, treatment with rivaroxaban would not be appropriate.

objective.__html: Manage symptomatic internal carotid artery disease.

references: Amarenco P. Transient ischemic attack. N Engl J Med. 2020;382:1933-1941.

title: Question 62

children: A 79-year-old man is evaluated for a 1-week history of increasing pain in the right foot. He sustained a nonhealing laceration on the plantar surface of the great toe 1 month ago. He has no other medical problems.

Vital signs are normal. A 1- × 1-cm ulcer associated with tenderness and warmth is seen directly below the proximal first metatarsal bone. Probe-to-bone test is negative. Complete blood count is normal.
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
is 50 mm/h.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging test?
Because of its low cost and specificity, plain radiography is recommended as an initial imaging test for suspected osteomyelitis.
In patients with unremarkable plain radiographs in the presence of high clinical suspicion for osteomyelitis, MRI is the preferred imaging study.
The most appropriate imaging test is plain radiography (
Option D

). The clinical hallmarks of acute osteomyelitis, namely local pain and fever, are often absent in patients with chronic contiguous osteomyelitis, necessitating the use of radiographic studies to confirm the diagnosis. Plain radiography is not adequately sensitive to exclude a diagnosis of osteomyelitis, but it is recommended during initial evaluation if symptoms have been present for at least 2 weeks because of the relatively low cost. The specificity of plain radiography is sufficient to confirm the diagnosis in most patients. If a plain radiograph is not diagnostic, MRI, with and without intravenous contrast, is preferred.
CT (
Option A

) shows excellent anatomic detail and is the imaging study of choice for patients with osteomyelitis if MRI cannot be obtained (such as when a cardiac device or other metal hardware is present) or is inconclusive.

Nuclear imaging studies can reliably detect inflammation as a result of acute infection but are less sensitive and specific than MRI and CT because visualized abnormalities from noninfectious causes may be present, including trauma, neoplasm, and osteoarthritis. Gallium scanning (
Option B
) visualizes inflammation and chronic infection as gallium binds to the membranes of neutrophils that are recruited to a site of infection.
In patients with unremarkable plain radiographs in the presence of high clinical suspicion for osteomyelitis, MRI (
Option C

) is the preferred imaging study. MRI can show changes of acute osteomyelitis within days of infection and is superior to and more sensitive (90%) and specific (80%) than plain radiography, CT, and nuclear studies. MRI can also detect soft tissue abscesses and epidural, paravertebral, or psoas abscesses that may require surgical drainage. However, false-positive MRI results may occur in patients with noninfectious conditions, such as fractures, tumors, and healed osteomyelitis.

references: Beaman FD, von Herrmann PF, Kransdorf MJ, et al; Expert Panel on Musculoskeletal Imaging. ACR Appropriateness Criteria
suspected osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, or soft tissue infection (excluding spine and diabetic foot). J Am Coll Radiol. 2017;14:S326-S337.

title: Question 63

children: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 5-day history of insidiously progressive left knee pain worse with weight bearing and relieved with rest. She recently started training for a 5-kilometer road race. She is postmenopausal.

Physical examination reveals only medial joint line tenderness. Plain radiograph is normal; MRI reveals a subchondral hypointensity with adjacent bone marrow edema of the medial femoral condyle. No other findings are present.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Typically, patients with stress fractures present with pain on activity that is relieved with rest, and point tenderness.
Radiography is first-line diagnostic testing for stress fracture but may fail to reveal a fracture; MRI should be performed when plain films are unrevealing but clinical probability is high.
This patient has a stress fracture of the knee (
Option D

), specifically a subchondral insufficiency fracture. Stress fractures can be categorized as two types: fatigue fracture and insufficiency fracture. A fatigue fracture occurs when there is abnormal loading on normal bone (e.g., athletes with heavy cyclical weight bearing), and an insufficiency fracture occurs when there is normal loading on abnormal bone (e.g., osteoporotic bone). Typically, patients present with pain on activity that is relieved with rest, and point tenderness. The most common location for fatigue fracture is the tibia. Insufficiency fractures typically occur in the spine, sacrum, pelvis, or knee. Insufficiency fracture of the knee has previously been known as spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee, but it is now recognized that this entity likely represents subchondral microfractures. It is more common in women and associated with meniscal tears in 80% of cases. Radiography is first-line diagnostic testing but may fail to reveal a fracture. MRI has greater sensitivity; it should be performed when plain films are unrevealing but clinical probability is high. This patient is postmenopausal, putting her at risk for osteoporosis and insufficiency fracture, and MRI findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Management is usually conservative with NSAIDs or analgesics and protected weight bearing; studies indicate conflicting results for bisphosphonate therapy. Surgery may be required for severe or large lesions.
Iliotibial band syndrome (
Option A

) is characterized by diffuse, poorly localized lateral knee and distal thigh pain. Pain is initially present at the end of exercise that involves knee flexion and extension, but it may occur earlier in exercise or with rest as the condition progresses. Running outdoors or downhill may worsen symptoms. On examination, there is often tenderness approximately 2 to 3 cm proximal to the lateral femoral condyle. This patient's joint line pain and imaging study exclude iliotibial band syndrome.
Medial tibial stress syndrome (
Option B

) (shin splints) presents as pain in the mid to distal shins, usually after activity. Diffuse tenderness is often found over the affected area. Diagnosis is clinical, although imaging may be required to rule out stress fracture. Treatment includes avoidance of high-impact activities (e.g., running) and using shock-absorbing insoles. The patient's pain description, pain location, and imaging results do not support medial tibial stress syndrome.
Meniscal tears (
Option C

) usually result from an acute twisting knee injury or can develop more insidiously as a result of chronic degeneration. Symptoms include pain, locking, catching, and grinding. This patient does not have a meniscal tear on knee MRI.

references: Matcuk GR Jr, Mahanty SR, Skalski MR, et al. Stress fractures: pathophysiology, clinical presentation, imaging features, and treatment options. Emerg Radiol. 2016;23:365-75.

title: Question 64

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated for bilateral exertional leg pain that resolves within 2 minutes after resting. He also has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications are metformin, atorvastatin and lisinopril.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Diminished distal popliteal, ankle, and pedal pulses are present. There are no bruits. Resting ankle-brachial index measurements are 1.42 in both legs.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

text.__html: Segmental pressure measurements of lower extremities

children: In patients with an ABI greater than 1.40, a toe-brachial index is used for diagnosis.
Exercise ankle-brachial index testing can be useful if there is a high clinical suspicion for peripheral artery disease but normal resting ankle-brachial index measurements.
The most appropriate diagnostic test for this patient is a toe-brachial index (
Option D

). Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is typically characterized by narrowing of the aortic bifurcation and arteries of the lower extremities, including the iliac, femoral, popliteal, and tibial arteries. Atherosclerosis is the most common cause. The most commonly used diagnostic modality to identify lower extremity PAD is measurement of the resting ankle-brachial index, the ratio of lower extremity to upper extremity systolic blood pressures. In healthy persons, the ankle pressure should be the same as or slightly higher than the brachial pressure; therefore, a normal resting ABI is between 1.00 and 1.40. In the presence of atherosclerotic narrowing of the limb arteries, the downstream blood pressure and concomitant ABI value is lower. A resting ABI of 0.90 or less is diagnostic for PAD and correlates with abnormalities seen on imaging of the arterial tree. A resting ABI greater than 1.40 indicates the presence of noncompressible, calcified arteries in the lower extremities and is considered uninterpretable. This is most commonly found in patients with diabetes mellitus and/or advanced chronic kidney disease. In patients with an ABI greater than 1.40, a toe-brachial index is used for diagnosis. A toe-brachial index less than 0.70 is diagnostic for PAD.
Exercise ABI testing (
Option A

) can be useful if there is a high clinical suspicion for PAD but normal resting ABI test result. A decrease in the ABI to less than 0.90 or a relative decrease of greater than 20% measured immediately after symptom-limited exercise is diagnostic of PAD. This patient has an abnormally elevated ABI, and the most appropriate test is measurement of the toe-brachial index.
In patients with an established diagnosis of PAD and indications for revascularization, further vascular anatomic data can be obtained noninvasively by using gadolinium-enhanced MR angiography (
Option B
) or contrast-enhanced multidetector CT angiography. However, these tests should be reserved for patients who have not benefitted from medical therapy and should not be used to diagnose PAD.
Segmental pressure measurements (
Option C

) in a vascular laboratory may be used to localize diseased vessels in the lower extremities. The procedure involves pulse volume recordings (measurement of the magnitude and contour of blood pulse volume in the lower extremities) and blood pressure measurements at several locations in the lower extremities (high thigh, low thigh, calf, posterior tibial artery, and dorsalis pedis artery). Segmental pressure measurements can be a useful noninvasive method to localize vascular obstruction, but a toe-brachial index is the initial test of choice in this patient with high probability of disease but normal resting ABI measurements.

objective.__html: Diagnose peripheral artery disease with a toe-brachial index.

references: Polonsky TS, McDermott MM. Lower extremity peripheral artery disease without chronic limb-threatening ischemia: a review. JAMA. 2021;325:2188-2198.

title: Question 65

children: A 72-year-old woman is evaluated for sudden right hip “snapping” followed by pain and inability to bear weight on the right leg. She has a 7-year history of alendronate therapy for osteoporosis. A previous plain radiograph of the right hip for chronic pain showed increased cortical width in the femoral shaft.
On physical examination, the patient cannot bear weight on the right hip. There is significant pain with palpation at the proximal thigh.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hip pain?
Chronic bisphosphonate therapy can be associated with atypical subtrochanteric femoral fracture.
Increased femoral cortical width on plain radiography is a risk factor for the development of bisphosphonate-related atypical subtrochanteric femoral fracture.
This patient has most likely experienced an atypical subtrochanteric femoral fracture related to chronic bisphosphonate therapy (
Option B

). The increased femoral cortical width on the previous plain radiograph is a characteristic finding in patients who later have atypical femoral fractures. This complication is believed to occur as a result of a reduction in bone turnover and, therefore, bone repair after prolonged treatment with bisphosphonates. The abnormal bone is fragile and prone to fracture. A large, prospective cohort study identified risk factors for bisphosphonate-related atypical fractures: duration of bisphosphonate therapy greater than 3 to 5 years, older age, chronic glucocorticoid use, shorter height, and higher weight. In this group, the risk for an atypical fracture was decreased with discontinuation of bisphosphonates. In one large study, the number needed to harm during a 3-year period in order to encounter one case of atypical femoral fracture was 417, whereas the number needed to prevent a single vertebral fracture was 14 and to prevent a hip fracture was 91. Simply stated, for every atypical femoral fracture encountered, 30 vertebral fractures and five hip fractures were prevented. Although this analysis favors the use of bisphosphonates in appropriate patients, it also underscores the need for discretion in the selection of patients and supports consideration of a drug holiday in stable improved patients after 5 years of continuous bisphosphonate use.
