Gradual onset of anterior hip pain occurs with avascular necrosis (or osteonecrosis) (
Option A

), which should be considered in the presence of alcohol abuse, glucocorticoid use, systemic lupus erythematosus, or sickle cell anemia. Acute onset of pain and inability to walk is not consistent with avascular necrosis of the hip.
Osteitis pubis (
Option C

) is the result of stress applied to bone, most often the superior pubic ramus. Osteitis pubis typically occurs in athletes but can follow any type of pelvic stress, including pregnancy. Early symptoms include pubic aching and stiffness after arising from bed or after activity, but suprapubic and perineal pain eventually develop if the condition progresses.
Trochanteric fractures (
Option D

) are most commonly found in young, active adults and are often the result of forced muscular contraction against a limb that is fixed in location. Groin pain suggests lesser trochanteric and is worse with hip flexion and rotation. Pain over the greater trochanter suggests greater trochanteric fracture which increases with abduction and tenderness over the greater trochanter. The patient's age and findings are not consistent with trochanteric fracture.

objective.__html: Diagnose an atypical femoral fracture in a patient taking bisphosphonates.

references: Black DM, Geiger EJ, Eastell R, et al. Atypical femur fracture risk versus fragility fracture prevention with bisphosphonates. N Engl J Med. 2020;383:743-753.

title: Question 66

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for a 15-month history of chest pain, dyspnea, and occasional near-syncope with exertion. He has no cardiovascular risk factors and no other medical problems.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. Carotid upstroke is diminished and delayed. Cardiac examination shows a sustained apical impulse, grade 3/6 late-peaking systolic murmur, diminished S
, and an S
. Valsalva maneuver diminishes the intensity of the murmur.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Classic manifestations of severe aortic stenosis are angina, syncope, and heart failure.
Characteristic findings of severe aortic stenosis include a narrow pulse pressure; delayed and diminished carotid upstroke; sustained apical impulse; late-peaking systolic ejection murmur; and S
Classic manifestations of severe aortic stenosis (
Option B

) are angina, syncope, and heart failure. In early stages, aortic stenosis may present subtly, with dyspnea or a decrease in exercise tolerance. Approximately half of patients with aortic stenosis are diagnosed when heart failure develops. This patient has characteristic findings of severe aortic stenosis, including narrow pulse pressure; delayed and diminished carotid upstroke; sustained apical impulse; late-peaking systolic ejection murmur; and S
Aortic sclerosis (
Option A

) without stenosis is common finding in the elderly. Aortic sclerosis is asymptomatic and is discovered either on physical examination (systolic ejection murmur) or incidentally on echocardiography (aortic valve thickening without stenosis). Typical findings include a midsystolic soft and short ejection murmur heard best over the second right intercostal space. A normal carotid upstroke and normal S
exclude aortic stenosis.
Most patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) (
Option C

) are asymptomatic and have normal life expectancy, with diagnosis often resulting from evaluation of a heart murmur or abnormal ECG. Physical examination findings may be normal in patients without left ventricular outflow obstruction. The most common feature related to left ventricular outflow obstruction is a cardiac murmur, and dynamic maneuvers during examination are helpful in differentiating HCM from fixed valvular obstruction, such as aortic stenosis. HCM is associated with an ejection-quality murmur usually best heard at left lower sternal border; it generally does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Brisk carotid upstroke is present and may have two impulses for each ejection (bifid). The murmur of HCM increases in intensity of murmur during Valsalva strain phase. The murmur of aortic stenosis either does not change or is diminished during Valsalva strain phase. This patient's findings are not compatible with findings associated with HCM.
Symptoms of pulmonary arterial hypertension (
Option D

) tend to be nonspecific, including progressively worsening dyspnea, although these symptoms usually occur in the absence of or out of proportion to pulmonary disease or left-sided heart disease. Physical examination may disclose signs of elevated pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular strain (loud P
, fixed split S
, tricuspid regurgitation, jugular venous distension), which are absent in this patient.

references: Bakaeen FG, Rosengart TK, Carabello BA. Aortic stenosis.

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's anemia?

text.__html: Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells

children: A restrictive transfusion threshold (hemoglobin level <7-8 g/dL [70-80 g/L]) is recommended in common clinical settings in which blood is transfused, such as in critically ill patients in the ICU.

The restrictive transfusion threshold (hemoglobin level <7-8 g/dL [70-80 g/L]) does not apply to patients who are hemodynamically unstable or actively bleeding and should not be applied to symptomatic patients with rapidly decreasing hemoglobin concentrations.
No change in treatment (
Option D

), including transfusion, is necessary for this patient. In a randomized phase III study of euvolemic patients whose hemoglobin level decreased to less than 9 g/dL (90 g/L) within 72 hours of ICU admission, participants were assigned to a liberal transfusion group (transfusion given at hemoglobin level <10 g/dL [100 g/L]) or a restrictive transfusion group (transfusion given at hemoglobin level <7 g/dL [70 g/L]). Mortality rates were at least as good for patients in the restrictive group as for those in the liberal group. However, a subset analysis revealed that patients with ischemic heart disease had a trend toward higher mortality in the restrictive group that was not statistically significant, which suggests that patients with ischemic heart disease should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis until further data dictate otherwise. The restrictive transfusion threshold does not apply to patients who are hemodynamically unstable or actively bleeding and should not be applied to symptomatic patients with rapidly decreasing hemoglobin concentrations.

Although this patient has an elevated creatinine level, it is likely the result of sepsis and seems to be improving. As such, there is no role for an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA), such as epoetin alfa (
Option A
). Furthermore, ESAs have not been studied for this indication.

This patient has iron indices typical of anemia of inflammation (low serum iron level, low total iron-binding capacity [TIBC], low transferrin saturation [<15%; iron/total iron-binding capacity × 100], and elevated ferritin level) that are most likely the result of sepsis and not iron deficiency anemia (low serum iron level, high-normal to high TIBC, high transferrin saturation, and low ferritin level). Therefore, intravenous iron dextran (
Option B

) is not indicated. Iron dextran was the principal intravenous iron product used in the past, but because of its risk for anaphylaxis and relatively poor bioavailability, newer parenteral iron preparations with a better safety profile and better ferrokinetics are used more often. These agents include iron sucrose, ferric gluconate, ferumoxytol, and ferric carboxymaltose. Data are inadequate to recommend one newer parenteral agent over another for patients requiring parenteral iron.
The Association for the Advancement of Blood & Biotherapies recommends a restrictive erythrocyte transfusion threshold in hemodynamically stable critical care patients; erythrocyte transfusion (
Option C

) should not be performed until the hemoglobin level is 7 g/dL (70 g/L) or lower. The guideline concludes that no data suggest that a restrictive approach is harmful and that a restrictive threshold is associated with reduced blood use and related costs, as well as fewer potentially serious, although uncommon, adverse events.

objective.__html: Manage anemia in a critically ill hospitalized patient.

references: Carson JL, Guyatt G, Heddle NM, et al. Clinical practice guidelines from the AABB: red blood cell transfusion thresholds and storage. JAMA. 2016;316:2025-2035.

Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?

Secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) with high-intensity statin therapy is indicated in all patients who have clinical manifestations ASCVD: acute coronary syndrome, coronary revascularization, stroke or transient ischemic attack, or peripheral artery disease.
High-intensity statin therapy includes atorvastatin (40-80 mg/d) or rosuvastatin (20-40 mg/d).
In addition to antiplatelet therapy and lifestyle counseling, high-intensity statin therapy (
Option B

) is indicated. Secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) with high-intensity statin therapy is indicated in all patients who have clinical manifestations of ASCVD. Clinical ASCVD comprises acute coronary syndrome, coronary revascularization, stroke or transient ischemic attack, or peripheral artery disease. High-intensity statin therapy includes atorvastatin (40-80 mg/d) or rosuvastatin (20-40 mg/d). Patients should have repeat serum lipid testing performed 4 to 12 weeks after statin initiation to ensure goal LDL reduction of 50% or more. Patients at very high risk for recurrent ASCVD events should have a goal LDL cholesterol level of less than 70 mg/dL.
Ezetimibe is a second-line cholesterol-lowering agent that can be added to statin therapy (
Option A

) for patients at very high risk for ASCVD who have not achieved their LDL goal of less than 70 mg/dL with statin therapy alone. It can also be used in patients with ASCVD who are intolerant of statins despite multiple attempts. Ezetimibe plus a statin may eventually be appropriate therapy if this patient does not reach his LDL cholesterol goal of less than 70 mg/dL but is not an initial therapy.

In patients with persistently elevated triglyceride levels despite statin therapy and either established cardiovascular disease or diabetes mellitus and multiple other risk factors, the addition of icosapent ethyl (
Option C

), a highly purified fish oil, may decrease the risk of cardiovascular events. Icosapent ethyl should not replace high-intensity statin therapy in this high-risk individual, and this patient has no indication for adding icosapent ethyl to statin therapy.
According to guidelines, moderate-intensity statin therapy (
Option D
) is not the first choice for patients with recurrent clinical ASCVD due to the superior benefits of high-intensity statin therapy in this population.

title: Question 69

children: A 79-year-old woman is evaluated for intermittent periods of weakness, malaise, and subjective fever without localizing signs. Specifically, she has had no hematuria, dysuria, urgency, frequency, or suprapubic pain. She has had periods of stress urinary incontinence, but this has been unchanged for the past 5 years.
Physical examination results, including vital signs, are normal. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Urinary tract infection is diagnosed and treated the same in older adults as it is in nonelderly persons.

Urine testing should be limited to patients with specific symptoms of urinary tract infection, such as new or worsening urgency, frequency, incontinence, suprapubic or costovertebral tenderness, or hematuria, or findings of a new, serious illness consistent with sepsis.
Clinical observation (
Option D

) is the best management for this patient. Urinary tract infection (UTI) is diagnosed and treated the same in older adults as it is in nonelderly persons. However, UTI may be difficult to diagnose in older patients, who often have chronic lower urinary tract symptoms, such as difficulty voiding (men) or incontinence (women). Eliciting information on specific symptoms of UTI (dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain, flank pain, hematuria) may be difficult in older patients with dementia, delirium, or preexisting chronic urinary symptoms. Because the prevalence of asymptomatic bacteriuria increases with age, it may be inappropriately attributed as the cause of various nonspecific symptoms (fatigue, malaise, fever, confusion, delirium). Finding bacteriuria in older patients with nonspecific symptoms may lead to overdiagnosis and overtreatment, with consequences such as antibiotic resistance and antibiotic-related side effects, which may be severe. Urine testing should be limited to patients with specific symptoms of UTI, such as new or worsening urgency, frequency, incontinence, suprapubic or costovertebral tenderness, or hematuria, or findings of a new, serious illness consistent with sepsis. In the absence of specific signs of UTI, another source for the patient's symptoms should be sought.

In an older patient with specific symptoms of UTI and abnormal urinalysis findings, it would be appropriate to offer antibiotic treatment. First-line therapy is the same as in nonelderly patients and includes nitrofurantoin (5 days), trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (3 days), or fosfomycin (1 dose). Fluoroquinolones, such as levofloxacin and ciprofloxacin (
Option A

), are not considered first-line therapy for cystitis; however, fluoroquinolones and β-lactam agents (including amoxicillin-clavulanate, cefdinir, cefaclor, and cefpodoxime proxetil) are considered acceptable alternative therapies. Because this patient lacks specific symptoms of UTI, antibiotic therapy is not indicated.
Clinical trials have demonstrated that cranberry juice (
Option B
) is not effective in the treatment or prevention of UTI and is not indicated.
Because it is unlikely that this patient has a UTI, a urine culture (
Option C
) is not indicated.

objective.__html: Avoid inappropriate treatment of a urinary tract infection in an older woman.

references: Gupta K, Grigoryan L, Trautner B. Urinary tract infection.

title: Question 70

children: A 29-year-old man is reevaluated for a 6-week history of intermittent hematochezia and rectal pain that worsens after bowel movements. He has chronic constipation. Fiber supplementation has resolved the constipation. However, sitz baths and topical hydrocortisone have not resolved the rectal pain and hematochezia.
Anorectal examination reveals a posterior anal fissure but no active bleeding.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Acute anal fissures generally resolve within a few weeks with the use of sitz baths, psyllium, and bulking agents; topical anesthetics and anti-inflammatory agents can be considered to address pain or bleeding.
Rectal spasm is the major reason for anal fissures becoming chronic and should be treated with either topical calcium channel blockers or nitrates.
The most appropriate management in this patient with an acute anal fissure is use of a topical calcium channel blocker (
Option D

), such as diltiazem or nifedipine. Anal fissures are longitudinal mucosal tears in the anal canal characterized by anorectal pain worsened by bowel movements and sitting. They are common, particularly after episodes of constipation or diarrhea. Pain is the most common symptom, but hematochezia may occur, which sometimes leads to an incorrect diagnosis of complicated hemorrhoids. The disease is confirmed by the presence of a fissure on anorectal inspection; the fissure is typically located posteriorly in the anal canal. Lateral and/or multiple fissures may be seen in association with syphilis, HIV infection, and Crohn disease. Acute anal fissures generally resolve within a few weeks with the use of sitz baths, psyllium, and bulking agents. Topical anesthetics, such as lidocaine, and anti-inflammatory agents can be considered to address pain or bleeding, but their use is not required to promote fissure healing. Anal fissures lasting more than 8 to 12 weeks are considered chronic and may be characterized by edema and fibrosis, as well as a sentinel pile (appearing as a skin tag) or hypertrophied anal papilla within the anal canal. Rectal spasm is the major reason for anal fissures becoming chronic and should be treated with either topical calcium channel blockers or nitrates. Topical nitroglycerin use is limited by headaches, a common side effect. Colonoscopy is indicated when additional alarm features are present; these include age older than 45 years, altered bowel habits, anemia, inflammatory bowel disease, unexplained weight loss, and/or family history of colorectal cancer.
Internal sphincter botulinum toxin (
Option A

), delivered by injection, has been used in the treatment of chronic anal fissures unresponsive to other conservative medical treatments, including topical agents. However, conservative therapy with topical agents should be tried first.
Surgical treatment with a lateral internal sphincterotomy (
Option B

) is usually unnecessary for acute anal fissures, but there is abundant high-quality evidence that internal lateral internal sphincterotomy has the highest healing rates in patients with chronic fissures. Therefore, surgery may be recommended for a chronic fissure, even if the patient did not experience medical treatment failure.
Pelvic floor muscle training (
Option C

) is a recommended intervention for the treatment of anal incontinence that has not responded to first-line measures, such as treating diarrhea and constipation, stopping offending medications, smoking cessation, weight loss, and physical inactivity. Pelvic floor muscle training is not an effective intervention for anal fissure.

objective.__html: Treat an anal fissure with topical diltiazem.

references: Stewart DB Sr, Gaertner W, Glasgow S, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the management of anal fissures. Dis Colon Rectum. 2017;60:7-14.

title: Question 71

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-month history of worsening lower extremity edema. He has a 15-pack-year smoking history but reports no cough or sputum production.
BMI is 42. Breath sounds are diminished without wheezing. There is bilateral edema of the legs. Arterial pH is 7.36,
P
O
is 52 mm Hg (6.9 kPa), and
P
CO
is 53 mm Hg (7.0 kPa). Chest radiograph shows only reduced lung volumes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is characterized by daytime hypercapnia (arterial P
CO
>45 mm Hg [5.9 kPa]) that is thought to be a consequence of diminished ventilation related to extreme obesity.
Biventricular heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, erythrocytosis, and volume overload are common manifestations of obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
The most likely diagnosis is obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) (
Option C
). OHS is characterized by daytime hypercapnia (arterial P
CO

>45 mm Hg [5.9 kPa]) that is thought to be a consequence of diminished ventilatory drive and capacity related to extreme obesity. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is usually but not always superimposed. Biventricular heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, erythrocytosis, and volume overload are common. Weight loss is essential, and consideration can be given to bariatric surgery. Positive airway pressure therapy is indicated. Although definitive trials comparing continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) are not available, the most recent guideline recommends CPAP as initial therapy for overlapping OSA and obesity hypoventilation, though BPAP might be warranted for those without coexisting OSA. Supplemental oxygen may need to be added and reassessed at a later date.
Long-standing, severe COPD (
Option A

) may lead to carbon dioxide retention and hypercapnia. However, despite this patient's smoking history, he does not have a history or clinical picture that is consistent with a diagnosis of COPD, such as cough and sputum production.
Nonproductive cough and dyspnea are the most common presenting symptoms of a diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD) (
Option B

). Wheezes and Velcro-like crackles may be present. Chest radiography may show various findings in patients with DPLD but can be normal in patients with minimal disease. Although hypercapnia defines OHS, such a finding is unusual in DPLD until the disease reaches a very advanced stage. The combined absence of cough and hypercapnia along with the normal chest radiograph argue against the diagnosis of DPLD.
OSA (
Option D

) often coexists with OHS, and polysomnography is usually required to determine the extent of OSA and titrate positive airway pressure therapy. However, OSA alone does not account for this patient's daytime hypercapnia.

title: Question 72

children: A 46-year-old man reports a 3-day history of a pruritic red rash that appeared 1 day after using a cologne he rediscovered in a bathroom drawer. The rash seems to be getting worse. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
Physical examination reveals poorly defined, eczematous-appearing patches with a few fine vesicles on the cheeks and anterior neck.
Which of the following is the most appropriate topical treatment?

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV, T-cell–mediated, delayed hypersensitivity reaction; sensitized T-cells trigger an inflammatory cascade, leading to an eczematous eruption at the site of contact.
To minimize the risk of complications, lower-potency topical glucocorticoids should be used in intertriginous areas, and hydrocortisone base should be used on the face.
Because this patient's rash involves the face and neck, the lowest-potency glucocorticoid, hydrocortisone (
Option B

), is the safest choice. This patient likely has allergic contact dermatitis in reaction to his cologne. Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV, T-cell–mediated, delayed hypersensitivity reaction. On re-exposure to a specific allergen, sensitized T-cells trigger an inflammatory cascade, leading to an eczematous eruption at the site of contact; rarely, a widespread eruption (autoeczematization or id reaction) may occur. Irritant contact dermatitis is more common than allergic contact dermatitis and is not immune mediated. Irritant contact dermatitis occurs from direct damage to the skin from harsh chemicals, soaps, or detergents. In addition to avoidance of the causative agent and treatment with emollients several times a day, topical glucocorticoids may help with symptom resolution. Appropriate choice of a topical glucocorticoid requires consideration of both the nature of the skin disease and the anatomic site being treated. Adverse effects of topical glucocorticoids include thinning of the skin, development of striae and hypopigmentation, and, with long-term use, development of telangiectasias. Anatomic areas that are at particular risk of complications from topical glucocorticoids include the face (particularly around the eyes, where skin is very thin) and any occluded areas of skin, such as the axillae, inguinal folds, skin under pendulous breasts, and abdominal pannus. When used on the face, halogenated (mid- and high-potency) glucocorticoids can induce acne, rosacea, perioral dermatitis, and rebound dermatitis. To minimize the risk of complications, lower-potency glucocorticoids should be used in intertriginous areas, and hydrocortisone base should be used on the face. Patients should be taught to use an adequate amount of glucocorticoid to treat the affected skin and should be encouraged to use it only as long as necessary.
Betamethasone dipropionate (
Option A
) is a high-potency glucocorticoid, and its routine use on the face and in other high-risk areas is not recommended.

The characteristic clinical presentation of tinea corporis, cruris, and faciei is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation. Dermatophytosis of non-hair–bearing skin with limited involvement can be treated topically with imidazole creams, such as miconazole (
Option C
), clotrimazole, and ketoconazole. This patient does not have tinea, and miconazole is not indicated.

Pityriasis versicolor is one of the most common, chronic, superficial fungal infections and is typically found in young adults. It presents as asymptomatic, oval-to-round, minimally scaly, hyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules that can coalesce into patches on the trunk and upper extremities. Topical treatment using ketoconazole 2% shampoo or selenium sulfide suspension (
Option D

) is effective. Either treatment should be applied from the upper neck to the thighs and used to wash the scalp. This patient does not have pityriasis versicolor and treatment with selenium sulfide is not necessary.

references: Fonacier L, Bernstein DI, Pacheco K, et al; American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology. Contact dermatitis: a practice parameter-update 2015. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2015;3:S1-39.

title: Question 73

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated following a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. He is asymptomatic. He has been referred to a dietician. Medications are metformin and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 29. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Serum creatinine
is 1.0 mg/dL (88.4 µmol/L),
estimated glomerular filtration rate
is greater than 60 mL/min/1.73 m
, and microscopic and dipstick urinalysis are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate chronic kidney disease screening strategy?

text.__html: 24-Hour urine collection for protein in 5 years

children: Guidelines recommend annual testing to assess urine albumin excretion in patients with type 1 diabetes of 5 years' duration and in all patients with type 2 diabetes starting at the time of diagnosis by measuring the urine albumin-creatinine ratio.

Use of ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers delays chronic kidney disease progression in patients with proteinuric kidney disease or in patients with diabetes and moderately increased albuminuria.
A spot urine albumin-creatinine ratio (
Option D

) is indicated to evaluate this patient for chronic kidney disease (CKD). Because moderately increased albuminuria (microalbuminuria) may go undetected by dipstick, direct quantification of albuminuria and/or proteinuria using a random (spot) protein-creatinine ratio or albumin-creatinine ratio or a 24-hour urine collection is required in high-risk patients. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM), which is associated with increased risk for CKD, and testing for albuminuria is appropriate. The National Kidney Foundation and the American Diabetes Association recommend annual testing to assess urine albumin excretion in patients with type 1 DM of 5 years' duration and in all patients with type 2 DM starting at the time of diagnosis by measuring the urine albumin-creatinine ratio. Moderately increased albuminuria is defined as an albumin-creatinine ratio of 30 mg/g to 300 mg/g; diagnosis requires an elevated albumin-creatinine ratio on two of three random samples obtained over 6 months. Patients with DM and moderately increased albuminuria are at increased risk for progression of CKD and cardiovascular disease. Use of ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers delays CKD progression in patients with proteinuric kidney disease or in patients with DM and moderately increased albuminuria, underscoring the importance of early detection.
The gold standard for measuring urine protein excretion is a 24-hour urine collection (
Option A

). However, this test is cumbersome and unreliable if not collected correctly. Patients have a difficult time accurately collecting and storing urine for 24 hours. Therefore, obtaining urine ratios on random urine samples is recommended as an alternative method of estimating proteinuria in the clinical assessment of kidney disease. Furthermore, a 24-hour urine collection may not diagnose moderately increased albuminuria. Finally, screening for CKD 5 years after the diagnosis of DM is appropriate for type 1 DM but not in this patient with type 2 DM; screening should be initiated at the time of diagnosis.
Kidney ultrasonography (
Option B
) can assess kidney size, shape, blood flow, echogenicity, and cysts/tumors and can be performed after a diagnosis of CKD is made but should not be used to screen for CKD.
There is no need to measure this patient's glomerular filtration rate with cystatin C measurement (
Option C

). Cystatin C is produced by all nucleated cells, freely filtered by glomeruli, and catabolized by tubules. Compared with serum creatinine, serum cystatin C levels are less affected by age, sex, or muscle mass. Changes in serum cystatin C may identify small decreases in kidney function better than serum creatinine. Formulas using cystatin C to estimate GFR are helpful for patients in whom creatinine-based GFR may be inaccurate.

objective.__html: Screen for chronic kidney disease in a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

references: Draznin B, Aroda VR, Bakris G, et al; American Diabetes Association Professional Practice Committee. 11.

children: C

references: hronic kidney disease and risk management: standards of medical care in diabetes-2022. Diabetes Care. 2022;45:S175-S184.

title: Question 74

children: A 72-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for urosepsis. In the first hour of management, blood cultures were drawn, serum lactate measurement was obtained, empiric antibiotics were initiated, and fluid resuscitation was begun. In the first 3 hours of hospitalization, he received 3 L of 0.9% saline.
Blood pressure is 80/45 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 112/min.
Hemoglobin
level is 11 g/dL (110 g/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

In patients with septic shock, an initial bolus of 30 mL/kg of crystalloid fluid should be given in the first 3 hours of presentation when hypotension or a lactate of 4 mEq/L (4 mmol/L) or more is present.

Norepinephrine is the initial vasopressor of choice for shock due to sepsis refractory to fluid resuscitation; vasopressin can be added to norepinephrine to further raise blood pressure or reduce the dose of norepinephrine.
The most appropriate next step in management is to start vasopressor therapy with norepinephrine (
Option C

). The goals of sepsis management are to treat infection and optimize tissue perfusion. This is accomplished by starting early and appropriate antibiotic therapy and using 0.9% saline or lactated Ringer solution (preferred) to maintain an adequate preload. An initial bolus of 30 mL/kg of crystalloid fluid should be given in the first 3 hours of presentation when hypotension is present. When lactate levels are elevated more than 2 mEq/L (2 mmol/L), they should be rechecked within 2 to 4 hours to ensure improvement. If a fluid challenge does not achieve an adequate blood pressure (defined as a mean arterial pressure ≥65 mm Hg), initiation of a vasoactive agent is indicated to ensure that tissue perfusion is maintained.

Despite adequate fluid resuscitation, this patient's mean arterial pressure remains less than 65 mm Hg, and a vasopressor is indicated. Norepinephrine is the initial vasopressor of choice for shock due to sepsis. Vasopressin can be added to norepinephrine to further raise blood pressure or reduce the dose of norepinephrine.
Dopamine (
Option A

) is not recommended for use in septic shock except in select patients with clinically significant bradycardia, given its association with increased tachyarrhythmia and death compared with norepinephrine.
Erythrocyte transfusions (
Option B

) act as colloidal fluids and may be useful in resuscitation when oxygen-carrying capacity is impaired (such as with acute blood loss), but this patient's measured hemoglobin level appears adequate to maintain tissue oxygenation without erythrocyte transfusion. Transfusion threshold for packed red blood cells is usually a hemoglobin level of less than 7.0 g/dL (70 g/L). Transfusion for volume expansion in the absence of another clear indication is not appropriate.
Phenylephrine (
Option D
) can lead to decreased stroke volumes despite improvement in mean arterial pressure. For adults with septic shock, norepinephrine is recommended as the first-line agent over other vasopressors.

references: Evans L, Rhodes A, Alhazzani W, et al. Surviving sepsis campaign: international guidelines for management of sepsis and septic shock 2021. Crit Care Med. 2021;49:e1063-e1143.

title: Question 75

children: A 71-year-old woman is evaluated for irregularly pigmented, tan to brown “bumps” on the back that began to appear at the age of 65 years. The lesions are asymptomatic but occasionally itchy. She thinks some of the bumps are getting larger and darker.
Skin examination reveals multiple small plaques on her back and similar lesions on her chest and arms. A representative lesion on her back is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Seborrheic keratoses are brown, scaly, round or oval waxy papules and plaques that commonly occur in older persons.
No treatment is required for seborrheic keratoses; irritated lesions may be removed with cryotherapy or electrodessication and curettage.
This patient has seborrheic keratoses (
Option B

), which are brown, scaly, round or oval waxy papules and plaques that commonly occur in older persons. Early lesions appear as a flat, light tan macule. As the lesion matures, it assumes a darker color and thickens to form a plaque. At this stage, they frequently have a “stuck-on” appearance and often have verrucous (warty) features. On the back they may assume a “Christmas tree” pattern, following skin cleavage lines. They most commonly appear on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Seborrheic keratoses typically exhibit horn cysts (epidermal cysts filled with keratin) on the surface that can best be visualized with a magnifying lens. Although benign, they may occasionally resemble melanoma because of the presence of asymmetry, an irregular border, irregular pigmentation, large size, and progressive enlargement. Atypical lesions are often biopsied to rule out malignancy. No treatment is required; irritated lesions may be removed with cryotherapy or electrodessication and curettage. The appearance of new lesions is common, particularly with advancing age. Seborrheic keratoses are not usually associated with any other medical condition. The sign of Lester-Trélat is the sudden eruption, usually over 3 to 6 months, of numerous seborrheic keratoses, usually on an inflammatory base, and is associated with an internal malignancy.
Acrochordons (skin tags) (
Option A

) are skin-colored, pedunculated papules. They are most commonly seen on the neck and skin folds in older adults. Skin tags appear with increased frequency during the second trimester of pregnancy and may regress postpartum. Skin tags are frequently seen in patients with obesity and in patients with diabetes mellitus. This patient's skin lesions are not characteristic of skin tags.
Solar lentigines (
Option C
), more commonly known as age or liver spots, are uniform, brown, scaly, regularly shaped macules and patches that occur in sun-exposed areas, such as the face and hands, rather than the trunk.
Verruca vulgaris (warts) (
Option D
) are recognized as flesh-colored firm hyperkeratotic papules with a rough cleft surface. Multiple pigmented keratotic lesions on the trunk are not typical findings associated with warts.

references: Moscarella E, Brancaccio G, Briatico G, et al. Differential diagnosis and management on seborrheic keratosis in elderly patients. Clin Cosmet Investig Dermatol. 2021;14:395-406.

title: Question 76

children: A 36-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-day history of fever, myalgia, and dry cough. He was previously healthy, has never been hospitalized, and has not recently been prescribed antibiotics.

Temperature is 38.3 °C (100.9 °F); the remainder of the vital signs is normal. Oxygen saturation is normal with the patient breathing ambient air. Lung examination reveals crackles at the left lung base. Result of a COVID-19 test is negative. Chest radiograph shows a left lower lobe infiltrate.
Which of the following oral agents is recommended for treatment?
In healthy outpatients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and no risk factors for methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
or
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
and no comorbid conditions that would increase the likelihood of poor outcomes with CAP, the recommended agents include amoxicillin or doxycycline or macrolides (azithromycin or clarithromycin).
Amoxicillin-clavulanate or cefuroxime is recommended in combination with a macrolide or doxycycline for outpatients with community-acquired pneumonia who have comorbid conditions.
Amoxicillin (
Option A

) is the most appropriate treatment for this healthy young patient with a clinical presentation and radiographic findings consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). In 2019, the American Thoracic Society and the Infectious Diseases Society of America updated their guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of adults with CAP. In these guidelines, comorbid conditions are identified as alcohol use disorder; cancer; asplenia; diabetes mellitus; and chronic liver, kidney, lung, or heart disease. In addition, risk factors for
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
or methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
(MRSA) include recent hospitalization and use of parenteral antibiotics in the previous 90 days or respiratory isolation of
P. aeruginosa
or MRSA previously. In healthy outpatients with no risk factors for MRSA or
P. aeruginosa

and no comorbid conditions that would increase the likelihood of poor outcomes with CAP, the recommended agents include amoxicillin or doxycycline or macrolides (azithromycin or clarithromycin). Of note, macrolides no longer receive a strong recommendation for treatment because of increasing pneumococcal macrolide resistance in the United States.
Amoxicillin-clavulanate (
Option B
) or cefuroxime (
Option C

) is recommended in combination with a macrolide or doxycycline for outpatients with CAP who have comorbid conditions. These patients are at higher risk for poor outcomes if the initial regimen is ineffective and are also more likely to be at risk for infection with antibiotic-resistant organisms. Consequently, broader-spectrum coverage is recommended. Although amoxicillin-clavulanate and cefuroxime should treat typical bacterial pathogens such as
Streptococcus pneumoniae
Haemophilus influenzae,
and
Moraxella catarrhalis
, neither provides coverage for atypical pathogens, such as
Mycoplasma
or
Chlamydophila
(which are covered by macrolides or doxycycline).
Ciprofloxacin (
Option D
) has very poor activity against
S. pneumoniae

and should never be used as empiric therapy for CAP. A respiratory fluoroquinolone, such as moxifloxacin or levofloxacin, provides appropriate coverage for the likely pathogens associated with CAP but is unnecessarily broad for this indication. A respiratory fluoroquinolone would be appropriate if this patient had risk factors for infection with drug-resistant
S. pneumoniae

objective.__html: Treat community-acquired pneumonia in an outpatient.

references: Metlay JP, Waterer GW, Long AC, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of adults with community-acquired pneumonia. An official clinical practice guideline of the American Thoracic Society and Infectious Diseases Society of America. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2019;200:e45-e67.

title: Question 77

children: A 61-year-old man is evaluated during routine follow-up of type 2 diabetes. He is confused about his most recent glucose values. Log records show several fasting blood
glucose
levels ranging from 110 to 140 mg/dL (6.1-7.8 mmol/L) over the past 6 months. Despite these values, the past two
hemoglobin A
1c
values are 8.5% and 8.1%. He also has had two early-morning hypoglycemic episodes. Medications are metformin and insulin glargine.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Increase frequency of fasting blood glucose measurements

children: The most common cause of fasting blood glucose levels at target and elevated hemoglobin A
1c
measurements is elevated postprandial blood glucose levels.
The possibility of postprandial hyperglycemia should be assessed by measuring blood glucose levels 2 hours after meals several times each week.
This patient requires measurement of his 2-hour postprandial blood glucose levels (
Option D
). A common clinical scenario in diabetes management is the patient whose hemoglobin A
1c
values are suboptimal despite fasting blood glucose results suggesting good glycemic control. Several possible explanations for this phenomenon exist, including a falsely altered hemoglobin A
1c

value in the setting of hemoglobinopathy or hemolytic anemia. However, there is no reason to suspect a blood disorder in this patient. The most common cause is elevated postprandial blood glucose levels. The possibility of postprandial hyperglycemia should be assessed by measuring blood glucose levels 2 hours after meals several times each week. If elevated blood glucose levels are noted postprandially, the addition of a mealtime rapid-acting insulin analogue, such as insulin aspart, insulin lispro, or insulin glulisine, is appropriate. These insulin preparations, which have peak action within 30 to 90 minutes and duration of action of 2 to 4 hours, successfully modulate the postprandial rise in glucose.
Increasing the frequency of blood glucose measurements (
Option A

) is unlikely to add actionable information to the data already collected. There is no reason to discard the results of fasting blood glucose measurements obtained over the past 6 months; rather, postprandial blood glucose should be measured to inform treatment decisions.
Basal insulin analogues, such as insulin glargine and insulin detemir, are effective agents to control fasting glucose levels and, in most circumstances, hemoglobin A
1c
values. However, they cannot reduce postprandial glucose excursions. In addition, increasing the dosage of insulin glargine (
Option B
) may increase the incidence of overnight hypoglycemia without addressing postprandial glucose spikes.
When hemoglobinopathy or hemolytic anemia is responsible for incorrect hemoglobin A
1c
readings, another biochemical measure of long-term glucose levels, such as fructosamine or glycated albumin (
Option C
), may be used instead of hemoglobin A
1c
. Because these conditions are uncommon, measurement of the patient's serum glycated albumin is not useful as the next management step.

objective.__html: Manage discordant fasting blood glucose and hemoglobin A<sub>1c</sub> results.

references: American Diabetes Association. 9. Pharmacologic approaches to glycemic treatment: standards of medical care in diabetes-2021. Diabetes Care. 2021;44:S111-S124.

title: Question 78

children: A 50-year-old man reports heartburn and regurgitation of gastric contents several times a week for the past 3 months despite lifestyle modifications and attempts at weight loss. No other symptoms are reported. He has taken omeprazole twice daily for 2 months with minimal relief.
Other than a BMI of 29, the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease, defined as a failure to improve after 8 weeks of twice-daily proton pump inhibitor therapy, requires evaluation with upper endoscopy.

Esophageal pH monitoring is most commonly used to confirm gastroesophageal reflux disease in patients who are refractory to medical therapy when upper endoscopy does not show erosive esophagitis or Barrett esophagus.
Refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), defined as a failure to improve after 8 weeks of twice-daily proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy, requires upper endoscopy (
Option D

) to evaluate for complications of acid reflux, such as stricture, as well as alternative diagnoses, such as malignancy and eosinophilic esophagitis. Other indications for upper endoscopy in patients with GERD are dysphagia, odynophagia, weight loss, bleeding, and anemia. GERD is a highly prevalent disease, with the most common symptoms being heartburn and regurgitation. PPIs are the most effective medications in controlling heartburn, but atypical manifestations of GERD (e.g., cough, hoarseness, and chest pain) may also respond to these medications. In addition to medical treatment and surgery (e.g., laparoscopic fundoplication), new therapeutic modalities have been developed in recent years, including the placement of a titanium ring around the lower esophagus and endoluminal treatments (transoral incisionless fundoplication and radiofrequency heat delivered to the muscle of the lower esophagus and cardia).
PPIs are much more effective than histamine-2 receptor (H
) blockers such as famotidine (
Option A
) in the treatment of GERD, and substituting an H
blocker for a PPI will not improve symptoms. The addition of a daily H
blocker to maximal PPI therapy does not result in meaningful additional acid blockade.
Esophageal manometry (
Option B

) has limited value in diagnosing GERD, but it should be considered part of the evaluation for antireflux surgery to rule out motility disorders such as achalasia. The most commonly performed antireflux surgery is laparoscopic fundoplication. However, before surgery is considered, patients should undergo upper endoscopy, pH monitoring, and esophageal manometry to confirm the diagnosis.
Esophageal pH monitoring (
Option C

) is most commonly used to confirm GERD in patients who are refractory to medical therapy when upper endoscopy does not show erosive esophagitis or Barrett esophagus. If upper endoscopy is unrevealing in this patient, ambulatory pH monitoring should be considered to document acid reflux, correlate reflux with symptoms, and differentiate acid reflux from nonacid reflux.

objective.__html: Treat gastroesophageal reflux disease refractory to proton pump inhibitor therapy.

references: Maret-Ouda J, Markar SR, Lagergren J. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. JAMA. 2020;324:2565.

title: Question 79

children: A 39-year-old man is evaluated 6 hours after he awoke with left facial droop and impaired taste. Symptoms seem slightly worse compared with this morning. He has no history of previous neurologic symptoms. He takes no medications.
Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals weakness of the left upper and lower facial muscles, including the inability to close his left eye. Otherwise, the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment?

The peripheral facial nerve involvement seen in Bell palsy causes widespread facial paralysis, including paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles and an inability to close the eyes tightly or raise the eyebrows.
Early treatment of Bell palsy with oral glucocorticoids, usually a 10-day course of prednisone, increases the probability of recovery if initiated within the first 72 hours.
This patient has acute onset of Bell palsy and should receive prednisone (
Option D

). Mounting evidence implicates an inflammatory/infectious cause of Bell palsy that is most likely due to human herpesvirus 1. The peripheral facial nerve involvement seen in Bell palsy causes widespread facial paralysis, including paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles and an inability to close the eyes tightly or raise the eyebrows. Patients also report dry mouth, hyperacusis, impaired taste, and pain and numbness near the ear. Abrupt onset with building symptoms over 1 to 2 days is typical. Early treatment with oral glucocorticoids, usually a 10-day course of prednisone, increases the probability of recovery if initiated within the first 72 hours. Patients with impaired eye closure should be advised to use lubricating eyedrops/ointment and nighttime eye taping to prevent corneal damage. If ocular symptoms of pain, itching, or irritation occur, referral to an ophthalmologist is recommended.
Aspirin, and in some cases, dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel (
Option A

), may be offered if there is clinical suspicion for a stroke. This patient exhibits a peripheral pattern of facial weakness, which is not typical for stroke, and does not have any other neurologic deficits. Isolated peripheral facial palsy in this patient favors Bell palsy.
The use of antiviral agents, such as famciclovir (
Option B

), as monotherapy for Bell palsy has not been shown to be helpful. The benefit of adding antiviral treatment to prednisone is less clear, and guidelines differ in their recommendations. Although adding antiviral treatment to prednisone in patients with severe palsy may have some benefit, it is modest at best.
High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone (
Option C

), may be used to treat acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis (MS) but are not indicated in the treatment of Bell palsy. This patient is less likely to have MS, because the pattern of facial weakness is more suggestive of a peripheral process (involvement of both upper and lower facial muscles) than a central process (involvement limited to lower facial muscles).

references: George E, Richie MB, Glastonbury CM. Facial nerve palsy: clinical practice and cognitive errors. Am J Med. 2020;133:1039-1044.

title: Question 80

children: A 57-year-old man is evaluated during the winter season because of a 9-day history of cough productive of yellow-green sputum. He has also felt feverish and is fatigued. He was treated with antibiotics 1 year ago for similar symptoms. He has no other medical problems.
On physical examination, vital signs and pulmonary examination are normal. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Acute bronchitis is a self-limited inflammation of the bronchi due to upper airway infection, typically caused by a viral pathogen; it is typically associated with a cough that lasts from 2 to 3 weeks, mild dyspnea, and sputum production.
Acute bronchitis is treated with supportive care; antibiotics are not indicated.
The most appropriate management is supportive care (
Option D

). This patient has acute bronchitis, which is a self-limited inflammation of the bronchi due to upper airway infection, typically caused by a viral pathogen. Classic symptoms include cough that lasts from 2 to 3 weeks, mild dyspnea, and sputum production. Findings on examination can include wheezing or rhonchi that are extinguished after coughing. Bronchitis is treated with supportive care. Several studies have shown an absence of benefit and possible harms in treating bronchitis with antibiotics. The presence of purulent sputum cannot be considered indicative of a bacterial etiology or a favorable response to treatment in acute bronchitis. Similarly, the duration of this patient's cough (9 days) does not confirm a bacterial cause, as the typical duration of cough in viral bronchitis is 2 to 3 weeks. This contrasts with the approach in acute rhinosinusitis, in which lack of improvement after 10 days and the presence of purulent nasal discharge suggest a bacterial etiology.
Chest radiography (
Option A

) is useful in evaluating for pneumonia in patients with suggestive signs or symptoms, such as fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, rales, or signs of parenchymal consolidation. This patient's presentation is consistent with bronchitis, and no further evaluation is needed.
Antibiotic therapy with doxycycline (
Option B

) or ampicillin is warranted in ambulatory patients without significant comorbidities with signs of pneumonia (fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, crackles, or parenchymal consolidation. A macrolide such as clarithromycin or azithromycin is also appropriate if local pneumococcal resistance is less than 25%. This patient does not exhibit findings of pneumonia.
During the winter, influenza causes a self-limiting illness with fever, cough, rhinorrhea, myalgia, and headache in most patients. Treatment with an antiviral agent such as oseltamivir (
Option C

) can be considered for otherwise healthy outpatients if started within 48 hours of symptom onset. The cough associated with influenza is typically nonproductive, and the window of therapeutic opportunity for treating influenza in an otherwise healthy person has passed.

references: Smith MP, Lown M, Singh S, et al; CHEST Expert Cough Panel. Acute cough due to acute bronchitis in immunocompetent adult outpatients: CHEST Expert Panel report. Chest. 2020;157:1256-1265.

title: Question 81

children: A 67-year-old man with Parkinson disease is evaluated for an acute change in mental status. He is diaphoretic and disoriented. Medical records indicate that his only medication is carbidopa-levodopa, but he has not filled his last prescription.
The patient is disoriented and inattentive. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F), blood pressure is 170/120 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 120/min. Generalized muscular rigidity is noted.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome can result from administration of antipsychotic agents (classically neuroleptics like haloperidol), antiemetic agents (including metoclopramide), or withdrawal of antiparkinsonian dopaminergic medications.
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is characterized by muscular rigidity, altered mental status, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction (hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis).
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (
Option B

) can result from administration of antipsychotic agents (classically neuroleptics like haloperidol), antiemetic agents (including metoclopramide), or withdrawal of antiparkinsonian dopaminergic medications, as in this patient. It can occur with any antipsychotic agent, even after prolonged use, although it is more common at times of initiation or dose escalation. The pathogenesis of this syndrome results from dopamine D

-receptor antagonism. Muscular rigidity, altered mental status, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction (hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis) are typically seen. Criteria for the diagnosis of neuroleptic malignant syndrome are based on clinical features, although metabolic acidosis and elevations in serum potassium, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase levels are common. The mortality rate is 10% to 20%, although the rate is generally higher in patients who develop severe rhabdomyolysis.
Malignant hyperthermia (
Option A

) is an inherited skeletal muscle disorder characterized by a hypermetabolic state precipitated by exposure to volatile inhalational anesthetics (halothane, isoflurane, enflurane, desflurane, sevoflurane) and the depolarizing muscle relaxants succinylcholine and decamethonium. Findings include sustained muscle contractions with skeletal muscle rigidity and masseter muscle spasm, tachycardia, hypercapnia, hypertension, hyperthermia, tachypnea, and cardiac arrhythmias. This patient's history does not include exposure to drugs responsible for malignant hyperthermia, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Serotonin syndrome (
Option C

) is due to increased central nervous system serotonin activity and typically occurs within 24 hours of initiating agents that affect release or reuptake of serotonin. Distinguishing features include shivering, hyperreflexia, myoclonus, and ataxia; hyperthermia may be present. This diagnosis is less likely given the presence of muscle rigidity and the fact that the patient was not taking a serotonergic agent.
Acute intoxication with 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) (
Option D

) can mimic many of the findings of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, including psychomotor agitation, delirium, and even psychosis. Some patients develop hyponatremia, hyperthermia, and rhabdomyolysis. Muscular rigidity is not common in MDMA intoxication, and there is no reason to suspect MDMA ingestion.

references: Apetauerova D, Patel PA, Burns JD, et al. Movement disorder emergencies. Neurol Clin. 2021;39:615-630.

title: Question 82

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 10-day history of left heel pain. The pain is sharp and occurs with her first few steps in the morning.

On physical examination, BMI is 29. Palpation over the left medial tubercle of the calcaneus reveals point tenderness. Passive dorsiflexion of the toes and palpation of the medial tubercle of the calcaneus reproduce the pain.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The pain associated with plantar fasciitis is typically sharp in character and present with the first few steps taken after prolonged inactivity,
Plantar fasciitis is associated with painful palpation of the medial calcaneal tubercle and is also typically elicited with passive dorsiflexion of the toes and calcaneal palpation.
The most likely diagnosis is plantar fasciitis (
Option C

). The pain associated with plantar fasciitis is typically sharp in character and present with the first few steps taken after prolonged inactivity, such as upon awakening in the morning or after sitting for an extended period of time. Plantar fasciitis has a peak incidence between the ages of 40 and 60 years. Risk factors include obesity, pes planus, and a sedentary lifestyle. On examination, there is pain with palpation of the medial calcaneal tubercle where the plantar fascia inserts. Pain is also typically elicited with passive dorsiflexion of the toes and calcaneal palpation.
Achilles tendon rupture (
Option A

) commonly occurs during strenuous activities, although it may occur spontaneously in the elderly or with fluoroquinolone use. Patients usually have heel pain and may report hearing a “pop.” On examination, a tendon defect may be palpable; a lack of plantar flexion with calf squeezing (Thompson test) suggests complete rupture (sensitivity, 93%; specificity. This patient's heel pain is not consistent with Achilles tendon rupture.
Heel pad syndrome (
Option B

) involves localized inflammation of the soft tissues overlying the heel and is often caused by walking barefoot on hard surfaces. It presents with pain in the middle of the heel that is reproducible on examination, and atrophy of the heel fat pad may occur. Pain is not elicited with passive dorsiflexion of the toes and calcaneal palpation.
Tarsal tunnel syndrome (
Option D

) is caused by posterior tibial nerve compression as it passes through the tarsal tunnel and results in posteromedial heel paresthesias that radiate distally into the plantar foot surface. On examination, pain may be reproduced with nerve tapping (Tinel sign) and with provocative measures that compress the nerve (plantar flexion-inversion and dorsiflexion-eversion tests). This patient's findings are not compatible with tarsal tunnel syndrome.

references: Choo YJ, Park CH, Chang MC. Rearfoot disorders and conservative treatment: a narrative review. Ann Palliat Med. 2020;9:3546-3552.

title: Question 83

children: A 68-year-old man reports a 5-day history of nasal congestion, yellow nasal discharge, forehead fullness, and pain in the upper teeth, particularly when bending over. For the first 2 days of his illness, he had a temperature of up to 37.8 °C (100.0 °F).

On physical examination, temperature is 36.7 °C (98.0 °F). There is tenderness to palpation over the maxillary sinuses bilaterally and erythema of the oropharynx. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Acute rhinosinusitis is characterized by symptoms of nasal congestion and obstruction; facial pain, pressure, and fullness that generally worsen when bending forward; headache; fever; purulent nasal discharge; and maxillary tooth pain.
Initial treatment of acute rhinosinusitis is focused on symptom relief with analgesics, intranasal glucocorticoids, and nasal saline irrigation; antibiotics are not indicated.
This patient has acute rhinosinusitis and should be treated with supportive care (
Option C

). Acute rhinosinusitis is most commonly caused by viral infections; a bacterial cause is found in only a small percentage of patients. Acute rhinosinusitis is characterized by symptoms of nasal congestion and obstruction; facial pain, pressure, and fullness that generally worsen when bending forward; headache; fever; purulent nasal discharge; and maxillary tooth pain. When caused by viral infection, fever may be present within the first 24 to 48 hours of symptom onset and is often associated with other symptoms, such as myalgia and fatigue, but temperature normalizes afterward. Bacterial sinusitis is more likely if there are severe symptoms associated with a high fever for at least 3 or 4 consecutive days after onset of illness or if symptoms are persistent (lasting >10 days). Initial treatment of acute rhinosinusitis is focused on symptom relief with analgesics, intranasal glucocorticoids, and nasal saline irrigation. Oral decongestants are not effective except in cases where eustachian tube dysfunction is present. Intranasal decongestants are not efficacious, neither are oral or intranasal antihistamines.

Antibiotics are not indicated in this patient at this time. Over 90% of cases of acute sinusitis are viral in origin. Antibiotics should be reserved for patients with persistent and severe symptoms (such as high fever and marked facial pain), progressively worsening symptoms, or no improvement after 10 days of supportive care. If antibiotics are indicated, both amoxicillin-clavulanate and doxycycline would be appropriate first-line agents. Although this patient has purulent nasal discharge and fever, the acute nature of the symptoms makes antibiotics inappropriate at this time. For patients with an indication for antibiotic therapy, macrolides, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin (
Option A
), and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option D
) are associated with high rates of
Streptococcus pneumoniae
resistance and should be avoided.
Imaging with plain radiography or CT (
Option B
) is rarely needed in acute rhinosinusitis unless there is concern for a complication, such as abscess or periorbital cellulitis.

title: Question 85

children: A 67-year-old man is evaluated following screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is asymptomatic. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. Recent lung cancer screening with low-intensity CT was negative. He has no other medical problems, and kidney function is normal.
Screening abdominal ultrasound shows a 5.6-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm.
High-intensity atorvastatin is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional management?

In patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) diameter smaller than 4.0 cm, surveillance with duplex ultrasonography every 2 to 3 years is recommended, whereas in patients with AAA diameter of 4.0 to less than 5.5 cm, surveillance with CT angiography or duplex ultrasonography should be performed every 6 to 12 months.

In patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm greater than 5.5 cm, either endovascular aneurysm repair or open surgery is indicated, and the choice is driven by the location of the aneurysm among other factors.
The most appropriate next step in management is abdominal CT angiography (
Option A

). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with duplex ultrasonography in men aged 65 to 75 years who have smoked at least 100 cigarettes during their lifetime and selective screening for men in this same age group who have never smoked but are otherwise at increased risk. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force concludes that the current evidence is insufficient to assess the balance of benefits and harms of screening for AAA with ultrasonography in women aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked or have a family history of AAA. AAA is a major and treatable cause of mortality, and risk factors (e.g., male sex, smoking history, advancing age) have been well established. In patients with AAA diameter smaller than 4.0 cm, surveillance with duplex ultrasonography every 2 to 3 years is warranted. In patients with AAA diameter of 4.0 to less than 5.5 cm, surveillance with CT angiography or duplex ultrasonography should be performed every 6 to 12 months. Once the aortic diameter meets the threshold for aortic repair (≥5.5 cm), CT angiography or MR angiography is indicated to determine the exact location of the AAA (suprarenal, juxtarenal, or infrarenal) for planning repair. Statin therapy is the mainstay of pharmacotherapy for dyslipidemia and the primary and secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Patients eligible for secondary prevention therapy include those with acute coronary syndrome, history of myocardial infarction, stable or unstable angina, coronary or other arterial revascularization, stroke, transient ischemic attack, or peripheral artery disease including aortic aneurysm. High-intensity statin therapy should be initiated in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who are aged 75 years or younger to achieve a reduction in LDL cholesterol of 50% or greater.
In patients with an indication for aortic repair, the choice between endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) (
Option B
) or open surgery (
Option C

) is driven by the location of the AAA and involvement of the renal and mesenteric arteries. Suprarenal and juxtarenal aneurysms most often necessitate open surgical repair. Patient age, comorbid conditions, and ability to tolerate open surgical repair determine which procedure is performed in patients with an infrarenal AAA. EVAR is associated with lower short-term (30-day) morbidity and mortality but no significant differences in long-term mortality. Additionally, EVAR is associated with greater need for repeat intervention and significantly higher rates of endoleak, device failure, and postimplantation syndrome (fever, leukocytosis, elevated serum C-reactive protein level). Before the choice between EVAR and open surgery is made, advanced imaging is necessary to determine the exact location of the AAA and potential involvement of other vessels.
In patients with AAA diameter of 4.0 to less than 5.5 cm, surveillance with CT angiography or duplex ultrasonography should be performed every 6 to 12 months (
Option D
). However, this patient has reached the threshold for intervention, and further surveillance is not indicated.

objective.__html: Manage an abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring intervention.

references: Chaikof EL, Dalman RL, Eskandari MK, et al. The Society for Vascular Surgery practice guidelines on the care of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67:2-77.e2.

children: A 28-year-old woman has right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain of 5 hours' duration without nausea or vomiting.
Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0 °F) and pulse rate is 98/min. Palpation of the RUQ causes discomfort and inspiratory arrest. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis.
Alanine aminotransferase
and
aspartate aminotransferase
levels are 45 U/L and 50 U/L, respectively, and
serum bilirubin
level is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

text.__html: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

children: Acute cholecystitis presents with right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, fever, and positive Murphy sign (arrest of respiration on palpation of the RUQ); leukocytosis may be present, and liver chemistries and bilirubin level are often normal or minimally elevated.
Abdominal ultrasonography can establish the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis by visualization of gallbladder wall thickening and/or edema and a sonographic Murphy sign.
Abdominal ultrasonography (
Option A

) is the most appropriate next diagnostic study for this patient with likely acute cholecystitis. Clues to this diagnosis include right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, fever, and positive Murphy sign (arrest of respiration on palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory studies may show leukocytosis; liver chemistries and bilirubin are often normal or minimally elevated, unless complications such as common bile duct obstruction or cholangitis are present. Abdominal ultrasonography can establish the diagnosis by visualization of gallbladder wall thickening and/or edema and a sonographic Murphy sign.
A contrast-enhanced CT scan (
Option B

) can show gallstones, gallbladder wall thickening, gallbladder distension, pericholecystic fluid, and inflammation of the pericholecystic fat. An unenhanced CT can show gallstones and a hyperdense gallbladder wall, which can suggest the presence of gangrenous cholecystitis. However, CT is expensive and exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. It is generally reserved to resolve diagnostic dilemmas and to detect possible complications of acute cholecystitis, such as generalized peritonitis, sepsis, or bowel obstruction.
Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scanning (cholescintigraphy) (
Option C

) can be used when the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis is unclear, such as when symptoms are consistent with cholecystitis yet the ultrasound is normal. The classic finding of acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is nonvisualization of the gallbladder due to cystic duct obstruction. If the gallbladder is not visualized within 60 minutes, delayed images are obtained after 4 hours. In patients who are critically ill, morphine may be administered to increase sphincter of Oddi pressure and to reduce the likelihood of false-positive results.

Symptoms of common bile duct stones include abdominal pain and jaundice due to obstruction of bile flow. Common duct stones may be visualized by transabdominal ultrasonography. In patients who are suspected of having common duct stones but who have indeterminate findings on ultrasonography, magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) (
Option D

) or endoscopic ultrasonography should be performed. The initial diagnostic study for either acute cholecystitis or common bile duct stone is abdominal ultrasonography; MRCP is not indicated as the initial imaging test in this patient

title: Question 87

children: A 76-year-old woman is evaluated for chronic constipation. She strains to pass hard stools, and experiences longer periods between evacuations. She takes no medications. Dietary fiber and bulking agents have not been effective. Screening colonoscopy 3 years ago was normal. Thyroid function is normal.
Physical examination is normal. Plain abdominal radiograph shows stool throughout the colon.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Initial treatment of chronic constipation includes diet and lifestyle changes (adequate water intake, dietary fiber, exercise), medication review, and evaluating for underlying endocrine, metabolic, neuropathic, or mechanical causes.

Pharmacologic treatment options for chronic constipation include bulking agents (first line), osmotic laxatives (second line), stimulant laxatives (rescue if no bowel movements), secretagogues, and/or biofeedback; the evidence for treatment efficacy is strongest for polyethylene glycol and the secretagogues lubiprostone and linaclotide.
The most appropriate management is polyethylene glycol (PEG) (
Option C

). Constipation can present as infrequent, difficult, or incomplete defecation. It can be acute or chronic and either secondary or idiopathic in nature. Medications are the most common cause of secondary constipation. The history should include an assessment for the presence of alarm features: hematochezia, acute constipation in elderly patients, unintentional weight loss, family history of colorectal cancer, unexplained anemia, and age older than 50 years with no previous colonoscopy. Anorectal examination, including a digital examination during Valsalva maneuver, is an important part of the physical examination because it may identify anatomic or functional causes of an evacuation disorder. A flat plate radiograph of the abdomen is the most useful initial study because it can assess for the presence and distribution of excessive stool in the colon and/or rectum. Initial treatment includes diet and lifestyle changes (adequate water intake, dietary fiber, exercise), medication review, and evaluating for underlying endocrine, metabolic, neuropathic, or mechanical causes. Treatment options include bulking agents (first line), osmotic laxatives (second line), stimulant laxatives (rescue if no bowel movements), secretagogues, and/or biofeedback. The evidence for treatment efficacy is strongest for PEG and the secretagogues lubiprostone and linaclotide. For refractory cases of constipation, combination therapy should include agents with different mechanisms of action, such as an osmotic laxative plus a stimulant laxative.
Physiologic testing, including colon transit testing (
Option A
), anorectal manometry, balloon expulsion testing, or defecography, is reserved for patients with constipation symptoms that do not respond to initial trials of laxative therapy.
There is little evidence to support the use of docusate sodium (
Option B
) in the treatment of chronic constipation, as it is generally less effective than fiber, bulking agents, and osmotic agents like lactulose or PEG and may be no more effective than placebo.
Sorbitol (
Option D

) is a disaccharide that is effective in improving stool frequency and consistency but may cause abdominal bloating and flatulence. PEG is superior to sorbitol in improving stool frequency and consistency and is associated with fewer adverse effects. Lactulose is a disaccharide that is equally as effective as sorbitol but more expensive.

objective.__html: Treat constipation in an elderly patient.

references: Lucak S, Lunsford TN, Harris LA. Evaluation and treatment of constipation in the geriatric population. Clin Geriatr Med. 2021;37:85-102.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Chronic myeloid leukemia is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterized by translocation of the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22), Philadelphia chromosome], leading to a
BCR

In chronic-phase chronic myeloid leukemia, the leukocyte count is high, the hemoglobin level is low or normal, and the platelet count is normal or high; the peripheral blood smear shows neutrophilia and left-shifted granulopoiesis.
The most likely diagnosis is chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) (
Option A
). CML is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterized by translocation of the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22), Philadelphia chromosome], leading to a
BCR
ABL

fusion gene. This gene codes for an abnormal activated tyrosine kinase that promotes dysregulated cell proliferation, resulting in myeloid proliferation. CML consists of a chronic, an accelerated, and a blast phase. The diagnosis may be established incidentally, or patients may report symptoms including fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, abdominal discomfort, early satiety, and bleeding. On physical examination, splenomegaly is the most common finding. In chronic-phase CML, the leukocyte count is high, the hemoglobin level is low or normal, and the platelet count is normal or high. The peripheral blood smear shows neutrophilia and left-shifted granulopoiesis. Basophilia is common. An increasing proportion of blasts are seen as the disease progresses to more advanced phases.
Essential thrombocythemia (ET) (
Option B
) is suspected in patients with sustained elevation of platelet counts greater than 450,000/µL (450 × 10
/L). Diagnosis of ET requires ruling out other myeloproliferative neoplasms, such as CML, polycythemia vera, primary myelofibrosis, and myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).
JAK2
mutation is present in about 50% of patients with ET. Other clonal mutations in ET have been identified involving the calreticulin and
MPL
genes. Approximately one third of patients with ET will have splenomegaly. The presence of the
BCR-ABL
translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 establishes the diagnosis of CML.
CML must be distinguished from leukemoid reactions (
Option C

/L) and is characterized by an increase in early neutrophil precursors in the peripheral blood.
The MDSs (
Option D

) are clonal hematopoietic progenitor cell disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and a variable rate of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia. Symptoms include fatigue and easy bleeding. Infections resulting from neutropenia are a common cause of death. Laboratory studies usually reveal normocytic/macrocytic anemia and other cytopenias. This patient's significant leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and (9;22) translocation are not consistent with an MDS.
