title: Question 89

children: A 77-year-old woman is evaluated for lightheadedness when assuming an upright posture and two episodes of syncope occurring shortly after arising from bed and after prolonged sitting. She has a 7-year history of diabetic peripheral neuropathy but no other cardiac conditions.
On physical examination, seated blood pressure and pulse rate are normal. The remainder of the general examination is normal.
ECG is normal.
Which of the following diagnostic tests should be performed next?
Orthostatic blood pressure measurements should be performed in all patients with syncope.

A drop in systolic blood pressure greater than 20 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure greater than 10 mm Hg immediately after standing or after 3 minutes of upright posture is diagnostic of orthostatic hypotension.
Performing orthostatic blood pressure (BP) measurement (
Option D

) is most likely to establish the cause of this patient's syncope. Orthostatic BP measurements should be performed in all patients with syncope. This patient's syncope occurred after standing up, making this test even more important. A drop in systolic BP greater than 20 mm Hg or diastolic BP greater than 10 mm Hg on immediate standing or after 3 minutes of upright posture is diagnostic of orthostatic hypotension. This patient has diabetes mellitus with peripheral neuropathy and may also have diabetic autonomic neuropathy, which can cause orthostatic hypotension. Other neurodegenerative causes of orthostatic hypotension include amyloidosis, Parkinson disease, and multiple system atrophy. Medications that commonly cause or contribute to orthostatic hypotension include diuretics, α-blockers, antihypertensives, and antiparkinson medications.

If the cause of syncope is unclear after the initial evaluation, continuous telemetry may be useful to screen for paroxysmal arrhythmias. If symptoms are frequent, 24-hour monitoring may be used; if symptoms are infrequent, an event monitor (
Option A

) or loop recorder can be used. This patient's history is compatible with orthostatic hypotension, and orthostatic BP measurements will likely confirm the diagnosis and make further investigation unnecessary.
Cardiac imaging with CT or MRI (
Option B

) is most useful when structural or infiltrative heart disease such as amyloidosis is suspected but initial diagnostic tests are inconclusive. This patient has not been fully evaluated for the most likely cause of syncope and decisions about advanced imaging should not be considered until orthostatic BP measurements are obtained.
Neuroimaging, such as MRI (
Option C

), is of limited use in evaluating syncope. It has the highest yield in older patients who have neurologic symptoms or neurologic examination abnormalities, have head trauma, or are taking anticoagulants. This patient has symptoms and risk factors suggestive of orthostatic hypotension, and she does not have signs or symptoms of neurologic deficits or head trauma.

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated for a lower-lip tumor of 6 months' duration. He has worked all his life as a tobacco farmer in North Carolina and has a 55-pack-year smoking history.
Physical examination shows actinic keratoses over the forehead, hands, and forearms. The lip lesion is
shown

Which of the following is the next step in management?
Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma can have multiple appearances, including papules, plaques, and nodules that can ulcerate, bleed, or become crusty.
Histopathologic examination is needed to confirm the diagnosis of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and for staging and prognosis.
This patient's lesion is highly concerning for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), and excisional biopsy (
Option B

) is the next step in management. SCC is the second most common skin cancer and arises from epidermal keratinocytes. Histopathologic examination is needed to confirm the diagnosis and for staging and prognosis. This can be achieved with an excisional biopsy or with a shave or punch biopsy. Smoking is a risk factor for SCC; other risk factors include sun exposure, human papillomavirus infection, immunosuppression, fair skin or hair color, older age, history of nonmelanoma skin malignancy, and arsenic exposure. SCC can have multiple appearances, including papules, plaques, and nodules that can ulcerate, bleed, or become crusty. SCC of the nail unit commonly arises in the nail fold and appears as a hyperkeratotic papule and plaque. In lightly pigmented skin, SCC tends to occur in areas of sun exposure. In patients with darker skin, SCC more often develops on areas of chronic inflammation or scarring and more commonly on the lower extremities. High-risk factors for SCC are tumor diameter greater than 2 cm, tumor thickness greater than 2 mm, poorly differentiated subtypes, perineural invasion, and tumor location on the ear or nonglabrous lip. SCC can be locally invasive and can metastasize.
Cryotherapy (
Option A
) and topical fluorouracil (
Option C)

are used for the treatment of precancerous lesions (actinic keratoses) and occasionally SCC in situ but would not be appropriate for this patient because his lesion appears to be an invasive SCC at a high-risk site. Similarly, electrodesiccation and curettage may be used for SCC in situ and, in certain settings, low-risk well-differentiated SCCs; however, it would not be an appropriate choice for a lesion at this location, particularly before obtaining a tissue diagnosis.
Tricarboxylic acid (
Option D

) is a topical treatment for warts. Warts are usually self-limited; however, in severe cases, including those with a protracted course or in persons who are immunocompromised, destructive treatments can be used. Location of the lesions must be taken into account when selecting treatment, which can be associated with pigment change or scarring. Numerous treatments that focus on destroying infected keratinocytes are available. Common warts are not found on lips in immunocompetent patients and do not ulcerate; topical treatment with tricarboxylic acid is not correct.

Which of the following acid-base disorders is present?
Respiratory acidosis is caused by any process associated with primary retention of carbon dioxide.
For patients with primary respiratory acidosis, the predicted increase in the serum bicarbonate level is calculated as 1 mEq/L (1 mmol/L) for each 10 mm Hg (1.3 kPa) increase in Pco

title: Question 92

children: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated during a routine examination. She has never been diagnosed with colorectal cancer or adenomatous polyp. Her mother was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 54 years; there is no other history of familial polyps, colon cancer, or other cancer diagnoses. She is up to date on all routine screening examinations.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management of colorectal cancer risk in this patient?

text.__html: Low-dose aspirin now, colonoscopy at age 50 years

children: If colorectal cancer is diagnosed in a first-degree relative aged less than 60 years or two or more first-degree relatives at any age, colonoscopy should begin at age 40 years or 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative at diagnosis, whichever comes first.
The most appropriate management strategy is colonoscopy at age 40 years (
Option B

). Nonmodifiable risk factors for colorectal cancer (CRC) include age (94% of new cases of CRC occurring in adults age 45 years or older), male sex, and a personal or family history of colon adenomas or colorectal cancer. The risk doubles with a family history of CRC in a first-degree relative. Long-standing (≥8 years) colonic inflammatory bowel disease (both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis) is associated with about a 2.7-fold increased risk and is dependent on the severity and extent of bowel involvement. Adult survivors of childhood malignancy who received abdominal radiation are also at increased risk for CRC. Familial adenomatous polyposis and Lynch syndrome are associated with markedly increased risks for colorectal neoplasia and other malignancies. This patient has a nonsyndromic family history, which is also associated with increased CRC risk. If CRC is diagnosed in a first-degree relative aged less than 60 years or two or more first-degree relatives at any age, colonoscopy should begin at age 40 years or 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative at diagnosis, whichever comes first. This patient, with a first-degree relative diagnosed at age 54 years, should initiate CRC screening at age 40 years because it is the earlier of the two options. Colonoscopy should be repeated every 5 years.
There is no need to begin CRC screening now (
Option A
) at age 35 years. In this patient, 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative at diagnosis would be 44 years (
Option C
); however, the earliest date for cancer screening is at age 40 years and should be selected for this patient.
The American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) strongly recommends against the use of aspirin as a substitute for CRC screening (
Option D

). ACG and others suggest low-dose aspirin in individuals between the ages of 50 and 69 years with a cardiovascular disease risk of 10% or greater over the next 10 years, who are not at an increased risk for bleeding and who are willing to take aspirin for at least 10 years to reduce the risk of CRC.

children: A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for chronic bumps on her cheeks and facial redness that worsens in the sun, after drinking alcohol, and after a hot shower. She sometimes experiences burning and stinging but most of the time has no skin symptoms, including pruritus.
Skin findings include erythema with some telangiectasias and pink papules over the forehead, nose (including the nasolabial folds), cheeks, and chin. There are no comedones.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory condition of the pilosebaceous units with increased vascular reactivity producing facial erythema with small pink papules and usually presents in the third to sixth decades of life.
Rosacea can be distinguished from acne by the lack of comedones and from acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus by the presence of papules and involvement of the nasolabial folds.
This patient has rosacea (
Option D

), a chronic inflammatory condition of the pilosebaceous units with increased vascular reactivity. It produces facial erythema with small pink papules and usually presents in the third to sixth decades of life. Burning and stinging may be present. Erythrotelangiectatic (vascular) rosacea is persistent flushing, especially of the central face, with prominent telangiectasias. Papulopustular (inflammatory) rosacea presents with pustules and papules that, unlike those of acne, are not follicularly based. Phymatous rosacea causes bulbous thickening of the nose (rhinophyma). Ocular rosacea results in dry, gritty-feeling eyes and conjunctival injection. Alcohol, heat, sun exposure, and other triggers can cause a transient increase in facial erythema but not rosacea itself. The malar erythema of rosacea includes involvement of the nasolabial folds. This patient has classic characteristics of rosacea, including small pink facial papules, prominent telangiectasias, and heat-induced vascular flushing with involvement of the nasolabial folds.
Acne vulgaris (
Option A

) is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the pilosebaceous unit (hair follicle and sebaceous gland). Although most common during adolescence, acne can affect patients at any age. The clinical features of acne are open comedones (blackheads), closed comedones (whiteheads), inflammatory papules and pustules, and nodulocystic lesions on the face, neck, chest, shoulders, and back. The papulopustular variant of rosacea can be confused with acne, but rosacea does not present with comedonal lesions.
The rash of acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (
Option B

), typically seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, is characteristically a transient erythematous patch over the cheeks, often sparing the nasolabial folds. This patient has nasolabial fold involvement and other distinctive features of rosacea.

In addition to muscle involvement, patients with dermatomyositis usually have characteristic skin findings including heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, and Gottron sign. Other skin findings include periungual erythema, mechanic's hands, photosensitive facial erythema or photosensitive poikiloderma, and calcinosis cutis. A small percentage of patients with dermatomyositis never develop muscle involvement and present with only the typical skin findings. This is known as amyopathic dermatomyositis (
Option C

); these patients can be diagnosed with skin biopsy confirmation of dermatomyositis in the setting of at least 6 months without muscle involvement. This patient does not have the characteristic cutaneous findings of dermatomyositis, and dermatomyositis is not associated with a papular facial eruption.

references: van Zuuren EJ. Rosacea. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:1754-1764.

title: Question 94

children: An 18-year-old man is seen during a routine evaluation before starting college. He was born in the United States, is healthy, has never traveled outside of the United States, and has no risk factors for hepatitis. He has had one heterosexual contact. All immunizations are up to date. He has not had screening for infectious diseases.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening strategy?

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that screening for hepatitis C virus (HCV) be conducted in all individuals aged 18 to 79 years with anti-HCV antibody testing, followed by polymerase chain reaction testing for HCV RNA.
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that clinicians screen for HIV infection in adolescents and adults aged 15 to 65 years.
This patient should be screened for hepatitis C virus (HCV) and HIV infection (
Option C

). Major medical organizations and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend that screening for HCV be conducted in all individuals aged 18 to 79 years with anti-HCV antibody testing, followed by PCR testing for HCV RNA. Most adults need to be screened only once. Persons with continued risk for HCV infection (e.g., persons using injected drugs) should be screened periodically. There is limited information about the specific screening interval that should occur in persons who continue to be at risk for new HCV infection, and the USPSTF makes no recommendation regarding frequency. The USPSTF recommends that clinicians screen for HIV infection in adolescents and adults aged 15 to 65 years. Younger adolescents and older adults who are at increased risk of infection should also be screened. The USPSTF found insufficient evidence to determine appropriate or optimal time intervals or strategies for repeat HIV screening. Repeat screening is reasonable for persons known to be at increased risk of HIV infection.

The USPSTF recommends screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in adolescents and adults at increased risk for infection. Persons born in countries with a prevalence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) of 2% or greater account for the majority of cases of new chronic HBV infection in the United States and should be screened; HBV screening should also be offered to groups defined by clinical and behavioral characteristics in which prevalence of positive HBsAg is 2% or greater. This includes persons who have injected drugs in the past or who do so currently; men who have sex with men; persons with HIV; and sex partners, needle-sharing contacts, and household contacts of persons known to be HBsAg-positive. This patient is not at increased risk for HBV. Therefore, routine screening for HBV is not indicated (
Options A, B

The USPSTF concludes with moderate certainty that screening for HCV infection in adults aged 18 to 79 years has substantial net benefit. HCV infection is the most common chronic bloodborne pathogen in the United States and a leading cause of complications from chronic liver disease. HCV infection is associated with more deaths than the top 60 other reportable infectious diseases combined, including HIV. Direct-acting antivirals offer a cure to more than 95% of patients, but less than 10% have actually received them. The estimated prevalence of HIV infection among persons aged 13 years and older in the United States is 0.4% (0.7% in males and 0.2% in females), and data from the CDC show a significant increase in HIV diagnoses starting at age 15 years. Therefore, this 18-year-old man be screened for both HCV and HIV, not HCV alone (
Option D

objective.__html: Screen a patient for hepatitis C and HIV infection.

references: Owens DK, Davidson KW, Krist AH, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for hepatitis C virus infection in adolescents and adults: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2020;323:970-975.

title: Question 95

children: A 69-year-old man is evaluated because of worsening cancer–related bone pain. He has metastatic prostate cancer. His pain management regimen consists of ibuprofen and immediate-release morphine every 6 hours, but he experiences breakthrough pain 4 hours after dosing. The pain interferes with sleep and has diminished his quality of life. He has no symptoms of cord compression.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

text.__html: Increase immediate-release morphine to every 4 hours
Switch to immediate-release hydrocodone every 4 hours
Switch to sustained-release morphine twice daily

children: When adding a sustained-release opioid, a strategy to avoid overmedication is to give a starting dose of 30% to 50% of the patient's average 24-hour opioid dosage.
The dose of the opioid for breakthrough pain is calculated as 10% of the total daily opioid dosage given as an immediate-release opioid.
The most appropriate pain management strategy for this patient is sustained-release morphine (
Option D

). Pain control is a common issue in terminally ill patients. NSAIDs and acetaminophen are effective first-line strategies for mild to moderate cancer pain, although dose limits exist for both. When these medications no longer provide sufficient control or if moderate to severe pain is present, adding as-needed short-acting, immediate-release (IR) opioid therapy is appropriate. This patient has moderate pain that returns before his next scheduled dose of IR opioid therapy and requires four doses per day continuously. He would benefit from use of a sustained-release (SR) opioid. An appropriate solution would be SR morphine twice daily. A breakthrough pain strategy should be available so that the patient has options if the SR medication does not provide complete relief. When adding an SR opioid, a strategy to avoid overmedication is to give a starting dose of 30% to 50% of the patient's average 24-hour opioid dosage. The dose of the opioid for breakthrough pain is calculated as 10% of the total daily opioid dosage given as an IR opioid. Titration is more easily achieved if both SR and IR medications are the same drug.
Gabapentin or pregabalin (
Option A

) can be useful in treating neuropathic pain and is used in postoperative patients and patients with cancer pain as an opioid-sparing strategy. This practice is supported by only modest-quality data, which are often extrapolated from studies of other pain syndromes. Adverse effects of gabapentinoids include dizziness, disequilibrium, somnolence, weight gain, peripheral edema, and cognitive difficulties. In 2019, the FDA issued a warning that gabapentinoids may cause serious breathing difficulties in patients with respiratory risk factors, including opioid use and COPD.
Increasing the frequency of the IR medication (
Option B

) is not the best answer because of the patient's need for frequent doses, given the recurrent bouts of pain. The goal of palliative therapy for pain is to relieve the patient of significant pain for most of the day, which will result in the infrequent need for additional doses of IR pain medication.
Switching the medication from one IR drug to another (
Option C
) is also unlikely to make the patient more comfortable.

objective.__html: Treat moderate to severe cancer-related pain with sustained-release morphine.

references: Alexander K, Goldberg J, Korc-Grodzicki B. Palliative care and symptom management in older patients with cancer. Clin Geriatr Med. 2016;32:45-62.

title: Question 96

children: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated for 15 hours of anterior crushing chest pain.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg and pulse rate is 100/min. The skin is warm. Mentation is normal. ECG shows 2-mm ST-segment elevation (leads V
-V
) and 1-mm ST-segment depression (leads II and III). Troponin I is elevated. Emergent cardiac catheterization shows complete occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

text.__html: Emergency coronary artery bypass grafting surgery

children: Percutaneous coronary intervention is the preferred reperfusion strategy in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction and symptoms of less than 12 hours' duration.

In late-presenting ST-elevation myocardial infarction (more than 12 hours), primary percutaneous coronary intervention for reperfusion is recommended if the patient has continuing symptoms or if hemodynamic or electrical instability is present.
This patient should undergo primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) (
Option D

). PCI is the preferred reperfusion strategy in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and symptoms of less than 12 hours' duration. She is being evaluated 15 hours after STEMI onset, with clinical (chest pain) and ECG evidence (ST-segment elevation) of ongoing ischemia. In late-presenting STEMI, primary PCI for reperfusion is recommended if the patient has continuing symptoms or if hemodynamic or electrical instability is present.
Emergency coronary artery bypass grafting surgery (
Option A

) is not a routine method of revascularization in patients with STEMI. Urgent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery or mechanical circulatory support is indicated in patients with STEMI and coronary anatomy not amenable to PCI who have high-risk features, such as refractory ischemia or cardiogenic shock. Logistical issues include performing cardiac catheterization, having access to an operating room, assembling a surgical team, and performing surgery within the time frame needed to salvage the greatest amount of myocardium.

Cardiogenic shock is a common complication of STEMI. It typically results from a large anterior myocardial infarction due to severely reduced left ventricular systolic function. Patients with cardiogenic shock, particularly those younger than 75 years, have a higher rate of survival if they receive emergent revascularization. In these cases, an intra-aortic balloon pump (
Option B

) or left ventricular assist device may be implanted temporarily, although limited data support their benefits in cardiogenic shock. Low blood pressure alone should not be considered diagnostic of end-organ hypoperfusion. Instead, blood pressure should be considered in the context of other physical examination findings that may suggest end-organ hypoperfusion (cool clammy skin, altered mentation, low urine output). This patient has no indication for intra-aortic balloon pump.
Intravenous thrombolytic therapy (
Option C

) has no clear benefit for patients with STEMI more than 12 hours from symptom onset. Patients best suited for thrombolytic therapy are those who present early after symptom onset and with low bleeding risk; however, PCI is always preferred if the patient is in a PCI-capable facility and the procedure is performed as soon as possible or if the patient can be transferred from an index hospital to a PCI-capable center quickly (time from first medical contact to primary PCI of 120 minutes or less).

objective.__html: Treat ST-elevation myocardial infarction with percutaneous coronary intervention.

references: Levine GN, Bates ER, Blankenship JC, et al. 2015 ACC/AHA/SCAI focused update on primary percutaneous coronary intervention for patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction: an update of the 2011 ACCF/AHA/SCAI guideline for percutaneous coronary intervention and the 2013 ACCF/AHA guideline for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines and the Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions. Circulation. 2016;133:1135-47.

title: Question 97

children: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-month history of easy bruising and menorrhagia. She has had recent onset of weekly tension headaches treated with over-the-counter medications but no other problems. At the ages of 19 and 21 years, she had two uneventful vaginal deliveries.
Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count, prothrombin time, and activated partial thromboplastin time.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

Several over-the-counter medications, such as aspirin, NSAIDs, and herbal supplements, have been implicated in qualitative platelet defects, which often present with increased bleeding or exacerbation of an underlying minor bleeding problem.
In this patient with new-onset easy bruising and menorrhagia, over-the-counter medication use (
Option B

) should be carefully assessed before extensive testing begins. Several over-the-counter medications, such as aspirin, NSAIDs, and herbal supplements, have been implicated in qualitative platelet defects, which often present with increased bleeding or exacerbation of an underlying minor bleeding problem. These medications may also interfere with laboratory testing, such as platelet function testing, so it is necessary to elicit an accurate medication history.
Platelet function can be assessed by various laboratory tests. A platelet function analyzer may be used as an initial screening test, replacing the traditional bleeding time (
Option A

). The test is run on a citrated blood sample exposed to collagen and either epinephrine or adenosine diphosphate. It is a sensitive test for von Willebrand disease (vWD) and will detect abnormalities caused by antiplatelet medications. Platelet aggregation tests are very sensitive and are affected by various drugs and supplements; therefore, aggregation tests should not precede a review of over-the-counter medications.
Thromboelastography (
Option C

) and rotational thromboelastometry are bedside devices that analyze platelet function, coagulation, and clot stability and may be useful as screening tests in patients with unexplained bleeding. However, a careful medication review may reveal the cause of this patient's excess bleeding.

vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Type 1 vWD, which is the mildest and most common type, usually begins at an early age and presents with mild bleeding symptoms, such as nosebleeds, easy bruising, and menorrhagia. Prothrombin time may be elevated or normal. It is not uncommon for children with mild symptoms not to be diagnosed with vWD. Therefore, it is reasonable to screen for vWD (
Option D

) in adult patients with suggestive symptoms but only after a review of over-the-counter medication–related qualitative platelet disorders. This patient's two previous uneventful vaginal deliveries argue against vWD.

objective.__html: Diagnose qualitative platelet disorder related to medication use.

references: Mohan G, Malayala SV, Mehta P, et al. A comprehensive review of congenital platelet disorders, thrombocytopenias and thrombocytopathies. Cureus. 2020;12:e11275.

title: Question 98

children: A 48-year-old woman is seen in the office for a routine wellness evaluation. She is asymptomatic. She eats a heart-healthy diet and drinks one or two alcoholic beverages each week. She does not exercise, drink coffee, smoke cigarettes, or take vitamins or supplements. Her 10-year risk for atherosclerotic heart disease is 1.7%.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. BMI is 25. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following should be recommended to reduce this patient's risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease?

text.__html: 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise weekly

children: Adults should engage in at least 150 minutes per week of accumulated moderate-intensity activity or 75 minutes per week of vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity (or an equivalent combination of moderate and vigorous activity) to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk.

The 2019 American Heart Association (AHA)/American College of Cardiology (ACC) guideline on the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease recommends that adults be routinely counseled during health care visits to optimize a physically active lifestyle. Adults should engage in at least 150 minutes per week of accumulated moderate-intensity activity (
Option D

) or 75 minutes per week of vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity (or an equivalent combination of moderate and vigorous activity) to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk.

Dietary guidelines recommend 3 cups of dairy (milk or foods made from milk) products daily. Consumption of dairy products may reduce the risk of total mortality, heart disease, stroke, and colorectal cancer. The patient should not be advised to eliminate dairy products from her diet (
Option A

Three to five cups of coffee daily may decrease the incidence of uterine cancer and hepatocellular carcinoma but has no impact on the incidence of cardiovascular disease. Advising the patient to engage in moderate physical activity will be more beneficial in reducing the risk of ASCVD than increasing coffee consumption (
Option B

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends low-dose aspirin for the primary prevention of ASCVD and colorectal cancer in willing adults aged 50 to 59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk of 10% or higher (using the Pooled Cohort Equation risk calculator). ACC/AHA guidelines recommend that aspirin should be used infrequently in the routine primary prevention of ASCVD because of lack of net benefit; specifically, low-dose aspirin may be considered for primary prevention of ASCVD in adults aged 40 to 70 years who are at higher ASCVD risk but not at increased bleeding risk. This patient does not have an indication for aspirin therapy (
Option C

objective.__html: Reduce the risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease with exercise.

references: Arnett DK, Blumenthal RS, Albert MA, et al. 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines. Circulation. 2019;140:e596-e646.

title: Question 99

children: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 2-week history of nonradiating right hip pain; symptoms worsen with walking or prolonged standing. She is able to point with one finger to the area of tenderness.
On physical examination, the right hip has full, painless range of motion. There is tenderness to palpation over the lateral hip. Straight leg raise test is negative; reflexes are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Greater trochanteric pain syndrome is the most common cause of lateral hip pain.

Patients with greater trochanteric pain syndrome describe pain over the lateral aspect of the hip when lying on their side, bending to the side, and with prolonged sitting; the most common examination finding is tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter.
This patient with lateral hip pain most likely has greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) (
Option A

). Evaluation of hip pain should be guided by location of the pain. GTPS is the most common cause of lateral hip pain. This syndrome comprises several soft tissue diagnoses, including trochanteric bursitis, hip abductor (gluteus minimus and/or maximus) tendinopathy, and external coxa saltans (snapping hip due to iliotibial tract or other tendons sliding over greater trochanter). Two or more of these diagnoses may coexist. Patients describe pain over the lateral aspect of the hip when lying on their side, bending to the side, and with prolonged sitting; pain may also radiate to the buttock or knee. The most common examination finding is tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter. Treatment is usually conservative, using heat, NSAIDs, stretching, physical therapy, and, if necessary, glucocorticoid injections.
Meralgia paresthetica (
Option C

) is characterized by distal anterolateral thigh paresthesia associated with tight-fitting clothes or obesity. Symptoms follow the distribution of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, and sensory deficits may be present. Patients report more numbness than pain.
Anterior hip pain can be caused by both intra- and extra-articular conditions. In older patients, pain that starts insidiously and worsens with standing and activity suggests osteoarthritis (
Option D
). The same pain characteristics in a younger person raise concern for a labral tear (
Option B

) if accompanied by painful clicking or catching. In both conditions, examination will reveal pain with both passive and active hip movement and/or pain or restricted range of motion with internal rotation or the FADIR (Flexion, ADduction, and Internal Rotation) test. This patient with lateral hip pain and a normal hip joint examination more likely has greater trochanter pain syndrome.

references: Pianka MA, Serino J, DeFroda SF, et al. Greater trochanteric pain syndrome: Evaluation and management of a wide spectrum of pathology. SAGE Open Med. 2021;9:20503121211022582.

title: Question 100

children: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for heat intolerance, tremor, palpitations, and anxiety at 7 weeks' gestation of an otherwise uncomplicated pregnancy.
On physical examination, pulse rate is 108/min. Fine resting tremor, brisk reflexes, and diffusely enlarged thyroid with bruit are present.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is below 0.008 µU/mL (0.008 mU/L),
free thyroxine
level is 5.5 ng/dL (80.0 pmol/L), and
total triiodothyronine
level is 400 ng/dL (6.2 nmol/L). Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin level is elevated.
Metoprolol is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Treatment of hyperthyroidism during pregnancy is typically with medical management; propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during the first trimester.
Radioactive iodine is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may cause destruction of the fetal thyroid.

This patient has overt hyperthyroidism (low serum thyroid-stimulating hormone with elevated free thyroxine and total triiodothyronine levels) occurring during the first trimester of pregnancy and should be treated with propylthiouracil (PTU) (
Option C

). Based on this patient's age, sex, and clinical findings (diffuse thyromegaly, thyroid bruit, and elevated thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin), the most likely cause of her hyperthyroidism is Graves disease. Treatment is typically with medical management. PTU, rather than methimazole, is the drug of choice during the first trimester. Although rare, methimazole has been associated with fetal development of aplasia cutis (absence of a portion of skin on the scalp in a localized or widespread area) and choanal atresia (blockage of the posterior nasal passage due to failed recanalization of the nasal fossae during fetal development) when used in the first trimester. Once organogenesis is complete, methimazole can be substituted for PTU. However, switching between antithyroid drugs in the middle of pregnancy may precipitate decompensation of control and thus must be carried out cautiously.
Methimazole (
Option A

) is typically the preferred agent in nonpregnant patients with hyperthyroidism because it has a longer intrathyroidal half-life than PTU and usually can be administered once daily. There is also an increased risk for severe liver toxicity with PTU. Regardless of the antithyroid drug used, the lowest effective dosage should be administered during pregnancy to prevent fetal hypothyroidism.
Guidelines do not recommend routine potassium iodide solution (
Option B

) for the primary treatment of pregnant women with Graves disease. Although iodine appears to be safe for the fetus, it is less effective than thionamides, such as PTU or methimazole, in controlling hyperthyroidism. Iodine may have a role in patients who cannot tolerate thionamide therapy.
Radioactive iodine (
Option D
) is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may cause destruction of the fetal thyroid.

references: Alexander EK, Pearce EN, Brent GA, et al. 2017 Guidelines of the American Thyroid Association for the diagnosis and management of thyroid disease during pregnancy and the postpartum. Thyroid. 2017;27:315-389.

children: A 59-year-old woman undergoes follow-up evaluation for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications are losartan, atorvastatin, and metformin.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg; the remainder of the examination is normal.
Laboratory studies:

24 mEq/L (24 mmol/L)

400 mg/g

35 mL/min/1.73 m
Which of the following treatments is most appropriate to slow the progression of chronic kidney disease in this patient?

In patients with diabetic kidney disease, guidelines recommend considering the use of a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor in those with an estimated glomerular filtration rate >30 mL/min/1.73 m
and a urine albumin-creatinine ratio >30 mg/g (particularly >300 mg/g) to reduce the risk for chronic kidney disease progression and cardiovascular events.
Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists, such as liraglutide, reduce the risk for chronic kidney disease progression and cardiovascular events.
This patient with diabetic kidney disease should be started on a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor such as canagliflozin (
Option A

). Diabetic kidney disease, defined as clinical evidence of kidney injury in response to chronic, long-standing hyperglycemia, has a 10% incidence over 25 years among patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) and a 12% incidence over 25 years among patients with type 2 DM. In patients with diabetic kidney disease, guidelines recommend considering the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor in those with an estimated glomerular filtration rate >30 mL/min/1.73 m

and a urine albumin-creatinine ratio >30 mg/g (particularly >300 mg/g) to reduce the risk for chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression and cardiovascular events. SGLT2 inhibitors reduce renal tubular glucose reabsorption, weight, systemic blood pressure, intraglomerular pressure, and albuminuria as well as slow CKD progression through mechanisms that appear independent of glycemic control. A glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist, such as liraglutide, will also reduce the risk for CKD progression and cardiovascular events.
Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs), such as epoetin (
Option B

), should not be used for most patients with chronic kidney disease and a hemoglobin level higher than 11 g/dL (110 g/L) because of an increased risk for serious cardiovascular events and strokes. In appropriately selected patients, ESAs result in modest improvements in fatigue but not slowing of CKD progression.
This patient does not require any modifications to her blood pressure regimen, such as with lisinopril (
Option C

). Guidelines recommend that patients with hypertension and diabetic kidney disease, particularly with proteinuria, be treated with either an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) to a goal blood pressure of <130/80 mm Hg, which this patient is achieving with losartan (an ARB). Furthermore, combining any two renin-angiotensin system drug classes (ACE inhibitor, ARB, or direct renin inhibitors) is not recommended, as adverse effects have been shown to be increased, including hyperkalemia and elevated serum creatinine; there is no evidence of additional clinical benefit from this combination strategy.

Large observational studies have shown a strong association between lower serum bicarbonate levels and increased progression of CKD and mortality. Meta-analysis of randomized trials of alkali therapy, most commonly sodium bicarbonate (
Option D
) or sodium citrate, support delayed progression of CKD. This patient has a normal serum bicarbonate level and treatment with sodium bicarbonate is not indicated.

objective.__html: Treat diabetic kidney disease with sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor.

title: Question 102

children: A 48-year-old man is evaluated following a recent hospitalization for hypertriglyceridemia-related acute pancreatitis. Evaluation for acquired hypertriglyceridemia is negative. He consumes a very-low-fat diet and avoids refined carbohydrates and alcohol. Medications are simvastatin and an omega-3 fatty acid supplement.
On physical examination, BMI is 25. Bilateral xanthelasmas are present. Fasting
triglyceride
level is 630 mg/dL (7.12 mmol/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Patients with persistent fasting severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides ≥500 mg/dL) are at risk for acute pancreatitis.

Patients with persistent triglycerides ≥500 mg/dL despite addressing contributing comorbidities and lifestyle modification should be considered for fibrate therapy with the goal of reducing triglycerides to <500 mg/dL to reduce the risk for pancreatitis.
The most appropriate treatment is fibrate therapy with fenofibrate (
Option D

). Patients with persistent fasting severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides ≥500 mg/dL) are at risk for acute pancreatitis. Those with a previous history of pancreatitis are at even higher risk. Patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia should make dietary modifications, including initiating a very-low-fat diet, avoiding refined carbohydrates and alcohol, and consuming omega-3 fatty acids. Contributing comorbidities, such as diabetes mellitus, obesity, hypothyroidism, and nephrotic syndrome, should also be addressed. If patients have persistent triglycerides of 500 mg/dL or more despite these interventions, fibrate therapy should be considered, with the goal of reducing triglycerides to less than 500 mg/dL to reduce the risk for pancreatitis. Fibrates can reduce triglycerides by 30% to 50% and could help this patient achieve a goal triglyceride level of less than 500 mg/dL.
Bempedoic acid (
Option A

) is an oral adenosine triphosphate-citrate lyase inhibitor that lowers LDL cholesterol. Bempedoic acid has been approved for use as a single agent or in a fixed-dose combination with ezetimibe and maximally tolerated statin therapy in adults with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who require additional lowering of LDL cholesterol. Bempedoic acid is not indicated for the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia.
Cholestyramine (
Option B

) is a bile acid sequestrant that can be used to lower LDL cholesterol. It may be considered in patients who are taking maximally tolerated doses of a statin and ezetimibe but whose LDL cholesterol level has not reached the desired goal reduction. Bile acid sequestrants raise triglycerides and should be avoided in this patient.
Ezetimibe (
Option C

) and the PCSK9 inhibitors are the preferred nonstatin drugs for high-risk patients who do not achieve goal LDL cholesterol reduction. Ezetimibe can be added to maximally tolerated statin therapy. Ezetimibe will not be as effective in reducing triglycerides as fenofibrate.

Circulation. 2019;139:e1046-e1081.

title: Question 103

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for a nonpruritic rash on the face that has been present for several years but is progressively worsening.
Skin examination reveals greasy, yellow, scaly, erythematous patches in seborrheic areas of the face, including the eyebrows, medial aspects of the cheeks, inter-eyebrow region, and nasal ala.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
Seborrhea can be treated with over-the-counter selenium sulfide or zinc pyrithione shampoos; ketoconazole shampoo and topical ketoconazole cream are also very effective.
Oral ketoconazole is contraindicated as a treatment for seborrheic dermatitis because of the risk for liver toxicity.
This patient should be treated with ketoconazole cream (
Option A

). Scaling and redness, specifically on the eyebrows, nasolabial folds, and sides of the chin, are characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis. Seborrhea is thought to be an overreaction of the body to commensal
Malassezia

yeasts that live on the skin. Men are more frequently affected than are women. The rash on the face is very common, especially in the elderly, in immunosuppressed patients (particularly in patients with HIV infection or organ transplantation), and in patients with neurologic disorders such as Parkinson disease. Patients may believe that their skin findings are due to dry skin on the face. However, the redness of the eyebrows and nasolabial folds, often extending onto the cheeks and chin with scaling, is typical of seborrhea and often does not respond to moisturization only. Seborrhea can be treated with over-the-counter selenium sulfide or zinc pyrithione shampoos that are lathered into the skin and allowed to work for a few minutes and then washed out. Ketoconazole shampoo and topical ketoconazole cream are also very effective.
Metronidazole (
Option B
) is used to treat rosacea, which usually presents with flushing and central facial erythema, telangiectasias, papules, and pustules but not typically with scaling.
Oral ketoconazole (
Option C
) is contraindicated for the treatment for seborrheic dermatitis because of the risk for liver toxicity. There are safer, effective topical treatments.
Topical immunomodulators, such as tacrolimus ointment (
Option D

) and pimecrolimus cream, can be used in place of topical glucocorticoids for an extended period of time without the development of atrophy or striae. These medications have a black box warning for the rare development of skin cancer and cutaneous lymphoma. Topical immunomodulators are not indicated for seborrheic dermatitis.

references: Shamloul G, Khachemoune A. An updated review of the sebaceous gland and its role in health and diseases Part 2: Pathophysiological clinical disorders of sebaceous glands. Dermatol Ther. 2021;34:e14862.

title: Question 104

children: An 84-year-old man hospitalized for diverticulitis is evaluated for acute right knee pain. He has never experienced this symptom before.
On physical examination, temperature is normal. The right knee is swollen, warm, tender, and erythematous. Arthrocentesis is performed. Synovial fluid analysis shows a
leukocyte count
/L) and intracellular positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. Gram stain is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (pseudogout) typically presents as monoarticular inflammatory arthritis, usually in a knee or wrist; intracellular positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals are consistent with a diagnosis of pseudogout.

Treatment of acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease is directed exclusively toward relieving the inflammation; an intra-articular glucocorticoid is usually recommended as first-line therapy if the joint is amenable to injection.
Administration of intra-articular triamcinolone (
Option C

) is appropriate for this patient. Acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease (pseudogout) typically presents as a monoarticular inflammatory arthritis, characterized by sudden onset of swelling, pain, loss of function, tenderness, and warmth of the affected joint, usually a knee or wrist. Similar to acute gout, flares may be provoked by systemic insults such as major surgery or acute illness. Flares are usually milder than those of gout but can persist for months if untreated. This patient has intracellular positively birefringent (blue when parallel to and yellow when perpendicular to the polarizing axis of an optical filter) rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals, consistent with a diagnosis of pseudogout. If present on radiographs, linear calcium deposits in the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) would also support the diagnosis of pseudogout. Treatment is directed exclusively toward relieving the inflammation with agents such as NSAIDs, colchicine, and glucocorticoids and is tailored to the individual patient. Initial therapy with an intra-articular glucocorticoid (after aspiration confirms no infection is present) is usually recommended as first-line therapy if the joint is amenable to injection.
Acetaminophen (
Option A
) is generally safe in older patients, but it is not an effective anti-inflammatory drug and cannot be recommended for acute CPPD disease.
Hydroxychloroquine (
Option B

) has been suggested in some guidelines as a treatment for patients with chronic CPPD not responding to first-line treatment. Hydroxychloroquine can also be combined with colchicine or NSAIDs. Maximum therapeutic effectiveness of hydroxychloroquine may take up to 6 months and would not be practical for treatment of acute CPPD disease.
Administration of a tapering dose of prednisone (
Option D

) could be effective in treating this patient's pseudogout flare but would be less desirable than an intra-articular glucocorticoid. Oral prednisone is more likely to cause systemic adverse effects, such as hyperglycemia, infection, and hypertension. It would be particularly worrisome in this patient being treated for acute diverticulitis.

objective.__html: Treat acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (pseudogout).

references: Rosenthal AK, Ryan LM. Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. N Engl J Med. 2016;374:2575-84.

title: Question 105

children: A 23-year-old woman reports 2 weeks of nasal congestion, sneezing, and rhinorrhea without fever. Her symptoms recur seasonally, typically in April. These symptoms may also be associated with bilateral itchy eyes. She is taking an oral decongestant.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Nose examination reveals pale nasal mucosa and clear mucoid discharge. Other examination findings are normal.
Which of the following is the most effective initial treatment?
Allergic rhinitis should be suspected if rhinitis symptoms (sneezing, congestion, rhinorrhea) are associated with a season, environment, or exposure.
Guidelines recommend intranasal glucocorticoid monotherapy as first-line treatment for seasonal allergic rhinitis.
This patient has allergic rhinitis, for which intranasal glucocorticoids (
Option B

) are the most effective therapy. Allergic rhinitis should be suspected if rhinitis symptoms (sneezing, congestion, rhinorrhea) are associated with a season, environment, or exposure. A thorough history focusing on symptom triggers is necessary for diagnosis. Allergic rhinitis is typically a clinical diagnosis, and additional testing for specific allergens (with blood or skin testing) is not necessary for making the presumptive diagnosis and initiating treatment. Studies have shown that intranasal glucocorticoids are superior to both intranasal and oral antihistamines (
Options A, C

) for relief of sneezing and nasal obstruction. A clinical practice guideline issued by the 2017 Joint Task Force on Practice Parameters, which consists of representatives of the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology and the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology, recommends intranasal glucocorticoid monotherapy as first-line treatment for seasonal allergic rhinitis (strong recommendation) in preference to a leukotriene inhibitor (
Option D

). The Joint Task Force additionally makes a weak recommendation that patients with moderate to severe symptoms may be treated initially with combination therapy with an intranasal glucocorticoid and intranasal antihistamine.

Some intranasal glucocorticoid preparations (e.g., fluticasone) may also relieve ocular symptoms, such as itching and tearing. Epistaxis is the most common adverse effect of intranasal glucocorticoids and occurs in approximately 10% of patients; however, it usually is not severe enough to warrant discontinuation of the drug. The rare side effect of nasal septal perforation can be avoided by using proper spray technique.

references: Wallace DV, Dykewicz MS, Oppenheimer J, et al. Pharmacologic treatment of seasonal allergic rhinitis: synopsis of guidance from the 2017 joint task force on practice parameters.

title: Question 106

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated after undergoing partial left mastectomy and postoperative radiation therapy for intermediate-grade ductal carcinoma in situ. The tumor is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive. She is premenopausal. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Other than a well-healed left breast surgical incision, the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional therapy?

text.__html: Doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel

children: In premenopausal women with low-risk invasive breast cancer who do not require adjuvant chemotherapy, tamoxifen for at least 5 years, and preferably 10 years, is recommended.
Aromatase inhibition with an agent such as anastrozole is a superior adjuvant endocrine therapy in postmenopausal women younger than 60 years who have estrogen receptor–positive breast cancer.
The most appropriate treatment is tamoxifen (
Option C

). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. Tamoxifen is used as adjuvant endocrine therapy in selected women with breast cancer who have hormone receptor–positive tumors. Patients with hormone receptor–positive breast cancers should receive tamoxifen for at least 5 years. In premenopausal women with low-risk invasive breast cancer who do not require adjuvant chemotherapy, tamoxifen for at least 5 years, and preferably 10 years, is recommended. This premenopausal woman has intermediate-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), which is classified as stage 0 (noninvasive) breast cancer. Initial treatment is lumpectomy, often followed by breast irradiation; mastectomy may be recommended if the DCIS cannot be fully removed by wide excisional lumpectomy. Because her DCIS is estrogen receptor (ER) positive, adjuvant endocrine therapy with tamoxifen for 5 years is recommended to decrease risk for local recurrence and contralateral breast cancer.
Aromatase inhibition with anastrozole (
Option A

) is a superior adjuvant endocrine therapy in postmenopausal women younger than 60 years who have ER-positive breast cancer, but it would not be recommended in this premenopausal woman. Concerns exist that reduced feedback of estrogen to the hypothalamus and pituitary will stimulate gonadotropin secretion and lead to an increase in ovarian androgen substrate and aromatase production, which would stimulate growth of hormonally responsive cancers. Patients who become postmenopausal while taking tamoxifen may be changed to an aromatase inhibitor.
Because DCIS is noninvasive and, by definition, is confined to the ductal system of the breast, chemotherapy (
Option B
) provides no benefit.
Adjuvant chemotherapy combined with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2
(HER2
)-targeted treatment with the monoclonal antibody trastuzumab is recommended for
HER2
-positive cancers that are greater than 5 mm in size, node positive, or both. However, there is no indication to test for the
HER2
receptor or use
HER2
-directed therapy in DCIS (
Option D

objective.__html: Treat estrogen and progesterone receptor–positive ductal carcinoma in situ.

title: Question 107

children: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office because she wants to quit smoking. She started smoking casually at age 17 years and now smokes one to two packs of cigarettes per day. She has a history of bulimia managed by cognitive behavioral therapy and is currently in remission. She is taking no medications.
Behavioral modification counseling is provided.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
As a single agent, varenicline is the most effective pharmacologic agent for smoking cessation.

Varenicline is not more effective than combination nicotine replacement therapy with short-acting and long-acting nicotine replacement products; varenicline plus nicotine replacement may be the most effective therapy.
Varenicline (
Option D

) is most likely to give this patient the greatest chance of success in quitting smoking. In addition to counseling and behavioral resources, all smokers without contraindications should receive at least one of seven FDA-approved treatments for smoking cessation. Long-acting preparations include varenicline, bupropion, and the nicotine patch. Four formulations of rapid-onset, short-acting nicotine replacement therapies (lozenge, gum, inhaler, spray) are also available. Varenicline is superior to single forms of nicotine replacement therapy and bupropion. Moderate- and high-dose preparations of nicotine replacement therapy are more effective than lower-dose ones, and combining more than one type of nicotine replacement therapy (rapid-onset and long-acting) is more effective than nicotine monotherapy. Initiation of therapy before smoking is stopped may also increase quitting success rates.
Varenicline is more effective than bupropion (
Option A
). Additionally, bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a seizure disorder and in patients with a history of an eating disorder such as anorexia/bulimia.
Varenicline is more effective than all forms of rapid-onset, short-acting nicotine replacement therapy, such as nicotine oral spray (
Option B
) and the long-acting nicotine patch (
Option C

) when used as single agents. Varenicline is not more effective than combination nicotine replacement therapy, such as the combination of a rapid-onset nicotine replacement product (e.g., nicotine spray or inhaler) with a long-duration nicotine replacement product (nicotine patch).

references: Leone FT, Zhang Y, Evers-Casey S, et al. Initiating pharmacologic treatment in tobacco-dependent adults. an official American Thoracic Society clinical practice guideline. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2020;202:e5-e31.

title: Question 108

children: A 52-year-old man is evaluated for an incidentally discovered pulmonary nodule on a chest radiograph obtained for minor trauma to the chest wall. He is otherwise asymptomatic and has no risk factors for lung cancer. Chest radiograph 10 years ago was normal.
CT reveals a 5-mm solid nodule with a smooth, well-defined border in the peripheral right lung.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Fleischner Society guidelines recommend that nodules smaller than 6 mm in a patient at low risk for lung cancer do not require follow-up evaluation; in patients at higher risk, repeat CT may be considered (optional) in 12 months.
This patient requires no follow-up (
Option D

) for the pulmonary nodule. Nodules measuring 8 mm or less in diameter are less likely than larger nodules to be malignant, are not reliably characterized by PET, and are difficult to biopsy. Benign nodules are more likely to be solid in appearance with well-defined, smooth borders. Nodules smaller than 6 mm in a patient at low risk for lung cancer do not require follow-up evaluation; in patients at higher risk, repeat CT may be considered (optional) in 12 months. The patient has a solitary pulmonary nodule of 5 mm in diameter and is at low risk for lung cancer. Therefore, no follow-up is appropriate.
Fleischner Society guidelines recommend that nodules 6 to 8 mm in size be followed by repeat CT in 6 to 12 months (
Option A
). This patient with a 5-mm nodule has no indication for repeat CT in 6 to 12 months.
PET functional imaging (
Option B

) is usually normal in a subcentimeter pulmonary nodule, even if the nodule is malignant. PET is reserved for characterization of larger nodules with a low to moderate probability of malignancy; a negative PET scan of these nodules supports continued surveillance rather than biopsy.
Transthoracic needle biopsy (
Option C

) is indicated for evaluation of an enlarging or suspicious-appearing peripheral nodule (spiculated or lobular border, intense uptake on PET scan, diameter >1 cm). Biopsy is not warranted in this patient with a low pretest probability of cancer and a nodule smaller than 8 mm.

references: MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for management of incidental pulmonary nodules detected on CT images: from the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. 2017;284:228-43.

children: A 72-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of a painful rash on her face. The rash was preceded by burning, stinging, and tingling followed by an eruption of small vesicles.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The rash consists of small vesicles containing clear fluid on an erythematous base in a dermatomal distribution that involves the right forehead, extending over the upper eyelid and down to the tip of the nose.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

When herpes zoster involves the V1 distribution of the fifth cranial nerve or extends to the tip of the nose, concurrent management with an ophthalmologist is indicated to help prevent or treat ocular complications.
Treatment of herpes zoster ophthalmicus typically involves an antiviral agent (acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir), urgent ophthalmologic evaluation, and topical glucocorticoid eye drops.
The most appropriate next step in management is administration of an antiviral agent, such as valacyclovir, and urgent ophthalmologic evaluation (
Option D

). This patient has a vesicular eruption in the V1 distribution of the fifth cranial nerve, which is typical of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. Lesions may be found on the nose, eyelid, and forehead and may result in ophthalmologic complications, such as keratitis, scleritis, uveitis, and acute retinal necrosis. When grouped vesicles on an erythematous base involve the V1 distribution or extend to the tip of the nose, concurrent management with an ophthalmologist is indicated to help prevent or treat these complications. Management of these patients usually involves antiviral therapy and topical glucocorticoid eye drops to reduce inflammation.

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir) speeds recovery and decreases the severity and duration of neuropathic pain if begun within 72 hours of herpes zoster onset. Intravenous acyclovir should be used for immunosuppressed or hospitalized patients and those with neurologic involvement. In this patient with involvement of the V1 distribution of the fifth cranial nerve, antiviral treatment with acyclovir (
Option A
) or famciclovir (
Option B
) without ophthalmologic evaluation would be insufficient.

All adults aged 50 years or older, including those with a previous episode of zoster, should receive the recombinant (inactivated) herpes zoster vaccine to reduce the incidence of zoster and postherpetic neuralgia. Patients aged 19 to 49 years who are immunocompromised because of disease or therapy should also be vaccinated. The timing of vaccine administration after an episode of herpes zoster is debated. The CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices states that there is no specific amount of time but does advise waiting until the rash has resolved. Other experts recommend deferring vaccination for 1 year after an episode in immunocompetent patients, because the cellular immune response is already primed by the recent episode of herpes zoster. Administration of the recombinant herpes zoster vaccine (
Option D
) at this time without antiviral therapy or ophthalmologic consultation would be inappropriate management.

title: Question 110

children: A 37-year-old man is evaluated because of daily pressure-like headaches, insomnia, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. He recently stopped attending his softball league games. He drinks a maximum of one to two beers nightly, unchanged for the past year, and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. He reports no other symptoms and takes no medications.
Physical examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends brief screening for depression in all adults by using a validated instrument such as the Patient Health Questionnaire-2.

If a patient has a positive screening test with the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 or if the patient has symptoms suggestive of depression, more comprehensive assessment using a validated screening tool is recommended.
Depression assessment (
Option B

) should be performed. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends brief screening for depression in all adults by using a validated instrument, such as the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-2. If the patient answers positively to one of the two questions on the PHQ-2 or if the patient has symptoms suggestive of depression, more comprehensive assessment using a validated screening tool, such as the PHQ-9, should be performed. The PHQ-9 has robust sensitivity and specificity for detecting (or excluding) depression and assessing the severity of depression, if present. The PHQ-9 additionally includes questions intended to screen for suicidal ideation. This patient has insomnia, decreased energy, decreased concentration, and loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities; these are all symptoms of depression that should be evaluated further.

The USPSTF recommends routine screening for unhealthy alcohol use. Recommended screening tools include the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), the abbreviated AUDIT-Consumption (AUDIT-C), and the single-question screen “How many times in the past year have you had five [four for women and adults older than age 65 years] or more drinks in 1 day?” Patients with a positive screening result should be assessed for the presence of an alcohol use disorder (
Option A

), the severity of the disorder, and related health consequences. This patient has no evidence of risky drinking on initial screening (less than 14 drinks per week and less than 4 drinks per day in the last year), and assessment for alcohol use disorder is not necessary.
First-line pharmacologic therapy for depression includes second-generation antidepressants such as fluoxetine (
Option C
). However, pharmacologic treatment for depression is premature because a diagnosis has not been established yet.
Melatonin (
Option D

) may be effective for circadian rhythm disruptions affecting sleep and has a low side-effect profile. Although melatonin is often recommended, especially to older adults owing to the lower risk for side effects, there is insufficient evidence to support its use. However, this patient's insomnia, in combination with reported changes in energy level and concentration, suggest that his sleep-related symptoms may represent undiagnosed depression, and screening and treating depression is preferred to treating a symptom of depression.

references: Park LT, Zarate CA Jr. Depression in the primary care setting. N Engl J Med. 2019;380:559-568.

title: Question 111

children: A 69-year-old man undergoes follow-up evaluation. He has stable but incapacitating angina and is being optimally treated with aspirin, metoprolol, atorvastatin, once-daily extended-release isosorbide mononitrate, and as-needed sublingual nitrate. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin and liraglutide.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg and pulse rate is 60/min. Coronary angiography reveals multivessel disease with involvement of the proximal left anterior descending artery;
left ventricular ejection fraction
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Increase isosorbide mononitrate to twice daily

children: Coronary artery bypass grafting surgery is recommended for patients who remain symptomatic despite optimal medical therapy and have either left main disease or multivessel disease with involvement of the proximal left anterior descending artery, concomitant reduced systolic function, or diabetes mellitus.
A nitrate-free interval of 8 to 12 hours, generally at night, is needed to avoid nitrate tolerance and reduced efficacy.
The most appropriate management of this patient is coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery (
Option B
). He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and multivessel coronary artery disease with severe symptoms despite optimal medical therapy. Compared with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) (
Option D

), performing CABG surgery as the initial revascularization strategy in patients with a clear indication is associated with improved outcomes, including reduced rates of death, myocardial infarction, and stroke. The FREEDOM trial evaluating management of multivessel coronary artery disease in patients with diabetes mellitus showed that the composite end point of death, myocardial infarction, and stroke was significantly lower in patients treated with CABG versus PCI. This difference was driven by a statistically significant reduction in the occurrence of death and myocardial infarction in patients undergoing CABG surgery, although stroke rates were higher in the CABG group than the PCI group. CABG is recommended for patients who have left main disease, triple vessel disease, and reduced systolic function, or multivessel disease with involvement of the proximal left anterior descending artery in the presence of diabetes.

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a reasonable second-line therapy in patients who are intolerant of β-blockers or who have continued symptoms on β-blockers and nitrates. However, it would not be appropriate to switch to a nifedipine (
Option A)

in this patient who currently tolerates β-blocker therapy. Furthermore, short-acting dihydropyridine formulations, such as short-acting nifedipine, should be avoided because they can paradoxically worsen angina by acutely lowering blood pressure, resulting in reflex tachycardia and increased myocardial oxygen demand. Nondihydropyridine CCBs should not be used in patients with left ventricular dysfunction, owing to the increased adverse events associated with their negative chronotropic and inotropic effects.

Nitrates improve myocardial oxygen delivery through coronary vasodilation and reduce oxygen demand by reducing preload, thereby reducing ventricular wall stress. The beneficial effects may be offset by reflex tachycardia unless combined with β-blockers or CCBs. Short-acting sublingual nitrates should be prescribed for acute relief of angina. Long-acting nitrates, including isosorbide mononitrate (
Option C

), provide constant vasodilation. A nitrate-free interval of 8 to 12 hours, generally at night, is needed to avoid nitrate tolerance and reduced efficacy. Increasing the patient's isosorbide mononitrate to twice daily will result in tolerance and worsening angina.

objective.__html: Treat stable angina pectoris with coronary artery bypass grafting.

title: Question 112

children: A 19-year-old man is evaluated for an itchy, scaly eruption on the back of his neck of 2 months' duration. Last week, he self-treated with over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream; this seemed to reduce the itching and inflammation, but the rash expanded, and a new area of involvement appeared on the posterior neck. He has no other symptoms.
The rash is

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The characteristic finding of tinea infection is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation; patients can experience pruritus, burning, or no sensation at all.
A definitive diagnosis of tinea is made with a potassium hydroxide scraping of the scale showing branching hyphae.
This patient has a superficial dermatophyte infection of the skin known as tinea corporis (
Option D

). The characteristic finding of tinea infection is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation. Patients can experience pruritus, burning, or no sensation at all. A definitive diagnosis is made with a potassium hydroxide scraping of the scale showing branching hyphae. Appropriate treatment is topical antifungal agents. This patient used an over-the-counter topical glucocorticoid and temporarily reduced the inflammation, which made his skin feel less irritated. Despite the impression of improvement, however, these agents do not treat the underlying condition and can delay diagnosis.
Early localized Lyme disease often presents with erythema migrans (
Option A

), an annular red skin lesion that often has central clearing. It typically is asymptomatic, but some patients report burning. The most common locations are the axilla, inguinal region, popliteal fossa, and belt line. Erythema migrans is not associated with scale and will not respond to topical glucocorticoids.
The skin findings of nummular dermatitis (
Option B

) are eruptions of extremely pruritic, well-demarcated, round eczematous patches that usually occur on the lower extremities. The lesions can be acutely inflamed and start to weep. Diagnosis can be confirmed by skin biopsy if there is doubt. Early lesions of tinea corporis can mimic nummular dermatitis, but this patient has developed a scale on the lesion, making nummular dermatitis unlikely.
Subcutaneous lupus erythematosus (
Option C

) appears as one of two variants: annular and polycyclic photosensitive macules and plaques on the back, chest, and extremities, or psoriasiform scaly plaques in a similar distribution. Subcutaneous lupus erythematosus may be idiopathic, occur in association with systemic lupus erythematosus, or be drug related. The decrease in inflammation in response to topical glucocorticoid and the presence of scale and central clearing are more suggestive of tinea corporis.

title: Question 113

children: A 32-year-old woman with an established diagnosis of primary hypothyroidism is evaluated during the fourth week of her first pregnancy. She is asymptomatic. Her only medications are levothyroxine, 125 µg/d, and prenatal vitamins with folic acid.
Physical examination findings are normal. Serum
thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is 4.2 µU/mL (4.2 mU/L), and
free thyroxine
level is 1.6 ng/dL (20.6 pmol/L).
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Increase the levothyroxine dosage by 10% now
Increase the levothyroxine dosage by 30% now
Increase the levothyroxine dosage by 50% in the second trimester

children: During pregnancy, the levothyroxine dosage is typically increased in the first trimester, with a possible total increase of 30% to 50%.
During pregnancy, thyroid-stimulating hormone levels should be maintained in the lower half of the trimester-specific reference range, or less than 2.5 µU/mL (2.5 mU/L).
This patient's levothyroxine dosage should be increased by 30% now (
Option B

), and the thyroid function tests should be repeated in 2 to 4 weeks. Pregnancy is known to increase levothyroxine requirements in most patients receiving thyroid replacement therapy, and this expected increase should be anticipated by increasing her levothyroxine dosage. The levothyroxine dosage is typically increased in the first (and sometimes in the second) trimester of pregnancy, with a possible total increase of 30% to 50%. During pregnancy, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels should be maintained in the lower half of the trimester-specific reference range, or less than 2.5 µU/mL (2.5 mU/L) if trimester-specific reference ranges are unavailable. In contrast, the upper range of normal for nonpregnant patients is approximately 4.5 to 5.0 µU/mL (4.5-5.0 mU/L).
Increasing the levothyroxine dosage by only 10% (
Option A
) will be insufficient; an increase in 30% to 50% is required to maintain the TSH level in the lower half of the trimester-specific reference range.
Increasing the thyroxine level by 50% in the second semester (
Option C

) will result in maternal hypothyroidism during the first trimester and places the fetus at substantial risk. The fetus is dependent on transplacental transfer of maternal thyroid hormones during the first 12 weeks of gestation. The presence of maternal subclinical or overt hypothyroidism may be associated with subsequent fetal neurocognitive impairment, increased risk for premature birth, low birth weight, increased miscarriage rate, and even an increased risk for fetal death. In pregnant women with hypothyroidism, thyroid function testing should be frequent, preferably every 4 weeks, to protect the health of mother and fetus and to avoid pregnancy complications. When serum TSH values are inappropriately elevated, the dosage of levothyroxine is increased, and free thyroxine and TSH levels are monitored every 2 to 4 weeks.
Continuing the current levothyroxine dosage (
Option D

) is inappropriate in this patient because her TSH level is already too high at 4.2 µU/mL (4.2 mU/L) and requirements for thyroxine will continue to increase during the first and possibly the second trimester.

references: Alexander EK, Pearce EN, Brent GA, et al. 2017 guidelines of the American Thyroid Association for the diagnosis and management of thyroid disease during pregnancy and the postpartum. Thyroid. 2017;27:315-389.

Physical examination is normal. There is no evidence of lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. Repeat blood count today confirms the presence of the original findings.

level is 13.5 g/dL (135 g/L).

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is diagnosed by an absolute increase in mature lymphocytes (>5000/µL) sustained for 3 months and demonstration of clonality of the circulating B-lymphocytes by flow cytometry.
Bone marrow biopsy is not required for the diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
The most appropriate next step in the diagnostic evaluation of this patient is flow cytometry of the peripheral blood (
Option B

). His clinical picture is consistent with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), which is diagnosed by an absolute increase in mature lymphocytes (>5000/µL) sustained for 3 months and demonstration of clonality of the circulating B-lymphocytes by flow cytometry. Immunophenotyping will show a monoclonal proliferation of mature B-lymphocytes expressing CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. CLL is the most common leukemia, and its incidence increases with age. Most patients are asymptomatic, with early-stage disease discovered incidentally during routine laboratory testing. The natural history of CLL is highly variable, and multiple prognostic models are used, including clinical signs and symptoms, β

-microglobulin level, heavy gene mutational status, and cytogenetic studies to assess risk for progression. Flow cytometry is the most appropriate next diagnostic step. This patient most likely has Rai stage 0 disease (lymphocytosis without lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or other organomegaly).
Bone marrow biopsy (
Option A
