) is not required to diagnose CLL; flow cytometry of a peripheral blood sample is adequate. Bone marrow biopsy can be helpful when a patient has cytopenia and the cause is unclear.

Patients with infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein-Barr virus infection present with fever, severe fatigue, exudative pharyngitis, cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Atypical lymphocytosis and aminotransferase level elevations are clues to the diagnosis, which is established by the presence of heterophile antibodies. This patient's age, the persistence of lymphocytosis for 3 months, and the presence of smudge cells on the peripheral blood smear exclude the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis and the need for heterophile antibody testing (
Option C
). Smudge cells are lymphocytes that appear flattened or smudged on the peripheral blood smear, a finding that is characteristic of CLL.
PET using fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) can be used to identify suspicious lymph nodes in many lymphomas (
Option D

). However, CLL and small cell lymphomas are not FDG avid, and PET scanning is not indicated. Similarly, chest, abdominal, and pelvic CT is unlikely to provide additional prognostic information for this patient with early disease and a normal clinical examination. The American Society of Hematology recommends against routine CT in asymptomatic patients with early-stage CLL.

references: Hallek M, Cheson BD, Catovsky D, et al. iwCLL guidelines for diagnosis, indications for treatment, response assessment, and supportive management of CLL. Blood. 2018;131:2745-2760.

title: Question 115

children: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless right heel ulcer of 1 week's duration. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes. Her only medication is metformin. She has no risk factors for methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus.

She is afebrile. There is a 1.5-cm rim of erythema around a shallow 3 × 4-mm ulceration; no drainage or exposed bone is seen. Pedal and ankle pulses are diminished but present bilaterally. Radiograph shows no foreign body or osteomyelitis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy?
Following debridement of overlying callous or necrotic tissue as necessary, diabetic foot infections should be classified according to severity and extent.

Mild diabetic foot infections involve only skin and subcutaneous tissue, with erythema confined to 2 cm beyond the ulcer and can be treated with a short course (7-14 days) of oral antibiotics, such as cephalexin, clindamycin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or dicloxacillin.
The most appropriate antibiotic treatment is oral cephalexin (
Option A

). Following debridement of overlying callous or necrotic tissue as necessary, diabetic foot infections should be classified according to severity and extent. Mild infections involve only skin and subcutaneous tissue, with erythema confined to 2 cm beyond the ulcer. Moderate infections extend deeper than subcutaneous tissue (e.g., abscess, fasciitis, and osteomyelitis), or the erythema is more extensive. Severe infections are associated with systemic signs such as fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, leukocytosis, and hypotension or metabolic complications such as acidosis, worsening kidney function, and hyperglycemia. The affected foot or limb should also be assessed for arterial ischemia, venous insufficiency, neuropathy, and biomechanical abnormalities such as Charcot arthropathy or hammer toe. Evidence of critical ischemia may be considered a proxy for severe infection. Uninfected wounds should not be cultured or treated with antibiotics. Mild infections, such as present in this patient, are typically caused by aerobic staphylococci (non–methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
[MRSA]) and streptococci and can be empirically treated with a short course (7-14 days) of oral antibiotics, such as cephalexin, clindamycin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or dicloxacillin.

For mild infections with pus or MRSA risk factors, wound cultures should be obtained by curettage or biopsy of deep tissue before initiating antibiotics. Doxycycline or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can also be used with a β-lactam antibiotic. This patient has a nonpurulent infection without MRSA risk factors, and neither doxycycline (
Option B
) nor trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option D
) is indicated.

For moderate and severe infections, polymicrobial coverage of staphylococci (including MRSA), streptococci, aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes is recommended. Following deep-tissue culture, initial antibiotic regimens include β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations such as piperacillin-tazobactam (
Option C

), carbapenems, or metronidazole plus a fluoroquinolone or third-generation cephalosporin in addition to an anti-MRSA agent (vancomycin, daptomycin, linezolid). Antibiotic choices are guided by culture results. Moderate to severe infections are usually treated with a longer course of antibiotics (2-4 weeks); if osteomyelitis is present, approximately 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy is administered after surgical debridement.

references: Armstrong DG, Boulton AJM, Bus SA. Diabetic foot ulcers and their recurrence. N Engl J Med. 2017;376:2367-2375.

title: Question 116

children: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for hand dermatitis. The rash is pruritic and involves both hands. He works as a veterinarian assistant, and the rash improves when he goes on vacation. Topical hydrocortisone alleviates the rash but only temporarily.
Physical examination shows scaling and erythematous patches on the dorsal hands, fingers, fingertips, and wrists without vesicles, bullae, or erosions. The feet show no changes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The hands are a common site for allergic contact dermatitis, especially in health care workers.
In acute allergic contact dermatitis, the skin is red, edematous, weepy, and crusted, with possible vesicles or bullae; chronic exposure results in chronic eczema.
Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) (
Option A

) is the most likely cause of this patient's hand dermatitis. ACD is a type IV or delayed hypersensitivity reaction caused by allergen-specific T lymphocytes. The first reaction to an allergen may occur several weeks after exposure, but subsequent reactions usually develop within 24 to 48 hours of re-exposure. Reactions often become more intense with repeated exposure. ACD is usually intensely itchy. In acute reactions, the skin is red, edematous, weepy, and crusted, with possible vesicles or bullae. Chronic exposure results in chronic eczema. The hands are a common site for ACD, especially in health care workers. Exposure history and pattern of the rash may provide clues as to the causal allergen. Epicutaneous patch testing is the gold standard for diagnosis of ACD and should be performed to evaluate recurrent or recalcitrant dermatitis. Patch testing is performed by applying multiple standardized chemicals on small discs to the patient's back, typically over three visits within a 1-week period. Patients should diligently avoid any identified allergens. Acutely, topical glucocorticoids are used for pruritus and inflammation. Systemic glucocorticoids may be used for severe cases for 2 to 3 weeks but should not be a long-term therapy.
Porphyria cutanea tarda (
Option B

) presents with increased skin fragility noted on sun-exposed areas, most frequently on the dorsal hands. Small vesicles rupture, leaving erosions. As the disease progresses, hyperpigmentation of skin and hypertrichosis of the forehead/temples are commonly seen. This patient's findings do not resemble the changes of porphyria cutanea tarda.
Scabies (
Sarcoptes scabiei
) infestation (
Option C

) is characterized by intensely pruritic, crusted papules, nodules, and burrows that develop in the interdigital spaces, wrists, ankles, breasts, periumbilical area, and genitals. In older adults, immunocompromised persons, or patients with Down syndrome, highly contagious crusted (Norwegian) scabies occurs with extensive thick concrete-like scale. The patient does not have findings consistent with scabies infestation.
Tinea manuum (
Option D

) presents as dry patches with peripheral scaling primarily on the palms and web spaces; nail involvement is common. Involvement of one hand is most common, and tinea is typically also present on the feet (one hand–two feet disease), findings that are not present in this patient.

objective.__html: Diagnose allergic contact dermatitis as the cause of hand dermatitis.

references: Chan CX, Zug KA. Diagnosis and management of dermatitis, including atopic, contact, and hand eczemas. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:611-26.

title: Question 117

children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine visit. She has Sjögren syndrome. Her medications are ibuprofen for joint pain and omeprazole.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is tenderness of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. Parotid enlargement is noted.
Laboratory studies:
Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL (79.6 µmol/L)
Sodium
138 mEq/L (138 mmol/L)
Potassium
3.1 mEq/L (3.1 mmol/L)
L
Chloride
118 mEq/L (118 mmol/L)
H
Bicarbonate
12 mEq/L (12 mmol/L)
L
Urinalysis is normal; urine pH is 7.0.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acidosis?

Type 1 (hypokalemic distal) renal tubular acidosis results from a defect in urine acidification in the distal tubule with impaired excretion of hydrogen ions; patients develop a metabolic acidosis with compensatory hyperchloremia, resulting in a normal anion gap and the inability to acidify urine below a pH of 6.0.

Type 2 (proximal) renal tubular acidosis involves a defect in regenerating bicarbonate in the proximal tubule and is characterized by a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, glycosuria (without hyperglycemia), low-molecular-weight proteinuria, and renal phosphate wasting.
The most likely diagnosis is type 1 (hypokalemic distal) renal tubular acidosis (RTA) (
Option C

), which results from a defect in urine acidification in the distal tubule with impaired excretion of hydrogen ions, most commonly caused by decreased activity of the proton pump in distal tubular cells. Because of the inability to excrete hydrogen ions, patients develop a metabolic acidosis with compensatory hyperchloremia, resulting in a normal anion gap (8 mEq/L in this patient) and the inability to acidify urine below a pH of 6.0. The urine pH is therefore almost always inappropriately elevated for the degree of acidemia. The same defects also cause potassium wasting, and the increased proximal resorption of citrate that occurs with metabolic acidosis leads to hypocitraturia and an increased risk for calcium phosphate kidney stones and nephrocalcinosis. Type 1 RTA is associated with genetic causes, autoimmune disorders, nephrocalcinosis/hypercalciuria, dysproteinemias, drugs/toxins, and tubulointerstitial disease; this patient has sicca complex secondary to Sjögren syndrome and kidney involvement with interstitial nephritis and a type 1 (hypokalemic distal) RTA.
NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (
Option A

) are common causes of drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis. Patients may present with low-grade proteinuria and sterile pyuria, which are not present in this patient. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is not associated with NSAID-related chronic kidney disease. Omeprazole (
Option B
) is also associated with the development of acute interstitial nephritis. Like ibuprofen, omeprazole is an unlikely cause of this patient's metabolic acidosis.
Type 2 (proximal) RTA (
Option D

) involves a defect in regenerating bicarbonate in the proximal tubule and is characterized by a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, glycosuria (without hyperglycemia), low-molecular-weight proteinuria, and renal phosphate wasting. However, distal urine acidification mechanisms are intact, and the urine pH is usually <5.5 without alkali therapy. This patient's high urine pH, absence of glycosuria, and normal urinalysis are inconsistent with type 2 RTA.

objective.__html: Diagnose type 1 (hypokalemic distal) renal tubular acidosis.

references: Vallés PG, Batlle D. Hypokalemic distal renal tubular acidosis. Adv Chronic Kidney Dis. 2018;25:303-20. [PMID 30139458] doi:10.1053/j.ackd.2018.05.003

title: Question 118

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated because of an ulcer between his toes. The ulcer is painful and is worse with leg elevation. He has peripheral artery disease.

Physical examination shows an ulcer involving the medial aspects of the third and fourth digits. It has well-demarcated borders with a dry and "punched-out" appearance. The ulcer base is pale pink in color. There is no bleeding.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Arterial ulcers occur in the setting of significant peripheral vascular disease, usually at the distal aspects of the arterial supply (such as the distal toes) or in areas of trauma (such as overlying the metatarsal heads or shins and ankles).
Venous stasis ulcers account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers, occurring most commonly near the medial malleolus, and are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency.
This patient has an arterial ulcer (
Option A

). Arterial ulcers occur in the setting of significant peripheral vascular disease and result from inadequate perfusion of the lower extremities. Ulceration usually occurs at the distal aspects of the arterial supply (such as the distal toes) or in areas of trauma (such as overlying the metatarsal heads or shins and ankles). The ulcers are usually tender, have a well-demarcated border with a “punched-out” appearance, and are surrounded by erythematous, tight skin. Leg elevation often results in worsening pain, and examination may reveal diminished or absent peripheral pulses.
Calciphylaxis (
Option B

) is a rare disease that is most commonly seen in persons with chronic end-stage kidney disease, and those on dialysis with an elevated calcium-phosphorous product. The initial presentation may start as tender, dusky red macules or a livedo reticularis pattern. It quickly progresses to tender subcutaneous plaques with an overlying dusky red discoloration. Surrounding purpura is often found. The area of involvement quickly expands in an angulated arrangement. As the skin infarcts, a black eschar forms. This patient's findings are not compatible with calciphylaxis.
Neuropathic ulcers (
Option C

) arise secondary to repetitive trauma to the skin, typically in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy and a reduced awareness of pressure or trauma to the skin. Diabetic ulcers are painless, are most common on the plantar surface of the feet, and have associated callus and foot deformity. Examination typically shows diminished sensation.
Venous stasis ulcers (
Option D

) account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers. They occur most commonly near the medial malleolus and are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency. Venous stasis ulcers can be single or multiple and are typically irregularly shaped, shallow, and often weep serous fluid. Physical findings suggestive of venous stasis ulcers include edema, varicosities, eczematous changes, brown pigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, atrophie blanche, and evidence of healed ulcers.

references: Rayala BZ. Skin ulcers: prevention and diagnosis of pressure, venous leg, and arterial ulcers. FP Essent. 2020;499:11-18.

title: Question 119

children: A 22-year-old woman reports a 5-day history of dry cough, scratchy throat, coryza, yellow rhinorrhea, ear fullness, and nasal congestion. For the first 2 days, she also experienced headache and malaise.

On physical examination, temperature is 37.4 °C (99.4 °F). Bilateral conjunctival injection, boggy nasal mucosa, and erythematous oropharynx without tonsillar exudates are noted. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Most patients with the common cold require no treatment other than reassurance.
Nasal symptoms due to the common cold may respond to intranasal cromolyn, intranasal ipratropium, or combination decongestant/antihistamines.
Reassurance (
Option D

) is the most appropriate management for this patient with a mild upper respiratory tract infection, or the common cold. The majority of cases of the common cold have a viral etiology. This syndrome is a benign, self-limited condition that typically presents with nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, sneezing, sore throat, cough, low-grade fever, headache, and malaise; different symptoms may be predominant in individual patients. Most patients require no treatment other than reassurance. Some patients with more severe symptoms may require symptomatic relief, but evidence of effectiveness for the recommended remedies varies. Nasal symptoms may respond to intranasal cromolyn, intranasal ipratropium, or combination decongestant/antihistamines. Other potential symptomatic treatments to consider are intranasal saline spray, NSAIDs, and acetaminophen.

The common cold is caused by viruses, and routine antibiotic treatment in immunocompetent hosts is not recommended. Only a small minority of rhinosinusitis/pharyngitis cases are caused by bacteria, which would be an indication for prescribing an antibiotic such as amoxicillin-clavulanate (
Option A

). Antibiotics given for viral illnesses do not improve symptoms, illness duration, or patient satisfaction with medical care. Purulent rhinorrhea or sputum does not reliably predict bacterial infection or superinfection. Therefore, purulence should not be used as a criterion for antibiotic administration. Evidence-based guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America suggest antibiotics if bacterial rhinosinusitis is highly suspected on the basis of persistent symptoms or signs lasting more than 10 days without evidence of clinical improvement, onset with severe symptoms (fever >39.0 °C [102.2 °F]), or onset with worsening symptoms or signs (new fever, headache, or symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection that were initially improving).
Multiple studies have found little if any improvement in acute cough associated with acute upper respiratory tract infection by using codeine, dextromethorphan (
Option B
), or moguisteine antitussive therapy. The American College of Chest Physicians does not recommend treatment with these medications.

No available treatments have been shown to decrease illness duration. Consistent high-quality data on the use of echinacea and vitamin C do not support their use. There is little evidence to support the use of expectorants or mucolytics. Over-the-counter zinc-containing intranasal products (
Option C
) should be avoided due to the risk for permanent anosmia.

references: Harris AM, Hicks LA, Qaseem A; High Value Care Task Force of the American College of Physicians and for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Appropriate antibiotic use for acute respiratory tract infection in adults: advice for high-value care from the American College of Physicians and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 120

children: An 82-year-old man is evaluated after having fallen while walking to his bedroom in the dark. He reports no preceding lightheadedness, loss of consciousness, current symptoms, or previous falls.

On physical examination, orthostatic vital signs are normal. Gait is normal. Position and vibration sensation are intact. Corrected vision is 20/20. The Timed Up and Go test is completed in 10 seconds.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
An evaluation for home safety is always an appropriate consideration for patients who have fallen, because hazards are found in two thirds of homes.

Patients with falls or fear of falling should be screened with the Timed Up and Go test; patients who take more than 12 seconds to complete these tasks are considered high risk for subsequent falling and should be further evaluated.
A home safety evaluation (
Option A

) is most appropriate for this patient. He fell in his home and has no indication of gait abnormality, visual deficit, or weakness. His walking to the bedroom in the dark and resulting mechanical stumble may have caused the fall. An evaluation for home safety is always an appropriate consideration for patients who have fallen, because hazards are found in two thirds of homes. It would be important to know if he has night lights in each room, because lack of proper lighting would contribute to his risk for falls. Installing night lights in each room is a simple and inexpensive fall prevention strategy. Other potential modifiable home safety issues related to falls include the presence of rugs, thresholds between rooms, general clutter, uneven lighting, and unsafe or absent handrails.

Patients with falls or fear of falling should be screened with the Timed Up and Go test, during which the patient is asked to arise from a chair, walk 10 feet, turn around, and sit in the same chair. Patients who take more than 12 seconds to complete these tasks are considered high risk for subsequent falling and should be further evaluated. This patient's normal gait and Timed Up and Go test result indicate that he does not require further gait evaluation (
Option B

Patients with falls and identified weakness or gait abnormalities may benefit from formal gait retraining/strengthening programs individualized to address their deficits. A supervised exercise program (
Option C
) is probably unnecessary in this patient with a normal gait examination and Timed Up and Go test result.
Neither vitamin B
nor vitamin D supplementation is indicated (
Option D
). Severe and prolonged vitamin B

deficiency can result in subacute combined degeneration, which refers to a dysfunction of the corticospinal and dorsal sensory tracts of the spinal cord that manifests as spastic paresis with reduced vibration and position sense and ataxia. Patients are at risk for falling and may be especially prone to fall in the dark. However, this patient has normal position and vibratory sensation as well as a normal gait, and vitamin B

supplementation is not indicated. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends against vitamin D supplementation to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults aged 65 years or older who are not known to have osteoporosis or vitamin D deficiency.

objective.__html: Manage fall risk in an elderly patient.

references: Phelan EA, Ritchey K. Fall prevention in community-dwelling older adults.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 121

children: A 52-year-old man is evaluated for 3 days of fever, headache, myalgia, dry cough, and pharyngitis. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications. Influenza A is prevalent. He is up to date on all vaccinations, including influenza.
He does not appear significantly ill. Temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8 °F). All other physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Guidelines recommend initiating antiviral treatment as soon as possible for adults with documented or suspected influenza who are hospitalized and for outpatients with severe or progressive illness regardless of illness duration.

Influenza treatment may also be considered for otherwise healthy outpatients if started within 48 hours, household contacts of severely immunosuppressed patients, and health care workers who care for patients at high risk for developing complications from influenza.
No testing or treatment is necessary (
Option D

). During seasonal influenza activity, testing for influenza should occur in patients at high risk who present with influenza-like illness, pneumonia, or nonspecific respiratory illness if the testing result will influence clinical management. Other outpatient candidates for testing include those who present with acute onset of respiratory symptoms and either exacerbation of chronic medical conditions or known complications of influenza, such as pneumonia, if the testing result will influence clinical management. During times of influenza activity, testing for influenza at hospital admission is recommended for all patients with acute respiratory infection and in patients with acute worsening of chronic cardiopulmonary disease. In all cases, treatment decisions should not be delayed pending confirmatory results. When influenza is prevalent, influenza testing is not needed for otherwise healthy outpatients with compatible findings.

The Infectious Diseases Society of America guidelines recommend initiating antiviral treatment as soon as possible for adults with documented or suspected influenza who are hospitalized and for outpatients with severe or progressive illness regardless of illness duration. Treatment should also be initiated as soon as possible for all other patients at high risk for influenza-related complications. Treatment may also be considered for otherwise healthy outpatients if started within 48 hours, household contacts of severely immunosuppressed patients, and health care workers who care for patients at high risk for developing complications from influenza.
Baloxavir (
Option A

) is a polymerase acidic endonuclease inhibitor that may be given as single-dose therapy for uncomplicated influenza. It must be started within 48 hours of symptom onset and seems to be as effective as a 5-day course of oseltamivir. In 2019, baloxavir was FDA approved for the treatment of patients at high risk for influenza complications. This patient is presenting 3 days into his illness, 24 hours beyond the time frame in which treatment might be considered for an otherwise healthy person with mild disease.
This patient has classic symptoms of influenza. He has mild illness and is otherwise healthy. Therefore, testing for influenza (
Option B
) will not alter his management, and treatment with either oseltamivir (
Option B
) or zanamivir is not indicated.

objective.__html: Manage influenza virus infection in a healthy patient.

references: Uyeki TM, Bernstein HH, Bradley JS, et al. Clinical practice guidelines by the Infectious Diseases Society of America: 2018 update on diagnosis, treatment, chemoprophylaxis, and institutional outbreak management of seasonal influenza. Clin Infect Dis. 2019;68:895-902.

title: Question 122

children: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for minimally elevated aminotransferase levels. He is asymptomatic. He does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs, medications, or supplements. Medical history is significant only for obesity.
Other than a BMI of 30, physical examination is normal. Complete metabolic profile, hepatitis serology, and iron studies are normal. Antinuclear and anti–smooth muscle antibodies are negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Abdominal ultrasonography is inexpensive and widely available, and it has a sensitivity of approximately 80% for detecting hepatic steatosis in patients with suspected nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) management focuses on weight loss through diet and lifestyle modification; there are no FDA-approved drugs for NAFLD.
This patient likely has nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and abdominal ultrasonography (
Option A

) should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate for fibrosis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. NAFLD has reached epidemic proportions in Western societies and has become one of the leading indications for liver transplantation in the United States. Elevated liver enzyme levels support the diagnosis, but normal values do not rule it out. Depending on the patient's demographics and social history, investigations for viral hepatitis, hemochromatosis, and autoimmune hepatitis may be conducted. Abdominal ultrasonography is inexpensive and widely available, and it has a sensitivity of approximately 80% for detecting steatosis when hepatocytes contain more than 20% of histologically detected fat. Because complications of NAFLD include liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, patients with NAFLD should have screening ultrasonography every 3 years. If fibrosis/cirrhosis is present, ultrasonographic screening should take place every 6 months. No specific treatment for NAFLD is available; therefore, weight reduction and moderation/cessation of alcohol use are strongly recommended. After the initial diagnosis of NAFLD, further evaluation for advanced fibrosis may be needed, particularly in patients with metabolic risk factors such as diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia.

NAFLD management focuses on weight loss through diet and lifestyle modification. No specific diet for NAFLD is recommended, although carbohydrate-restricted diets may result in greater reduction in liver fat than other diets. Bariatric surgery (
Option B

) and concomitant weight loss exceeding 8% to 10% improve NAFLD-associated inflammation and fibrosis. However, this patient does not have an established diagnosis of NAFLD, and lifestyle modifications are first-line interventions for patients with obesity.
Liver biopsy (
Option C

) is the diagnostic gold standard for fibrosis and provides invaluable information in the assessment of advanced fibrosis; however, its invasiveness makes it a test rarely needed in the early evaluation stages of suspected NAFLD.
There is no FDA-approved drug therapy for NAFLD. Clinical trials of metformin (
Option D

) in patients with NAFLD have focused on aminotransferases and/or liver histology in patients with steatohepatitis. Studies have demonstrated improvement in aminotransferase levels but not liver histology in NAFLD. Metformin is not recommended by current guidelines for treating NAFLD.

references: Chalasani N, Younossi Z, Lavine JE, et al. The diagnosis and management of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease: practice guidance from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases. Hepatology. 2018;67:328-357.

title: Question 123

children: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for new-onset headache. She reports a 3-month history of twice-monthly severe hemicranial throbbing headaches associated with photophobia that may last between 4 and 72 hours and are sometimes incapacitating. The headaches respond partially to acetaminophen.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. Brain MRI is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The effectiveness of the NSAIDs ibuprofen, naproxen sodium, and diclofenac potassium for acute episodic migraine headache is supported by strong evidence.
Guidelines recommend the use of triptans in patients with moderate to severe migraine who have not responded to NSAID therapy over a series of at least three migraine attacks.
This patient should be treated with naproxen sodium (
Option B

) for acute episodic migraine. Evidence-based guidelines recommend several simple and combination analgesic agents as first-line therapies for acute migraine. Acetaminophen has established efficacy only in migraine of mild to moderate intensity; data suggest the response may be enhanced by coadministration with metoclopramide. Aspirin administered alone or in combination with acetaminophen and caffeine also has established efficacy in acute migraine. The effectiveness of the NSAIDs ibuprofen, naproxen sodium, and diclofenac potassium is supported by strong evidence.
Ergot alkaloids, such as dihydroergotamine (
Option A

), have been used for years to treat moderate to severe migraine headaches but have largely been replaced by triptans, which have better safety and tolerability profiles. Parenteral and nasal formulations of dihydroergotamine are the most available and effective options among the ergot alkaloids.
Guidelines recommend avoiding the use of opioids, such as oxycodone (
Option C

), and butalbital-containing compounds for acute migraine. In addition to the potential for dependence or addiction, use of these agents has been linked to an increased risk for transformation from episodic to chronic migraine. They should be used sparingly and only when more appropriate acute therapies are contraindicated.
Triptans, such as sumatriptan (
Option D

), are migraine-specific selective agonists at 5-hydroxytryptamine 1B and 1D receptors. These drugs inhibit the release of calcitonin gene–related peptide, which mediates cerebral vasodilation, neurogenic inflammation, and pain sensitization of migraine. Guidelines recommend the use of triptans in patients with moderate to severe migraine who have not responded to NSAID therapy over a series of at least three migraine attacks. Current evidence suggests that all oral triptans possess nearly similar clinical efficacy.

references: Ashina M. Migraine. N Engl J Med. 2020;383:1866-1876.

title: Question 124

children: A 75-year-old man with Graves disease is evaluated for fever, cough, and confusion. He did not refill his last prescription for methimazole.
Temperature is 39.4 °C (102.9 °F), blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 138/min. He is delirious. Pulmonary crackles are present.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is <0.1 µU/mL (0.1 mU/L);
free thyroxine
level is 4.4 ng/dL (56.8 pmol/L). Chest radiograph shows a left lower lobe infiltrate.
Antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia are initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Thyroid storm is distinguished from hyperthyroidism by the presence of severe and life-threatening symptoms, most often including cardiac dysfunction (tachyarrhythmias, shock, heart failure) and others (fever, delirium).

Therapy for thyroid storm includes a combination of β-blockers, antithyroidal medications, potassium iodide, hydrocortisone therapy, cooling of body temperature, and treatment of any underlying precipitant.
This patient should receive propranolol, propylthiouracil, and hydrocortisone (
Option C

). He has pneumonia complicated by thyroid storm, a life-threatening condition. Common precipitants of thyroid storm include iatrogenic causes, such as therapy with radioactive iodine, abrupt cessation of antithyroidal drugs, acute nonthyroidal illnesses, and thyroid or nonthyroid surgery in a patient with unrecognized or inadequately treated thyrotoxicosis. The diagnosis of thyroid storm is clinical. What distinguishes thyroid storm from hyperthyroidism is the presence of severe and life-threatening symptoms, most often including cardiac dysfunction (tachyarrhythmias, shock, heart failure) and others (fever, delirium). A point scale, such as the Burch-Wartofsky Point Scale, can be used to facilitate the early diagnosis of thyroid storm. There is no cutoff range of free thyroxine (T
) or free triiodothyronine (T

) levels that supports the diagnosis. Patients in thyroid storm require admission to an intensive care unit. Appropriate therapy includes a combination of β-blockers, antithyroidal medications, potassium iodide, hydrocortisone therapy, cooling of body temperature, and treatment of any underlying precipitant. Iodide should be administered more than 1 hour after antithyroid drugs to avoid providing substrate to the gland.
The combination of atenolol, methimazole and cholestyramine (
Option A
) is not the best therapy for thyroid storm. Propranolol and propylthiouracil have the added benefit over atenolol and methimazole in thyroid storm by reducing T
-to-T

conversion. Usually, high dosages of propranolol (240-480 mg/d) and propylthiouracil (>450 mg/d) are required to take advantage of that benefit and to adequately treat thyroid storm. Cholestyramine interrupts the enterohepatic recirculation of thyroid hormone, reducing total thyroid hormone burden. Cholestyramine may be used as adjunctive therapy or when the patient cannot take a thionamide such as propylthiouracil. Glucocorticoids are commonly recommended for thyroid storm because they decrease conversion of T
to T
, suppress stimulating antibody production, and simultaneously treat hypocortisolism, if present, and should be part of this patient's therapy.
Plasmapheresis (
Option B

) can remove cytokines, antibodies, and thyroid hormones from plasma. The evidence supporting plasmapheresis for thyroid storm is from case reports. Plasmapheresis is usually reserved for patients in whom standard therapy has failed.
Radioactive iodine ablation (
Option D

) may acutely exacerbate the thyrotoxic state by releasing preformed thyroid hormone from injured thyrocytes and takes many weeks (or even months) to bring about hypothyroidism. Therefore, this therapy is not appropriate for patients in thyroid storm.

references: Feldt-Rasmussen U, Emerson CH, Ross DS, et al. Thoughts on the Japanese and American perspectives on thyroid storm [Editorial]. Thyroid. 2019;29:1033-1035.

title: Question 125

children: A 58-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated for persistent hypertension despite lifestyle modifications, including adherence to the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet, exercise, alcohol cessation, and weight loss. Home blood pressure recordings average 158/92 mm Hg. She has no other medical problems and is taking no medications.
Serum electrolytes and kidney function are normal; urinalysis is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
For patients with blood pressure 20/10 mm Hg above target, combination therapy with two antihypertensive agents from different classes is preferred to treatment with a single agent.
Combination therapy with the ACE inhibitor lisinopril and the calcium channel blocker amlodipine (
Option A

) is appropriate for this patient with stage 2 hypertension, which is defined as a systolic blood pressure (BP) of 140 mm Hg or higher and/or a diastolic BP of 90 mm Hg or higher. There is general agreement among hypertension societies that a single agent, such as chlorthalidone, losartan, or nifedipine (
Options B, C, D

), is unlikely to control BP in patients with BP 20/10 mm Hg above target. Given this patient's degree of hypertension, it is unlikely that a single agent will achieve her treatment goal of less than 130/80 mm Hg. Therefore, continued therapeutic lifestyle interventions and combination drug therapy are indicated. In this circumstance, initial therapy may include a combination of two agents from two different classes of antihypertensive drugs, either separately or in a fixed-dose pill. A combination of two agents at moderate doses is often more successful at achieving BP goals than one BP agent at maximal dose and minimizes the adverse effects that are more commonly noted at higher doses. Guidelines recommend that drug combinations with similar mechanisms of action or clinical effects should be avoided. For example, two drugs from the same class should not be administered together (e.g., two different β-blockers, ACE inhibitors, or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers). Likewise, two drugs from classes that target the same BP control system are less effective and potentially harmful when used together (e.g., ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers). Exceptions to this rule include concomitant use of a thiazide diuretic, potassium-sparing diuretic, and/or loop diuretic in various combinations. Also, dihydropyridine and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers can be combined. Combined use of any renin-angiotensin system drug classes (ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and direct renin inhibitors) is harmful; several clinical trials have revealed more adverse events with these combinations (hyperkalemia, hypotension, acute kidney injury), without additional cardiovascular or kidney benefits.

objective.__html: Treat a patient with stage 2 hypertension using combination therapy.

references: Whelton PK, Carey RM, Aronow WS, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA guideline for the prevention, detection, evaluation, and management of high blood pressure in adults: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines. Hypertension. 2018;71:e13-e115.

title: Question 126

children: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department 90 minutes after developing left leg and arm weakness.

Blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg; pulse rate is 85/min and irregularly irregular. Cardiac examination is remarkable only for an irregular rhythm. Carotid pulses are normal. Neurologic examination reveals left-sided homonymous visual field loss, hemiplegia, and neglect. Plasma glucose level and head CT are normal. ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

Patients who receive intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator within 3 hours of an ischemic stroke onset have a greater likelihood of clinical improvement at 3 months compared with untreated patients.

Before treatment with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, the patient's blood pressure should be less than 185/110 mm Hg; higher readings should prompt administration of intravenous labetalol or nicardipine before alteplase.
This patient should receive thrombolysis with intravenous (IV) alteplase (
Option C

), a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator. She has acute and disabling neurologic deficits consistent with an ischemic stroke in the right middle cerebral artery territory, with no evidence of hemorrhage or acute infarct on head CT. Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardioembolic cause of stroke and is the most likely cause of this patient's stroke. She is within the 3-hour treatment window for patients who do not meet any exclusion criteria for thrombolysis and should receive this treatment. Patients who receive alteplase within 3 hours of stroke onset have a greater likelihood of clinical improvement at 3 months compared with nontreated patients. In addition, patients who present within 3 to 4.5 hours of stroke onset and fulfill additional criteria may also benefit from alteplase, but it is not FDA approved for this population. The main complication of alteplase is symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage, which may present with headache or clinical deterioration. The main risk factors for symptomatic hemorrhage are treatment after 4.5 hours and hypertension before and after treatment. Accordingly, before treatment with alteplase, the patient's blood pressure should be less than 185/110 mm Hg. Higher readings should prompt administration of IV labetalol or nicardipine before alteplase, and blood pressure should be kept below 180/105 mm Hg after treatment.
Anticoagulation, including apixaban therapy (
Option A

), does not reduce the 14-day risk for recurrent stroke or mortality in patients with AF who have a new stroke, and it is therefore not indicated. Eventual initiation of oral anticoagulation therapy would be an appropriate step for secondary prevention of future strokes in this patient with AF; it would be inappropriate as an acute treatment.

For patients with acute ischemic stroke who are not eligible for alteplase or endovascular stroke therapy, antiplatelet therapy is the mainstay of acute treatment. When administered either orally or rectally within 48 hours of stoke, aspirin reduces the short-term risk for recurrent stroke, and its use in the acute setting is a stroke-specific quality-of-care core measure. Monotherapy with clopidogrel (
Option B

), however, has no established benefit in the acute stroke setting. As long as a follow-up CT scan of the head shows no hemorrhage, aspirin should be initiated 24 hours after administration of alteplase.
Clinical trials have shown that in ischemic strokes caused by suspected large-vessel occlusion, endovascular thrombectomy (
Option D

) is superior to alteplase alone and can improve long-term outcomes. This therapy may be offered to a select subset of patients who fulfill criteria on additional imaging, such as CT angiography. Treatment with alteplase, however, should not be delayed in appropriate candidates, including those who may go on to receive thrombectomy.

objective.__html: Treat acute ischemic stroke with thrombolysis.

references: Kleindorfer DO, Towfighi A, Chaturvedi S, et al. 2021 guideline for the prevention of stroke in patients with stroke and transient ischemic attack: a guideline from the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Stroke. 2021;52:e364-e467.

title: Question 127

children: A 71-year-old woman is evaluated for urinary incontinence. She has Parkinson disease with dementia and osteoarthritis of the knees. She ambulates with assistance and a walker. She is aware of the need to urinate but often cannot make it to the toilet in time. Current medications are carbidopa-levodopa, donepezil, and topical diclofenac.
Urinalysis is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Nonpharmacologic behavioral therapy is recommended first-line treatment for urinary incontinence, and behavioral therapy utilizing prompted voiding is the most appropriate management for urinary incontinence in patients with cognitive impairment and decreased mobility.
Pelvic floor muscle training and weight loss are effective in improving stress or mixed incontinence.
The most appropriate treatment is prompted voiding (
Option D

) for this patient with functional incontinence. Nonpharmacologic behavioral therapy is recommended first-line treatment for urinary incontinence, and behavioral therapy utilizing prompted voiding is the most appropriate management for this patient whose incontinence may be due to her cognitive impairment and decreased mobility. Prompted voiding involves regularly asking the patient to report on incontinence, asking the patient if he or she needs to void, providing assistance with access to the bathroom, and praising the patient for continence. This technique has been shown to reduce urinary incontinence in older patients who have caregivers capable of working with them, including those residing in assisted-care facilities. Prompted voiding should be timed to occur before a large volume of urine has accumulated in the bladder, reducing the likelihood of incontinence. With active and consistent caregiver involvement, prompted urination can help achieve improved bladder control.
Mirabegron (
Option A
) is a β

-adrenergic agonist that can be used to decrease urgency, frequency, or incontinence in overactive bladder not responding to weight loss and behavioral therapies. Efficacy is similar to muscarinic agents but with fewer side effects. This patient most likely does not have urge incontinence, and prompted voiding is the most practical and safest intervention.
Like β
-adrenergic agonists, antimuscarinic agents, such as oxybutynin (
Option B

), are used to decrease urgency, frequency, or incontinence in overactive bladder with urge incontinence. Adverse effects are common, however, and include constipation, dry mouth, dizziness, and confusion. Older patients are at greater risk for these effects, and antimuscarinic agents are included on the Beers Criteria list of drugs to avoid in the elderly. Therefore, an antimuscarinic agent would not be an appropriate therapeutic choice in this older patient with cognitive impairment and probable functional incontinence.
Pelvic floor muscle training (
Option C

) and weight loss are effective in improving stress or mixed incontinence but require active participation by the patient. Although training is implemented by physical therapists or advanced practice nurses, both pelvic floor muscle and bladder training require intact cognition and the ability to self-manage and self-sustain a training regimen. It is therefore unlikely to be effective in this patient with dementia and is unlikely to improve functional incontinence.

references: Balk EM, Rofeberg VN, Adam GP, et al. Pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic treatments for urinary incontinence in women: A systematic review and network meta-analysis of clinical outcomes.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 128

children: A 62-year-old man with a long history of gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) was diagnosed with Barrett esophagus with low-grade dysplasia 6 months ago. He takes omeprazole twice daily. Other than occasional breakthrough symptoms of GERD, he is asymptomatic and without other medical problems.
A follow-up endoscopy is performed today. Endoscopic biopsy reveals high-grade dysplasia.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Patients with Barrett esophagus and high-grade dysplasia should undergo ablation treatment to eradicate all neoplastic and at-risk epithelium.
Patients with Barrett esophagus and low-grade dysplasia are candidates for ablation therapy, but endoscopic surveillance is an accepted alternative.
The most appropriate next step in management for this patient with Barrett esophagus (BE) and high-grade dysplasia is endoscopic ablation (
Option A

). BE is a complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease in which the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus is replaced by specialized columnar epithelium. Patients with BE have more severe esophageal acid reflux than those with nonerosive reflux disease. BE is a premalignant condition; patients have an estimated 30- to 50-fold increased risk for developing esophageal adenocarcinoma compared with those without BE, with an annual incidence of esophageal adenocarcinoma of 0.5%. Patients without dysplasia have very low risk for progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma. Due to high interpersonal variability in staging BE, the diagnosis should be made by a pathologist with expertise in esophageal disease. In patients without dysplasia, surveillance upper endoscopy every 3 to 5 years is recommended. Patients with BE and low-grade dysplasia are candidates for ablation therapy, but endoscopic surveillance, as initially chosen for this patient, is an accepted alternative. Patients with high-grade dysplasia should undergo treatment to eradicate all neoplastic and at-risk epithelium. Endoscopic therapy for BE includes mucosal resection as well as ablation, of which radiofrequency is the best studied. Ablation has a high rate of eradication of both metaplasia and dysplasia. Because BE has a high tendency to recur, continuation of treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, such as omeprazole, and posttreatment surveillance are essential.
Although esophagectomy (
Option B

) is an option for the treatment of both BE with high-grade dysplasia and intramucosal (T1a) adenocarcinoma, endoscopic ablation is preferred because of the high morbidity and mortality associated with esophagectomy.
Patients with high-grade dysplasia should undergo treatment to eradicate all neoplastic and at-risk epithelium. Repeat endoscopy and biopsy in 3 months (
Option C
) would be inadequate, placing the patient at risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is commonly associated with dysphagia and food bolus obstruction, which may be recurrent. The diagnostic criteria for EoE are esophageal symptoms (dysphagia), esophageal biopsy specimens showing persistent eosinophil counts of 15/hpf or greater, and exclusion of other causes of eosinophilia. If assessment identifies no other causes of eosinophilia, EoE can be diagnosed and appropriate therapy initiated with a proton pump inhibitor and/or swallowed topical glucocorticoids (fluticasone or budesonide). This patient does not have EoE, and treatment with a swallowed topical budesonide (
Option D
) is not appropriate treatment for Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia.

objective.__html: Treat Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia.

references: Sharma P, Shaheen NJ, Katzka D, et al. AGA clinical practice update on endoscopic treatment of Barrett's esophagus with dysplasia and/or early cancer: expert review. Gastroenterology. 2020;158:760-769.

title: Question 129

children: A 53-year-old woman is evaluated for an acute, slightly pruritic rash over her legs. She also has chronic venous insufficiency.

On physical examination, she is afebrile. In addition to typical changes of chronic venous insufficiency, lower extremity examination shows bilateral eczematous patches with redness, weeping, and in some areas, scaling, most prominent over the medial aspect of the leg.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Stasis dermatitis is a complication of chronic venous insufficiency, which is recognized by the presence of dependent edema, varicose veins, and trophic skin changes such as hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulcers.
Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory reaction that can be very pruritic and erythematous and may include vesiculation and weeping skin.
This patient has acute stasis dermatitis (
Option A

). Stasis dermatitis is a complication of chronic venous insufficiency, which is recognized by the presence of dependent edema, varicose veins, and trophic skin changes such as hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulcers. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory reaction that can be very pruritic and erythematous and may include vesiculation and weeping skin. Symptoms are often bilateral, although it may be unilaterally symptomatic. Treatment typically includes exercise (walking or heel lifts) and compression stockings to decrease venous hypertension and dependent edema.
Cellulitis (
Option B

) presents as a painful, erythematous, well-demarcated patch that is warm to the touch. The presence of fever, lymphadenopathy, or other evidence of infection, such as an elevated leukocyte count, also would suggest this diagnosis. It is important to consider alternative diagnoses when there are erythematous patches on both legs.
Lichen simplex chronicus (
Option C

) is a condition caused by repetitive scratching or rubbing. Predisposing conditions include atopic dermatitis, xerosis, and psychiatric conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder. Lichen simplex chronicus manifests as thickened plaques with erythema and hyperpigmentation. Exaggerated skin markings are seen on the surface of the skin as well. Common sites include the genitals, back of the neck, wrists, ankles, and lower legs. Lichen simplex chronicus does not present as an acute eczematous skin reaction with weeping associated with chronic venous insufficiency.
Xerotic eczema (
Option D

), also called eczema craquelé or asteatotic eczema, is often seen on the lower extremities of older persons. Dry weather and excessive bathing are known inciting factors. The lesions are erythematous with plate-like cracked scale, often resembling a dried-up creek bed. Redness and weeping would not be consistent with the diagnosis of xerotic eczema.

references: Barstow C, Kassop D. Cardiovascular disease: chronic venous insufficiency and varicose veins. FP Essent. 2019;479:16-20.

children: A 59-year-old woman is evaluated for a 7-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She currently smokes cigarettes.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Jugular venous distention is present. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals pulmonary crackles and an S
. Pedal edema is noted. Chest radiograph shows vascular congestion. ECG shows inferior Q waves. Echocardiogram reveals inferior wall hypokinesis and a
left ventricular ejection fraction
Treatment is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?

Patients with heart failure and exertional chest pain, history of myocardial infarction, or other symptoms suggesting coronary artery disease should undergo further evaluation with stress testing or cardiac catheterization as clinically appropriate.
Heart failure caused by ischemia may improve or resolve with percutaneous or surgical revascularization.
The most appropriate next step in diagnostic testing is coronary angiography (
Option B

). Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the leading cause of heart failure in the United States (>50% of patients) and should be considered in all patients with newly diagnosed heart failure. The decision to evaluate for CAD depends on the patient's symptoms and risk factors (family history, male sex, diabetes, hypertension, tobacco use). Additionally, findings on ECG and echocardiography may suggest an ischemic cause for left ventricular dysfunction. Patients with exertional chest pain, history of myocardial infarction, or other symptoms suggesting CAD should undergo further evaluation with stress testing or cardiac catheterization as clinically appropriate. Identification of significant CAD is important, as left ventricular dysfunction caused by ischemia may improve or resolve with percutaneous or surgical revascularization. This patient has a high likelihood for ischemic heart disease as evidenced by a previous inferior wall myocardial infarction on ECG, which likely accounts for her symptoms and reduced ejection fraction. Given the high pretest probability of ischemic heart disease and findings suggestive of extensive myocardial ischemia, coronary angiography is indicated in this patient.
Cardiac MRI (
Option A
) is useful for evaluating possible infiltrative or inflammatory cardiomyopathy, which is unlikely in this patient with high likelihood of ischemic heart disease.
Endomyocardial biopsy (
Option C

) has proven value when used to monitor for cardiac allograft rejection. Otherwise, endomyocardial biopsy is useful in only a limited number of patients who may have heart failure secondary to giant cell myocarditis, restrictive and infiltrative cardiomyopathies, or other types of myocarditis. Clinical situations where biopsy might be considered include unexplained acute onset and fulminant heart failure associated with normal size or dilated left ventricle; in patients with dilated left ventricle, new ventricular arrhythmias, or conduction block; and in patients who fail to respond to guideline-directed medical therapy. This patient has risk factors for CAD, and endomyocardial biopsy is not indicated.
Noninvasive stress testing, such as nuclear myocardial perfusion imaging (
Option D
), would likely identify ischemic heart disease in this patient, but the more relevant issue is whether the coronary anatomy is amenable to revascularization, which could improve function.
Ann Intern Med

title: Question 131

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a painful rash. Carbamazepine was initiated 40 days ago for epilepsy. Four days ago, she developed fever and red macules on the trunk that progressed to vesicles and erosions.

On physical examination, temperature is 39.9 °C (102.9 °F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 116/min. Sloughing skin on the trunk and extremities involves 60% body surface area. Oral erosions are present.
Carbamazepine is discontinued.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

text.__html: Intensive care unit admission and supportive care

children: Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis are related clinical syndromes that are characterized by acute epidermal necrosis; most deaths result from secondary infection, complications of transcutaneous fluid loss, or respiratory distress.
The treatment of Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis involves stopping the offending agent and supportive care, often in an intensive care unit or burn unit.
This patient with toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) should be admitted to the intensive care unit and receive supportive care (
Option B

). The most commonly implicated medications with TEN are antiepileptic agents, especially carbamazepine, lamotrigine, and phenytoin. Minocycline, sulfonamides, fluoroquinolones, β-lactam antibiotics, pantoprazole, sertraline, NSAIDs (oxicam and acetic acid type), tramadol, and allopurinol are also frequent causes. The treatment of TEN begins with drug cessation and aggressive care in the intensive care unit or burn center. Ophthalmologic and urologic consultations are mandatory if ocular or genital involvement is present, as destructive scarring may occur in these areas. Most deaths result from secondary infection, complications of transcutaneous fluid loss, or respiratory distress. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is often necessary. A low threshold is recommended for performing cultures and initiation of empiric antibiotics, but use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and TEN are related clinical syndromes that are characterized by acute epidermal necrosis. The classification of SJS and TEN is determined by the percentage of body surface area with epidermal detachment: SJS involves less than 10%, SJS-TEN overlap involves 10% to 30%, and TEN involves greater than 30%. TEN is almost exclusively caused by medications, whereas SJS is also triggered by vaccines or infection. SJS and TEN occur within 8 weeks of drug initiation. Patients may have flu-like symptoms for 1 to 3 days before skin eruption. Red-purple macules or patches that enlarge and coalesce develop on the trunk and extremities; skin pain is prominent. Vesicles, bullae, and erosions reflect the epidermal necrosis seen on biopsy. Nikolsky sign (the shearing off of the epidermis with lateral pressure on the skin) is present. Two or more mucosal surfaces are involved in more than 80% of patients. Systemic inflammation can result in pneumonia, hepatitis, nephritis, arthralgia, and myocarditis.
Infliximab (
Option A

) is a monoclonal antibody used in several conditions, including psoriasis, but has no role in TEN management. Evidence shows that treatment with systemic glucocorticoids, such as intravenous methylprednisolone (
Option C

), can increase mortality rates in patients with TEN. Infection is a risk for patients with SJS or TEN because of the extensive damage to the skin barrier; however, antibiotics, such as vancomycin and ceftriaxone (
Option D
), are not started without signs or symptoms of infection.

references: Charlton OA, Harris V, Phan K, et al. Toxic epidermal necrolysis and Steven-Johnson syndrome: A comprehensive review. Adv Wound Care (New Rochelle). 2020;9:426-439.

title: Question 132

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for mild fatigue of 3 years' duration. He is otherwise asymptomatic and takes no medications. Depression screening is negative.
Physical examination findings are normal. Serum
thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is 7.1 µU/mL (7.1 mU/L; unchanged from 6 months ago) and
free thyroxine
level is 1.3 ng/dL (16.8 pmol/L). Complete blood count, complete metabolic profile, and thyroid peroxidase antibody level are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Repeat thyroid function testing in 6 months

children: Subclinical hypothyroidism is diagnosed by thyroid-stimulating hormone suppression with normal thyroxine levels.

Evidence is insufficient to conclude that treatment of subclinical hypothyroidism minimizes risk or improves outcomes when the serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 10 µU/mL (10 mU/L) or less (some guidelines suggest <20 µU/mL [20 mU/L]).
This patient's thyroid function studies should be repeated in 6 months (
Option B
). He has subclinical hypothyroidism, diagnosed by a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level higher than normal with a normal thyroxine (T

) level. Patients typically have mild or no symptoms of hypothyroidism. The causes of subclinical hypothyroidism are generally considered the same as for overt hypothyroidism. Patients with subclinical hypothyroidism may have mild elevations in serum total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and even C-reactive protein levels, and some meta-analyses have shown an increased risk for atherosclerosis and cardiac events. Two percent to 4% of patients with subclinical hypothyroidism progress to overt hypothyroidism yearly, whereas in one third of patients, thyroid function will spontaneously revert to normal. The normal range for TSH increases with age, and a TSH level of up to 7.9 µU/mL (7.9 mU/L) is within the normal range for persons 80 years of age and older. Thus, it is reasonable to repeat the thyroid function studies in 6 months.
Evidence is insufficient to conclude that treatment with levothyroxine (
Option A

) minimizes risk or improves outcomes when the serum TSH level is 10 µU/mL (10 mU/L) or less (some guidelines suggest <20 µU/mL [20 mU/L]). Treatment is recommended when serum TSH levels are greater than 10 µU/mL (10 mU/L; or possibly ≥20 µU/mL [20 mU/L]). This recommendation does not apply to women who are pregnant, and it may not apply to younger patients (age <30 years). Levothyroxine also may be considered for patients who have marked symptoms, a goiter, or positive serum thyroid peroxidase antibody titers. This patient is asymptomatic (except for mild fatigue) and in good health. His clinical examination findings are normal and thus support the concept that he does not require exogenous levothyroxine.
Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin or thyrotropin receptor antibody (TRAb) (
Option C

) measurements can identify Graves disease with high sensitivity and specificity. Third-generation TRAb measurement may provide a quicker and more cost-efficient diagnosis than a radioactive iodine uptake study. However, this patient's elevated TSH level excludes the diagnosis of Graves disease and the need for TRAb testing.
Measurement of triiodothyronine (T
Option D
) in the setting of hypothyroidism is not necessary; normal levels are maintained unless hypothyroidism is severe. TSH increases first in hypothyroidism, followed by T
decreases. Measurement of T
in hyperthyroidism is recommended in three settings: (1) the evaluation of thyrotoxicosis to identify isolated T
toxicosis, (2) the assessment of hyperthyroidism severity and therapeutic response, and (3) the differentiation of hyperthyroidism from destructive thyroiditis.

references: Peeters RP. Subclinical hypothyroidism. N Engl J Med. 2017;376:2556-2565.

title: Question 133

children: A 63-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for heart failure. Medications include furosemide, valsartan-sacubitril, and metoprolol.
Diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion are noted at the posterior right lung base. Chest radiograph shows a right pleural effusion.
Thoracentesis is performed, and 150 mL of serous fluid is removed.
Pleural fluid studies:
Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH
Pleural fluid LDH percentage of upper limit of normal for serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein/serum protein
Gram stain
Negative
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion?

The Light criteria for exudative pleural fluid are a pleural fluid to serum protein ratio greater than 0.5, pleural fluid to serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio greater than 0.6, or pleural fluid LDH more than two thirds the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.
The most common causes of transudates are heart failure and cirrhosis; the most common causes of exudates are infection and malignancy.
The most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion is heart failure (
Option B

). The first step in pleural fluid analysis is to assess the appearance of the pleural fluid. The next step is to determine whether the effusion is a transudate or exudate. Transudates are due to an imbalance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures, as occurs with heart failure and cirrhosis, the two most common causes. Exudates are due to inflammation causing increased capillary permeability, impaired drainage by lymphatics, or both. There are many causes of exudative effusions, but the most common are infection and malignancy. Differentiation is commonly made using the Light criteria. These criteria are very sensitive for exudates; however, they are less specific, and approximately 25% of transudates are misclassified as exudates. Light criteria define an exudative effusion by the presence of any one of the following findings: pleural fluid to serum protein ratio greater than 0.5, a pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH ratio greater than 0.6, or pleural fluid LDH more than two thirds the upper limit of normal for serum LDH. This patient's pleural fluid is consistent with a transudative process. Pleural fluid differentiation into an exudative category by at least one of the Light criteria is nearly 100% sensitive but less specific. Specificity further declines when a transudative process is treated with diuretic therapy, as may be the case in a patient in whom heart failure remains the most likely posttest diagnosis. Pleural fluid cholesterol level greater than 55 mg/dL is a less sensitive indicator of exudative effusion than the Light criteria, but it is more specific and would increase posttest probability of an exudate. A difference of less than 1.2 g/dL between serum and pleural fluid albumin levels is also more specific for an exudate than the Light criteria. For other patients in whom an exudative effusion is not clinically suspected but is suggested by the Light criteria, further testing may be necessary.
Parapneumonic pleural effusions (
Option A
) are exudative. The absence of abnormalities on Gram stain of pleural fluid from thoracentesis reduces the probability of a parapneumonic effusion.
Pleural effusions due to malignancy such as lung cancer (
Option C
) are exudative and tend to be unilateral. The effusion in this patient is most consistent with a transudate.
Pleural effusions due to pulmonary embolism (
Option D
) are usually exudative. They are generally small and unilateral.

references: Feller-Kopman D, Light R. Pleural disease. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:740-751.

title: Question 134

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for postherpetic neuralgia. Three months ago, he developed herpes zoster involving the left posterior thorax in a T7 distribution. He was treated with antiviral therapy, and the lesions healed; however, he has persistent severe burning pain. He also has severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease treated with fluticasone furoate/umeclidinium/vilanterol combination inhaler.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

First-line pharmacologic therapies for patients with neuropathic pain include the gabapentinoids gabapentin or pregabalin, tricyclic antidepressants, or the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors duloxetine or venlafaxine.
Gabapentin may cause serious breathing difficulties in patients with respiratory risk factors, including opioid use and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Duloxetine (
Option A

) is an appropriate treatment for this patient with postherpetic neuralgia, a form of neuropathic pain. Neuropathic pain is often described as burning, stabbing, prickling, or having a “pins and needles” quality. First-line pharmacologic therapies for patients with neuropathic pain include the gabapentinoids gabapentin or pregabalin, tricyclic antidepressants, or the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors duloxetine or venlafaxine. Topical therapies, such as lidocaine or capsaicin, can be used as adjuncts, especially if the pain is localized. Neuropathic pain results from a maladaptive response to damage sustained to the sensory nervous system, in this case caused by herpes zoster. Other common causes of neuropathic pain include diabetic neuropathy, trigeminal neuralgia, stroke, nerve trauma, and spinal cord injury.
In 2019, the FDA issued a warning that gabapentinoids such as gabapentin (
Option B

) may cause serious breathing difficulties in patients with respiratory risk factors, including opioid use and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Gabapentin would not be the most appropriate first choice of therapy for this patient with severe COPD.
Oxycodone (
Option C

) and other opioid medications are not first-line therapy for pain because of their adverse-effect profile and potential for misuse. Opioids must also be used with caution in patients with COPD. Opioids can be considered for patients with severe pain refractory to other interventions in the absence of contraindications.
Prednisone (
Option D

) might be offered to a patient with acute neuritis due to herpes zoster. Other treatments for acute zoster neuritis might include NSAIDs or a short course of opioid therapy if the patient is unresponsive to first-line therapies. Prednisone is not generally effective for patients with chronic pain due to postherpetic neuralgia, and prolonged use is associated with significant adverse effects.

references: In brief: Respiratory depression with gabapentinoids. Med Lett Drugs Ther. 2020;62:81.

title: Question 135

children: A 31-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia is evaluated in the emergency department for fever after his first cycle of cytarabine and daunorubicin. He has no other symptoms.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.8 °C (101.8 °F); the remainder of the vital signs are normal. No localizing findings are noted.
Leukocyte count
/L) with 0 neutrophils. Chest radiograph is normal. Blood and urine cultures are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Neutropenic fever is a medical emergency, and immediate broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage within 60 minutes of presentation is recommended.

Although many factors influence the empiric antibiotic choice for patients with neutropenic fever, monotherapy with a β-lactam agent with broad coverage for gram-positive and gram-negative organisms and antipseudomonal activity (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam) is effective and is the most commonly used approach.
This patient requires immediate parenteral administration of a broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as piperacillin-tazobactam (
Option C

), while blood and urine cultures are pending. Patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), an absolute neutrophil count <500/µL, and expected prolonged neutropenia (>7 days) are at high risk for neutropenic fevers. This is a medical emergency, and immediate broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage within 60 minutes of presentation is recommended. Multiple clinical factors should influence the initial empiric therapy, such as localizing symptoms, prior infections, local antibiotic resistance pattern, previous prophylactic antibiotic coverage, and others. Monotherapy with a β-lactam agent with broad coverage for gram-positive and gram-negative organisms and antipseudomonal activity is effective in treating neutropenic fever and is the most commonly used approach. Although combination antibiotic therapy is often used (e.g., adding an aminoglycoside for additional antipseudomonal coverage), no specific regimen is superior to broad-spectrum monotherapy. Antifungal agents are usually considered only for patients with mucosal barrier inflammation and prolonged neutropenia (>1 week).
Hematopoietic growth factors, including granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (
Option A

), are effective prophylaxis in patients receiving chemotherapy who have a high incidence of neutropenic fevers. However, they should not replace immediate antimicrobial therapy in patients with fever and neutropenia and do not have a clear role in treating established neutropenic fevers.

Because of resistance, levofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones are not frequently used as initial monotherapy for patients with high-risk neutropenic fever and antiviral agents, such as acyclovir, are used only in patients with immunosuppression (
Option B
). Monotherapy with a fluoroquinolone may have a role in selected low-risk patients eligible for outpatient oral therapy at experienced centers with close monitoring capability.

If a specific source (e.g., central catheter) of infection is suspected, directed antimicrobial therapy can be further broadened, such as by adding gram-positive coverage with vancomycin to piperacillin-tazobactam (
Option D
). This patient has no compelling need to broaden antimicrobial coverage with vancomycin.

objective.__html: Treat neutropenic fever in a patient with leukemia.

references: Zimmer AJ, Freifeld AG. Optimal management of neutropenic fever in patients with cancer. J Oncol Pract. 2019;15:19-24.

title: Question 136

children: A 58-year-old man undergoes a wellness examination. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. He has never smoked cigarettes, does not drink alcohol, and takes no medications. Screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer was performed 8 years ago and was negative. Depression screening is negative. Immunizations are up to date. He has never had screening for prostate cancer.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in prostate cancer screening for this patient?

text.__html: Digital rectal examination and prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing
Measurement of PSA velocity over time
One-time PSA testing at age 60 years
Discussion of prostate cancer screening risks and benefits

children: All major professional organizations encourage patients to discuss the potential harms and benefits of prostate cancer screening with their physician before making individual decisions.
Guidelines recommend not screening for prostate cancer in men who do not express a preference.
The most appropriate next step is to discuss the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening (
Option D

) with this patient. Guidance on screening for prostate cancer among men at average risk is controversial and continues to evolve. Early diagnosis has not been shown to reduce morbidity or mortality due to prostate cancer. Screening carries risks related to prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing as well as harms from subsequent diagnosis and treatment. PSA testing frequently produces false-positive results, as PSA elevation is seen not only in prostate cancer but also in prostatitis and benign prostatic hyperplasia. This can lead to anxiety and unnecessary prostate biopsies. The harms of biopsies include pain, infection, urinary obstruction, and hematospermia. Screening for prostate cancer also leads to overdiagnosis (the diagnosis of cancer that would not become clinically apparent or caused harm in the patient's lifetime), and treatment of these patients exposes them to potential long-term harms, including urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and bowel dysfunction. Thus, all major professional organizations encourage patients to discuss the potential harms and benefits of prostate cancer screening with their physician before making individual decisions. It is reasonable to initiate these conversations at age 50 years with average-risk patients with a life expectancy of at least 10 years.
The patient should not undergo digital rectal examination (
Option A

) for prostate cancer screening due to its poor sensitivity and specificity for prostate cancer. In addition, the physician should discuss the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening before measuring the PSA (
Option A
). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends not screening for prostate cancer in patients who do not express a preference.
Methods for better use of PSA testing, such as PSA velocity (
Option B
) and doubling time, one-time PSA measurement at prespecified ages (
Option C
), and adjusted-threshold testing, are being investigated. However, there is currently insufficient evidence to support these methods.

objective.__html: Discuss risk and benefits of prostate cancer screening.

references: Grossman DC, Curry SJ, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for prostate cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;319:1901-1913.

title: Question 137
