children: A 35-year-old asymptomatic man undergoes screening with abdominal ultrasonography for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Kidneys are normal, but ultrasound shows numerous small gallstones, a normal-appearing gallbladder wall without evidence of polyps, and normal liver.
Following the procedure, the patient affirms he has never experienced biliary colic or unexplained epigastric pain, fever, or jaundice.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

The vast majority of patients with incidentally discovered gallstones remain symptom-free over the next 15 years and rarely develop gallstone-related complications without first having at least one episode of biliary colic.
Patients with asymptomatic gallstones should be observed and their symptoms managed if they arise.
Clinical observation (
Option D

) is appropriate for this patient with an incidental finding of gallstones, which is a frequent finding when patients undergo CT or ultrasonography of the abdomen. This patient has no symptoms of gallstone disease or imaging findings concerning for complications of gallstone disease. Approximately 10% to 20% of the population in most Western countries has gallstones; among them, 50% to 70% are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. Asymptomatic gallstone disease has a benign natural course; 80% of patients remain symptom-free over the next 15 years. Patients rarely develop gallstone-related complications without first having at least one episode of biliary pain (colic); thus, it is appropriate to manage this patient with observation and to manage symptoms if they arise.
Statins such as atorvastatin (
Option A

) reduce cholesterol secretion in bile. Statins have been associated with a reduction in gallbladder disease when used chronically, but there is no evidence that statins can dissolve gallstones. Regardless, no intervention is required for this asymptomatic patient who is at low risk.
Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (
Option B

) may result in fragmentation of select solitary gallstones. Lithotripsy is of uncertain benefit, even in patients with symptomatic gallstones who cannot tolerate cholecystectomy. Complications include biliary colic and gallstone recurrence. Gallstone lithotripsy is not indicated in this asymptomatic patient.
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (
Option C

) is the treatment of choice for symptomatic biliary colic and acute cholecystitis. Among asymptomatic patients, cholecystectomy is indicated for patients at high risk for gallbladder cancer, such as those with gallstones greater than 3 cm in size, porcelain gallbladder (intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall), gallbladder adenomas or polyps greater than 1 cm in size, or anomaly of pancreatic ductal drainage. In the absence of either symptoms or concerning findings on imaging, laparoscopic cholecystectomy is not indicated. Likewise, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is not indicated in this patient.

references: Lam R, Zakko A, Petrov JC, et al. Gallbladder disorders: a comprehensive review. Dis Mon. 2021;67:101130.

title: Question 138

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for persistent fever, cough, and worsening dyspnea after completing appropriate antibiotic therapy for community-acquired pneumonia.

Temperature is 38.1 °C (100.7 °F), pulse rate is 90/min, and respiration rate is 25/min. Breath sounds are decreased over the lower left hemithorax. A lateral decubitus radiograph shows a left-sided, 1.5-cm pleural effusion. Ultrasound shows a pleural effusion with loculations.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Complicated parapneumonic effusion and empyema should be suspected in all patients who do not respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy for pneumonia.
Any pleural effusion greater than 1 cm in depth on a lateral decubitus radiograph that is associated with pneumonia should be investigated with diagnostic thoracentesis.
The most appropriate management is to perform diagnostic thoracentesis (
Option A

). Complicated parapneumonic effusion and empyema should be suspected in all patients who do not respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy for pneumonia. This patient has fever and worsening dyspnea after completing antibiotic therapy for pneumonia, as well as a pleural effusion associated with recent bacterial pneumonia that is consistent with parapneumonic effusion. Any pleural effusion greater than 1 cm in depth on a lateral decubitus radiograph that is associated with pneumonia should be investigated with diagnostic thoracentesis. The radiograph suggests an uncomplicated, free-flowing effusion, but the ultrasound reveals details (including loculations) that indicate a complicated effusion. Diagnostic thoracentesis should be performed, with the resulting fluid examined for pH, cell count with differential, Gram stain, glucose, and culture; culture bottles should be directly inoculated at the bedside to increase yield. Parapneumonic effusions can be uncomplicated (sterile and free flowing) or complicated (infected and typically loculated). Empyema refers to collection of purulent fluid in the pleural space.
Therapeutic thoracentesis (
Option B
), without placement of a drain, is insufficient treatment for complicated parapneumonic effusion. Complicated parapneumonic effusions and empyema recur and require ongoing drainage.

Pleural drainage is indicated if the pleural fluid analysis shows a positive Gram stain (or culture), pus, glucose level less than 40 to 60 mg/dL (2.2-3.3 mmol/L), or pH less than 7.2. Options for drainage include thoracostomy tube (
Option C

) with or without the combined use of intrapleural fibrinolytics (streptokinase, urokinase, tissue plasminogen activator) and a mucolytic agent (deoxyribonuclease, or DNase) or surgical intervention via video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (
Option D
). There is controversy regarding which approach is best. Diagnostic thoracentesis should be performed in this patient before consideration of a drainage strategy.

objective.__html: Diagnose an infection of the pleural space.

references: Feller-Kopman D, Light R. Pleural disease. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:740-751.

children: A 75-year-old man is evaluated for an incidentally discovered elevated hemoglobin level. He has a 1-year history of pruritus without skin rash. He has no other medical problems and has never smoked cigarettes.
Blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. Facial plethora and splenomegaly are present.
Hemoglobin
level is 17.9 g/dL (179 g/L),
leukocyte count
/L), and
platelet count
/L). Urinalysis results are normal.
Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis?
Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by excess erythrocyte mass; leukocytosis and thrombocythemia are also frequently present.
More than 95% of patients with polycythemia vera (PV) have the
JAK2
mutation, so it is an appropriate confirmatory test for suspected PV; serum erythropoietin level should also be measured, because it is usually low in PV.

This patient most likely has polycythemia vera (PV), a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by excess erythrocyte mass, and the diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the erythropoietin level and testing for the
JAK2
V617F mutation (
Option A

). Most patients are incidentally diagnosed with elevated hemoglobin on laboratory studies. Presenting symptoms may include fatigue, headache, generalized pruritus that often worsens after bathing, erythromelalgia (a burning sensation in the palms and soles), hypertension, and arterial/venous thrombosis. On physical examination, patients may have plethora and splenomegaly. Twenty percent of patients have arterial or venous thrombosis as their initial symptom. More than 95% of patients with PV have the
JAK2

mutation, so it is an appropriate confirmatory test for suspected PV. Serum erythropoietin level should also be measured because it is usually low in PV. Bone marrow biopsy shows hypercellular marrow with erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Treatment of PV is required at diagnosis. In addition to receiving antiplatelet and other stroke prevention therapy, if PV is confirmed in this patient, he will have to undergo phlebotomy to normalize his hematocrit concentration (goal <45%). He will also need treatment with the myelosuppressive agent hydroxyurea to decrease thrombotic events.
Kidney ultrasonography (
Option B

) may be used to diagnose renal cell carcinoma. Many different paraneoplastic syndromes may be seen in patients with renal cell carcinoma, including erythrocytosis, anemia, hepatic dysfunction in the absence of liver metastases (known as Stauffer syndrome), fever, hypercalcemia, amyloid A (secondary) amyloidosis, thrombocytosis, and polymyalgia rheumatica. Polycythemia is associated with renal cell carcinoma in 1% to 2% of cases and is a result of increased erythropoietin production. Renal cell carcinoma is not a likely cause of leukocytosis, thrombocythemia, and pruritus.
Peripheral blood flow cytometry (
Option C

) would not add useful information, because this patient has isolated polycythemia and no evidence of abnormal lymphocytes or immature myeloid precursors. Flow cytometry is best used to help establish a diagnosis when evaluating for lymphomas and leukemia.

Most causes of secondary erythrocytosis share the mechanism of an elevated erythropoietin level, which is most commonly driven by hypoxemia. Polycythemia may be the presenting symptom of undiagnosed sleep apnea, and all patients with polycythemia should be screened for symptoms and signs of sleep apnea. However, in this patient with splenomegaly, leukocytosis, and thrombocythemia, PV is much more likely, and measurement of the erythropoietin level and
JAK2
mutational analysis should be performed rather than a sleep study (
Option D

Measurement of the triiodothyronine (T

The serum triiodothyronine (T

and/or T

and/or total T

and T

Once other causes of the laboratory abnormalities have been excluded (thyroid assay interference, thyroid hormone resistance, or familial dysalbuminemic hyperthyroxinemia), a pituitary MRI should be performed. This patient's TSH is suppressed, excluding a TSH-secreting pituitary tumor; pituitary MRI is not indicated (
Option A
A thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibody titer (

) will not provide additional information about this patient. Determining TPO antibody status may be helpful in patients with a mildly elevated TSH level, which suggests the diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis and future risk for permanent hypothyroidism. However, this patient demonstrates signs and symptoms consistent with significant hyperthyroidism.
Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (

title: Question 141

children: A 72-year-old woman is evaluated for short episodes of vertigo. The most severe episodes last less than 1 minute and primarily occur when turning over in bed.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Horizontal nystagmus is observed following the Dix-Hallpike maneuver after a 3-second latency that resolves in 30 seconds. With repeated maneuvers, the nystagmus is more difficult to elicit.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The Dix-Hallpike maneuver indicates a peripheral vertigo when there is a latency period of 2 to 20 seconds before the onset of the positional nystagmus, the duration of nystagmus is less than 1 minute, and the nystagmus is fatigable with repeated Dix-Hallpike maneuvers.
Common causes of peripheral vertigo include benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, vestibular neuronitis, labyrinthitis, and Meniere disease.
This patient has benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) (
Option A

). The first step in the evaluation of a patient with dizziness is to distinguish between its major causes: vertigo, presyncope, or disequilibrium. This patient describes vertigo, which is the sensation that her stationary environment is spinning around her (or that one is spinning around in one's environment). There are two major categories of vertigo: peripheral and central. In addition to history and risk factors, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver is very helpful in distinguishing peripheral from central vertigo. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver indicates a peripheral vertigo when there is a latency period of 2 to 20 seconds before the onset of the positional nystagmus, the duration of nystagmus is less than 1 minute, and the nystagmus is fatigable with repeated Dix-Hallpike maneuvers. This patient has typical symptoms of BPPV, including episodes of vertigo lasting less than 1 minute and provocation by rapid changes in head movement, and the Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the peripheral nature of her vertigo. Other common causes of peripheral vertigo include vestibular neuronitis, labyrinthitis, and Meniere disease.
Cerebellar infarction (
Option B

) is a cause of central vertigo and would cause a different pattern with Dix-Hallpike testing. When performed with a central disorder, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver provokes nystagmus with no latency, the nystagmus usually lasts more than 1 minute, and the nystagmus is not fatigable with repeated testing. In addition, cerebellar infarction usually leads to persistent symptoms (not episodic, like in this patient) and is often accompanied by gait impairment.
Meniere disease (
Option C
) is a cause of peripheral vertigo and can result in recurrent vertigo episodes; however, it is usually accompanied by unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, which is not seen in this patient.
Vestibular neuronitis (
Option D

) is a peripheral cause of vertigo, most often preceded by a viral infection affecting the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. Patients experience rapid onset of severe vertigo commonly associated with nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. Symptoms tend to last longer than those associated with BPPV and are more persistent.

references: Bhattacharyya N, Gubbels SP, Schwartz SR, et al. Clinical practice guideline: benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (update). Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2017;156:S1-S47.

title: Question 142

children: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated before discharge from the hospital following a lateral ST-elevation myocardial infarction treated with percutaneous cardiac intervention and coronary stenting. Medications are aspirin, ticagrelor, carvedilol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and eplerenone. She is currently asymptomatic.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Echocardiogram obtained on admission revealed a
left ventricular ejection fraction
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is indicated for patients with ischemic heart disease and reduced ejection fraction 40 or more days after acute myocardial infarction and 90 or more days after revascularization, while on guideline-directed medical therapy.

Reduced ejection fraction immediately following myocardial infarction may be related to myocardial stunning and can improve over the next few months, especially with guideline-directed medical therapy.
The most appropriate management is to perform echocardiography in 3 months (
Option C

). Patients with reduced ejection fraction due to ischemic cardiomyopathy are at increased risk for sudden cardiac death. Placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is indicated for patients with ischemic heart disease and reduced ejection fraction 40 or more days after acute myocardial infarction and 90 or more days after revascularization, while on guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). Because this patient underwent primary revascularization for acute myocardial infarction, she should be treated with optimal medical therapy, and repeat echocardiography should be performed after 90 days to reassess ejection fraction. Reduced ejection fraction immediately following myocardial infarction may be related to myocardial stunning and can improve over the next few months, especially with GDMT.
Loop diuretics, such as furosemide (
Option A

), are the primary diuretic option for treating patients with heart failure who have volume overload. Furosemide is the most commonly used loop diuretic, although torsemide and bumetanide may be more effective owing to longer half-lives and increased bioavailability. Diuretic therapy may be complicated by electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. In patients who are asymptomatic and without evidence of volume overload, such as this one, diuretic therapy is unnecessary.
The nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers verapamil (
Option B

) and diltiazem are detrimental in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, probably related to negative inotropic effects, and should not be used. Amlodipine and felodipine have shown neither benefit nor harm and can be used in patients with persistent hypertension despite therapy with other agents at maximal dosage.

Arrhythmias are a common cause of death in patients with heart failure, and ICDs improve survival when used for both primary and secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death. Current guidelines recommend ICD placement in patients receiving GDMT who have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less and New York Heart Association functional class II or III heart failure symptoms. It is important to reassess both left ventricular ejection fraction and symptoms after GDMT (40 days after myocardial infarction, 3 months in all others, including following revascularization). Many patients with new-onset heart failure experience substantial improvements in ejection fraction with medical therapy and may not require or benefit from ICD placement (
Option D

J Am Coll Cardiol. 2018;72:e91-e220.

title: Question 143

children: A 49-year-old woman is evaluated for irregular menses for the past 9 months. She is perimenopausal. Her last period was 10 weeks ago and lasted 15 days. She has never been pregnant. Her family and medical history are unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal, as is the pelvic examination. Complete blood count is normal. Urine pregnancy test is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Any abnormal vaginal bleeding occurring in perimenopausal women and bleeding in postmenopausal women warrant evaluation to rule out malignancy, usually with endometrial biopsy.

Transvaginal ultrasonography may have a role in evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding to assess for endometrial thickness, a sign of endometrial hyperplasia, but it is not useful in assessing bleeding in premenopausal or perimenopausal women due to significant variations in endometrial thickness.
The most appropriate management is endometrial biopsy (
Option C

). Any abnormal vaginal bleeding occurring in perimenopausal women and bleeding in postmenopausal women warrant evaluation to rule out malignancy, usually with endometrial biopsy. This patient has an anovulatory pattern of bleeding based on the unpredictable occurrence of bleeding of variable flow and duration. In women with prolonged anovulation, there is exposure to unopposed estrogen without the normal endometrial protective effect of progesterone. This increases the risk for endometrial hyperplasia and malignancy. Additional risk factors for endometrial cancer include age 45 years and older, obesity, and prolonged exposure to estrogen without progesterone other than anovulation (early menarche, nulliparity, late menopause). In women younger than 45 years with anovulatory bleeding and no other risk factors for endometrial cancer, hormonal therapy for anovulation is appropriate. However, in women younger than 45 years with risk factors for endometrial cancer, endometrial biopsy should be performed to exclude significant endometrial pathology. This 49-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding is at higher risk for cancer and should have an endometrial biopsy.

Initial laboratory testing includes a pregnancy test and complete blood count. Additional testing should be based on clinical indications and may include coagulation tests, thyroid stimulation hormone level, iron studies, and hormone levels. This patient with a negative family and personal history of bleeding and no medications known to prolong bleeding time does not require coagulation testing (
Option A

For women with anovulatory cycles, treatment is aimed at providing adequate progestin to maintain endometrial stability. The type of therapy depends on the patient's plans for contraception. For women who wish to preserve fertility, medroxyprogesterone acetate used for the second half of the menstrual cycle will restore cyclic withdrawal bleeding. For women interested in contraception, a combined oral contraceptive pill (
Option B

) containing estrogen and progesterone, the levonorgestrel intrauterine device, or depot medroxyprogesterone may be used. However, prior to treatment, the patient needs an endometrial biopsy to exclude endometrial cancer.
Transvaginal ultrasonography (
Option D

) may have a role in evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding to assess for endometrial thickness, a sign of endometrial hyperplasia, but it is not useful in assessing bleeding in premenopausal or perimenopausal women due to significant variations in endometrial thickness caused by hormonal fluctuation. It is therefore not used routinely for evaluation of premenopausal bleeding unless a structural uterine abnormality is suspected.

objective.__html: Evaluate anovulatory bleeding in a perimenopausal woman.

references: Khafaga A, Goldstein SR. Abnormal uterine bleeding. Obstet Gynecol Clin North Am. 2019;46:595-605.

title: Question 144

children: A 59-year-old man is evaluated because of a 5-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea. Three months ago, he was evaluated for palpitations with transthoracic echocardiogram, which showed normal left ventricular size,
left ventricular ejection fraction
of 65%, and moderate mitral regurgitation.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla. The remainder of the examination is normal.
ECG shows sinus rhythm.
Which of the following is the most appropriate test?
All patients with valvular heart disease should undergo repeat transthoracic echocardiography with any change in clinical status.

In patients with valvular heart disease, transthoracic echocardiography can evaluate valve function and other causes of progressive shortness of breath, such as an interval reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction or new wall motion abnormalities suggestive of myocardial infarction.
Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) (
Option D

) is the most appropriate test in this patient with moderate mitral regurgitation (MR) and a change in clinical status. Periodic TTE is indicated in patients with MR, and frequency is dependent on regurgitation severity, rate of progression, left ventricular ejection fraction, and left ventricular chamber size. All patients should undergo repeat TTE with any change in clinical status. In patients with myxomatous mitral valve disease, rupture of a valve chorda may cause an acute change in the degree of mitral regurgitation. TTE also evaluates other causes of progressive shortness of breath, such as an interval reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction or new wall motion abnormalities suggestive of myocardial infarction.
Measurement of natriuretic peptide levels, such as B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) (
Option A

), provides objective evidence of decompensation in patients with chronic severe MR. Elevated BNP levels indicate increased reliance on preload to maintain an adequate forward cardiac output, and finding elevated levels may be helpful in making management decisions about intervention when other data are conflicting. Although BNP measurement may be necessary in this patient's evaluation at some point in time, the first diagnostic step is to repeat the TTE.
In patients with primary MR, cardiac MRI (
Option B

) is indicated to assess left and right ventricular volumes and function and may help with assessing MR severity when there is a discrepancy between the findings on clinical assessment and echocardiography. Cardiac MRI may also be helpful in cases when TTE image quality is poor. However, in most cases, TTE provides the data needed for adequate cardiac evaluation and should be the first imaging test performed.
Transesophageal echocardiography (
Option C

) is indicated when TTE provides insufficient or discordant information and is needed to evaluate the severity of MR, mechanism of MR, and status of left ventricular function, particularly when surgical or interventional therapy is planned. Transesophageal echocardiography may be especially useful in evaluating for acute MR, in which rapid systolic equalization of left ventricular and atrial pressures can pose challenges for both the bedside examination and TTE. However, the initial management of this patient with a change in clinical status is noninvasive TTE.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient with mitral regurgitation and recent change in clinical status.

references: Otto CM, Nishimura RA, Bonow RO, et al. 2020 ACC/AHA guideline for the management of patients with valvular heart disease: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association joint committee on clinical practice guidelines. Circulation. 2021;143:e72-e227.

title: Question 145

children: A 74-year-old woman is evaluated for increasing cough, dyspnea, and weight loss. She has a 35-pack-year smoking history. She has never been screened for lung cancer with low-dose CT.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Multiple firm nonmobile lymph nodes are palpable in the left supraclavicular space. Breath sounds are diminished in the left upper chest. Chest radiography and subsequent CT scan show a left upper lobe mass and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
