Needle aspiration of the left supraclavicular lymph nodes
Transbronchial biopsy of the left apical mass

children: The most appropriate diagnostic test for lung cancer is one that not only confirms the diagnosis but also provides adequate staging to help plan treatment.
During evaluation of lung cancer, it is important not to miss a concomitant head and neck cancer; smoking is a common risk factor for both lung and head and neck cancer.
The most appropriate next diagnostic test is needle aspiration of the left supraclavicular lymph nodes (
Option B

). Given this patient's significant smoking history and imaging findings of a pulmonary mass and associated lymphadenopathy, she has a high pretest probability of primary lung cancer. The most appropriate diagnostic test is one that not only confirms the diagnosis but also provides adequate staging to help plan treatment. Needle aspiration of the left supraclavicular lymph nodes is the least invasive procedure and would also stage the likely cancer by documenting metastatic disease to these lymph nodes. During evaluation of this patient, it is important not to miss a concomitant head and neck cancer; smoking is a common risk factor for both lung and head and neck cancer. If the patient has high cervical or contralateral cervical lymph nodes, they might need further evaluation to confirm or exclude a second head and neck primary cancer.
CT-guided percutaneous needle biopsy (
Option A

) could potentially diagnose lung cancer in this patient. However, the needle would need to pass through normal lung tissue, which carries a risk for inducing pneumothorax. In addition, CT-guided needle biopsy would not provide information on staging because it would not assess whether there is involvement of the mediastinal or supraclavicular lymph nodes.

PET scans can be very helpful in the initial evaluation of potential lung cancer. Several studies have demonstrated that PET identifies unsuspected mediastinal involvement, distant disease, or both, which informs staging biopsies and reduces futile (noncurative) surgery. This patient has clinically apparent metastatic disease involving the supraclavicular lymph nodes. Needle aspiration of the lymph nodes will likely provide evidence of metastatic disease, which will inform treatment options, obviating the need for a PET scan (
Option C
Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy of the left apical mass (
Option D
) may be technically difficult given the apical position of the mass. More importantly, however, it would not provide any information about possible metastases to the lymph nodes.

objective.__html: Diagnose lung cancer with lymph node biopsy.

references: Rivera MP, Mehta AC, Wahidi MM. Establishing the diagnosis of lung cancer: diagnosis and management of lung cancer, 3rd ed: American College of Chest Physicians evidence-based clinical practice guidelines. Chest. 2013;143:e142S-e165S.

title: Question 146

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 2-month history of intermittent substernal chest pain with exertion that is not consistently relieved with rest. She also has postprandial pain. The patient can walk rapidly without mechanical or respiratory limitation. She has hypertension controlled with lisinopril.
On physical examination, vital signs and cardiopulmonary examination are normal. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and 1.5-mm nonspecific ST-segment depression in the anterior and lateral leads.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Exercise ECG is a reasonable option as the initial test in patients with intermediate probability of coronary artery disease and normal findings on baseline ECG.

If there are baseline ECG abnormalities, ST-segment changes with exercise cannot be used to evaluate for the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease; functional testing with imaging or anatomic assessment with coronary CT angiography is indicated in these instances.
This patient should undergo exercise myocardial perfusion imaging (
Option D

) to evaluate for coronary artery disease (CAD). The decision to order a specific stress test is based on the pretest probability of CAD, the patient's ability to exercise, findings on the resting ECG, and the presence of comorbid conditions. This patient's age, sex, and atypical chest pain place her pretest probability of CAD at 51%; therefore, it would be most appropriate to start with noninvasive testing to establish a diagnosis. An exercise myocardial perfusion test is the best option because she is able to exercise and has abnormalities on her resting ECG.
If this patient were unable to adequately exercise, a pharmacologic stress test, such as dobutamine echocardiography (
Option A

), would be indicated. Options for pharmacologic stress agents include adenosine, dipyridamole, dobutamine, and regadenoson. Adenosine and dipyridamole are both contraindicated in patients with reactive airways disease.

The development of chest pain from an esophageal cause can mimic chest pain from cardiac disease. Once a cardiac cause is ruled out, the most common cause of chest pain is gastroesophageal reflux disease. Starting a course of an acid-reducing agent, such as esomeprazole (
Option B
), can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. However, the initial evaluation should focus on life-threatening conditions of chest pain, and this patient should first be evaluated for CAD.
Exercise ECG (
Option C

) is a reasonable option as the initial test in patients with normal findings on baseline ECG, although it is less accurate than stress testing with imaging. If there are baseline ECG abnormalities (such as ST-segment depression >1 mm, left bundle branch block, left ventricular hypertrophy, paced rhythm, or preexcitation), ST-segment changes with exercise cannot be used to evaluate for the presence of obstructive CAD; these abnormalities will result in a nondiagnostic ECG stress test. Functional testing with imaging (with exercise or pharmacologic stress) or anatomic assessment with coronary CT angiography is indicated in these instances.

objective.__html: Evaluate chest pain with noninvasive stress testing.

references: Alderwish E, Schultz E, Kassam Z, et al. Evaluation of acute chest pain: evolving paradigm of coronary risk scores and imaging. Rev Cardiovasc Med. 2019;20:231-244.

title: Question 147

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for excessive water ingestion and urinary frequency. She has bipolar disorder and pulmonary sarcoidosis. Current medications include lithium and low-dose glucocorticoids.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The remainder of the examination is normal. Blood
glucose
level is 108 mg/dL (5.9 mmol/L),
serum sodium
level is 152 mEq/L (152 mmol/L), and urine osmolality is 117 mOsm/kg H
O. Antidiuretic hormone level is inappropriately low.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Patients with hyperosmolality who have submaximally concentrated urine without evidence of osmotic diuresis have diabetes insipidus by definition.

Distinguishing between central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) in a patient with hyperosmolality can be done by measuring antidiuretic hormone levels (patients with central DI have an inappropriately low level, whereas patients with nephrogenic DI have a normal to elevated level) or by evaluating the response to administering the vasopressor analogue desmopressin.
The most likely cause of this patient's hypernatremia is central diabetes insipidus (DI) (
Option A
). This patient has elevated serum osmolality, as estimated by multiplying the serum sodium level by 2 (304 mOsm/kg H
O) (normal, 275-295 mOsm/kg H

O). The appropriate kidney response to hyperosmolality is to retain free water, which results in urine osmolality greater than serum osmolality. This response is not seen in this patient (urine osmolality is low compared with serum osmolality); therefore, she has either DI or osmotic diuresis. Patients with hyperosmolality who have submaximally concentrated urine without evidence of osmotic diuresis have DI by definition. The patient's glucose concentration is normal, arguing against osmotic diuresis. Distinguishing between central and nephrogenic DI in a patient who already demonstrates hyperosmolality can be done by measuring antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels (patients with central DI have an inappropriately low level, whereas patients with nephrogenic DI have a normal to elevated level) or by evaluating the response to administering the vasopressor analogue desmopressin (arginine vasopressin). A significant increase in urine osmolality (>50%) within 1 to 2 hours after administration indicates central DI, whereas a lack of response indicates nephrogenic DI. Central DI can result from tumors that invade the hypothalamus, infiltrating diseases such as sarcoidosis, or surgical destruction. Nephrogenic DI can be caused by medications (for example, lithium), hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, sickle cell disease and trait, and amyloidosis. Central DI can be treated with intranasal or oral desmopressin.
The patient's antidiuretic hormone measurement is inappropriately low, ruling out the diagnosis of nephrogenic DI (
Option B
An osmotic diuresis is most often caused by hyperglycemia (
Option C

). This patient's plasma glucose level is normal. Furthermore, solute diuresis is usually characterized by isotonicity of the urine, whereas this patient has markedly hypotonic urine. Consequently, an osmotic diuresis is an unlikely cause of his hypernatremia.
Patients with primary polydipsia also manifest polyuria and polydipsia but do not develop hypernatremia and hyperosmolality (
Option D
). These patients may develop hyponatremia and typically have a clearly identifiable psychiatric illness.

references: Seay NW, Lehrich RW, Greenberg A. Diagnosis and management of disorders of body tonicity-hyponatremia and hypernatremia: core curriculum 2020. Am J Kidney Dis. 2020;75:272-86.

title: Question 148

children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated following a wasp sting and the development of cough and dyspnea.

Blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 109/min, and respiration rate is 28/min. Diffuse wheezing and coughing are present. No stridor, rash, or swelling of the face, tongue, or oropharynx is noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The initial treatment of anaphylaxis is intramuscular epinephrine, repeated as needed every 5 to 15 minutes.
Neither antihistamines nor glucocorticoids have been shown to improve outcomes in anaphylaxis.
The most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient experiencing anaphylaxis from a hypersensitivity reaction to insect venom is intramuscular (IM) epinephrine (
Option A

). In addition, this patient should receive basic life support measures with high-flow oxygen, cardiac monitoring, recumbent positioning, and establishment of intravenous (IV) access with IV fluid administration as needed. Concerns include airway obstruction, bronchospasm, and distributive shock. Of these, the patient has evidence only of bronchospasm at this time, but she should be monitored for the other manifestations of anaphylaxis. The initial treatment of anaphylaxis is IM epinephrine, repeated as needed every 5 to 15 minutes, preferably in the anterolateral thigh. Patients with wheezing unresponsive to IM epinephrine should also receive treatment with an inhaled β

-agonist, such as albuterol. If airway closure appears to be a threat and is not responsive to initial treatment with epinephrine, immediate intubation of the trachea is advisable. Patients with a history of anaphylactic reactions should carry an epinephrine autoinjector, wear an alert bracelet to let responders know of their hypersensitivity, and be referred to an immunologist/allergist for possible venom immunotherapy.
Neither IV antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (
Option B
), nor IV glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone (
Options D

), have been shown to improve outcomes in anaphylaxis, and these agents would not reverse this patient's bronchospasm quickly enough. When these agents are used, it is usually to decrease pruritus and rash or to prevent a delayed recurrence of symptoms. However, guidelines suggest against administering glucocorticoids or antihistamines as an intervention to prevent biphasic anaphylaxis.
Slow IV infusion of epinephrine (
Option C

) may be indicated for patients with refractory hypotension. This patient has only mild hypotension; therefore, an IV infusion of epinephrine, with its associated risks for arrhythmia, rapid and uncontrolled increase in blood pressure, myocardial infarction, and stroke, is not warranted.

objective.__html: Treat anaphylaxis secondary to stinging insect bite.

references: Shaker MS, Wallace DV, Golden DBK, et al; Collaborators. Anaphylaxis-a 2020 practice parameter update, systematic review, and Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) analysis. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2020;145:1082-1123.

title: Question 149

children: A 60-year-old woman is evaluated after fecal immunochemical test obtained for colorectal cancer screening was positive. A routine screening colonoscopy performed at the age of 50 years was normal. She has no gastrointestinal symptoms. She has no other medical problems that would increase her colorectal cancer risk, and she takes no medications. Family history is unremarkable.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The remainder of the examination is normal. Complete blood count is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?
Any single positive stool test for colorectal cancer should prompt diagnostic colonoscopy.
This patient should have colonoscopy now (
Option A

). Any single positive stool test for colorectal cancer should prompt diagnostic colonoscopy. The fecal immunochemical test (FIT) has improved accuracy compared with guaiac fecal occult blood test, but the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force has reported that sensitivity remains only about 73% to 88%, with specificity ranges from 91% to 96%. The lower sensitivity is the main indication for performing stool-based FIT screening at least every other year. This woman with average risk for colorectal cancer and a positive FIT screening result should be advised to have diagnostic colonoscopy.
The U.S. Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer recommends CT colonography (
Option B

) as a second-tier test for colorectal cancer screening every 5 years in average-risk patients. CT colonography provides a computer-simulated endoluminal perspective of the air-inflated colon. As for colonoscopy, bowel preparation is required. Colonoscopy is more accurate in the diagnosis of colorectal cancer compared with colonography and has the added ability to biopsy suspicious lesions; CT colonography is only an imaging test, and biopsy cannot be performed.
Repeat FIT (
Option C

) may result in a false-negative result because of the test's lower sensitivity than specificity; repeat FIT should not be used to delay or avoid diagnostic colonoscopy. Repeat FIT every other year is appropriate for continued screening when FIT results are negative, but in this woman with a positive FIT result, a diagnostic colonoscopy should not be delayed for repeat FIT.
Stool DNA testing (
Option D

) increases sensitivity but lowers specificity for detection of colon cancer. In this patient with a positive FIT result, stool DNA testing would not provide added diagnostic information. A negative result from a less specific stool DNA test would not negate the concern for colorectal cancer raised by this patient's more specific FIT result.

references: Qaseem A, Crandall CJ, Mustafa RA, et al; Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians. Screening for colorectal cancer in asymptomatic average-risk adults: a guidance statement from the American College of Physicians.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 150

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for decreased food intake and weight loss. He has advanced Lewy body dementia and lives in an extended care facility. He no longer interacts verbally with staff or family and eats less than half his meal when fed a regular diet. He is edentulous.
BMI is 17.5; weight is 6% less than it was 6 months ago.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his weight loss?

text.__html: Several small feedings throughout the day

children: Malignancy, gastrointestinal disorders, and psychiatric conditions (including dementia) are the most common causes of weight loss in elderly patients when a cause is identified; in 15% to 20% of patients, no cause is found.
Recommended first-line treatment strategies in elderly patients with weight loss include diet modification to address patient preferences and swallowing and chewing issues.
Diet modification (
Option A

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient. Unintentional weight loss occurs in 15% to 20% of elderly persons and is associated with increased risk for hospitalization, skilled nursing facility placement, and mortality. Some weight loss is expected with normal aging, but loss of more than 5% of body weight in a 6- to 12-month time period should be investigated. Malignancy, gastrointestinal disorders, and psychiatric conditions (including dementia) are the most common causes when a cause is identified. However, in 15% to 20% of patients, no cause is found. Recommended first-line treatment strategies in these patients include diet modification to address patient preferences and swallowing and chewing issues. This patient is edentulous; modification to a soft diet that does not require chewing would be appropriate. Other strategies of potential benefit include nutritional supplements (in addition to, rather than instead of, meals) and flavor enhancers. In patients in communal living situations, such as skilled nursing facilities, modification of the dining environment to resemble the home environment has been shown to improve caloric intake.
Mirtazapine (
Option B

) is a serotonin agonist antidepressant that improves appetite and promotes weight gain when used to treat depression. Adverse effects, including orthostasis and increased fall risk, limit use in older adults. It has not been specifically studied to promote weight gain in the absence of depression.
The use of enteral or parenteral artificial nutritional support (
Option C
) in patients with limited life expectancy or at the end of life does not improve survival, is invasive, and can cause side effects.

Many clinical nutrition guidelines generally recommend 6 to 10 feedings per day for patients with early satiety and anorexia due to chronic pancreatitis and gastroparesis, or those who are receiving chemotherapy. There is no clear indication for several small feedings throughout the day (
Option D
) for this patient.

objective.__html: Treat weight loss in a geriatric patient with dementia.

references: Perera LAM, Chopra A, Shaw AL. Approach to patients with unintentional weight loss. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:175-186.

title: Question 151

children: A 27-year-old woman is seen in the office for a routine evaluation. She is at 20 weeks' gestation. She delivered her first child 20 months ago. During her previous pregnancy, she received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine. She is currently up to date on all her immunizations.
Which of the following is the best timing for repeat Tdap immunization?

text.__html: Ten years after her last dose

children: Pregnant women should receive a single dose of the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine during each pregnancy, regardless of when they last received either the tetanus and diphtheria or Tdap vaccine; optimal administration is between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation.
This pregnant patient should receive the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine in 7 to 16 weeks (
Option B

). To decrease the burden of pertussis in infants (who are at greatest risk for the disease), the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommends that pregnant women receive a single dose of the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, regardless of when they last received either the tetanus and diphtheria (Td) or Tdap vaccine. Because maternal immunity wanes over time, administering the Tdap vaccine between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation is thought to provide optimal protection against pertussis for the infant throughout the newborn period, during which time the child is solely dependent on maternal antibodies for protection, by boosting the mother's antibody levels. The Td and Tdap vaccines do not contain live elements and are considered safe to administer to pregnant women; there is no evidence to suggest an increased rate of adverse events in this population.

Although the Tdap vaccine can be given at any point during a woman's pregnancy, administering the vaccine between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation is thought to confer maximal antibody protection to newborn infants. It is not advisable to wait until after 36 weeks of pregnancy (
Option A
Administration of Tdap now (
Option C
) will not provide optimal protection against pertussis for the infant throughout the newborn period.

The recommended interval for tetanus vaccination for nonpregnant adults is every 10 years. Either the Td or Tdap vaccine can be used for the decennial booster. However, this strategy does not confer protection to the newborn, so this interval is not adequate for the neonate (
Option D

). Although this patient received the Tdap vaccine during her first pregnancy, that vaccination is unlikely to provide sufficient protection for her second child at the time of delivery because antibody levels wane significantly during the first year after vaccination.

objective.__html: Administer the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine during pregnancy.

references: Freedman MS, Ault K, Bernstein H. Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommended immunization schedule for adults aged 19 years or older - United States, 2021. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2021;70:193-196.

title: Question 152

children: A 77-year-old woman is evaluated for generalized weakness and diarrhea, paresthesia of the hands and feet, and perioral numbness. She has alcohol use disorder.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 18. Spontaneous carpopedal spasm is present, and muscle spasm can be demonstrated by percussion of the facial nerve.
Laboratory studies:
Albumin
Calcium
6.5 mg/dL (1.6 mmol/L)
L
Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL (97.2 µmol/L)
Potassium
2.8 mEq/L (2.8 mmol/L)
L
ECG shows QT prolongation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
Hypomagnesemia impairs the release of parathyroid hormone and results in renal potassium wasting.
In patients with hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia, it is crucial to correct the magnesium level, as it is difficult to increase potassium or calcium levels until this is done.
This patient's serum magnesium level (
Option C

) should be measured. She has a very low serum calcium level that is likely contributing to the clinical findings and ECG changes. She also has alcohol use disorder, and magnesium deficiency is common in persons with alcohol use disorder. This patient's diarrhea will also deplete her magnesium stores. Her low serum calcium level should stimulate parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion to help correct the hypocalcemia. However, decreased levels of magnesium impair release of PTH; levels in patients with significant magnesium deficiency are either low or inappropriately normal. Low magnesium levels are also associated with resistance to PTH activity at the level of bone, further contributing to hypocalcemia. In addition, hypomagnesemia causes hypokalemia due to renal potassium wasting. Therefore, in patients with hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia, it is crucial to correct the magnesium level, as it is difficult to increase potassium or calcium levels until this is done.
Measuring 24-hour urine calcium excretion (
Option A

) in this patient would not be diagnostically helpful because significant urinary loss of calcium is uncommon, and the urine calcium level in this patient would be expected to be low due to compensatory kidney retention of calcium.
Ionized calcium measurement (
Option B

) is indicated in the setting of fluctuating acid/base status or low albumin levels. This patient with low total calcium also has symptoms (paresthesia), physical examination findings (carpopedal spasm, muscle irritability), and ECG findings of hypocalcemia. A serum ionized calcium level will add little diagnostic information.

The initial response to a decline in serum calcium is an increase in PTH secretion. Low or inappropriately normal PTH suggests hypoparathyroidism. However, hypomagnesemia causes functional, reversible parathyroid hypofunction and must be excluded before a low or inappropriately normal PTH level (
Option D
) is attributed to hypoparathyroidism.

objective.__html: Identify hypomagnesemia as a cause of hypocalcemia.

references: Ahmed F, Mohammed A. Magnesium: the forgotten electrolyte-a review on hypomagnesemia. Med Sci (Basel). 2019;7.

title: Question 153

children: A 19-year-old man is evaluated for redness over the right leg at the site of an abrasion obtained while playing soccer 5 days ago. He is otherwise well and takes no medications.
Temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F); all other vital signs are normal. There is a warm and tender erythematous 6 × 3-cm patch on the right leg without purulence.
Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric therapy?
Treatment of skin and soft tissue infections is guided by categorizing the infection as purulent or nonpurulent and by grading the severity of the infection as mild, moderate, or severe.

Mild nonpurulent cellulitis is most likely caused by β-hemolytic streptococci; empiric outpatient treatment with a β-lactam agent (such as penicillin VK, a cephalosporin, or dicloxacillin) or clindamycin is recommended.

This patient has mild cellulitis, a nonpurulent skin and soft tissue infection that is most likely caused by β-hemolytic streptococci. Empiric outpatient treatment with a β-lactam agent (such as penicillin VK [
Option C

], a cephalosporin, or dicloxacillin) or clindamycin is recommended. Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection involving the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues; it is most frequently associated with dermatologic conditions involving breaks in the skin, such as eczema, tinea pedis, or chronic skin ulcers, and conditions leading to chronic lymphedema, such as mastectomy with lymph node dissection or saphenous vein grafting in bypass surgery. Cellulitis should be suspected in patients with acute-onset spreading erythema, edema, pain or tenderness, and warmth. Fever, although common, is not uniformly present. Patients with severe disease may have associated systemic toxicity. Cellulitis is a clinical diagnosis, although cultures of any drainage should be performed for those who are immunocompromised, exhibit severe sepsis, or have unusual precipitating circumstances, including immersion injury or animal bites. The most common pathogens are β-hemolytic streptococci, especially group A β-hemolytic
Streptococcus
(GABHS). GABHS is most often associated with nonpurulent cellulitis, whereas
Staphylococcus aureus

causes purulent skin infections, such as abscesses, furuncles, and carbuncles. Treatment of skin and soft tissue infections is guided by categorizing the infection as purulent or nonpurulent and by grading the severity of the infection as mild, moderate, or severe.
Intravenous daptomycin (
Option A
) or oral or intravenous linezolid (
Option B

) are appropriate for severe purulent skin infections (failed oral therapy; systemic signs of infection; immunocompromise; or signs of deep tissue infection, such as abscess). This patient has a mild nonpurulent skin infection that can be treated with a β-lactam agent, such as oral penicillin VK.
In patients with systemic signs (moderate infection), intravenous treatment is recommended. An antibiotic such as vancomycin (
Option D
) with coverage against streptococci and methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus

(MRSA) is recommended if nonpurulent cellulitis is associated with penetrating trauma, nasal colonization or infection with MRSA elsewhere, or injection drug use. Intravenous vancomycin is also appropriate for patients with severe purulent skin infections. This patient has no indication for intravenous vancomycin.

references: Bystritsky R, Chambers H. Cellulitis and soft tissue infections.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 154

children: A 51-year-old woman is screened for breast cancer. She is healthy and has no breast symptoms or family or personal history of cancer. Previous breast cancer screening demonstrated dense breast tissue and no other abnormalities. Menarche was at age 13 years, and she is now perimenopausal. She gave birth to two children at maternal ages 19 and 24 years.
Breast examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate breast cancer screening test for this patient?
Digital mammography is recommended as the breast cancer screening test for average-risk women with dense breasts.
MRI is not recommended for either primary screening or as a supplemental test for average-risk women with increased breast density.
This patient with high breast density should undergo routine digital screening mammography (
Option C

). High breast density is common, occurring in up to 50% of women. Women with high breast density have an increased risk for breast cancer (relative risk of 1.2 for heterogeneously dense breast tissue, relative risk of 2.1 for extremely dense breast tissue) but not breast cancer–related mortality. High breast density also decreases the sensitivity of film mammography to detect small lesions. Digital mammography has an increased sensitivity for detecting small lesions in dense breasts compared with film mammography; it is therefore the preferred modality for routine screening, if available.
MRI (
Option A

) is not recommended for either primary screening or as a supplemental test for average-risk women with increased breast density due to a lack of documented effectiveness and a high false-positive rate leading to unnecessary biopsies. However, women with dense breasts and other risk factors that impart a lifetime risk for breast cancer of 20% to 25% or higher, as calculated by models largely dependent on family history, should undergo breast MRI in addition to screening mammography.
Digital breast tomosynthesis (
Option B

), also known as 3-D mammography, uses a moving x-ray source and a digital detector to capture breast images at different angles. A computer algorithm reconstructs the two-dimensional images into a three-dimensional image of the breast. Digital breast tomosynthesis exposes the patient to twice as much radiation as conventional mammography. There are no clinical studies comparing standard mammography to digital breast tomosynthesis, and it is not considered the standard of care for average-risk women with dense breasts.
Breast ultrasonography (
Option D

) is recommended by some organizations as a supplemental test in addition to mammography in women with dense breasts; however, up to 90% of positive results on supplemental ultrasonography are false-positive findings. No prospective trials of breast ultrasonography as a primary screening modality currently exist, and the role of ultrasonography as a supplemental test to mammography has not been clearly defined. It is therefore not recommended as a replacement for digital mammography.

objective.__html: Screen for breast cancer in a patient with high breast density.

references: Qaseem A, Lin JS, Mustafa RA, et al; Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians. Screening for breast cancer in average-risk women: a guidance statement from the American College of Physicians.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 155

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless vulvar lesion that developed 3 days ago. History is notable for multiple unprotected sexual encounters during the past 6 months.
Vital signs are normal. The vulvar lesion is
shown
. Bilateral, nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. No other lesions or discharge are noted. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Syphilitic chancres are most frequently single lesions, but multiple lesions may occur; lesions are generally painless, and the border of the ulcer is raised with a firm, indurated consistency.
Treatment for primary syphilis is a single injection of benzathine penicillin.
This patient's clinical presentation and examination findings are most consistent with a syphilitic chancre (
Option D

). Chancres are most frequently single lesions, but multiple lesions may occur. The lesions are generally painless, and the border of the ulcer is raised with a firm, indurated consistency. Chancres are frequently accompanied by regional inguinal lymphadenopathy. The incidence of primary and secondary syphilis in the United States has increased among certain populations, especially young men who have sex with men, commercial sex workers, and patients with HIV infection. Because the method needed to demonstrate
Treponema pallidum

organisms in clinical specimens is not available in most settings (dark-field examination), the clinical diagnosis can be confirmed by serologic testing. However, findings on serum rapid plasma reagin testing are frequently negative in primary syphilis. Treatment of primary syphilis with a single injection of intramuscular benzathine penicillin is recommended. Without treatment, primary lesions will spontaneously regress within 3 to 6 weeks before the disease moves into later stages. This patient should be offered HIV testing, screening for gonorrhea and chlamydia, and counseling on risk reduction. In addition to syphilis, the differential diagnosis of genital ulcer disease includes chancroid and herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Secondary bacterial infection of traumatic genital lesions may also have the appearance of an ulcer.
Chancroid (
Option A

) causes single or multiple painful ulcers with a ragged border. The base of the ulcer has a granulomatous appearance, frequently with a purulent exudate. This patient does not have symptoms or findings of chancroid.
HSV infection (
Option B
) generally presents with multiple painful ulcers that were initially vesicular on an erythematous base.
Human papillomavirus infection (
Option C
) causes genital warts, not ulcerative lesions.

references: Workowski KA, Bachmann LH, Chan PA, et al. Sexually transmitted infections treatment guidelines, 2021. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2021;70:1-187.

title: Question 156

children: A 54-year-old woman is evaluated for tremor that has gradually worsened over several years. The tremor involves both hands and the head and is most noticeable when writing, reading a newspaper, or drinking from a cup. Her tremors improve after drinking wine. She takes no medications.
Examination is remarkable only for symmetric action tremor in the hands and arms. She also demonstrates a “yes-yes” bobbing of the head, and her voice is tremulous.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

In patients with essential tremor, tremor is often noted in outstretched arm position and with activities, such as writing or use of utensils, but is absent at rest and characteristically improves with alcohol; a positive family history is often present.
First-line therapies for essential tremor are propranolol and primidone.
This patient has a symmetric action tremor in the upper extremities and head consistent with essential tremor (
Option B

). Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder. This type of tremor is often noted in outstretched arm position and with activities, such as writing or use of utensils, but is absent at rest. Tremor can involve other parts of the body, including the head and vocal cords. Tremor characteristically improves with ethanol use. There is often, although not universally, a positive family history. This patient's otherwise normal neurologic examination rules out alternative diagnoses such as Parkinson disease or dystonia. Assessment of any form of action tremor should include thyroid and renal function studies, liver chemistries, serum electrolytes, and a review of medications. Patients younger than 40 years should undergo screening for Wilson disease with serum ceruloplasmin and 24-hour urine copper measurements. First-line therapies for essential tremor are propranolol and primidone. In severe medication-refractory essential tremor, neurosurgical treatments can be helpful.
Enhanced physiologic tremor (
Option A

) is a low-amplitude action tremor that is often associated with medications, stress, caffeine, or other triggers. This tremor often has an intermittent or fluctuating course and resolves with removal of underlying triggers. There is no indication of typical stressors in this patient, and she is not on any medications. Additionally, presence of head tremor, tremulous voice, and improvement of tremor with ethanol are features of essential tremor and are not typical for enhanced physiologic tremor.
Tardive dyskinesia (
Option C

) is an extrapyramidal complication of dopamine receptor–blocking medications (e.g., first- or second-generation antipsychotic drugs, metoclopramide). It is associated with characteristic choreiform and dystonic craniofacial movements, which often involve other body parts, such as the neck and trunk. Other movements, such as tremor, myoclonus, and akathisia (restlessness), can also be part of a tardive syndrome. Treatment involves removal of the offending medication. This patient does not manifest either choreiform or dystonic movements and is not taking any medications, making the diagnosis of tardive dyskinesia unlikely.
Parkinson disease (
Option D

) is characterized by an asymmetric rest tremor along with other cardinal features, including bradykinesia, rigidity, and changes in gait and balance. Isolated action tremor is not consistent with Parkinson disease.

references: Haubenberger D, Hallett M. Essential tremor. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:1802-10.

title: Question 157

children: A 22-year-old man is evaluated for a 9-month history of overwhelming and uncontrollable anxiety associated with insomnia and difficulty concentrating, all of which interfere with his work. His last performance evaluation was concerning for possible termination. He lies awake at night thinking about career issues and personal concerns.
Depression screening is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about various events or activities for at least 6 months, difficulty exercising control over worrying, the presence of several symptoms associated with the anxiety (fatigue, irritability, restlessness, sleep disturbance, or difficulty concentrating), and functional impairment.

Cognitive behavioral therapy, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin–norepinephrine receptor inhibitors are equally effective first-line therapies for treating patients with generalized anxiety disorder.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) (
Option A

). His presentation is characteristic of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). GAD is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about various events or activities for at least 6 months, difficulty exercising control over worrying, the presence of several symptoms associated with the anxiety (fatigue, irritability, restlessness, sleep disturbance, or difficulty concentrating), and functional impairment. Psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are equally effective in treating patients with GAD. CBT is the psychotherapy of choice. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin–norepinephrine receptor inhibitors (SNRIs) have proven efficacy in treating GAD, are relatively safe and well tolerated, and are approved by the FDA for this indication.
Some evidence suggests that imipramine (
Option B

), a tricyclic antidepressant, may be effective in treating GAD. This antidepressant causes anticholinergic adverse effects and has the potential to cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias. Imipramine may be considered for GAD that is unresponsive to first-line therapy (SSRI/SNRI) and second-line therapy (benzodiazepines, buspirone, or pregabalin).
Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam (
Option C

), are also approved for treating GAD. Benzodiazepines, however, may cause dependence and tolerance, and adverse effects include sedation and impaired cognition, which would likely be unacceptable to this patient. Benzodiazepines are considered second-line therapy to CBT, SSRIs, and SNRIs.
Pregabalin (
Option D

) is effective in some patients with GAD and may be associated with shorter response time than SSRIs or SNRIs; however, dependency potential exists, and adverse effects of sedation and anticholinergic symptoms may limit use. Pregabalin is generally considered second-line therapy.

references: DeMartini J, Patel G, Fancher TL. Generalized anxiety disorder.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 158

children: Stem

A 58-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-year history of slowly progressive dysphagia with both solid food and liquids and regurgitation of undigested food without associated heartburn, weight loss, or chest pain. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol, and there is no significant travel history outside of the United States.
Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Patients with achalasia present with slowly progressive dysphagia occurring with both solids and liquids along with nonacidic regurgitation of undigested food.
Guidelines recommend performing upper endoscopy in all patients with suspected achalasia to exclude neoplastic pseudoachalasia.
The most likely diagnosis is achalasia (
Option A

). Patients with achalasia present with dysphagia occurring with both solids and liquids along with nonacidic regurgitation of undigested food. Additional symptoms may include heartburn, weight loss, and chest pain unresponsive to acid-reducing agents. Symptoms are slowly progressive, with patients waiting an average of 5 years before seeking medical attention. Achalasia is a hypertonic motility condition defined by inadequate relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and aperistalsis. Achalasia can be idiopathic or associated with viral, autoimmune, or neurodegenerative disorders and infection (Chagas disease). Damage to the ganglion cells and myenteric plexus in the esophageal body and LES leads to uncontested cholinergic nerve activation, which prevents LES relaxation. Approaches to the treatment of achalasia include endoscopic (botulinum toxin, pneumatic dilation, peroral endoscopic myotomy) or surgical intervention with the goal of lowering LES pressure, which relieves symptoms. Medical therapy with nitrates and calcium channel blockers is ineffective and not recommended.
Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) (
Option B

) is commonly associated with dysphagia and food bolus obstruction, which may be recurrent. Most patients are diagnosed between the second and fifth decades of life, and EoE is more common in men. Patients often have other atopic conditions, such as asthma, rhinitis, dermatitis, and seasonal or food allergies. This patient's slowly progressive dysphagia for both solid food and liquids and regurgitation of undigested food are not compatible with the diagnosis of EoE.
This patient has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. Dysphagia occurring with solids alone suggests a mechanical obstruction, such as esophageal web (
Option C

), whereas dysphagia with either liquids alone or the combination of liquids and solids favors a motility disorder. Dysphagia that progresses from occurring with solids alone to occurring with both solids and liquids suggests malignancy.
Neoplastic pseudoachalasia (
Option D

) is a result of malignant tumor infiltration of the gastroesophageal junction or other secondary causes. It can present similarly to achalasia; however, unlike achalasia, this condition progresses rapidly and has been associated with sudden weight loss later in life, usually after age 50 years. Guidelines recommend performing upper endoscopy in all patients with suspected achalasia to exclude neoplastic pseudoachalasia. Other diagnostic modalities to exclude pseudoachalasia include endoscopic ultrasonography and CT. A 5-year history of dysphagia would not be compatible with cancer.

references: Zaninotto G, Bennett C, Boeckxstaens G, et al. The 2018 ISDE achalasia guidelines. Dis Esophagus. 2018;31.

title: Question 159

children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated during follow-up for an unprovoked proximal leg deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The DVT was diagnosed 3 months ago, and anticoagulation therapy initiated at that time. She has tolerated the treatment well, she has no other medical problems, and her risk for bleeding is estimated to be low. Her only medication is rivaroxaban.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Continue rivaroxaban for another 3 months, then discontinue

children: Extended anticoagulant therapy is recommended in patients with unprovoked proximal leg deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism who have a low or moderate bleeding risk.

Short-term anticoagulant therapy (3-6 months) is suggested for patients with venous thromboembolism associated with a major transient risk factor, those with unprovoked distal leg deep venous thrombosis, and those with unprovoked proximal leg deep venous thrombosis who are at high risk for bleeding.
This patient should be offered extended anticoagulation therapy (
Option C

). Because her venous thromboembolism (VTE) was unprovoked, she is at relatively high risk for recurrence, in the range of 10% in the first year and 5% per year afterward, without anticoagulation. Treatment with full-dose anticoagulation has been shown to decrease this recurrence by about 90%. Based on her history, absence of comorbid conditions, and age, her bleeding risk is low. In addition to risks for recurrence and bleeding, patient preference should also be considered in deciding on long-term anticoagulation. The decision to treat this patient for an extended period is consistent with current guidelines, which suggest extended anticoagulant therapy in patients with unprovoked proximal leg deep venous thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism who have low or moderate bleeding risk. Guidelines also suggest considering reduced-dose anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant (apixaban or rivaroxaban) when opting for extended anticoagulation therapy. Reevaluation of this indication based on periodic risk/benefit assessments, new clinical study data, and new anticoagulation drug availability is appropriate.

Short-term anticoagulant therapy (3-6 months) is suggested for patients with VTE associated with a major transient risk factor, those with unprovoked distal leg DVT, and those with unprovoked proximal leg DVT who are at high risk for bleeding. Therefore, discontinuing treatment now (
Option B
) or after another 3 months (
Option A
) would not be the optimal approach for this patient with unprovoked proximal DVT.

Identification of an inherited thrombophilia often does not change treatment decisions in a patient with VTE, because it does not reliably predict risk for recurrence or influence the duration of recommended anticoagulation; therefore, evidence-based guidelines recommend against routine thrombophilia testing (
Option D

). In this patient with an unprovoked proximal DVT, the recommendation for long-term anticoagulation would not be altered by the results of such testing; thus, it would not be helpful. Testing may be indicated, however, in patients with VTE at intermediate risk for recurrence by traditional predictors, in whom finding a strong thrombophilic risk might alter therapeutic decisions. Finally, some tests for thrombophilia are inaccurate in patients receiving anticoagulation treatment, so these studies should be performed when the patient is not taking anticoagulants.

objective.__html: Determine the length of anticoagulation therapy in a patient with venous thromboembolism disease.

references: Ortel TL, Neumann I, Ageno W, et al. American Society of Hematology 2020 guidelines for management of venous thromboembolism: treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Blood Adv. 2020;4:4693-4738.

title: Question 160

children: A 53-year-old woman is evaluated during a wellness visit. She is asymptomatic. All immunizations are up to date. Colonoscopy for colorectal cancer screening and primary high-risk human papillomavirus testing for cervical cancer screening were completed 3 years ago, and mammography for breast cancer screening was completed 1 year ago. All results were negative. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago.
Physical examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test to perform?

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose CT in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years.
Low-dose chest CT (
Option B

) is the most appropriate screening test for this patient. Seventy-five percent of patients with lung cancer present with metastatic or advanced local disease and have a poor prognosis. At the earliest stage, the median 5-year survival for non–small cell lung cancer is 77%. Therefore, patients with earlier detection and treatment have the greatest chance for cure. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose CT in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. Screening should be discontinued once a person has not smoked for 15 years or develops a health problem that substantially limits life expectancy or the ability or willingness to have curative lung surgery. This recommendation is based on results from a series of randomized controlled trials. In the largest trial, the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST), low-dose CT had a sensitivity of 93.8% and specificity of 73.4% for the detection of lung cancer. The NLST demonstrated a 16% reduction in lung cancer mortality with low-dose CT. All persons enrolled in a screening program who are current smokers should receive smoking cessation interventions.
Chest radiography (
Option A
) had a sensitivity of 73.5% and specificity of 91.3% for the detection of lung cancer in the NLST. In addition, a series of studies on chest radiography and/or sputum cytology (
Option C
) since 1960 have shown no benefits in lung cancer mortality.

The 2021 USPSTF recommendation for lung cancer screening replaces the 2013 USPSTF recommendation for lung cancer screening. In 2013, the USPSTF recommended annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose CT in adults aged 55 to 80 years who have a 30-pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. The change in the recommendation is based on several lines of evidence suggesting that screening for lung cancer in persons with fewer pack-years of smoking (fewer than the 30-pack-year eligibility criterion of the 2013 USPSTF recommendation) and at an earlier age (50 years) can increase the benefits of screening. Screening the patient for lung cancer now, at age 53 years and with a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking, is consistent with the most recent guidelines; no additional screening (
Option D
) is not in the best interest of this patient.

references: Krist AH, Davidson KW, Mangione CM, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for lung cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2021;325:962-970.

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated for a 12-day history of slowly progressive right leg weakness and blurred vision. In addition, she has ocular pain and photopsia when moving the left eye and has experienced loss of color vision. She experienced double vision last year that resolved over 5 weeks.
Physical examination reveals reduced visual acuity and left optic disc pallor and weakness, hyperreflexia, and plantar extensor response of the right leg.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Diagnostic criteria for multiple sclerosis require symptoms of central nervous system demyelination separated in space and time from a series of clinical relapses or progression, signs on physical examination, distribution of lesions on MRI, and (if necessary) the presence of cerebrospinal fluid-unique oligoclonal bands.
The most common clinical manifestations of multiple sclerosis are optic neuritis, myelitis, and brainstem/cerebellar syndromes.
This patient most likely is experiencing a relapse of multiple sclerosis (MS) (
Option B

). MS is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) that causes inflammatory damage to the brain, spinal cord, and optic nerve. Relapses or flares involve development of neurologic symptoms over the course of hours to days and often peak in severity over the course of days to weeks. This is typically followed by a period of remission lasting weeks to months. Remyelination and recruitment of other brain regions to functionally substitute for the damaged area may result in clinical improvement during times of remission. The most common clinical manifestations of MS are optic neuritis, myelitis, and brainstem/cerebellar syndromes. This patient had a previous self-limited episode of diplopia and a new episode of optic neuritis (as suggested by monocular blurry vision with optic disc pallor) and central pattern focal right leg weakness (suggested by hyperreflexia and plantar extensor response). An MRI of the brain and cervical spine should be obtained to evaluate for lesions consistent with MS. If they are present, a diagnosis of MS is likely, based on validated diagnostic criteria, which require symptoms of CNS demyelination separated in space and time from a series of clinical relapses or progression, signs on physical examination, distribution of lesions on MRI, and (if necessary) the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)-unique oligoclonal bands. In this patient, the occurrence of two disparate clinical events happening at separate times satisfies criteria for dissemination in time, and the presence of an optic nerve (cranial nerve II) lesion (detected on clinical examination) and additional lesions (if shown by MRI) would satisfy criteria for dissemination in space.
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) (
Option A

) presents as an acute ascending paralysis associated with diffuse areflexia. Symptoms are symmetric, and disease course is often monophasic. GBS is associated with inflammatory demyelination of peripheral nerves and nerve roots, whereas MS is a central demyelinating disease. In this patient, the relapsing course, asymmetric presentation, hyperreflexia, and involvement of the optic nerve are inconsistent with GBS.
Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder (
Option C

) is an antibody-mediated inflammation directed at aquaporin-4 antibody channels in the CNS, or less commonly, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG), that results in inflammatory demyelination in the optic nerves and spinal cord. NMO can be differentiated from MS by NMO IgG (anti-aquaporin-4) or anti-MOG antibody testing and by its lack of significant brain involvement, large and longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions, and profound CSF leukocytosis. The patient's central pattern of focal weakness (leg weakness, hyperreflexia) excludes the diagnosis of NMO.
Idiopathic transverse myelitis (ITM) (
Option D

) is a monophasic, inflammatory, and demyelinating disorder of the spinal cord. ITM typically affects only one region of the spinal cord and is considered to be a para- or postinfectious inflammatory response. Affected patients frequently experience subacute weakness, sensory changes, and bladder or bowel dysfunction. Some patients experience an initial prodrome of back pain or a thoracic banding sensation. The patient's optic nerve involvement excludes the diagnosis of ITM.
Ann Intern Med

title: Question 162

children: A 52-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for acute chest pain that radiates to his back. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications are losartan and atorvastatin.
Blood pressure is 198/120 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 90/min. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals an S
and clear lungs; peripheral pulses are intact. Chest CT scan shows aortic dissection extending from the subclavian artery into the left renal artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intravenous treatment?

Patients with hypertensive emergency and a compelling indication (aortic dissection, severe preeclampsia or eclampsia, pheochromocytoma) require urgent blood pressure reduction to less than 140 mm Hg during the first hour and to less than 120 mm Hg in aortic dissection.

In hypertensive emergency complicated by aortic dissection, intravenous β-blockers are the initial drugs of choice owing to their antihypertensive and negative chronotropic effects, which lead to reduced shear stress on the aortic wall.
The most appropriate treatment is to start an esmolol infusion (
Option A

) in this patient with a hypertensive emergency. Hypertensive emergencies are defined as severe elevations in blood pressure (BP) (for example, higher than 180/120 mm Hg) associated with evidence of new or worsening end-organ damage. Patients with a compelling indication require urgent BP reduction. Compelling indications include aortic dissection, severe preeclampsia or eclampsia, and pheochromocytoma. In patients with a compelling indication, systolic BP should be reduced to less than 140 mm Hg during the first hour and to less than 120 mm Hg in aortic dissection. In aortic dissection, intravenous β-blockers are the initial drugs of choice owing to their antihypertensive and negative chronotropic effects, which lead to reduced shear stress on the aortic wall. Options include labetalol and esmolol. Esmolol is a very short-acting agent that allows careful titration of BP and heart rate.
Direct vasodilators, such as hydralazine (
Option B
), increase heart rate and aortic wall shear stress and are more difficult to use in predictably controlling BP. They are therefore not used in treating acute aortic dissection.
Phentolamine (
Option C

) is a nonselective α-adrenergic blocker used in hypertensive emergencies induced by catecholamine excess such as pheochromocytoma, interactions between monoamine oxidase inhibitors and other drugs or food, cocaine toxicity, amphetamine overdose, or clonidine withdrawal. Phentolamine does not have the beneficial effects of reducing heart rate and myocardial contractility.
Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil (
Option D
), are preferred second-line agents in patients who are unable to tolerate β-blockade. Nitroprusside can be added following β-blockade if BP remains elevated above target.

objective.__html: Treat hypertensive emergency complicated by a dissecting aortic aneurysm.

references: Whelton PK, Carey RM, Aronow WS, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA Guideline for the prevention, detection, evaluation, and management of high blood pressure in adults: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2018;71:e127-e248.

title: Question 163

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for a 6-week history of worsening confusion, visual defects, and right hemiparesis. She is HIV positive with a CD4 cell count of 35/μL; she has never received treatment.

Vital signs are normal. Neurologic examination shows right hemiparesis/hemianopsia; Mini–Mental State Examination score is 15/30. Brain MRI with contrast shows bilateral, hypodense, nonenhancing, periventricular parieto-occipital white matter lesions without mass effect.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system caused by the JC polyomavirus, occurring almost exclusively in severely immunocompromised patients.
Among patients with advanced HIV/AIDS, the probability of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy exceeds 80% in those with white matter lesions with no mass effect.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) (
Option B

) is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) caused by the JC polyomavirus (JCV). It occurs almost exclusively in severely immunocompromised patients, including those with advanced AIDS. Clinical findings of PML include dementia, hemiparesis or paralysis of one extremity, ataxia, hemianopsia, and diplopia. The characteristic appearance of these lesions on MRI is hyperintense (white) areas on T2-weighted images and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequences and hypointense (dark) areas on T1-weighted images. There is usually no mass effect. Among patients with advanced HIV/AIDS, the probability of PML exceeds 80% in those with white matter lesions with no mass effect. The treatment approach involves initiation of antiretroviral therapy to reverse the immunosuppression that interferes with the normal host response to JCV.
Primary CNS lymphoma (
Option A

) occurs in approximately 2% to 12% of patients with HIV infection, typically when the CD4 cell count is less than 200/µL, and often less than 50/μL. Primary CNS lymphoma is typically associated with mass effect on MRI.
Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) (
Option C

) is characterized by recurrent thunderclap headache and multifocal constriction of intracranial vessels, usually normalizing within 3 months of onset. Focal deficits, encephalopathy, and seizures are seen in a few patients. RCVS is not associated with immunosuppression, demonstrates more gray matter involvement, and does not cause hypointense lesions on T1-weighted MRI.
In patients with HIV infection and CD4 cell counts less than 100/μL, localized or focal encephalitis is the most common presentation of toxoplasmosis (
Option D
). Toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of a focal brain lesion in patients with HIV infection, and multiple lesions are the rule. Like CNS lymphoma,
Toxoplasma
lesions are typically associated with enhancement and mass effect, which are absent in this patient.

objective.__html: Diagnose progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy associated with HIV/AIDS.

references: Pruitt AA. Central nervous system infections in immunocompromised patients. Curr Neurol Neurosci Rep. 2021;21:37.

title: Question 164

children: A 24-year-old man is evaluated for severe asthma requiring frequent hospitalizations and oral glucocorticoids. He is adherent to his medical regimen and demonstrates excellent inhaler technique. He follows a written asthma management plan. Medications are high-dose inhaled budesonide, formoterol, montelukast, tiotropium, and albuterol.
Blood eosinophil percentage is normal. Total serum IgE level is elevated. Skin testing is positive for multiple allergens.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds IgE and has been shown to reduce exacerbations in patients with severe persistent asthma despite standard therapy.

Mepolizumab and reslizumab are anti-interleukin-5 monoclonal antibodies that reduce eosinophil levels in airway and sputum and are effective in patients with severe asthma associated with elevated eosinophil levels, regardless of IgE level.
The most appropriate treatment is omalizumab (
Option D

), a humanized monoclonal antibody directed at IgE. This patient has severe asthma, which is asthma that is uncontrolled despite adherence to maximal optimized therapy and treatment of contributory factors, that worsens when high-dose inhaled glucocorticoid treatment is decreased, or that requires continuous oral glucocorticoids. Severe asthma is characterized by frequent exacerbations; patients may require emergency department visits or hospitalizations and may experience long durations of treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids. This patient's asthma has not been controlled despite trigger avoidance and treatment with multiple controller drugs. Omalizumab is indicated in patients with severe persistent asthma inadequately controlled with standard therapy who have elevated IgE levels and sensitivity to multiple allergens, as documented by skin testing, or elevated serum allergen-specific IgE. Omalizumab is administered subcutaneously every 2 to 4 weeks.
Allergen immunotherapy (
Option A

) can be useful when a single trigger is identified or when a trigger is consistently the source of asthma instability. In this patient with sensitivity to multiple allergens, omalizumab anti-IgE therapy is a more appropriate choice. Beneficial effects of allergen immunotherapy begin during the first year of therapy, whereas omalizumab would be expected to provide asthma control within weeks.
Bronchial thermoplasty (
Option B
) is a radiofrequency airway treatment using bronchoscopy that can reduce exacerbations and improve quality of life. Candidates are patients with an FEV
greater than 60% and severe asthma that is poorly controlled despite high-dose inhaled glucocorticoid/long-acting β
agonist combination therapy. This patient has a recognizable asthma phenotype that will respond to less invasive therapy with omalizumab.
Mepolizumab (
Option C

) and reslizumab are anti-interleukin-5 monoclonal antibodies that reduce eosinophil levels in airway and sputum by blocking the action of interleukin-5, a cytokine that plays a significant role in eosinophil recruitment and maturation. Mepolizumab is effective in patients with severe asthma associated with elevated eosinophil levels, regardless of IgE level. Mepolizumab is not an appropriate choice in this patient with normal serum eosinophil levels.

references: Israel E, Reddel HK. Severe and difficult-to-treat asthma in adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:965-76.

title: Question 165

children: A 58-year-old woman reports 2 years of finger joint swelling, morning stiffness lasting 20 minutes, and use-related pain. She has had no other symptoms.

Physical examination reveals bony enlargement of the first carpometacarpal joints bilaterally, resulting in squaring of the joints. There is swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. The involved joints are tender, but there is no joint warmth, redness, or effusions.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next test?
The diagnosis of osteoarthritis is based on history and physical examination; laboratory testing is not necessary, and radiography is confirmatory but may be unnecessary.
No further testing (
Option D

) is necessary in this patient who has clinical findings consistent with hand osteoarthritis (OA). OA is a chronic progressive multifactorial disorder of maladaptive cellular repair responses to joint stress. It is a clinical diagnosis, and the cardinal symptom is pain with activity that is relieved with rest. Affected patients also typically experience morning stiffness that lasts for less than 30 minutes daily. Bony hypertrophy is commonly detected in the fingers, and Heberden nodes of the distal interphalangeal joints and Bouchard nodes of the proximal interphalangeal joints may be easily palpated. OA also may cause squaring or boxing of the carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb. The diagnosis of OA is based on history and physical examination; laboratory testing is not necessary, and radiography is confirmatory but may be unnecessary.

The most useful laboratory studies to aid in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are rheumatoid factor and anti–cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. Rheumatoid factor is found in approximately 70% of patients with RA and may be present at the time of disease onset. Because other diseases can be associated with rheumatoid factor, its specificity for RA is somewhat limited. Anti-CCP antibodies are present in 70% of patients with RA but have a specificity of 95%. Anti-CCP antibodies are also more predictive than rheumatoid factor for erosive disease. The key features of RA are swelling and tenderness in and around the metacarpal phalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints and prominent morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour. RA spares the distal interphalangeal joints. Because this patient has no clinical evidence of RA, testing for anti-CCP antibodies (
Option A
) is unnecessary.
Inflammatory markers, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate (
Option B

) and C-reactive protein, are normal in osteoarthritis. These markers of inflammation may help exclude the presence of other inflammatory diseases; however, this patient has no other symptoms, and her presentation is classic for OA, negating the usefulness of erythrocyte sedimentation rate or C-reactive protein measurement.
Radiography (
Option C

) is not needed to confirm the diagnosis of OA in patients with a history and physical examination compatible with this condition. Clinical examination is more sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of hand OA compared with radiography.

objective.__html: Clinically diagnose osteoarthritis of the hands.

references: Hunter DJ, Bierma-Zeinstra S. Osteoarthritis. Lancet. 2019;393:1745-1759.

title: Question 166

children: A 65-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated after screening abdominal ultrasonography for aortic aneurysm revealed diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall. The gallbladder examination was negative for gallbladder wall calcification, stones, polyps, and masses. The patient has never experienced gallbladder or biliary tract symptoms.
Physical examination is normal. Complete blood count and liver chemistry test results are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

For the diagnosis of gallbladder cancer, cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI is generally preferred because of the additional ability to detect liver involvement and the presence of regional lymph node and distant metastases, which will inform treatment decisions.
The initial treatment for gallbladder cancer is cholecystectomy.
The most appropriate next step is MRI and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) (
Option B

) for this patient with an ultrasound finding of diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall, which is concerning for gallbladder cancer. Gallbladder cancer, the most common cancer of the biliary tree, is rare, with an observed frequency of less than 0.001%. Patients with early invasive gallbladder cancer may have no symptoms or may present with episodic right-upper-quadrant abdominal pain or biliary colic. Risk factors include gallstones, porcelain gallbladder (intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall), gallbladder polyps, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. The potential resectability of this lesion should be evaluated with MRI and MRCP. The extent of local invasion can be evaluated, and the distinction between benign and malignant lesions potentially can be made. The initial treatment for gallbladder cancer is cholecystectomy. Tumors that extend beyond the lamina propria require extended cholecystectomy. If the tumor is found to be unresectable, chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy or palliative care can be considered.
Endoscopic ultrasonography (
Option A

) is likely more accurate than transabdominal ultrasonography for the diagnosis of gallbladder cancer, but cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI is generally preferred because of the additional ability to detect liver involvement and the presence of regional lymph node and distant metastases, which will inform treatment decisions.
Serial ultrasonographic imaging (
Option C
) is indicated in certain situations, such as for surveillance in patients who have gallbladder polyps smaller than 10 mm. However, in this patient, it is not advisable to postpone evaluation.
Serum tumor markers such as CA 19-9 (
Option D
) or CEA can be measured in patients with gallbladder cancer, and their response to therapy can be monitored. However, these markers would not be diagnostically useful at this point.

references: Valle JW, Borbath I, Khan SA, et al; ESMO Guidelines Committee. Biliary cancer: ESMO clinical practice guidelines for diagnosis, treatment and follow-up. Ann Oncol. 2016;27:v28-v37.

children: A 68-year-old woman is treated for acute heart failure with torsemide. She has a history of hypertension, obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation. Medications are metoprolol, hydrochlorothiazide, empagliflozin, and apixaban.
Echocardiogram shows a
left ventricular ejection fraction
of 60% without valvular abnormalities.
On the following day, blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse rate is 50/min. BMI is 30. There is no jugular venous distention, pulmonary crackles, or edema.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
In patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, antihypertensive agents should target a systolic blood pressure of less than 130 mm Hg.
The most appropriate treatment is to add losartan (
Option C

). This patient has heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), which is characterized by symptoms of heart failure in the setting of normal systolic function and no valvular abnormalities. This patient with HFpEF was appropriately treated with a loop diuretic to control symptoms of volume overload. She now needs an additional antihypertensive agent to attain a target systolic blood pressure of less than 130 mm Hg. Adding losartan for better hypertension control is appropriate at this time. Neurohormonal blockade of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system in HFpEF is beneficial in reducing sodium and water retention and ameliorating adverse cardiac remodeling.
Digoxin (
Option A

) is a positive inotropic agent occasionally used in the treatment of symptomatic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. It is used for rate control in the setting of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate, which may exacerbate heart failure, but there are currently no data to support its use for the primary treatment of HFpEF.
Ivabradine (
Option B

) reduces heart failure–associated hospitalizations and the combined endpoint of mortality and heart failure hospitalization in patients with chronic symptomatic heart failure and left ventricular ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% who are in sinus rhythm and taking maximally tolerated doses of a β-blocker. In these patients, ivabradine should be considered for those with an elevated heart rate (≥70/min). This patient has no indication for ivabradine.
This patient appears euvolemic on her current diuretic regimen and, from a clinical standpoint, would not need to switch from hydrochlorothiazide to another diuretic agent, such as furosemide (
Option D
). There are no significant cardiac remodeling or outcomes benefits beyond simple volume management associated with switching between diuretic classes.

objective.__html: Treat heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for obesity. She is too busy with her job and children to exercise. She does not smoke cigarettes. She has never been treated for weight loss. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. BMI is 36, and waist circumference is 42 in. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Guidelines recommend lifestyle modification that includes reduced caloric intake, increased physical activity, and behavioral therapy in all patients with obesity.
The most appropriate intervention is lifestyle changes (
Option B

), including exercise, reduced caloric intake, and behavioral modifications. With a BMI of 36, this patient meets the criterion for obesity (BMI ≥30). Furthermore, her waist circumference is greater than 40 inches, which is independently associated with increased cardiovascular risk. American Heart Association/American College of Cardiology/The Obesity Society guidelines recommend lifestyle modification that include reduced caloric intake, increased physical activity, and behavioral therapy in all patients with obesity. Similarly, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends offering or referring patients with obesity to intensive, multicomponent behavioral interventions. In addition to increasing physical activity (150-300 min/wk of moderate exercise) and behavioral therapy (aimed at avoiding fast food and inappropriate snacking), this patient should be prescribed a diet that maintains a deficit of 500 kcal/d. Maintaining a continuous negative energy balance of 500 kcal/d results in a weight loss of about 1.1 lb per week. Involving dieticians, exercise therapists, and behavioral therapists increases the chances of success.
Bariatric surgery (
Option A

) should be considered in all patients with a BMI of 40 or higher and in patients with a BMI of 35 or higher plus obesity-related comorbid conditions, such as diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, hypertension, or osteoarthritis. This patient has a BMI of 36 and is otherwise healthy.

Pharmacologic treatment is preferably used as an adjunctive therapy in patients with a BMI of 30 or higher or in patients with a BMI of 27 or higher with overweight- or obesity-associated comorbidities who have not achieved significant weight loss with comprehensive lifestyle interventions. Liraglutide (
Option C

) is an injectable glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist It delays gastric emptying and, in one systematic review and meta-analysis, resulted in an average 5.2-kg (11.5-lb) weight loss over 52 weeks as compared with placebo. Liraglutide can be used in patients with or without diabetes but may be best suited for a patient with type 2 diabetes and increased cardiovascular risk. This patient should pursue lifestyle modifications before considering pharmacologic therapy for obesity.
Ma huang/ephedra (
Option D

) has been associated with myocardial infarction and stroke. Some weight loss supplements may also have undisclosed ingredients, most commonly sibutramine. Physicians should be prepared to discuss the lack of effectiveness and potential for adverse effects of supplements during weight loss counseling and advise discontinuation.
Ann Intern Med

title: Question 169

children: A 21-year-old man is evaluated for abdominal pain and vomiting that began yesterday morning after 3 days of cough and fever. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus and has not taken insulin in 24 hours.
