Blood pressure is 94/64 mm Hg, pulse rate is 118/min, and respiration rate is 30/min. He is lethargic. His breath has a fruity odor; decreased skin turgor and dry oral mucosa are present. Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness.
In addition to serum glucose measurement, which of the following laboratory tests will establish the diagnosis?

text.__html: Serum electrolytes and arterial blood gases (ABGs)

children: The diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis is typically based on a blood glucose level greater than 250 mg/dL (13.9 mmol/L), increased anion gap metabolic acidosis (arterial pH <7.3), a serum bicarbonate level of 18 mEq/L (18 mmol/L) or less, and presence of serum or urine ketones.
This patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), and the tests to establish the diagnosis are measurement of serum glucose, electrolytes, ketones, and arterial blood gases (ABGs) (
Option B

). The most life-threatening acute complication of diabetes mellitus is DKA, which mostly affects patients with type 1 diabetes younger than 65 years and is sometimes its presenting manifestation. DKA is associated with hyperglycemia (350-1000 mg/dL [19.4-56 mmol/L]) and must be treated early and aggressively to avoid life-threatening consequences caused by dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities. At presentation, patients with DKA usually report a several-day history of polyuria, polydipsia, and blurred vision, culminating in nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dyspnea, and altered mental status. Physical examination typically reveals deep, labored breathing (Kussmaul respirations); a fruity odor to the breath (from acetone); poor skin turgor; tachycardia; and hypotension. This complication may occur as a result of precipitating acute stresses, such as infections (influenza, pneumonia, or gastroenteritis) or acute myocardial infarction; in patients with insulin pumps, when a technical interruption of insulin infusion occurs; and in patients who are nonadherent to their medication regimen. In almost all instances, DKA is entirely preventable if patients practice regular glucose monitoring and understand the need for increased insulin doses during acute stress events. The diagnosis of DKA is typically based on a blood glucose level greater than 250 mg/dL (13.9 mmol/L), increased anion gap metabolic acidosis (arterial pH <7.3), a serum bicarbonate level of 18 mEq/L (18 mmol/L) or less, and presence of serum or urine ketones.
Serum electrolytes and ABGs (
Option A
) will help diagnose the presence of an increased anion gap metabolic acidosis but will not confirm the cause of the acid-base disturbance.
Phosphate concentrations (
Options C
) are often normal early in DKA and decline with therapy. Phosphate concentrations are not useful in the diagnosis of DKA.
Serum ketones and bicarbonate (
Option D
) suggest the presence of acidosis but not its nature or cause.

references: American Diabetes Association. 15. Diabetes care in the hospital: standards of medical care in diabetes-2021. Diabetes Care. 2021;44:S211-S220.

title: Question 170

children: A 25-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of a disfiguring lump in her right neck at the angle of the jaw. She has no other symptoms. She works as an investment banker and does not appear distressed by the symptom.
Examination of the neck is normal. She remains convinced the lump is still present. Affect is normal, and there is no evidence of disorganized thinking.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Delusional disorder is a psychotic disorder characterized by persistent false beliefs that the patient remains convinced to be true despite evidence to the contrary.
Somatic symptom and related disorders are characterized by medically unexplained symptoms that cause emotional distress and psychosocial impairment.
This patient's symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of delusional disorder (
Option B

), a psychotic disorder characterized by persistent false beliefs that the patient remains convinced to be true despite evidence to the contrary. Symptoms must be present for at least 1 month, typically only impair function minimally, and may or may not be distressing to the patient. Because patients often do not perceive the delusion as problematic, they may not seek medical attention voluntarily. Common delusional themes include paranoia (often about persecution or infidelity), grandiosity (belief in special worth, knowledge, power, or status), erotomania (belief that a person with elevated status is in love with the patient), or, as with this patient, somatic delusions of physical defect or abnormality. Symptoms diagnostic of other psychotic disorders, including disorganized thinking, motor dysfunction, and negative symptoms, must not be present.

Personality disorders involve consistent patterns of interpersonal behavior and perceptions that are inflexible, diverge significantly from the behavioral standards of the person's culture, and cause substantial functional impairment and emotional distress. Borderline personality disorder (
Option A

) is characterized by the following: chaotic relationships (idealized and devalued) and a fragile self-image; fear of abandonment; labile and intense emotions (e.g., anger); a sense of emptiness; engaging in impulsive and risky behaviors (e.g., gambling, sex); and possibly self-injury and suicidality.
Schizophrenia (
Option C

) is a psychotic disorder that may include delusions or hallucinations. Patients with schizophrenia experience disorganized thinking and behaviors and negative symptoms, such as social withdrawal, flattened affect, and poverty of speech and thought. Social and occupational functioning are usually significantly impaired. This patient with an isolated delusion regarding a physical defect does not have symptoms supportive of a diagnosis of schizophrenia.
Somatic symptom and related disorders (
Option D

) are characterized by medically unexplained symptoms that cause emotional distress and psychosocial impairment. Prevalence is as high as 4%, and primary care is a common setting for presentation. Patients with these disorders have very high health care utilization rates yet are often dissatisfied with their care.

references: Erdmann T, Mathys C. A generative framework for the study of delusions. Schizophr Res. 2021:S0920-9964(20)30627-7. [PMID: 33648810.] doi:10.1016/j.schres.2020.11.048

title: Question 171

children: A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for acute alcoholic hepatitis. She reports a 6-week history of binge drinking, a 2-week history of jaundice, and a 3-day history of fever. She has no other risk factors for liver disease and no other medical problems.
Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F). Jaundice and tender hepatomegaly are present.
Aspartate aminotransferase
and
alanine aminotransferase
levels are 124 U/L and 57 U/L, respectively. Maddrey discriminant function score is greater than 32. Supportive treatment is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A history of excessive alcohol consumption, low-grade fever, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, an aspartate-to-alanine aminotransferase ratio greater than 2, and a Maddrey discriminant function score of 32 or more are consistent with severe alcoholic hepatitis.
In the absence of systemic infection, acute kidney injury, uncontrolled gastrointestinal bleeding, and multiorgan failure, prednisolone is the treatment of choice for severe alcoholic hepatitis.

The patient's history of excessive alcohol consumption and findings of low-grade fever, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, an aspartate-to-alanine aminotransferase ratio greater than 2, and a Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) score of 32 or more are consistent with severe alcoholic hepatitis, for which prednisolone (
Option C

) is the treatment of choice. Alcoholic hepatitis, an acute liver inflammation associated with alcohol intake, usually occurs in patients with a history of heavy and prolonged alcohol use. The MDF score is used to select patients for glucocorticoid treatment after ruling out contraindications, such as systemic infection, acute kidney injury, uncontrolled gastrointestinal bleeding, and multiorgan failure. If the patient shows improvement after the first week, glucocorticoids are continued along with nutritional support for a total of 28 days. Improved short-term survival (30 days) is achieved in approximately 50% of patients on glucocorticoids, whereas long-term survival heavily depends on the degree of coexistent chronic liver disease and abstinence from alcohol. Patients who do not respond to glucocorticoids may become candidates for liver transplantation or palliative care.
A liver biopsy (
Option A
) is not routinely recommended in patients with alcoholic hepatitis but may be necessary if other causes of liver disease are present or suspected and/or the history of alcohol use is unclear.
Pentoxifylline (
Option B

) has been used in patients with contraindications to glucocorticoids, although its use remains controversial due to inconclusive data supporting its benefit. The American College of Gastroenterology makes a conditional recommendation against its use for severe alcoholic hepatitis based on the low level of existing evidence.
Nonsevere alcoholic hepatitis (MDF score <32) requires supportive measures (
Option D

) and should not be treated with prednisolone. All patients require assessment for nutritional deficiencies, nutritional management, thiamine replacement, and alcohol treatment, with a goal of abstinence. This patient has severe alcoholic hepatitis, and treatment with prednisone is indicated.

references: Crabb DW, Im GY, Szabo G, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of alcohol-associated liver diseases: 2019 practice guidance from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases. Hepatology. 2020;71:306-333.

children: A 78-year-old woman is hospitalized for pneumonia. Appropriate antibiotics were initiated, and a urinary catheter was placed. The patient has a history of dementia. Her only other medication is donepezil.

On physical examination, temperature is 37.8 °C (100.1 °F); other vital signs are stable. The patient appears stable but is disoriented. Crackles are present in the left lower posterior lung field. Neurologic examination reveals cognitive impairment without inattention or evidence of focal neurologic deficits.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent delirium in this patient?

text.__html: Frequent nighttime vital signs and safety checks

children: Nonpharmacologic measures that reduce risk for delirium in elderly patients include removal of “tethers” (such as bladder catheters and restraints), cognitive reorientation, sleep enhancement, early mobility, adaptations for visual and hearing impairment, nutrition and fluid repletion, pain management, appropriate medication usage, adequate oxygenation, prevention of constipation, and family or a sitter at the bedside.
The use of antipsychotic medications in elderly patients with dementia is associated with an increased risk for death, stroke, and myocardial infarction.
The most appropriate next step to prevent delirium in this patient is urinary catheter removal (
Option D

). Elderly patients with a history of dementia are at very high risk for developing delirium during hospitalization. Delirium is an acute state of confusion that may manifest as fluctuations in the level of consciousness and attention, disorganized thinking, perceptual disturbances, and emotional disturbances. A range of toxic, metabolic, or infectious causes may precipitate delirium, but the risk is higher in elderly persons with preexisting cognitive impairment. Prevention involves addressing medical and environmental issues. Urinary catheters are associated with an increased risk for delirium and infection. In the absence of a medical indication for a catheter (such as relieving urinary retention, monitoring fluid status in acutely ill patients when this directly impacts medical treatment, managing stage 3 or 4 pressure injuries on patients' buttocks), the catheter should be removed. Additional nonpharmacologic measures that reduce risk for delirium in elderly patients include cognitive reorientation, sleep enhancement, early mobility, adaptations for visual and hearing impairment, nutrition and fluid repletion, pain management, appropriate medication usage, adequate oxygenation, prevention of constipation, and family or a sitter at the bedside.
Benzodiazepines, such as flurazepam (
Option A

), have sedating effects but can cause delirium in elderly patients. They should generally be avoided. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, can be useful when a specific indication is present, such as alcohol withdrawal.

A normal sleep-wake cycle should be maintained as much as possible in elderly patients, minimizing interruptions or unnecessary testing during the night and keeping a light on and increasing stimulation during the day. Unless medically necessary, routine vital sign measurement and safety checks (
Option B
) throughout the night are not indicated.
Current evidence does not support routine use of first-generation or second-generation antipsychotic agents, such as quetiapine (
Option C

), to prevent delirium. When safety is a concern, newer-generation antipsychotic agents may help control behavior, but these drugs are not indicated for the prevention of the disorder. The use of antipsychotic medications in elderly patients with dementia is associated with an increased risk for death, stroke, and myocardial infarction.

objective.__html: Prevent delirium in a hospitalized high-risk patient.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 173

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of right anterior knee pain and swelling. The symptoms began after working in her garden for several days. She has no other medical problems.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is globular, fluid-like swelling; erythema; and tenderness anterior to the right patella. There is full range of motion of the right knee without joint line tenderness. There is no other joint involvement.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Prepatellar bursitis presents as anterior knee pain and swelling; physical examination reveals a palpable fluid collection with preserved active and passive knee range of motion.
Bursal aspiration is necessary to establish the cause of bursitis and determine the treatment plan.
The most appropriate next step in management in this patient with acute prepatellar bursitis is to aspirate the bursal fluid collection for diagnostic purposes (
Option A

). Prepatellar bursitis is caused by inflammation of the prepatellar bursa that overlies the patella. Patients present with anterior knee pain and swelling. Physical examination reveals a palpable fluid collection with preserved active and passive knee range of motion. Repetitive trauma (e.g., kneeling with gardening) predisposes to the development of bursitis but does not rule out other possible or additional diagnoses, namely infection and crystalline disease. Skin lesions overlying the bursa, including psoriasis and eczema, may predispose to septic bursitis. Aspiration is necessary to establish the diagnosis and determine the treatment plan. Bursal fluid cell count, polarized microscopy for crystals, Gram stain, and culture should be performed. An extremely elevated leukocyte count (>50,000/µL [50 x 10

/L]) should raise suspicion for septic bursitis, although a lower count does not eliminate this possibility. Furthermore, both crystalline and infectious disease can coexist, increasing the importance of Gram stain and culture results. Treatment of noninfectious bursitis includes drainage of the fluid, compression to prevent re-accumulation, anti-inflammatory agents, and measures to avoid future trauma to the bursa. Antibiotics and drainage are indicated for septic bursitis.
An NSAID, such as celecoxib (
Option B
), can be helpful for symptomatic relief of pain and swelling but will not rule out or treat infection.
Intra-bursal triamcinolone injection (
Option C

) is not indicated for prepatellar bursitis of unknown cause because it may worsen pre-existing septic bursitis. Glucocorticoid injection is typically avoided in chronic persistent noninfectious bursitis due to concerns of introducing infection.
Topical NSAIDs, such as diclofenac (
Option D

), are strongly recommended for patients with knee osteoarthritis and conditionally recommended for patients with hand osteoarthritis. Like oral NSAIDs, topical NSAIDs may reduce inflammation and discomfort associated with prepatellar bursitis but will not rule out or treat infection.

references: Lormeau C, Cormier G, Sigaux J, et al. Management of septic bursitis. Joint Bone Spine. 2019;86(5):583-588.

title: Question 174

children: A 58-year-old man is hospitalized for recent-onset, severe, nontraumatic low back pain. He had localized prostate cancer treated with radiation 6 years ago.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is lower spine point tenderness approximately at the level of the iliac crests. There is no saddle anesthesia; lower extremity muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal.
Prostate-specific antigen
level is 50 ng/mL (50 µg/L). Spine radiograph shows an osteoblastic metastasis at L4. Bone scan and CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis show no other metastases.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

In castrate-sensitive metastatic prostate cancer, androgen deprivation therapy is used in combination with docetaxel, abiraterone/prednisone, enzalutamide, or apalutamide depending on the volume of disease and prior treatment.
The most appropriate treatment is androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) in combination with enzalutamide (
Option B

). This patient has recurrent prostate cancer after treatment for localized prostate cancer. The mainstay of treatment for metastatic prostate cancer is ADT, provided by orchiectomy (surgical castration) or chemical castration. Surgical castration ADT provides cost-effective and rapid results and is widely used internationally. Chemical castration ADT is as effective as bilateral orchiectomy in treating patients with metastatic disease but is often preferred by patients in the United States. However, it requires repeated intramuscular or subcutaneous administration of hormonal agents. Chemical castration may be accomplished with a GnRH receptor agonist (leuprolide, goserelin, triptorelin, histrelin) or antagonist (degarelix). GnRH receptor agonists often initially trigger a surge of testosterone that can cause transient tumor growth; thereafter, the pituitary–testes axis is disrupted, which decreases testosterone levels and reduces the size of the tumor. The GnRH receptor antagonist degarelix lowers testosterone quickly and does not cause tumor flare. Oral antiandrogens, such as bicalutamide and flutamide, directly block androgen receptors on cancer cells and are provided in combination with a GnRH agonist or antagonist. When used with a GnRH agonist, antiandrogens should be initiated first to protect against the transient testosterone surge caused by initiation of GnRH agonist therapy. In this patient with a lumbar spinal metastasis, ADT is indicated with surgical castration or a GnRH agonist or GnRH antagonist combined with an antiandrogen. Men with clinical metastatic disease who respond to ADT are considered to have castrate-sensitive prostate cancer. In this population, ADT can be combined with docetaxel, abiraterone/prednisone, enzalutamide, or apalutamide to improve survival. The choice of which specific agent to add to ADT is dependent on the volume of disease and prior treatment regimens. In a patient with metastatic disease following local therapy, such as radiation therapy, enzalutamide or apalutamide is indicated.
The CYP17 inhibitor abiraterone (
Option A

) is used in castrate (ADT)-sensitive prostate cancer. It is not given before ADT. Abiraterone blocks androgen synthesis, not only in the testes but also in tumor tissue and the adrenal glands. It is indicated as an option in combination with ADT in de novo metastatic androgen-sensitive prostate cancer but not as monotherapy.
Chemotherapy with docetaxel (
Option C

) in addition to ADT increases overall survival in patients with de novo metastatic disease and those with high-volume disease (visceral metastases and/or four or more bone metastases). It is not indicated as initial therapy, however, in patients with low-volume metastatic disease, such as this one.
5α-Reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride (
Option D
), or dutasteride are primarily used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia. They have no role in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer.

objective.__html: Treat metastatic prostate cancer to bone.

references: Virgo KS, Rumble RB, de Wit R, et al. Initial management of noncastrate advanced, recurrent, or metastatic prostate cancer: ASCO guideline update. J Clin Oncol. 2021;39:1274-1305.

title: Question 175

children: A 17-year-old boy is evaluated for several papules on the sole of his right foot. The lesions are not pruritic, but occasionally the heel lesions are painful when he runs during track practice.
Physical examination reveals several hyperkeratotic, flat-topped papules. Black dots are visible after the lesions are pared down. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Plantar warts usually present as exophytic papules on the soles of the feet; after scraping the lesion surface, black or red dots (thrombosed capillaries) become visible.

Warts are usually self-limited; however, in severe cases, destructive treatments such as cryosurgery or topical application of salicylic acid, tricarboxylic acid, cantharidin, or podophyllin can be used.
This patient has plantar warts (
Option D

), otherwise known as verrucae plantaris. Plantar warts usually present as exophytic papules on the soles of the feet. Hyperkeratotic debris often covers the tops of the lesions. After scraping the lesion surface, black or red dots (thrombosed capillaries) become visible. Plantar and palmar warts also cover skin lines and thus obscure dermatoglyphics (skin markings or ridge patterns of the skin). Plantar warts are usually caused by human papillomavirus type 1. Warts are usually self-limited; however, in severe cases, destructive treatments such as cryosurgery or topical application of salicylic acid, tricarboxylic acid, cantharidin, or podophyllin can be used.
Black heel (formerly known as calcaneal petechiae) (
Option A

) results from intraepidermal extravasation of red blood cells in the epidermis of the heel. The appearance can mimic the thrombosed capillaries of plantar warts. Black heel often occurs in athletes, such as runners, because of intradermal hemorrhages caused by sheer friction against the shoe. The lesions of black heel resolve spontaneously with discontinuation of the causative activity. Black heel lesions do not obscure dermatoglyphics and can be removed by scraping, thus differentiating them from plantar warts.
Erythrasma (
Option B

) is a benign superficial bacterial infection of the skin. Afflicted patients report red-brown plaques in the groin, crural folds, gluteal folds, axillae, or less commonly in the interdigital or inframammary regions. The skin often has a thin, wrinkled appearance similar to cigarette paper. Symptoms, limited to mild pruritus, are minimal in most patients. The causative organism is most commonly
Corynebacterium minutissimum
. This organism produces porphyrins that fluoresce a soft coral red under a Wood lamp. Treatment is best accomplished with oral erythromycin, clarithromycin, or tetracyclines.
Pitted keratolysis (
Option C

) is a bacterial infection of the soles of the feet or (less commonly) the palms of the hand, with characteristic appearance and odor. As the name suggests, the infection manifests as scale and pitting of the skin surface. These pits may coalesce into larger erosions. In the United States, the infection is most common among patients with hyperhidrosis and prolonged occlusion of the feet (athletes, military personnel, laborers). Other than appearance and odor, symptoms are usually minimal and limited to mild pruritus or slight discomfort. Treatment is with topical antibacterial therapy, such as clindamycin, erythromycin, or over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide preparations.

references: Topical treatment for plantar warts: A systematic review. Dermatol Ther. 2021;34(2):e14941.

title: Question 176

children: A 37-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for 3 days of fever. He is receiving prolonged parenteral antibiotics through a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) for infective endocarditis.

Temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °F). A right brachial PICC site appears normal. A grade 2/6 diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Blood cultures are growing
Candida
species.
In addition to continuing intravenous antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Continue PICC use; add amphotericin B

children: When candidemia is likely to be the result of an intravenous catheter, the catheter must be removed promptly because it serves as a nidus for ongoing candidemia.
An echinocandin (micafungin, caspofungin, or anidulafungin) is typically the preferred empiric agent for all patients with candidemia.
Removal of the peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) and initiation of antifungal therapy with an echinocandin, such as micafungin (
Option D

), caspofungin, or anidulafungin, is the most appropriate management for this patient. When candidemia is likely to be the result of an intravenous (IV) catheter, the catheter must be removed promptly because it serves as a nidus for ongoing candidemia. For candidemia related to IV catheters, the duration is shorter and mortality rate is lower when the catheter is removed than when it remains in place. In addition, catheter salvage is extremely difficult with fungal colonization, almost always requiring removal of the catheter. Although removal of long-term catheters may be a management challenge in patients being treated with a prolonged course of antibiotics, such as this patient, alternative short-term access is indicated to continue treatment and allow antifungal therapy to be given. Empiric antifungal therapy should be started because candidemia can be prolonged and may lead to metastatic complications (endophthalmitis, endocarditis, osteomyelitis) if not already present at the time of diagnosis. An echinocandin is typically the preferred empiric agent for all patients with candidemia. Other considerations in choosing empiric therapy include a history of recent azole exposure, prevalence of different species and susceptibility data in a particular institution, the severity of illness, comorbid conditions (such as neutropenia), and evidence of disseminated involvement (such as the central nervous system or eyes). Blood cultures should always be repeated until candidemia clearance is documented. Treatment should be given for 2 weeks after symptoms resolve and blood cultures are negative for candidemia, or longer if metastatic complications are present.
PICC retention (
Options A, B
) is inappropriate, as this will promote relapse after cessation of antifungal therapy. In addition, amphotericin B (
Option A
) is associated with greater toxicity compared with echinocandins and is typically reserved for patients with resistance to the other antifungal classes.
Removal of the PICC without use of concurrent antifungal therapy (
Option C
) is inadequate management because metastatic complications of infection will develop in their absence.

objective.__html: Treat central line–associated fungal bloodstream infection.

references: Pappas PG, Kauffman CA, Andes DR, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the management of candidiasis: 2016 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clin Infect Dis. 2016;62:e1-50.

title: Question 177

children: A 19-year-old man is evaluated for acute worsening of chronic atopic dermatitis over the past week. The rash has developed small opaque vesicles and is associated with intense itching despite use of petrolatum jelly and triamcinolone ointment. He is otherwise well.
On physical examination, he is afebrile. There are eczematous plaques with scattered pustules in the areas of rash and fresh excoriations. No other abnormalities are noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Atopic dermatitis is characterized by xerotic, pink, scaly skin and is most commonly seen on the periocular areas, posterior neck, antecubital and popliteal fossae, wrists, and ankles.
Most localized
Staphylococcus aureus
infections associated with atopic dermatitis may be treated with a topical antibiotic such as mupirocin.
The most appropriate treatment is topical mupirocin (
Option D
). This patient has atopic dermatitis with new pustules, which is typical of a
Staphylococcus aureus

infection. Atopic dermatitis is characterized by xerotic, pink, scaly skin and is most commonly seen on the periocular areas, posterior neck, antecubital and popliteal fossae, wrists, and ankles. Staphylococcal colonization is present at the site of skin involvement in almost all patients with atopic dermatitis. Scratching of the skin with breakdown of the skin barrier is conducive to infection, which is a common occurrence in patients with atopic dermatitis. Most localized
S. aureus
infections associated with atopic dermatitis may be treated with a topical antibiotic, such as mupirocin, with more extensive infections requiring systemic antibiotic therapy.
For extensive infections requiring systemic antibiotic therapy, empiric trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or doxycycline would be excellent choices. Oral cephalexin (
Option A
) would not be appropriate for a patient with a purulent skin infection caused by
S. aureus

Herpes simplex virus can superinfect atopic dermatitis (eczema herpeticum), but this infection typically presents as painful groups of vesicles on an erythematous base, “punched-out” erosions, and hemorrhagic crusting. Intact herpetic vesicles may transition to pustules and may be difficult to distinguish from a staphylococcal infection. A viral cause should be suspected in a patient with superinfected atopic dermatitis who does not respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy. Treatment now with the antiviral agent famciclovir (
Option B
) is not indicated.

Although topical glucocorticoids are associated with multiple potential adverse effects, including skin thinning, purpura, and changes in pigmentation, their use is not directly associated with staphylococcal infection. Glucocorticoids may help reestablish the skin barrier by decreasing the inflammatory response of atopic dermatitis but would not treat a staphylococcal infection. Furthermore, betamethasone dipropionate, 0.05% (
Option C
), is a high-potency topical glucocorticoid, and use on flexural skin should be avoided if possible due to the high risk of skin thinning.

objective.__html: Diagnose Staphylococcus aureus infection in atopic dermatitis.

references: Ständer S. Atopic dermatitis. N Engl J Med. 2021;384:1136-43.

title: Question 178

children: A 17-year-old boy is evaluated for a 3-week history of cough following a typical upper respiratory tract infection. Although his symptoms of fever, headache, nasal congestion, and productive cough improved, a dry cough persisted. He has no other symptoms or medical problems.
On physical examination, there is a single episode of coughing. No other abnormalities are noted.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Subacute cough (3-8 weeks' duration) is most often a postinfectious cough following an acute respiratory tract infection, particularly viral or
Mycoplasma
infection.
Bordetella pertussis
infection should be considered in patients with subacute cough characterized by paroxysms of severe coughing and posttussive emesis.
Subacute cough (3-8 weeks' duration) is most often a postinfectious cough (
Option D
) following an acute respiratory tract infection, particularly a viral or
Mycoplasma

infection. The cough tends to be mild and generally improves progressively from the time of initial infection but may persist for 4 or more weeks. Postinfectious cough is usually caused by postnasal drip or airway hyperreactivity.
Cough-variant asthma (
Option A

) is a manifestation of asthma in which cough is the predominant presenting symptom. This patient has no other history or respiratory symptoms suggestive of asthma, and his clinical presentation is more consistent with a diagnosis of postinfectious cough.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease-related cough (
Option B

) is a common cause of persistent, mild cough; however, the onset of the patient's cough with an acute infectious process, the cough severity, and the lack of gastrointestinal symptoms makes this a less likely diagnosis.
Bordetella pertussis
infection should be considered in patients with subacute cough characterized by paroxysms of severe coughing and posttussive emesis (
Option C

). Although traditionally associated with children, more than half of cases of pertussis now occur in adolescents and adults. Symptoms in adults may be less severe than the “whooping cough” usually associated with infection in children, and a severe, persistent cough may be the primary clinical manifestation in adults. The incubation period is 7 to 10 days, which is then followed by the catarrhal phase that lasts for 1 to 2 weeks and is characterized by malaise, rhinorrhea, and mild cough. The paroxysmal phase, in which the other symptoms improve but the cough becomes severe, follows. Vigorous inspiration during paroxysms of cough causes the characteristic “whooping” sound, and the episodes of coughing may be severe enough to trigger emesis. This phase may last weeks to months if untreated, followed by the convalescent phase that lasts 1 to 3 months during which the cough slowly resolves. Pertussis is highly communicable, and treatment with a macrolide antibiotic in the first 2 to 3 weeks of infection decreases the severity of symptoms and decreases transmission of disease.

references: Irwin RS, French CL, Chang AB, et al; CHEST Expert Cough Panel*. Classification of cough as a symptom in adults and management algorithms: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;153:196-209.

title: Question 179

children: A 19-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-week history of polyuria and polydipsia. He has no other symptoms. His mother has type 1 diabetes, and his father has type 2 diabetes.
Other than a BMI of 30, physical examination is normal. Random
glucose
level is 324 mg/dL (18 mmol/L); kidney function, electrolytes, and urine ketones are normal.
Which of the following will help inform the management of this patient?

text.__html: Islet cell, insulin, and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody titers

children: In young patients with probable diabetes, the distinction between type 1 and type 2 diabetes should be made as soon as possible to inform the selection of proper therapy.
Among patients with newly recognized type 1 diabetes, 90% have measurable antibodies against specific β-cell proteins present at the time of diagnosis.
This patient's blood should be evaluated for pancreatic autoantibodies, such as islet cell antibodies (ICAs), insulin antibodies (IAs), and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (GADAs) (
Option C

). Although he has obesity and his father has type 2 diabetes, he may have type 1 diabetes presenting at an earlier stage of the disease process (when he still has significant endogenous insulin secretion) because of his obesity and insulin resistance. In young patients with probable diabetes, the distinction between type 1 and type 2 diabetes should be made as soon as possible. The presence of ICAs, IAs, or GADAs is suggestive of type 1 diabetes, and he should begin receiving insulin immediately. Among patients with newly recognized type 1 diabetes, 90% have measurable antibodies against specific β-cell proteins present at the time of diagnosis. Insulin treatment in type 1 diabetes helps preserve endogenous insulin secretion for a longer period, which makes it easier to achieve excellent glycemic control without hypoglycemia. If testing does not show these antibodies, type 2 diabetes is more likely. In addition to lifestyle modifications, therapy with insulin may be required initially for this patient to control hyperglycemic symptoms, but then he may be transitioned to oral therapy, such as metformin.
Measuring this patient's plasma C-peptide level (whether fasting or stimulated) (
Options A, D
) or fasting plasma insulin level (
Option B

) is less helpful in distinguishing type 1 from type 2 diabetes. A person who has obesity and hyperglycemia but no ketonuria or acidosis is clearly producing sufficient endogenous insulin now. Therefore, this patient's plasma C-peptide and insulin levels will both be high, no matter which type of diabetes he has.

references: American Diabetes Association Professional Practice Committee. 2. Classification and diagnosis of diabetes: standards of medical care in diabetes—2022. Diabetes Care. 2022;45:S17-S38.

title: Question 180

children: A 58-year-old man has a 24-hour history of acute, severe, and progressive retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia. He is being treated for early localized Lyme disease but has no other medical problems. His only medication is doxycycline, initiated 3 days ago.
Other than an annular skin lesion with central clearing in the left groin, the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Typical symptoms of pill-induced esophagitis include retrosternal pain, dysphagia, and odynophagia.
Tetracyclines, aspirin, NSAIDs, iron preparations, quinidine, potassium, and bisphosphonates have been identified as causative agents for pill-induced esophagitis.
The most likely diagnosis is pill-induced esophagitis (
Option D

) caused by doxycycline, which is acidic and may cause mucosal burn and ulceration. Typical symptoms of pill-induced esophagitis include retrosternal pain, dysphagia, and odynophagia. The injury usually occurs at sites of anatomic narrowing of the esophagus, such as the aortic arch, the gastroesophageal junction, or the esophageal indentation caused by an enlarged left atrium. Symptoms may begin hours to days after therapy is started. GERD increases the risk for pill-induced esophagitis by providing an acidic environment and decreasing esophageal motility, which prolongs the pill contact time with the esophageal mucosa. Other risk factors include decreased salivary output, large pills, medications that increase the lower esophageal sphincter tone (opioids, anticholinergic agents), ingestion of medications in the supine position, and taking pills without adequate water ingestion. Tetracyclines, aspirin, NSAIDs, iron preparations, quinidine, potassium, and bisphosphonates have been identified as causative agents. Treatment includes avoiding the culprit medication, if possible. It is unclear if antacids, histamine-2 receptor blockers, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), or sucralfate are beneficial. PPIs are used if GERD is an associated comorbid condition. Preventive strategies to decrease pill-induced esophagitis include drinking plenty of water and remaining upright for 30 minutes after taking the medication.
Diffuse esophageal spasm (
Option A

) is a hypercontractile state presenting with dysphagia for liquids and solids and may be associated with chest pain. Symptoms often respond to nitroglycerin, suggesting a flaw in esophageal nitric oxide production. The esophagus has a “corkscrew” or “rosary bead” appearance on esophagography. Esophageal manometry shows simultaneous high-amplitude (>30 mm Hg) esophageal contractions with intermittent aperistaltic contractions. This patient's symptoms of chest pain and odynophagia after starting doxycycline are a much more compelling history for pill-induced esophagitis.
Eosinophilic esophagitis (
Option B

) is defined as esophageal squamous mucosal inflammation caused by eosinophilic infiltration. It is usually seen in young men with an history of atopy who present with dysphagia and food impaction. Patients do not describe chest pain or odynophagia.
Infectious esophagitis is often caused by herpes simplex virus (
Option C
Candida albicans

, or cytomegalovirus and typically occurs in patients who are immunosuppressed or have swallowed aerosolized glucocorticoids. Dysphagia and odynophagia are usually present in infectious esophagitis, but chest pain is less common. Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus esophagitis is made by endoscopic biopsy. This patient has no risk factors for herpes simplex virus esophagitis.

references: Syed M. Pill-induced oesophagitis. Postgrad Med J. 2021;97:349-350.

title: Question 181

children: A 59-year-old man is evaluated before undergoing total left hip arthroplasty. He has dyslipidemia, hypertension, and a history of a minor stroke 3 years ago. His estimated risk for major adverse cardiac event is greater than 1%. He has heartburn with exertion. Medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and losartan.
Examination of the left hip shows restricted and painful passive range of motion. The remainder of the examination is normal. ECG shows no resting abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative testing?

In the preoperative evaluation of coronary artery disease, guidelines recommend noninvasive pharmacologic stress testing (either dobutamine stress echocardiography or pharmacologic stress myocardial perfusion imaging) for patients at increased risk of a major adverse cardiovascular event or if assessed functioning is less than four metabolic equivalents, provided that testing will change management.
This patient should undergo pharmacologic stress testing (
Option C

) before his total left hip arthroplasty. Patients at highest risk for perioperative cardiac complications are those with pre-existing cardiovascular conditions. Risk factors that predispose to higher risk for a major adverse cardiac event (MACE) include ischemic heart disease, compensated heart failure, diabetes mellitus, cerebrovascular disease, and chronic kidney disease. Guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) are commonly used, in conjunction with validated risk assessment tools, such as the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Surgical Risk Calculator and the Revised Cardiac Risk Index, to assess risk for MACE. This patient has cardiovascular risk factors, an estimated risk for MACE of greater than 1%, and no reliable means of assessing his functional capacity. In this situation, or if his assessed functional capacity was less than four metabolic equivalents, it is reasonable to perform additional testing. The ACC/AHA recommends noninvasive pharmacological stress testing (either dobutamine stress echocardiography or pharmacological stress myocardial perfusion imaging) if testing will change management.
Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging (
Option A

) may be used with dobutamine to assess wall motion abnormalities or with vasodilators to assess perfusion. It is commonly performed to evaluate degree of infarction. Viability can be determined by evaluating the extent of myocardial fibrosis within the left ventricle. Measures of right and left ventricular function can be obtained with gating. CMR imaging is limited by operator expertise, length of time for image acquisition, and availability and is not the best initial or recommended diagnostic test for this patient.
Calcification of the coronary arteries is indicative of atherosclerosis and may be quantified with CT. Although coronary artery calcium scoring (
Option B
) provides information regarding the burden of disease, it cannot determine the degree of obstruction or myocardial functioning.
Because this patient is at elevated risk for MACE and has uninvestigated exertional chest discomfort, no further testing (
Option D
) would not be an appropriate choice because test results could change management.

objective.__html: Assess perioperative cardiac risk with pharmacologic stress testing.

references: Smilowitz NR, Berger JS. Perioperative cardiovascular risk assessment and management for noncardiac surgery: A review. JAMA. 2020;324:279-290.

title: Question 182

children: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated after an unprovoked pulmonary embolism. Family history is negative for venous thromboembolism. She is otherwise healthy and has never been pregnant.
Physical examination findings are remarkable only for livedo reticularis on both lower extremities. Results of laboratory studies show a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time.
Anticoagulation therapy is initiated.
Which of the following tests will support the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Genetic testing for factor V Leiden

children: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome diagnosis requires the presence of objectively documented arterial or venous thromboembolism or pregnancy morbidity and positive laboratory results (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody assay, anti–β
-glycoprotein antibody assay) on at least two occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
A clue to the presence of the lupus anticoagulant is activated partial thromboplastin time prolongation.
Antiphospholipid antibody testing (
Option A

) will support the most likely diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. This patient's prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), the presence of livedo reticularis, and newly diagnosed pulmonary embolism suggest antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLAS). Livedo reticularis is characterized by a blue or purple network-like pattern on the lower extremities and is classically the result of impaired blood flow in medium-sized cutaneous vessels due to vasculitis, vasospasm, hypercoagulable states, thrombosis, increased blood viscosity, or emboli. The APLAS diagnosis requires the presence of objectively documented arterial or venous thromboembolism or pregnancy morbidity and positive laboratory results (lupus anticoagulant [LAC], anticardiolipin antibody assay, anti–β

-glycoprotein antibody assay) on at least two occasions at least 12 weeks apart. Pregnancy morbidity includes at least three unexplained pregnancy losses at less than 10 weeks' gestation; one or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at greater than 10 weeks' gestation; or one or more premature births of a normal fetus before 34 weeks' gestation because of eclampsia, preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency. LAC testing is functional coagulation testing to detect phospholipid-dependent inhibitors. Two commonly used tests optimized for this purpose are the dilute Russell viper venom time and aPTT. Because it is functional, LAC testing is affected by test timing in relation to the clot and anticoagulants. Antibody tests for anticardiolipin antibody and anti–β

-glycoprotein 1 antibody are not affected by anticoagulation. Tests with abnormal results should be repeated in 12 weeks to confirm the diagnosis. Hypercoagulability testing is not recommended in most patients with venous thromboembolism (VTE). However, diagnosing APLAS is important because most patients typically need longer-term anticoagulation, and APLAS testing can influence the choice of anticoagulant.

Factor V Leiden (FVL) is the most common inherited thrombophilia. Activated factor V combines with factor X to produce thrombin, which leads to clot formation. This process is regulated by activated protein C, which inactivates factor V to stop the process of ongoing clot formation. In FVL, mutated factor V resists cleavage by activated protein C, leading to a prothrombotic state. Although persons who are heterozygous have a fourfold to eightfold increased risk for developing a first VTE compared with otherwise healthy persons, most remain asymptomatic, and recent studies suggest that these patients are not at higher risk for recurrent thrombosis compared with healthy persons. This patient does not have a family history of thrombosis, and FVL does not increase the aPTT; therefore, genetic testing for FVL (
Option B
) is not indicated.
Methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase (
MTHFR
) gene mutations are associated with a modestly increased (1.6-fold) risk for VTE. Testing for
MTHFR
mutations (
Option C
) would not change management in this patient, and
MTHFR
mutations would not cause increased aPTT.

Protein C is a vitamin K–dependent protein that degrades activated factors V and VIII. Heterozygous protein C deficiency has a prevalence of 2 to 5 per 1000 persons and is often associated with pregnancy morbidity or a thrombotic event before age 50 years, with a strong family history of thrombosis. Protein C functional testing (
Option D

) may be ordered to evaluate for deficiency. This patient does not have a family history of thrombosis, and protein C deficiency does not cause a prolonged aPTT; therefore, protein C functional testing is not necessary.

references: Garcia D, Erkan D. Diagnosis and management of the antiphospholipid syndrome. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:2010-2021.

title: Question 183

children: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated after being transferred from an acute care hospital to a skilled nursing facility. She is bedbound with a spinal cord injury.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Three 1- to 2-cm, nonblanching, erythematous, shallow ulcers with no purulence or necrosis are noted over the sacrum and bilateral ischial tuberosities.
Hydrocolloid dressings are applied, and frequent repositioning is instituted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Patients at risk for or diagnosed with pressure injuries should be repositioned a minimum of every 2 hours to reduce pressure on jeopardized tissue.

Foam mattresses or foam overlays have been shown to reduce the incidence of pressure injury postoperatively, which is the basis for recommending foam mattresses or overlays for medical inpatients and others at risk.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient's pressure injuries is pressure redistribution and use of a foam mattress or foam mattress overlay (
Option A

). Limited evidence suggests that patients at risk for or diagnosed with pressure injuries should be repositioned a minimum of every 2 hours to reduce pressure on jeopardized tissue. It is important to avoid generating shear forces or friction during this procedure. The other element in pressure redistribution is the use of a pressure-reducing support surface. Many different categories of support surfaces are available, and within each category, there are a variety of different products. Head-to-head comparisons of support surfaces are generally lacking, and available evidence is weak. However, high-quality foam mattresses or foam overlays have been shown to reduce the incidence of pressure injury postoperatively. This is the basis for recommending foam mattresses or overlays for medical inpatients and others at risk. Foam mattresses and overlays have the advantages of availability and relatively low cost.
There are no studies to suggest that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (
Option B

) is beneficial for pressure injury. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been used in the treatment of other types of wounds, and although some short-term benefits can be seen with certain wounds, evidence of long-term benefits is lacking.
Imipenem and vancomycin (
Option C

) are not appropriate because there is no evidence of infection. Infected pressure injuries are recognized by the presence of warmth, erythema, increased tenderness, purulence, and foul odor. Failure of healing may be the primary manifestation of infection in some patients. Fever and leukocytosis are typically absent. This patient does have some nonblanching erythema around the ulcers, but this alone does not indicate infection or need for antibiotics. Empiric treatment with imipenem and vancomycin would be indicted in patients with severe cellulitis and deep soft tissue infection or with sepsis.
No evidence exists to support the use of zinc or vitamin C (
Option D
) in treating pressure injuries. Low- to moderate-strength evidence for use of protein-containing nutritional supplements has been demonstrated.

references: Munoz N, Posthauer ME, Cereda E, et al. The role of nutrition for pressure injury prevention and healing: the 2019 international clinical practice guideline recommendations. Adv Skin Wound Care. 2020;33:123-136.

title: Question 184

children: A 28-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-day history of an intensely pruritic rash on his arms and torso. Individual lesions appear suddenly, may persist for only a few hours, and then disappear, but new lesions appear in other locations. He works outside as a horticulturist. He is otherwise well and takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. A representation of the rash on his inner arm is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Individual urticarial lesions may be erythematous or white, often surrounded by a red halo, and have a variety of shapes, including round, oval, annular, arciform, and serpiginous; the center of a lesion is typically blanchable pink or clear skin.
Although individual urticarial lesions should resolve in less than 24 hours, recurrent crops of hives may last for weeks.
This patient has acute urticaria (
Option A

). Urticaria, also known as hives, is a common skin finding caused by mast cell degranulation and release of inflammatory proteins. This results in sudden, but transient, cutaneous swelling and erythema. Individual lesions may be erythematous or white, often surrounded by a red halo, and have a variety of shapes, including round, oval, annular, arciform, and serpiginous. The center of a lesion is typically blanchable pink or clear skin. These lesions are extremely pruritic and tend to appear on body sites with repetitive pressure or rubbing, such as the waistline and posterior neck. Although individual urticarial lesions should resolve in less than 24 hours, recurrent crops of hives may last for weeks. Acute urticaria may be related to environmental allergens, including drugs, viral infections, foods, and occasionally inhalants; however, in most cases, the cause is never determined. This man with transient, well-demarcated, pruritic plaques exhibits key features of acute urticaria. Chronic urticaria is an urticarial condition lasting longer than 6 weeks. If individual urticarial lesions do not resolve after 24 hours, or if they are accompanied by pain or systemic symptoms (joint pain, fever), urticarial vasculitis must be considered.
Angioedema (
Option B

) is a severe, life-threatening form of urticaria. The hallmark of angioedema is self-limited, localized swelling of the skin or mucosa, usually the lips, face, hands, feet, penis, or scrotum. The skin is either normal or red in color, and itching is absent unless associated with urticarial lesions. This man has urticaria that is neither severe nor localized to characteristic angioedema body locations.
Contact with the plant oil urushiol, a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis, is found in plants such as poison ivy (
Option C

), oak, and sumac. Clinically, patients present with intensely pruritic, often linear, vesicular papules, plaques, and vesicles. Lesions can present at different locations at different times up to 14 days after exposure in sensitized patients. This patient has transient pruritic papules without vesicles, a finding not consistent with poison ivy reaction.
Most spider bites (
Option D

) are characterized by wheals, papules, or pustules. It is rare to see a punctum. Bites may itch or burn with most symptoms resolving in about 1 week. Bites may become secondarily infected from scratching. The widespread, transient, and recurring nature of this patient's rash is not consistent with spider bites.

references: Saini S, Shams M, Bernstein JA, et al. Urticaria and angioedema across the ages. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2020;8:1866-1874.

title: Question 185

children: A 75-year-old woman is hospitalized for osteomyelitis of a right toe phalanx secondary to an ischemic ulcer. On day 1, she undergoes angiography and stenting of the iliac artery. On day 3, bone culture–directed vancomycin and gentamicin are initiated at therapeutically appropriate dosages. On day 8, she develops non-oliguric acute kidney injury.
Vital signs are normal. A healing foot ulcer is noted. Urinalysis shows brown granular casts.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?

Aminoglycoside-induced acute kidney injury typically presents as non-oliguric acute tubular necrosis with pigmented granular casts and tubular epithelial cells in the urine sediment 5 to 7 days after starting therapy.

Contrast-associated acute kidney injury is defined as either an increase in serum creatinine of 0.5 mg/dL (44.2 µmol/L) or an increase in serum creatinine of 25% from baseline at 48 hours after contrast administration.
This patient has developed acute kidney injury (AKI) from gentamicin (
Option C

). Aminoglycoside-induced AKI typically presents as non-oliguric acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with pigmented granular casts and tubular epithelial cells in the urine sediment. There is a loss of renal concentrating ability due to tubular damage; the urine osmolality is around 300 mOsm/kg H
O. If measured, the FE
Na

is >1%. The serum creatinine level characteristically rises 5 to 7 days after starting therapy. Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia also can occur with aminoglycoside toxicity due to potassium and magnesium wasting. Recognizing drug-induced ATN is important because eliminating the nephrotoxic agent often leads to renal recovery. Common medications that can cause ATN include other aminoglycosides, vancomycin, cisplatin, contrast agents, mannitol, hydroxyethyl starch, and dextran. ATN can also occur due to cannabinoid and amphetamine use, in addition to pigment deposition. Incidence of toxic ATN increases in older patients and in patients with decreased effective blood volume, chronic kidney disease, or concomitant nephrotoxin exposure, such as vancomycin in this case.
Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is a common cause of AKI characterized by inflammation and edema of the interstitium (
Option A

). The classic clinical presentation of fever, rash, and peripheral eosinophilia occurs in only 10% to 30% of patients with AIN. Urinary findings can include eosinophiluria by Hansel stain, leukocytes, erythrocytes, and leukocyte casts. Brown granular casts are not consistent with AIN.
Contrast-associated AKI (
Option B

) is defined as either an increase in serum creatinine of 0.5 mg/dL (44.2 µmol/L) or an increase in serum creatinine of 25% from baseline at 48 hours after contrast administration. This patient had no change in the serum creatinine level until day 8, making contrast-associated AKI an unlikely diagnosis.
Infection-related glomerulonephritis (IRGN) (
Option D

) can develop at the time of infection or weeks later. IRGN is an immune complex–mediated disease. The antigen in the immune complex is derived from the infectious agent. After depositing in the subepithelial area (either within preformed immune complexes or as in-situ immune complex formation), complement activation and subsequent recruitment of inflammatory cells occur, leading to a proliferative glomerulonephritis. Patients with IRGN clinically present with acute nephritic syndrome. The patient's urinalysis that shows only granular casts, making IRGN an unlikely diagnosis.

references: Perazella MA. Drug-induced acute kidney injury: diverse mechanisms of tubular injury. Curr Opin Crit Care. 2019;25:550-557.

title: Question 186

children: A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for 2 days of lower abdominal pain. She is otherwise healthy.

Temperature is 37.6 °C (99.8 °F). Bowel sounds are present. There is tenderness in the left lower quadrant without guarding or rigidity. Contrast CT scan shows sigmoid diverticula with focal bowel wall thickening and inflammation of the pericolic fat.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Current guidelines based on high-quality evidence strongly recommend that antibiotics be avoided in select patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis.
Immunocompromised patients with acute diverticulitis and those with systemic infection or associated comorbidities should be treated with antibiotics.
The most appropriate management strategy for a healthy patient with early uncomplicated diverticulitis is observation (
Option D

). Diverticulitis results from obstruction at the diverticular neck by fecal matter, leading to mucus accumulation, bacterial overgrowth, and inflammation. Left lower quadrant pain is the most common clinical manifestation and is often accompanied by fever. Other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. An elevated leukocyte count, C-reactive protein level, or procalcitonin level supports the diagnosis. Diverticulitis may be diagnosed based on the history and physical examination, but imaging is helpful and can predict failure of medical treatment and development of complications. Although uncomplicated diverticulitis traditionally has been treated with oral antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin, current guidelines based on high-quality evidence strongly recommend that antibiotics be avoided in select patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis. The supporting evidence for this recommendation implies that such patients include otherwise healthy adults with early diverticular disease. Immunocompromised patients and those with systemic infection or associated comorbidities should be treated with antibiotics.
Acute diverticulitis may be associated with colon cancer, but colonoscopy (
Option A

) should be avoided in the acute setting because of the increased risk for perforation and potential worsening of inflammation. Colonoscopy is advised after resolution of an episode of complicated diverticulitis and after resolution of a first episode of uncomplicated diverticulitis. Colonoscopy should be delayed by 6 to 8 weeks after an acute episode or until complete resolution of the acute symptoms, whichever is longer, unless there are alarm features suggesting colon cancer.
Hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics, such as piperacillin-tazobactam (
Option B

), are generally reserved for patients with complicated diverticulitis (abscess, fistula, obstruction, peritonitis, or stricture) or significant comorbidities, as well as for those who cannot tolerate oral intake. Antibiotics should at least include coverage for anaerobes and gram-negative bacilli.
Surgery (
Option C
) for acute diverticulitis is indicated for patients who present with or develop peritonitis, perforation, obstruction, or persistent sepsis. This patient has no indication for surgery.

references: Hall J, Hardiman K, Lee S, et al; Prepared on behalf of the Clinical Practice Guidelines Committee of the American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons. The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of left-sided colonic diverticulitis. Dis Colon Rectum. 2020;63:728-747.

title: Question 187

children: A 74-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive mouth swelling and hoarseness over the past 15 hours. She was started on valsartan-sacubitril 2 days ago for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Other medications include metoprolol and furosemide.
Respiration rate is 28/min with inspiratory stridor;

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: oxygen saturation
is 96% with the patient breathing ambient air. Lungs are clear. Lips and tongue are edematous.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Angioedema (localized subcutaneous or submucosal swelling of face, lips, or upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract) can be mast cell mediated (i.e., histaminergic), as in allergic IgE-mediated reactions to foods, drugs, and insect stings.

Angioedema due to an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor is mediated largely by bradykinin, and acute treatment involves discontinuing the drug and carefully monitoring the airway until the episode is clearly resolving.
The most appropriate next step in management is endotracheal intubation (
Option A

). This patient is experiencing angioedema, likely triggered by use of the angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) valsartan-sacubitril, and should be intubated immediately because she is at high risk of asphyxiation from upper airway edema. Angioedema (localized subcutaneous or submucosal swelling of face, lips, or upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract) can be mast cell mediated (i.e., histaminergic), as in allergic IgE-mediated reactions to foods, drugs, and insect stings. The absence of signs and symptoms of allergic reaction, such as urticaria, pruritus, bronchospasm, and hypotension, is more typical of bradykinin-mediated angioedema, which can be seen with hereditary angioedema, acquired C1-inhibitor deficiency, and ARNI or ACE inhibitor use. Although angioedema is most often reported early after starting or increasing the dose of an ARNI or ACE inhibitor, it can occur years later. The risk for recurrence with continued exposure to an ARNI or ACE inhibitor is substantial, and patients should be switched to an alternative medication. Angioedema typically resolves within 2 to 3 days of discontinuation.
Epinephrine (
Option B
) is useful in the treatment of upper airway obstruction triggered by anaphylactic reactions, and methylprednisolone (
Option D

) may be useful in patients with cutaneous allergic reactions. However, these agents have no clear role in the treatment of bradykinin-mediated angioedema associated with ARNI or ACE inhibitors. This patient's airway is severely compromised, and there is insufficient time to delay intubation in order to allow a trial of therapy. Patients with severe angioedema may require nasotracheal intubation.

Angioedema due to an ARNI or ACE inhibitor is mediated largely by bradykinin, and acute treatment involves discontinuing the drug and carefully monitoring the airway (if that is the affected area) until the episode is clearly resolving. There are no pharmacologic therapies with proven efficacy in ARNI- or ACE inhibitor–induced angioedema, although some treatments for other bradykinin-mediated forms of angioedema, such as intravenous C1 inhibitor (
Option C

) for hereditary angioedema, may be used in severe cases. The data on C1 inhibitor therapy for ARNI or ACE inhibitor angioedema are mixed, but even if therapy were effective, the first order of medical care is to intubate and protect this patient's airway.

references: Rosenbaum S, Wilkerson RG, Winters ME, et al. Clinical practice statement: what is the emergency department management of patients with angioedema secondary to an ACE-inhibitor? J Emerg Med. 2021;61:105-112.

title: Question 188

children: A 43-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo an emergency root canal for irreversible pulpitis. She has a prosthetic mitral valve. She has severe dental pain but is otherwise well and has never had an episode of endocarditis. She is able to take oral medications and has no drug allergies.
Which of the following is the most appropriate endocarditis prophylaxis?

High-risk cardiac conditions requiring infective endocarditis prophylaxis include prosthetic cardiac valves, prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, a history of previous infective endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects or abnormalities, and cardiac transplantation with valvulopathy resulting in valvular regurgitation.

Endocarditis prophylaxis in high-risk patients is reasonable for dental procedures that involve manipulation of the gingival tissue or periapical region of the teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa but are not recommended for nondental procedures, including transesophageal echocardiography and genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures in the absence of active infection.
Amoxicillin (
Option A

) is appropriate prophylaxis before this patient's dental procedure. Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis (IE) is recommended for patients with underlying conditions with the highest risk for an adverse outcome from IE, which do not include heart murmurs associated with native valve abnormalities. Although prophylaxis previously had been widely provided to persons with murmurs before dental procedures, it has been found that the bacteremia associated with dental procedures is much less likely to cause IE than the bacteremia resulting from poor oral hygiene and gingival disease and that only an extremely small number of cases of community-acquired IE are prevented by prophylaxis. Therefore, antibiotic prophylaxis is now recommended only for high-risk patients and only when those patients undergo specific procedures in which risk for bacteremia is higher.

High-risk cardiac conditions include prosthetic cardiac valves, prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, a history of prior IE, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects or abnormalities, surgical or transcatheter pulmonary valve or conduit placement, and cardiac transplantation with valvulopathy resulting in valvular regurgitation. Endocarditis prophylaxis in high-risk patients is reasonable for dental procedures that involve manipulation of the gingival tissue or periapical region of the teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa. Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent bacterial endocarditis is not recommended for nondental procedures, including transesophageal echocardiography and genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures in the absence of active infection. In patients with an indication for treatment, antibiotics directed toward viridans streptococci are recommended. Oral amoxicillin and, in penicillin-allergic patients, oral cephalexin are recommended. In patients unable to take oral medications, ampicillin, cefazolin, or ceftriaxone can be given intramuscularly or intravenously; in penicillin-allergic patients (nonsevere, non–IgE-mediated penicillin allergy), cefazolin or ceftriaxone can also be given intramuscularly or intravenously.
In an updated American Heart Association guideline, clindamycin (
Option B
) is no longer a suggestive alternative to amoxicillin because it is associated with more frequent occurrence of
Clostridioides difficile infection
and other adverse effects.
Some fluoroquinolones have activity against a limited number of gram-positive organisms, but their potency is often less than that of other antibiotics. Ciprofloxacin (
Option C
) particularly has limited activity against gram-positive organisms and would be a poor choice for endocarditis prevention in this patient.
This patient with a prosthetic mitral valve has an indication for endocarditis prophylaxis; therefore, no prophylaxis is inappropriate (
Option D

references: Wilson WR, Gewitz M, Lockhart PB, et al; American Heart Association Young Hearts Rheumatic Fever, Endocarditis and Kawasaki Disease Committee of the Council on Lifelong Congenital Heart Disease and Heart Health in the Young; Council on Cardiovascular and Stroke Nursing; and the Council on Quality of Care and Outcomes Research. Prevention of viridans group streptococcal infective endocarditis: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2021;e963-e978.

title: Question 189

children: A 74-year-old woman has a 1-week history of melena and midepigastric pain. Today she developed sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain. She has osteoarthritis of the hands and takes ibuprofen daily.

Blood pressure is 100/56 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 110/min. There is generalized abdominal distension, absent bowel sounds, and abdominal rigidity. An upright radiograph of the chest and abdomen shows no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
Helicobacter pylori
infection and NSAID use account for most cases of peptic ulcer disease.
If chronic NSAID therapy is needed, patients, including those taking a COX-2 inhibitor, should concomitantly take a proton pump inhibitor to reduce the risk for peptic ulcer disease.
This patient likely has complicated peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and should undergo abdominal CT (
Option A

) to evaluate for perforation, which carries a high mortality rate and requires immediate surgical treatment. A classic diagnostic triad of peptic ulcer perforation is sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and abdominal rigidity. Although PUD may be an incidental endoscopic finding, some patients experience epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting, abdominal distension, and bleeding, manifested as melena or hematochezia. Possible causes of PUD include Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, glucocorticoids, and bisphosphonates, but
Helicobacter pylori

infection and NSAID use account for most cases. If chronic NSAID therapy is needed, patients, including those taking a COX-2 inhibitor, should concomitantly take a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). Aspirin may cause PUD but must be reintroduced as soon as possible in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) to avoid the associated excess morbidity and mortality. Aspirin taken for primary prevention of ASCVD should be stopped permanently.

Complications of PUD include perforation, gastric outlet obstruction, and penetration of adjacent organs, but upper gastrointestinal bleeding is the most common complication. Thermocoagulation, injection of sclerosing agents, and placement of clips are examples of endoscopic intervention, the treatment of choice in patients with PUD complicated by bleeding. PPIs should be used, as they facilitate healing by reducing the acid burden to which the ulcer is exposed.
Abdominal ultrasonography (
Option B

) can detect small amounts of intraperitoneal air and support the diagnosis of peptic ulcer perforation. However, abdominal CT is more accurate and is the imaging test of choice for suspected perforation.
Catheter-based abdominal angiography (
Option C

) is not indicated in a patient with suspected visceral perforation; this diagnostic modality and simultaneous embolization are usually reserved for patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic treatment.
Upper endoscopy (
Option D

) is the test of choice for patients with increased risk for malignancy or alarm symptoms, such as weight loss and iron deficiency, and for patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, but it should not be performed in those with confirmed or suspected perforation.

references: Kavitt RT, Lipowska AM, Anyane-Yeboa A, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Am J Med. 2019;132:447-456.

title: Question 190

children: A 71-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative evaluation before total right knee arthroplasty. She is overweight and has knee osteoarthritis. She has no cardiovascular symptoms or risk factors other than age.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 28. Cardiovascular examination is normal. There is crepitus, decreased range of motion, bony enlargement, and a small effusion of the right knee.
Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative testing?

If preoperative evaluation reveals coronary artery disease risk factors, the estimated risk for a major adverse cardiac event should be calculated using a validated risk assessment tool; patients with low calculated cardiovascular risk (<1%) may proceed to surgery without additional evaluation, whereas patients with elevated risk (≥1%) should have functional capacity assessed with a validated tool such as the Duke Activity Status Index score.
If the functional capacity of a patient exceeds four metabolic equivalents, the patient may proceed to surgery without further testing.
No cardiac testing is needed (
Option D

). Guidelines from the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association recommend first assessing the patient for the presence of coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors, which may include known CAD, cerebrovascular disease, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, and heart failure. In the absence of risk factors, the patient can proceed to surgery without additional evaluation. In patients with CAD risk factors, the estimated risk for a major adverse cardiac event should be calculated using a validated risk assessment tool. Patients with low calculated cardiovascular risk (<1%) may proceed to surgery without additional evaluation, whereas patients with elevated risk (≥1%) should have functional capacity assessed. Metabolic equivalents are used to represent a patient's functional capacity based on the intensity of activity the patient can perform. If functional capacity exceeds four metabolic equivalents, the patient may proceed to surgery without further testing. The Duke Activity Status Index score is a standardized and accurate means of estimating functional capacity and outperforms unaided physician judgement, including asking a patient how fast they can walk, or if they can run, climb a hill, or climb stairs.
Anatomic assessment of the epicardial coronary arteries can be performed with noninvasive coronary CT angiography (
Option A

) or invasive angiography. Both tests require administration of contrast agents and expose the patient to radiation. Coronary angiography is indicated only for patients with severe or unstable CAD or significant ischemia detected by noninvasive testing. It is not indicated in this patient.

Preoperative cardiac stress testing should be considered in patients at elevated risk for a major adverse cardiac event with functional capacity objectively assessed to not be low risk, but only if the results will change perioperative management. This patient has no indication for stress testing. If stress testing were indicated, exercise stress testing (
Option B
) would be a poor choice for a patient with knee osteoarthritis; pharmacologic stress testing would likely be a better choice.
Transthoracic echocardiography (
Option C

) is not an appropriate modality for CAD assessment and is not indicated in this patient. In certain clinical situations, echocardiography may be indicated (such as heart failure with worsening dyspnea, dyspnea of unknown origin, or diagnosed [or suspected] moderate to severe valvular stenosis or regurgitation without echocardiographic assessment in the past year or with a recent change in clinical status); this patient has none of these conditions.

objective.__html: Assess preoperative risk in a patient at low cardiac risk.

references: Smilowitz NR, Berger JS. Perioperative cardiovascular risk assessment and management for noncardiac surgery: a review. JAMA. 2020;324:279-290.

title: Question 191

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent epigastric pain 8 weeks after completing treatment with amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and omeprazole for a
Helicobacter pylori
–positive duodenal ulcer. The local clarithromycin
H. pylori
