resistance rate is less than 15%, and the patient was adherent to the medication regimen.
Physical examination and hemoglobin measurement are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Repeat amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and omeprazole therapy

children: All patients with
Helicobacter pylori
infection must be treated and then retested 8 weeks later to document eradication.
Both the stool antigen test and urea breath test for
Helicobacter pylori
have sensitivities and specificities greater than 95%; the antigen test is widely available and less expensive.
The most appropriate next diagnostic test is the
Helicobacter pylori
stool antigen test (
Option A
). All patients with
H. pylori

infection must be treated and then retested 8 weeks later to document eradication. Both the stool antigen test and the urea breath test have sensitivities and specificities greater than 95%; the antigen test is widely available and less expensive.
H. pylori

is a highly prevalent infection associated with dyspepsia, gastric and duodenal ulcers, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma. Associations with unexplained iron deficiency and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura have been described as well. Several therapeutic regimens (all of which must include a proton pump inhibitor [PPI]) have been found to be effective in the eradication of
H. pylori,

including the commonly prescribed macrolide-based triple therapy (clarithromycin, omeprazole, and amoxicillin or metronidazole). This regimen should not be used in patients with documented penicillin allergy, those previously treated with a macrolide, or those who live in an area with a macrolide resistance rate of 15% or greater. In these patients, quadruple bismuth-based therapy (bismuth, tetracycline, PPI, and metronidazole) is recommended. Patients are treated orally for 10 to 14 days. Due to the suppressive effect on
H. pylori
, patients should be tested at least 30 days after discontinuing treatment.
The presence of IgG
H. pylori
antibodies (
Option B
) reflects exposure to
H. pylori
but not necessarily active infection. IgG
H. pylori
antibody testing is not recommended in countries with a prevalence of 30% or less, such as the United States.
Repeating triple therapy with amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and omeprazole (
Option C
) for recurrent symptoms of
H. pylori

infection is not appropriate. Instead, quadruple therapy with bismuth subcitrate or subsalicylate, tetracycline, metronidazole, and a PPI is recommended for failure of first-line clarithromycin-based therapy. More importantly,
H. pylori
infection must be documented before quadruple therapy can be recommended.
Although histologic sampling has a sensitivity greater than 95%, upper endoscopy with biopsy (
Option D
) is usually unnecessary to document
H. pylori
infection or eradication in patients younger than 60 years with low risk for malignancy and no alarm symptoms, such as weight loss or anemia.

references: Chey WD, Leontiadis GI, Howden CW, et al. ACG clinical guideline: treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection. Am J Gastroenterol. 2017;112:212-39.

title: Question 192

children: A 22-year-old woman reports a 2-day history of sore throat that worsens with swallowing and fever without a cough. She also reports fatigue, headache, and malaise but no neck pain. She has an allergy to penicillin, manifesting as a maculopapular rash.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F). The pharynx is erythematous with tonsillar enlargement and exudates bilaterally. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Rapid streptococcal antigen detection test result is positive.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

The Centor criteria (presence of temperature >38.0 °C [100.4 °F], tonsillar exudates, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, absence of cough) predict the likelihood of streptococcal pharyngitis, and using these criteria is a reasonable way to triage patients for further testing for group A β-hemolytic streptococcal pharyngitis.

Patients with fewer than three Centor criteria have a low (<3%) probability of group A β-hemolytic streptococcal pharyngitis and do not require testing; patients with three or more criteria should undergo testing with a rapid antigen detection test.
This patient should receive cephalexin therapy (
Option A

). The patient's primary symptoms of fever and sore throat are compatible with either a viral upper respiratory tract infection or streptococcal pharyngitis. The Centor criteria (presence of temperature >38.0 °C [100.4 °F], tonsillar exudates, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, absence of cough) predict the likelihood of streptococcal pharyngitis, and using these criteria is a reasonable way to triage patients for further testing for group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis. Patients with fewer than three criteria have a low (<3%) probability of GABHS pharyngitis. Patients with three or more criteria, such as this patient, have an intermediate probability of GABHS pharyngitis; a rapid antigen detection test (RADT) should be performed, with confirmation of negative results with a throat culture only in patients at high risk for complications (immunocompromised patients). The advantage of the RADT is the immediate availability of results and high specificity (between 88% and 99%); if the test is positive, patients should be treated with antibiotics. The RADT has comparable sensitivity and specificity to throat culture. No guidelines recommend antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis without confirmatory testing. For patients with confirmed GABHS pharyngitis and penicillin allergy, cephalosporins and macrolide antibiotics such as clarithromycin (or clindamycin) can be substituted.
This patient with a positive rapid streptococcal antigen detection test can be treated without a confirmatory throat culture (
Option B
Fusobacterium necrophorum
Option C
) has been implicated in approximately 10% to 20% of endemic pharyngitis cases in adolescents.
F. necrophorum

infection can cause Lemierre syndrome, a rare suppurative complication of pharyngitis caused by local spread of infection with resultant septic thrombosis of the internal jugular vein. Routine testing for
F. necrophorum

is not recommended. However, a high index of suspicion should be maintained for patients with severe pharyngitis or patients with pharyngitis and neck pain that does not respond to appropriate antibiotics.
Supportive therapy with no further testing (
Option D
) would not be an appropriate choice for this patient with possible GABHS pharyngitis.

references: Harris AM, Hicks LA, Qaseem A; High Value Care Task Force of the American College of Physicians and for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Appropriate antibiotic use for acute respiratory tract infection in adults: advice for high-value care from the American College of Physicians and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Question 193

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for apathy, difficulty with her memory, insomnia, fatigue, and constipation since her partner died 13 months ago. She also has diabetes mellitus, COPD, chronic stable angina, and narrow-angle glaucoma.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The patient appears uninterested during the examination. PHQ-9 score is 12. Mini-Cog assessment is normal, but answers are slow in coming.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Mild to moderate depression in elderly patients can be treated with psychotherapy or antidepressant medications.

Second-generation antidepressants, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, are recommended as first-line pharmacologic therapy for depression; caution is advised for patients on multiple medications because medication interactions may occur.
This patient should receive sertraline (
Option C

). Elderly patients with depression, such as this one, may have somatic and vegetative symptoms that are often misattributed to chronic illnesses or dementia. Evaluation for depression is recommended for all adults. The PHQ-9 is validated in elderly adults and has a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 92%, with a cutoff score of 10 or greater. The Geriatric Depression Scale has a sensitivity of 80% to 90% and a specificity of 70% to 85% and may be easier to use in patients with cognitive impairment. Mild to moderate depression in elderly patients can be treated with psychotherapy or antidepressant medications. Antidepressants are appropriate for more severe depression, as indicated by a PHQ-9 score of 12 or greater. Second-generation antidepressants, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (such as sertraline) and selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, are recommended as first-line therapy, are generally well tolerated, and are effective. Caution is advised for patients on multiple medications because medication interactions may occur.
Doxepin (
Option A

) is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). TCAs are associated with anticholinergic adverse effects, which might worsen this patient's constipation and narrow-angle glaucoma. Cardiac complications can also occur, making TCAs less appropriate for an elderly patient.
Flurazepam (
Option B

) is a benzodiazepine that inhibits GABA-benzodiazepine receptors and has been used for the treatment of insomnia. Benzodiazepines are no longer recommended for insomnia because of their longer half-lives, addiction risk, and the availability of other safer options, such as cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic/sedatives. In this patient, management of insomnia should focus on the treatment of depression.
Rivastigmine (
Option D

) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor approved for the treatment of mild to moderate dementia. This patient has normal results on screening for cognitive function. Changes in cognitive function may be a symptom of depression in geriatric adults; thus, patients with these changes should also be evaluated for depression. If depression screening is positive, cognitive symptoms can be improved with depression treatment.

objective.__html: Treat depression in an elderly patient.

references: Kok RM, Reynolds CF 3rd. Management of depression in older adults: a review. JAMA. 2017;317:2114-2122.

children: A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman is evaluated after routine screening for osteoporosis with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry. The femur neck T-score was −2.9. On further questioning, the patient reports an unintentional 2.7-kg (6-lb) weight loss over the past year and heat intolerance but no other symptoms.
Physical examination is unremarkable. BMI is 29. Complete blood count, metabolic profile, and serum calcium and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels are normal.
Which of the following tests is indicated?

text.__html: Bone-specific alkaline phosphatase and N-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen testing

children: Appropriate laboratory testing for most patients with newly diagnosed osteoporosis includes complete blood count; metabolic profile; and 25-hydroxyvitamin D, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and urine calcium levels.
Measuring this patient's serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level (
Option D

) is the most appropriate next step before initiating pharmacologic therapy for osteoporosis. Although osteoporosis in postmenopausal women is most commonly associated with nonmodifiable risk factors (age, sex, menopausal status, height, and build), it is always important to assess for possible secondary causes of bone loss that might be amenable to treatment, particularly if there is clinical suspicion in a specific patient. Appropriate laboratory testing for most patients with newly diagnosed osteoporosis includes complete blood count (to evaluate for malignancy, including multiple myeloma); metabolic profile (calcium levels, liver and kidney function); and 25-hydroxyvitamin D, TSH, and urine calcium (hypercalciuria) levels. This patient's unintentional weight loss and heat intolerance may be symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which might contribute to her osteoporosis and should be treated along with therapy for her osteoporosis.
Both serum and urine markers of bone turnover, such as bone-specific alkaline phosphatase and N-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen (
Option A

), are released from osteoclasts and osteoblasts as part of bone metabolism. However, they are not used for clinical decision making in most patients with osteoporosis, primarily because of the significant variability in the different measures within individual patients or among different patients, which makes standardization of results difficult. Therefore, use of bone turnover markers is typically limited to research settings or the management of specific patients who have not responded to usual therapy for osteoporosis.

Hyperparathyroidism should always be considered as a possible secondary cause of bone loss. However, this patient's serum calcium and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels are normal. Therefore, hyperparathyroidism would be highly unlikely, and checking her parathyroid hormone level (
Option B
) is not indicated.
Serum protein electrophoresis (
Option C

) should be obtained in patients with osteoporosis if multiple myeloma is suspected. Multiple myeloma should be considered in patients with suggestive findings, such as hypercalcemia, unexplained elevation of serum creatinine, anemia, or elevated serum protein level. There is no indication that this patient has multiple myeloma, and serum protein electrophoresis is not indicated.

title: Question 195

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated after a third episode of vasovagal syncope. Episodes occurred while standing for a prolonged period. Syncope was preceded by a feeling of warmth, diaphoresis, and tunnel vision lasting for approximately 30 seconds before fainting.
Physical examination, orthostatic blood pressure measurements, and ECG are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

In patients with vasovagal syncope, physical counterpressure maneuvers can be useful in patients who have a sufficiently long prodromal period; these measures include leg crossing, limb and/or abdominal contraction, and squatting.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient with vasovagal syncope is education and counterpressure maneuvers (
Option A

). Given the benign nature of vasovagal syncope and its frequent remissions, medical treatment is usually not required unless conservative measures are unsatisfactory. According to the 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/Heart Rhythm Society syncope guideline, all patients with vasovagal syncope should be provided an explanation of the diagnosis, education targeting awareness of and possible avoidance of triggers (e.g., prolonged standing, warm environments), and reassurance about the benign nature of the condition. The guideline suggests that physical counterpressure maneuvers can be useful in patients with vasovagal syncope who have a sufficiently long prodromal period. These measures, including leg crossing, limb and/or abdominal contraction, and squatting, are considered a core management strategy.
The use of β-blockers, such as metoprolol (
Option B

), might be reasonable, but the success of this therapy is age dependent and is recommended in patients with recurrent vasovagal syncope who are aged 42 years or older. Metoprolol should not be recommended to this 32-year-old patient who has yet to try first-line therapy.
Midodrine (
Option C

) is reasonable in patients with recurrent vasovagal syncope despite first-line therapy and no history of hypertension, heart failure, or urinary retention. Midodrine is a prodrug that is metabolized to a peripherally active α-agonist. It is used to ameliorate the reduction in peripheral sympathetic neural outflow responsible for venous pooling and vasodepression in vasovagal syncope. A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials found midodrine reduced recurrent vasovagal syncope by 43%. Midodrine might be reasonable in patients with symptoms unresponsive to first-line therapy.
A cardiac pacemaker (
Option D

) might be considered for select individuals who develop bradycardia-related hypotension in the absence of a vasodepressor component as documented by tilt-table testing. The bradycardia and syncope should be documented by electrocardiographic monitoring, and first-line therapy, including volume support, physical counterpressure maneuvers, and medications, must have failed. This patient does not have an indication for pacemaker placement.

references: Shen WK, Sheldon RS, Benditt DG, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/HRS guideline for the evaluation and management of patients with syncope: executive summary: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines and the Heart Rhythm Society. Circulation. 2017;136:e25-e59.

title: Question 196

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-week history of muffled hearing and fullness in the right ear without tinnitus. She also has seasonal allergies with nasal congestion and itchy eyes. She takes no medications.
There is a conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals yellow fluid with bubbles behind a retracted but intact right tympanic membrane.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Patients with otitis media with effusion frequently present with aural fullness and a conductive hearing loss; otoscopic examination shows clear or yellowish fluid behind an intact tympanic membrane.
Most cases of otitis media with effusion resolve without treatment within 12 weeks.
This patient has otitis media with effusion (OME), or fluid in the middle ear without signs of infection, and clinical observation (
Option D

) is the most appropriate next step in management. Information about otitis media in adults is sparse, and clinical guidance is provided by studies performed mainly in children and adolescents. Patients with OME frequently present with aural fullness and a conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic examination shows clear or yellowish fluid present behind an intact tympanic membrane. Most cases resolve without treatment within 12 weeks. OME and acute otitis media are associated with eustachian tube dysfunction, which impairs drainage and causes retention of fluid in the middle ear. Eustachian tube dysfunction often occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection or with exacerbation of seasonal allergies, as in this patient.
Although many patients with OME are treated with decongestants, antihistamines, and/or nasal glucocorticoids, such as loratadine-phenylephrine and intranasal fluticasone (
Option A
), evidence of effectiveness is very limited.

Acute otitis media is characterized by fluid and inflammation in the middle ear accompanied by symptoms of infection. Otoscopic examination typically shows a bulging tympanic membrane and opacification of the tympanic membrane. Although evidence to guide treatment of acute otitis media in adults is lacking, oral antibiotics such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, along with analgesics and decongestants, are the mainstays of therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option B
) is not recommended because of a high rate of resistance among both
Haemophilus influenzae
and
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and lack of effectiveness in group A
Streptococcus
. This patient has no evidence of infection, and therefore, antibiotic therapy is not indicated.

Although symptoms of OME will resolve in most patients within 12 weeks, those with persistent symptoms who have not responded to other interventions may be considered for myringotomy with tympanostomy tubes (
Option C
). It would be premature to pursue this treatment at this time.

references: Vanneste P, Page C. Otitis media with effusion in children: Pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment. A review. J Otol. 2019;14:33-39.

title: Question 197

children: A 53-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-hour history of dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. At age 51 years, she had a provoked deep venous thrombosis that was treated with 3 months of anticoagulation.
Heart rate is 110/min, and respiratory rate is 25/min; all other vital signs are normal. No other abnormalities are noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate test to perform next?

text.__html: Pulmonary Embolism Rule-Out Criteria score calculation

children: D-dimer testing is very sensitive for detecting thromboembolic disease, and a negative study in patients with a low probability for deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism excludes the need for further testing.
In patients with a moderate or high probability of pulmonary embolism, CT angiography is the preferred imaging test.
The most appropriate next step in management is CT angiography (CTA) (
Option A

). This patient has a moderate probability of having a pulmonary embolism (PE) as assessed by one of the validated risk stratification systems (Wells score). Using the Wells risk stratification tool, this patient has a score of 6 (heart rate >100/min, previously documented deep venous thrombosis [DVT] or PE, and PE as the most likely diagnosis). Therefore, the diagnosis of PE should be pursued by further definitive testing. In this patient, CTA is the preferred method of diagnosis given her lack of contraindications to this study. CTA findings of filling defects within the segmental or larger pulmonary arteries are specific for PE. Relative contraindications for CTA include kidney failure and contrast allergy.
D-dimer testing (
Option B

) is very sensitive for detecting thromboembolic disease; in patients with a low probability of DVT or PE, a negative study is helpful in excluding the need for further testing. However, D-dimer testing is less sensitive in patients with a moderate or high probability of disease, which is an indication for definitive testing with CTA; D-dimer testing should not be performed in these situations.
Clinical studies have identified a subset of patients at very low risk for PE who can be identified by using the Pulmonary Embolism Rule-Out Criteria (PERC) score (
Option C

). Patients at low risk for PE as determined by the Wells or Geneva risk assessment tool who have a PERC score of 0 do not require D-dimer testing or CTA. American College of Physicians guidelines published in 2015 recommend using the PERC as the initial step in evaluating patients at low risk. This patient has at least a moderate risk for PE, and calculation of the PERC score is not indicated.
Results of ventilation/perfusion scanning (
Option D

) are typically more difficult to interpret than CTA findings in patients with an intermediate risk for PE and in those with structurally abnormal lungs. However, this test remains a diagnostic option for PE in patients with contraindications to CTA (such as kidney failure and pregnancy) and is the preferred imaging test in patients with suspected chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.

objective.__html: Diagnose pulmonary embolism in a patient with moderate pretest probability by using CT angiography.

references: Lim W, Le Gal G, Bates SM, et al. American Society of Hematology 2018 guidelines for management of venous thromboembolism: diagnosis of venous thromboembolism. Blood Adv. 2018;2:3226-3256.

title: Question 198

children: A 66-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for crushing chest pain. She is diagnosed with a high-risk non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction and treated with emergent percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent. Medical history includes a stroke 5 months ago. The patient has never had an episode of atrial fibrillation and does not have a prosthetic heart valve.
Which of the following is the most appropriate antithrombotic treatment for this patient?
Guidelines recommend at least 1 year of dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus a P2Y
inhibitor) for patients with acute coronary syndrome.
Antiplatelet therapy is recommended indefinitely after an acute coronary syndrome or revascularization.
This patient, who had a drug-eluting stent placed after a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, should receive dual antiplatelet therapy, such as aspirin and ticagrelor (
Option B
), for at least 1 year. Guidelines from the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association recommend at least 1 year of dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus a P2Y
inhibitor) for patients with an acute coronary syndrome (ACS). Transition to monotherapy with a P2Y

inhibitor after 1 to 3 months of aspirin or monotherapy with aspirin after 6 months may be reasonable in some patients with a high risk for bleeding. In the PLATO trial, ticagrelor was found to be superior to clopidogrel in reducing the incidence of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, and stroke after ACS, and the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guideline confirms that it is reasonable to use ticagrelor in preference to clopidogrel for maintenance P2Y

inhibitor therapy. Clopidogrel or ticagrelor therapy may be used regardless of the ACS treatment strategy; however, prasugrel is indicated only in patients treated with percutaneous coronary intervention.
Antiplatelet therapy is recommended indefinitely after an ACS or revascularization, but aspirin alone (
Option A
) is not sufficient. The addition of a P2Y
inhibitor to aspirin is indicated to reduce the risk for stent thrombosis and remote ischemic events.
Prasugrel (
Option C

) is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack because of an increased risk for intracranial hemorrhage. FDA labeling suggests that use of prasugrel in patients aged 75 years or older generally should be avoided because of increased risk for fatal and intracranial bleeding and uncertain benefit, except in high-risk situations (patients with diabetes mellitus or a history of myocardial infarction) in which its effect appears to be greater and its use may be considered.

In patients requiring oral anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation, warfarin or a direct oral anticoagulant (preferred) plus clopidogrel can be considered without aspirin, often after 2 to 4 weeks of triple therapy. In patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, warfarin plus clopidogrel therapy is reasonable; direct oral anticoagulants are contraindicated in these patients. This patient has no indication for triple therapy with aspirin, warfarin, and clopidogrel (
Option D

objective.__html: Manage dual antiplatelet therapy after acute coronary syndrome.

references: Levine GN, Bates ER, Bittl JA, et al. 2016 ACC/AHA guideline focused update on duration of dual antiplatelet therapy in patients with coronary artery disease: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines: an update of the 2011 ACCF/AHA/SCAI guideline for percutaneous coronary intervention, 2011 ACCF/AHA guideline for coronary artery bypass graft surgery, 2012 ACC/AHA/ACP/AATS/PCNA/SCAI/STS guideline for the diagnosis and management of patients with stable ischemic heart disease, 2013 ACCF/AHA guideline for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction, 2014 AHA/ACC guideline for the management of patients with non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes, and 2014 ACC/AHA guideline on perioperative cardiovascular evaluation and management of patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Circulation. 2016;134:e123-55.

title: Question 199

children: A 60-year-old woman with exertional dyspnea is evaluated for pulmonary arterial hypertension. She has limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, a prominent S

, right ventricular heave, peripheral edema, and sclerodactyly. Lungs are clear. Chest radiograph shows right ventricular (RV) enlargement. CT angiography is negative. Pulmonary function tests show a diffusing capacity of 47% of predicted and are otherwise normal. RV systolic pressure is 52 mm Hg by echocardiography.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?

In the evaluation of pulmonary hypertension, echocardiography may underestimate true pulmonary artery pressures; therefore, right heart catheterization is required to confirm pulmonary hemodynamics and determine whether there is a specific response to vasodilator infusion, which may help guide therapy.
The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is right heart catheterization (
Option C

). Systemic sclerosis, particularly limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, is associated with pulmonary vascular disease caused by direct proliferative effects on the vascular wall that obliterate pulmonary arterioles and capillaries. These changes result in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), which eventually leads to right ventricular (RV) dysfunction, or cor pulmonale. This patient's symptoms (exertional dyspnea), physical examination findings (jugular venous distention, prominent S

, and right ventricular heave), and echocardiographic findings (RV enlargement, elevated pulmonary artery pressure) are consistent with PAH. Because echocardiography may underestimate true pulmonary artery pressures, right heart catheterization is required to confirm pulmonary hemodynamics, diagnose PAH, and determine whether there is a specific response to vasodilator infusion, which may help guide therapy.
Measurement of fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) (
Option A

) provides a noninvasive way to quantify eosinophilic airway inflammation and serves as a complementary tool in the diagnosis and management of lung diseases—in particular, asthma. Elevated FeNO levels correlate modestly with blood and sputum eosinophilia and can predict glucocorticoid responsiveness in patients with respiratory symptoms. More than half of patients with asthma have eosinophilic (type 2) airway inflammation, and FeNO levels may be useful in patients in whom treatment is being considered. Measurement of FeNO does not assist in the diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
In the evaluation of suspected pulmonary hypertension, a high-resolution CT (HRCT) scan of the chest (
Option B

) should be obtained if there is suspicion for interstitial lung disease. However, this patient has lungs clear to auscultation, a normal chest radiograph, and except for a low diffusing capacity, normal pulmonary function tests. HRCT is not necessary in this patient.
The 6-minute walk test (
Option D

) provides a useful baseline before initiation of specific PAH therapy. This test or cardiopulmonary exercise testing can be performed to assess functional status and contribute to prognostic assessment. However, neither test provides the specific diagnostic information obtained by right heart catheterization and would not be the appropriate next diagnostic test.

references: Poch D, Mandel J. Pulmonary hypertension.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 200

children: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-week history of blood-tinged sputum that is worse in the morning. She has had a productive cough for years. She has no other symptoms. She has a 60-pack-year history of smoking.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Pulmonary examination is normal. Chest radiograph is normal. Complete blood count, serum creatinine level, and urinalysis results are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
The most commonly encountered causes of hemoptysis in ambulatory patients are infection (bronchitis or pneumonia) and malignancy.
Patients at increased risk for lung malignancy who have hemoptysis should be referred for chest CT with contrast even if the chest radiograph is normal.
For this patient with hemoptysis, the most appropriate next step is chest CT with contrast (
Option A

). The most commonly encountered causes of hemoptysis in ambulatory patients are infection (bronchitis or pneumonia) and malignancy. Chest radiography should be performed in all patients with hemoptysis. Patients at increased risk for lung malignancy who have hemoptysis should be referred for chest CT with contrast even if the chest radiograph is normal. Lung malignancy is found in approximately 10% of patients with hemoptysis and risk factors for lung cancer who have a normal chest radiograph. This patient is at high risk for lung malignancy based on her age and extensive smoking history; thus, chest CT with contrast should be performed despite the normal chest radiograph.
Flexible bronchoscopy (
Option B

) is not the initial test for patients with hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy may follow if the CT scan is unrevealing or if the CT scan reveals an abnormality that requires visualization or endobronchial biopsy. Flexible bronchoscopy is particularly useful in high-risk patients who have negative imaging studies, often allowing localization of the site of hemoptysis and visualization of the endobronchial pathology causing the bleeding.
Because this patient is considered at high risk for lung cancer, clinical follow-up with repeat chest radiography in 3 months (
Option C
) is not appropriate because a delayed diagnosis could result in a suboptimal outcome.
Sputum cytology (
Option D

) has low sensitivity and is not recommended for lung cancer detection. Sputum cytology may have a role in patients who have abnormal findings on imaging but are not suitable candidates for bronchoscopy; in these situations, sputum cytology may provide a diagnosis.

references: Gagnon S, Quigley N, Dutau H, et al. Approach to hemoptysis in the modern era. Can Respir J. 2017;2017:1565030.

title: Question 201

children: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated for acute left knee pain and swelling. She has gout, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease.
On physical examination, temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F). The left knee is swollen, red, warm, and tender.
Serum creatinine
level is 1.7 mg/dL (150.3 µmol/L). Synovial fluid demonstrates intracellular urate crystals and negative Gram stain.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Treatment for acute gout should focus on anti-inflammatory therapy; colchicine, an NSAID, or a glucocorticoid is recommended.

Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections for acute gout are a good treatment strategy when only one or two joints are affected, the presence of joint infection has been ruled out, and oral therapies have potential adverse events.
Intra-articular glucocorticoid therapy, such as triamcinolone (
Option C

), is the most appropriate treatment for this patient with an acute gout flare of the knee. Gout is characterized by intermittent painful inflammatory joint flares in response to crystals formed because of excessive levels of urate (hyperuricemia). Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections are a good treatment strategy when only one or two joints are affected, the presence of joint infection has been ruled out, and oral therapies have potential adverse events. Given the documented presence of intracellular urate crystals (negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals that are yellow when parallel and blue when perpendicular to a polarizing axis) and the negative synovial fluid on Gram stain, the probability of a joint infection is very low in this patient. Treatment for acute gout should focus on anti-inflammatory therapy, typically using colchicine, an NSAID, or a glucocorticoid. Although any of the three would effectively treat this patient's gout, the best choice would be a glucocorticoid because of potential adverse effects of other anti-inflammatory agents. Intra-articular glucocorticoids are preferred to systemic glucocorticoids in this patient to avoid the possible adverse effects of systemic glucocorticoids in a patient with diabetes mellitus.
Febuxostat (
Option A

) is as efficacious as or more efficacious than allopurinol in lowering serum urate levels. It is less likely to cause hypersensitivity reactions than allopurinol and does not require dose adjustment in mild to moderate chronic kidney disease. In February 2019, the FDA mandated a boxed warning regarding cardiovascular risk with febuxostat compared with allopurinol and has limited the approved use of febuxostat to patients who are unresponsive to or cannot tolerate allopurinol. Neither allopurinol nor febuxostat is an effective treatment for acute gout.

The simplest acute gout treatment is low-dose colchicine, 1.2 mg at the first symptoms of a gout flare, followed 1 hour later by a 0.6-mg dose. Colchicine is most effective when used within 24 hours after onset of an acute flare. High-dose colchicine (
Option B

) (1.2 mg initially, followed by 0.6 mg 1 hour later) is no more effective but is associated with an increased risk for adverse effects. High-dose colchicine could be particularly dangerous in patients with chronic kidney disease.
The presence of kidney disease makes the use of an NSAID such as naproxen (
Option D
) undesirable because cyclooxygenase inhibition adversely affects the kidneys.

objective.__html: Treat an acute monoarticular gout flare with intra-articular glucocorticoids.

references: FitzGerald JD, Dalbeth N, Mikuls T, et al. 2020 American College of Rheumatology guideline for the management of gout. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2020;72:879-95.

title: Question 202

children: A 43-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue of 4 months' duration. He is discovered to have iron deficiency anemia. He has no other symptoms. Medical and family histories are unremarkable.
Vital signs and the remainder of the physical examination are normal. The result of an in-office fecal occult blood test is negative.
Iron replacement is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
In men and nonmenstruating women, gastrointestinal blood loss is always the presumed cause of iron deficiency unless proven otherwise.
In asymptomatic postmenopausal women and men with iron deficiency anemia, guidelines recommend bidirectional endoscopy.
This patient should have bidirectional endoscopy (colonoscopy and upper endoscopy) (
Option A

). In asymptomatic postmenopausal women and men with iron deficiency anemia (IDA), the American Gastroenterological Association recommends bidirectional endoscopy. Patients with IDA should always be evaluated for the underlying cause. Iron deficiency may result from blood loss or malabsorption. In men and nonmenstruating women, gastrointestinal (GI) blood loss is always the presumed cause of iron deficiency unless proven otherwise. Although this patient has no history of GI bleeding and the result of a single fecal occult blood test is negative, he still might have intermittent microscopic bleeding that may have been missed. Many GI causes, such as peptic ulcer disease, colon cancer, and varices, can be evaluated by endoscopy.

In developed nations, GI bleeding is the most common cause of iron deficiency; iron malabsorption is much less common. Iron malabsorption may result from celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, or surgical resection affecting the duodenum. Some malabsorption syndromes, such as celiac disease, are not accompanied by diarrhea, steatorrhea, or weight loss. Testing for IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody (
Option B
) is sensitive for celiac disease and may be ordered if celiac disease is clinically suspected.
Colon cancer is the most commonly detected cancer responsible for IDA. Performing upper endoscopy (
Option C
) alone can potentially miss early-stage colon cancer. Colonoscopy and upper endoscopy are appropriate diagnostic tests for IDA.
Wireless capsule endoscopy (
Option D

) provides visualization of the small bowel. Capsule endoscopy is another way of investigating potential sources of blood loss after other investigations have been unrevealing. Wireless capsule endoscopy should not precede colonoscopy and upper endoscopy as the first diagnostic test for patients with IDA and presumed GI blood loss.

objective.__html: Determine the cause of iron deficiency anemia.

references: Ko CW, Siddique SM, Patel A, et al. AGA clinical practice guidelines on the gastrointestinal evaluation of iron deficiency anemia. Gastroenterology. 2020;159:1085-94.

title: Question 203

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for midepigastric postprandial abdominal pain, which has resulted in a voluntary reduction in food intake and a subsequent 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. The pain occurs within the first hour after eating. She has a history of coronary artery and peripheral vascular disease. She does not drink alcohol.
Abdominal examination reveals an epigastric systolic bruit. Result of a fecal occult blood test is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The classic symptom triad of chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI) is postprandial abdominal pain, sitophobia, and weight loss; however, this triad occurs in only 30% of patients with CMI, and CMI should be suspected in the setting of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain.
CT angiography of the abdomen is the most useful test in the evaluation of mesenteric lesions and also aids in the evaluation of alternative diagnoses.
The most likely diagnosis is chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI) (
Option B

), an uncommon condition that involves a gradual decrease in blood flow to the small intestine over months to years. It most commonly results from atherosclerotic narrowing of the mesenteric arteries. The classic symptom triad of CMI is postprandial abdominal pain, sitophobia (fear of eating), and weight loss. However, this triad occurs in only 30% of patients with CMI, and CMI should be suspected in the setting of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain. Diagnosis requires symptoms, exclusion of alternative causes of postprandial abdominal pain and weight loss, and compatible radiographic findings. CT angiography (CTA) of the abdomen is the most useful test in the evaluation of mesenteric lesions and also aids in the evaluation of alternative diagnoses. MR angiography appears to be less valuable than CTA in the assessment of inferior mesenteric artery pathology but is preferred in patients with abnormal kidney function. It is recommended that patients with CMI and multivessel disease undergo revascularization, but the choice is less clear when only one artery is involved. Endovascular revascularization is usually the first choice, but its failure, as well as the presence of vasculitic or heavily calcified arteries, may require open surgery.
Abdominal migraine (
Option A

) is a cause of recurrent abdominal pain. Most patients with abdominal migraine also have classic migraine headaches, but rarely patients present with only abdominal migraine. Abdominal migraine is not necessarily precipitated by eating and is not associated with weight loss or abdominal bruits.
Chronic pancreatitis (
Option C

) is rare in patients without a history of alcohol abuse. It may present as chronic diarrhea secondary to fat malabsorption. Pain can be constant and worse with recumbency and may be exacerbated by eating.
The most frequently reported symptom of peptic ulcer disease (
Option D

) is epigastric pain, which is frequently described as occurring 2 or 3 hours after eating when gastric acid secretion is no longer buffered by food. Some patients with pyloric channel ulcers may develop pain while eating. This patient's significant vascular disease, pain within 1 hour of eating, weight loss, and abdominal bruit argue more convincingly for chronic mesenteric ischemia.

references: van Dijk LJ, van Noord D, de Vries AC, et al. Clinical management of chronic mesenteric ischemia. United European Gastroenterol J. 2019;7:179-188.

title: Question 204

children: A 22-year-old woman who is considering pregnancy is seen for general prenatal counseling. This would be her first pregnancy. Her only other medical problem is an 8-year history of temporal lobe epilepsy treated with lamotrigine. She has no personal or family history of neural tube defects. She takes folic acid, 0.8 mg daily.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vitamin management?

text.__html: Increase the folic acid dose to 8 mg daily

children: All women who are planning or capable of pregnancy should take a daily supplement containing 0.4 to 0.8 mg (400-800 µg) of folic acid.

Factors increasing the risk for neural tube defects during pregnancy include having a personal or family history (first- or second-degree relative) of neural tube defects and taking antiepileptic drugs.
This patient requires no additional management (
Option D

). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends that all women who are planning or capable of pregnancy take a daily supplement containing 0.4 to 0.8 mg (400 to 800 µg) of folic acid. The USPSTF notes that although all women of childbearing age are at risk of having a pregnancy affected by neural tube defects and should take folic acid supplementation, some factors increase their risk, including a personal or family history (first- or second-degree relative) of neural tube defects. The risk of neural tube defects is also increased in women taking antiepileptic drugs.

Experts differ on the dose of folic acid for patients at increased risk; some suggest 1 mg daily for women taking antiepileptic drugs and 4 mg daily for women with previous pregnancies complicated by neural tube defects. However, available guidelines do not recommend an increase in dose. No guideline or expert recommends increasing the dose to 8 mg daily (
Option A
). Although no adverse effect has been associated with increased folic acid supplementation of 1 to 4 mg daily, data on larger doses is sparse.
The USPSTF recommendation is to treat all pregnant women with folate supplementation empirically rather than to measure serum folate levels (
Option B
It is not necessary to measure serum vitamin B
levels (
Option C
) in a pregnant patient. Pregnancy does not pose a risk for vitamin B
deficiency. Stores of vitamin B
are sufficient in most patients for 1 to 2 years after cessation of absorption.

objective.__html: Prevent neural tube defects with appropriate folic acid supplementation.

references: Bibbins-Domingo K, Grossman DC, Curry SJ, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Folic acid supplementation for the prevention of neural tube defects: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2017;317:183-189.

title: Question 205

children: A 21-year-old woman is evaluated after being found unconscious on a park bench. She has gone to the emergency department on two previous occasions for opioid overdose. She responds to treatment with naloxone.
Serum creatinine

level is 3.2 mg/dL (282.8 µmol/L); baseline is 0.8 mg/dL (70.7 µmol/L). Urinalysis is 4+ for occult blood and negative for erythrocytes. Complete blood count with reticulocyte count is normal. Toxicology testing results are positive for opioids and cocaine.
Which of the following will most likely confirm the cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?

In rhabdomyolysis, myoglobin is released in the circulation from damaged skeletal muscle, causing acute kidney injury via intravascular volume depletion, renal vasoconstriction, direct proximal tubular injury, and tubular obstruction.

Diagnosis of rhabdomyolysis is based on clinical findings and a history of predisposing factors (such as prolonged immobilization or drug toxicity) and confirmed by the presence of an elevated serum creatine kinase level (often >5000 U/L) and myoglobinuria (detected by a positive urine dipstick for blood in the absence of erythrocytes).
Serum creatine kinase (CK) measurement (
Option A

) will most likely confirm the diagnosis of rhabdomyolysis as the cause of this patient's acute kidney injury (AKI). In rhabdomyolysis, myoglobin is released in the circulation from damaged skeletal muscle, causing AKI via intravascular volume depletion, renal vasoconstriction, direct proximal tubular injury, and tubular obstruction. Major causes of rhabdomyolysis include trauma, drugs and toxins, seizures, metabolic and electrolyte disorders, endocrinopathies (diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome, hypothyroidism), and exercise. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and a history of predisposing factors (such as prolonged immobilization or drug toxicity) and confirmed by the presence of an elevated serum CK level (often >5000 U/L) and myoglobinuria (detected by a positive urine dipstick for blood in the absence of erythrocytes). Other possible laboratory manifestations may include hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Treatment consists of aggressive isotonic fluid resuscitation; fluids should be adjusted to maintain the hourly urine output of greater than 200 to 300 mL until the urine is negative for myoglobin. AKI resulting from acute tubular necrosis occurs in approximately one third of patients with rhabdomyolysis. Dialysis is sometimes necessary to correct severe electrolyte and acid-base abnormalities or significant volume overload.
In patients with AKI due to rhabdomyolysis, urinary findings include a fractional excretion of sodium greater than 1% due to renal vasoconstriction (
Option B
). However, this finding is not specific to rhabdomyolysis and may be found in patients with prerenal AKI or chronic postrenal obstruction and in some cases of acute glomerulonephritis.
Ultrasonography of the kidneys and bladder (
Option C

) should be performed for suspected urinary tract obstruction or when the underlying cause of AKI is unclear. Kidney size may help distinguish between AKI and chronic kidney disease because diminished kidney size and cortical thinning suggest chronic kidney disease. However, bladder and kidney ultrasonography will not confirm the diagnosis of rhabdomyolysis.
Serum haptoglobin (
Option D

) should be measured if hemolytic anemia is suspected; however, this patient has a normal complete blood count and reticulocyte count, and hemolytic anemia does not usually cause severe kidney failure. Heme pigment nephropathy occurs when large amounts of heme pigment are released into circulation due to intravascular hemolysis. Causes include glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, drug reactions, hemolysis related to cardiopulmonary bypass circuits, transfusion of stored red blood cells, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, malaria, certain poisonings, and snakebites.

references: Long B, Koyfman A, Gottlieb M. An evidence-based narrative review of the emergency department evaluation and management of rhabdomyolysis. Am J Emerg Med. 2019;37:518-23.

title: Question 206

children: A 64-year-old man is evaluated for heat intolerance and hand tremors.
On physical examination, pulse rate is 96/min. Fine hand tremors and brisk reflexes are noted. A left-sided thyroid nodule is palpated.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is 0.05 µU/mL (0.05 mU/L), and
free thyroxine
level is 2.9 ng/dL (37.4 pmol/L). Neck ultrasound shows a 1.4-cm right thyroid nodule and 2.0-cm left thyroid nodule.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the left nodule

children: The initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule begins with measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH); patients with thyroid nodules and a suppressed TSH level are evaluated with thyroid scintigraphy.
Autonomous “hot” nodules have a very low risk for malignancy and do not require fine-needle aspiration biopsy.
Performing a radioactive iodine (
I) uptake and scan (
Option C

) is the most appropriate management for this patient, who most likely has a toxic nodule or nodules causing his hyperthyroidism. The initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule begins with measuring thyroid stimulating-hormone (TSH). TSH suppression is found with autonomously functioning or “hot” nodules, accounting for 5% to 10% of palpable thyroid nodules. Patients with thyroid nodules and a suppressed TSH are evaluated with thyroid scintigraphy. A radioactive isotope is administered, the percentage taken up by the thyroid is calculated (radioactive iodine uptake), and an image is obtained (thyroid scan). Hot nodules concentrate radioactive iodine to a greater extent than normal thyroid tissue. Autonomous hot nodules have a very low risk for malignancy and do not require fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB). Because multiple nodules were identified on neck ultrasonography, it is important to ascertain which of them are autonomous. Performing a radioactive iodine uptake and scan will help identify whether one or more of the nodules are responsible for the patient's thyroid function abnormalities.
A thyroid scan will also determine whether FNAB (
Option A

) is indicated elsewhere in the gland. Nodules identified as autonomously functioning (or hot) do not require fine-needle aspiration, whereas nodules that are either “cold” or “warm” (with uptake similar to that of the surrounding nonnodular thyroid tissue) may require cytologic evaluation. Performing an FNAB on the largest nodule may not be necessary if the nodule is autonomously functioning, and not performing an FNAB on the small nodule may miss a nonfunctioning nodule that might harbor thyroid cancer.
This patient may ultimately benefit from methimazole therapy (
Option B

); however, his hyperthyroidism is mild, and it is safe to wait to initiate medical therapy until after the thyroid scan is performed. In patients with a greater degree of thyrotoxicosis, beginning methimazole to lower the thyroid hormone levels before performing additional testing is reasonable. Once the hormone levels are nearing the normal range, methimazole should be withheld for 5 days before a thyroid scan.
First-line therapy for a toxic adenoma or toxic multinodular goiter is either
I therapy (
Option D

) or thyroid surgery. Therapy selection is determined by patient preference, presence of compressive symptoms, and access to a high-volume thyroid surgeon. Because the functional status of the patient's thyroid nodules has yet to be determined, treating with radioactive iodine is premature.

references: Haugen BR, Alexander EK, Bible KC, et al. 2015 American Thyroid Association management guidelines for adult patients with thyroid nodules and differentiated thyroid cancer: the American Thyroid Association guidelines task force on thyroid nodules and differentiated thyroid cancer. Thyroid. 2016;26:1-133.

title: Question 207

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for 7 weeks of progressive muscle weakness and myalgia. He does not have sensory symptoms. He has dyslipidemia treated with atorvastatin.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is no rash. Examination reveals proximal limb weakness and diffuse hyporeflexia. Proximal muscles are tender to palpation. The remainder of the neurologic examination is normal. Serum creatine kinase level and blood C-reactive protein levels are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Statins and other lipid-lowering agents, including fibrates such as gemfibrozil and fenofibrate, can cause muscle-related symptoms that range from asymptomatic hyperCKemia and mild myalgia to progressive myopathy and, in rare cases, rhabdomyolysis.
The lipophilic statins (simvastatin, atorvastatin, and lovastatin) have a higher propensity to cause myopathy than the hydrophilic agents (pravastatin and rosuvastatin).
This patient has evidence of progressive proximal muscle weakness, myalgia, and hyporeflexia consistent with a subacute painful myopathy. Drug-induced myopathy (
Option A

) secondary to atorvastatin is the most likely diagnosis. Drug-induced myopathy is an important and treatable cause of subacute myopathy. Statins and other lipid-lowering agents, including fibrates such as gemfibrozil and fenofibrate, can cause muscle-related symptoms that range from asymptomatic hyperCKemia and mild myalgia to progressive myopathy and, in rare cases, rhabdomyolysis. Concomitant use of these agents; age older than 65 years; use of higher doses of statins; and coexisting kidney disease, liver disease, or hypothyroidism can increase the risk for myopathy. Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels can be normal, mildly, or highly elevated in statin myopathy. The lipophilic statins (simvastatin, atorvastatin, and lovastatin) have a higher propensity to cause myopathy than the hydrophilic agents (pravastatin and rosuvastatin). The risk for myopathy increases with higher dosages, the addition of fenofibrate or gemfibrozil, and the addition of cytochrome P450 3A4 isozyme inhibitors. Other toxins and drugs known to cause toxic myopathy include alcohol, cyclosporine, amiodarone, hydroxychloroquine, antiretroviral drugs, glucocorticoids, and immune checkpoint inhibitors.
Inclusion body myositis (
Option B

) is a uniformly insidious condition and is usually easily distinguishable from the other inflammatory myopathies because of its very slow onset and pattern of muscle involvement. Patients typically report a history of preexisting weakness averaging 5 years. Although proximal muscle involvement is present, distal muscle involvement also occurs, distinguishing it from polymyositis and dermatomyositis. Muscle distribution is typically symmetric, but asymmetry may occur. On physical examination, muscle weakness and atrophy are often present in the hip flexors, quadriceps, finger flexors, and forearm flexors. Serum CK levels are elevated.
Myasthenia gravis (MG) (
Option C
) presents with fluctuating weakness of extraocular, bulbar, and proximal limb muscles and is painless. In this case, the progressive course and muscle pain are inconsistent with MG.
The symptoms of polymyositis (
Option D

) usually progress slowly over months, although a more rapid onset may occur. Progressive, symmetric, proximal muscle weakness is the classic and dominant feature. Activities such as arising from a chair, stair climbing, and lifting objects above shoulder height are typically affected. Neck flexors are also commonly involved. Muscle pain and tenderness, if present, are mild. Muscle atrophy is a late manifestation. Weakness of respiratory muscles may also occur. Serum CK is almost universally elevated in polymyositis and is a marker of muscle damage.

references: Pasnoor M, Barohn RJ, Dimachkie MM. Toxic myopathies. Curr Opin Neurol. 2018;31:575-82.

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of bothersome hot flushes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness with dyspareunia. These symptoms impair her quality of life. Her last period was 13 months ago. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Cervical, breast, and colorectal cancer screening are up to date, and all results have been negative. Her 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk is 3%.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

In appropriately selected patients, hormone replacement therapy for vasomotor symptoms should be initiated within 10 years of menopause and begin with the lowest effective dose needed to achieve symptom relief.
Because hormone treatment duration longer than 1 year is associated with increased breast cancer risk, the need for treatment should be reassessed annually in patients on this regimen.
The most appropriate management for this patient with bothersome vasomotor and genitourinary symptoms is a combination of oral estradiol and progestin replacement (
Option B

). An individualized approach based on personal risk factors (including age; time since menopause; and absence of increased risk for cardiovascular disease, thromboembolism, or breast cancer) suggests that this patient is an appropriate candidate. Estradiol can be administered orally or transdermally in gel, patch, or spray forms; progestin is needed to prevent endometrial proliferation in this patient with an intact uterus. Treatment should be initiated within 10 years of menopause and begin with the lowest effective dose needed to achieve symptom relief. Hormone therapy of more than 1 year in duration has also been associated with breast cancer in a dose-dependent manner; longer use results in greater risk. Estrogen with daily progestin results in the highest risk for breast cancer, whereas estrogen-only hormone therapy has the lowest risk. All women considering hormone therapy should receive individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling. Use of hormone therapy in menopause should be reassessed every year to determine benefits and risks. Treatment duration is based on continued presence of vasomotor symptoms.

For women who prefer not to use or have contraindications to hormone therapy, nonhormonal drugs can help modulate vasomotor symptoms. Antidepressant agents, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as citalopram (
Option A

), escitalopram, and paroxetine; serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors such as venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, and duloxetine; and gabapentinoids such as gabapentin, pregabalin, and clonidine are effective. Research is inconclusive regarding supplements such as soy, black cohosh, and other phytoestrogens for treating vasomotor symptoms.
Estradiol alone (
Option C

) is not appropriate for this patient with an intact uterus. Women who have an intact uterus also require progestin either dosed continuously or cyclically to avoid estrogen-related endometrial proliferation. Continuous daily estrogen with progestin does not result in cyclic vaginal bleeding, whereas estrogen with cyclic progestin will result in withdrawal bleeding.

Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is the result of estrogen deficiency and is characterized by vaginal symptoms, such as vaginal burning or irritation; sexual symptoms, such as dyspareunia or sexual dysfunction; or urinary symptoms, such as dysuria or recurrent urinary infections. Pelvic examination findings of vaginal atrophy include a pale, dry vaginal lining with reduction in rugae. Vaginal estradiol (
Option D
) will alleviate symptoms of vaginal atrophy. However, local therapy will not relieve her severe hot flushes and night sweats. Therefore, systemic hormone therapy is a better choice for this patient.

objective.__html: Treat vasomotor symptoms in a low-risk menopausal woman.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 209

children: A 78-year-old, previously healthy man is hospitalized with pneumonia. Ten days ago, he developed low-grade fever, headache, myalgia, and nonproductive cough. His initial symptoms improved after 7 days, but 3 days ago, he developed a high fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough.
Temperature is 39.2 °C (102.6 °F). Lung examination reveals diffuse rhonchi. Chest radiograph shows new bilateral cavitary infiltrates. Result of a COVID-19 test is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely causative pathogen in this patient?

The most common clinical presentation in patients with secondary bacterial pneumonia is the exacerbation of respiratory symptoms and fever after a period of initial improvement of acute influenza symptoms.
Patients with secondary bacterial pneumonia typically develop higher fevers than were present with influenza and a cough producing purulent sputum.
This patient most likely has postinfluenza pneumonia caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
Option C
). He presents with recurrent cough and dyspnea after a recent influenza-like illness, and his chest radiograph shows cavitary lesions, which are most consistent with
S. aureus

infection. Secondary bacterial pneumonia after influenza is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly in patients aged 65 years or older. Influenza virus affects the tracheobronchial epithelium, impairing normal mucociliary clearance mechanisms and predisposing to bacterial infection. The most common clinical presentation in patients with secondary bacterial pneumonia is the exacerbation of respiratory symptoms and fever after a period of initial improvement of acute influenza symptoms. Patients with secondary bacterial pneumonia typically develop higher fevers than were present with influenza and a cough producing purulent sputum.
Klebsiella pneumoniae
Option A

) is a relatively rare cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in the United States, most often diagnosed in patients with alcohol use disorder, diabetes mellitus, or severe COPD and is an unlikely cause of secondary pneumonia in this previously healthy patient. Finally, the radiographic findings of community-acquired
K. pneumoniae
most typically are those of lobar pneumonia, which are quite unlike the cavitary lesions seen in this patient.
Atypical pneumonia
refers to CAP caused by organisms not cultivatable on standard bacterial media, including viruses and fastidious bacteria such as
Legionella
species,
Mycoplasma pneumoniae
Option B
), and
Chlamydophila pneumoniae
. Typical radiographic changes associated with
Mycoplasma
infection include unilateral or bilateral reticulonodular and/or patchy opacities.
Mycoplasma
species are an uncommon cause of secondary pneumonia associated with influenza infection compared with
S. pneumoniae
and
S. aureus
and are not associated with cavitary lung lesions as seen in this patient.
Although
S. pneumoniae
Option D
) is more common than S
. aureus
in postinfluenza pneumonia, it does not typically produce the radiographic picture of cavitary lesions, so it is unlikely to be the causative pathogen in this patient.

objective.__html: Diagnose Staphylococcus aureus community-acquired pneumonia following influenza.

references: Metlay JP, Waterer GW, Long AC, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of adults with community-acquired pneumonia. An official clinical practice guideline of the American Thoracic Society and Infectious Diseases Society of America. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2019;200:e45-e67.

title: Question 210

children: A 17-year-old woman reports 3 months of decreased ability to maintain her cross-country training schedule. Menstrual periods are regular at 28 days, with 7 days of moderate bleeding. Hemoglobin level was normal 1 year ago.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. BMI is 18.
Hemoglobin
level is 10.9 g/dL (109 g/L),
mean corpuscular volume
is 62 fL, and the red cell distribution width is elevated. Peripheral blood smear shows microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Oral ferrous gluconate, three times daily
Oral ferrous sulfate, once every other day

children: For simple iron deficiency, oral ferrous sulfate is the least expensive and simplest treatment option and is therefore the most appropriate.
Data show that every-other-day dosing of oral iron is more effective than daily dosing.
The most appropriate treatment is oral ferrous sulfate, once every other day (
Option C

). Iron deficiency may result from blood loss or malabsorption in addition to increased iron requirements. Women of reproductive age may lose enough iron through normal menstrual blood loss to become iron deficient in the absence of uterine or gastrointestinal disease. This patient has iron deficiency that is probably a result of menstrual blood loss. For simple iron deficiency, oral ferrous sulfate is the least expensive and simplest treatment option and is therefore the most appropriate. Several ferrous preparations available over the counter are probably as effective. New data show that every-other-day dosing of oral iron is more effective than daily dosing.

Parenteral iron is reserved for patients receiving dialysis or for those who have absorption problems (e.g., patients who have had gastric bypass surgery) or an intolerance to oral iron replacement. The availability of newer parenteral iron preparations, which are simpler to administer and have better adverse effect profiles, has lowered the threshold for giving parenteral treatment. The intramuscular (IM) route for iron (e.g., IM iron dextran) (
Option A
) is generally not preferred because of the risk for local complications.
Although oral ferrous fumarate, ferrous gluconate (
Option B

), and other oral iron salts are available, none has proven superior to ferrous sulfate in tolerability, efficacy, or cost. Frequent dosing (two or three times daily) of oral iron may lead to increased hepcidin production, which actually reduces iron absorption.

A low mean corpuscular volume, elevated red cell distribution width, and peripheral blood smear showing microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis are virtually diagnostic of iron deficiency, especially in premenopausal women; these findings may obviate the need for additional laboratory testing, including serum ferritin measurement (
Option D

), provided that a follow-up complete blood count is performed to assess response to iron therapy. A low serum iron level, elevated total iron-binding capacity, low transferrin saturation (>15%; iron/total iron-binding capacity × 100), and a serum ferritin level less than 14 ng/mL (14 μg/L) confirm the diagnosis of iron deficiency. The ferritin value is highly specific (99%) but has a low sensitivity (59%), resulting in potentially false-negative results and missed diagnosis of iron deficiency.

references: Auerbach M, Adamson JW. How we diagnose and treat iron deficiency anemia. Am J Hematol. 2016;91:31-8.

title: Question 211

children: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for an 18-month history of intermittent nonproductive cough and exertional dyspnea with intermittent wheezing. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack-year smoking history. He works in an auto body shop as a painter. He takes no medications.
Vital signs are normal. An occasional faint wheeze is auscultated. Chest radiograph is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

Spirometry should be performed before and after bronchodilator treatment in patients aged 40 years and older who present with progressive dyspnea, chronic cough, or chronic sputum production, particularly if a risk factor for COPD (such as smoking or occupational inhalation exposure) is present.
The diagnosis of COPD is confirmed by a postbronchodilator FEV
/FVC ratio of less than 0.70.
The most appropriate next step in management is spirometry (
Option D

). This patient smokes and has an intermittent cough and dyspnea, and he likely has COPD. Dyspnea and productive cough are characteristic symptoms of COPD; however, the presentation is variable, and the cough can be nonproductive. Diagnosis requires the presence of appropriate symptoms and spirometric findings of fixed airflow obstruction. Spirometry should be performed before and after bronchodilator treatment in patients who present with progressive dyspnea, chronic cough, or chronic sputum production, particularly if a risk factor (such as smoking or occupational inhalation exposure) is present. The role of screening spirometry in asymptomatic individuals with risk factors is controversial. Spirometry measures FEV
, FVC, and the FEV
/FVC ratio to assess for and quantify airflow obstruction. The presence of persistent airflow limitation is confirmed by a postbronchodilator FEV
/FVC ratio of less than 0.70. This differs from the finding in patients with asthma, whose airflow obstruction is fully reversible with bronchodilator therapy.
Chest CT (
Option A

) is used to evaluate parenchymal lung lesions (such as nodules) and other potential chest pathology (such as pleural or mediastinal disease). It is not useful in diagnosing airway obstruction, particularly in this patient with a normal chest radiograph. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual lung cancer screening with low-dose helical CT in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years; this 45-year-old patient does not fit these criteria.
Measuring diffusing capacity (D
LCO
Option B
) or lung volumes (
Option C
) is not required to diagnose COPD but may help in determining the severity of disease. D
LCO
measurement estimates the amount of gas transfer through the alveolar/capillary unit and is proportional to the surface area of functional lung. D
LCO
is measured by inhalation of a gas mixture containing carbon monoxide and helium; the resulting value is corrected for lung volumes and hemoglobin level. D
LCO

is reduced in conditions in which functioning alveolar capillary units are destroyed (emphysema), infiltrated (interstitial lung diseases), or removed (lung resection), and in which their function is compromised (pulmonary parenchymal and vascular disorders). Conditions that increase pulmonary capillary blood volume, such as pulmonary alveolar hemorrhage, left-to-right shunt, or asthma, can cause an elevation in D
LCO

Lung volumes can be measured by body plethysmography of nitrogen diffusion. Measures include total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity, functional residual capacity, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume (RV). The TLC is normal or even increased in pure obstructive disease. Elevation of TLC and RV (120% of predicted or greater) can be observed in obstruction and generally indicates hyperinflation and air trapping, a common pattern in severe COPD and asthma. If FEV
or FVC is reduced and the FEV

/FVC ratio is 0.70 or greater, the pattern may be interpreted as restrictive, but measurement of TLC is needed for confirmation. If TLC is less than 80% of predicted (or the lower limit of normal), a restrictive pattern is present.

references: Vogelmeier CF, Criner GJ, Martinez FJ, et al. Global strategy for the diagnosis, management, and prevention of chronic obstructive lung disease 2017 report. GOLD executive summary. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2017;195:557-582.

title: Question 212

children: A 69-year-old man is evaluated for mild lower abdominal pain, tenesmus, and bloody diarrhea that began 36 hours ago. His only other medical problem is peripheral vascular disease.
Vital signs are normal. Examination shows active bowel sounds with tenderness of the lower abdominal quadrants without guarding or rigidity. Maroon-colored stool is present in the rectal vault.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Most patients with colonic ischemia experience abdominal pain, tenesmus, and bloody diarrhea and follow a favorable course that requires only observation and supportive therapy.
Contrast CT is the preferred initial imaging test for most patients with colonic ischemia.
This patient has features consistent with colonic ischemia (
Option D

), and abdominal CT with contrast should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of colonic involvement. Colonic ischemia is more common in women and commonly affects older persons with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and vascular disease. However, other risk factors, such as hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, opioids, chemotherapeutics agents, and immunomodulators, have been associated with colonic ischemia. In most instances, the precipitating factor remains unidentified. Most patients experience abdominal pain, tenesmus, and bloody diarrhea and follow a favorable course that requires only observation and supportive therapy. In severe cases, colonic gangrene, perforation, and peritonitis may occur; these patients require surgery and have a poor prognosis. Contrast abdominal CT may show circumferential colonic thickening, thumbprinting, and pericolonic fat stranding. The left colon is most frequently affected, particularly in areas of marginal blood flow ("watershed" areas), but any segment may be involved. Patients with right-sided colonic ischemia require noninvasive imaging of the mesenteric vasculature to exclude an occlusive process of the superior mesenteric artery. Colonoscopy, which allows diagnostic confirmation and collection of tissue samples, should be performed within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms. Common colonoscopic findings include hemorrhagic nodules, mucosal edema, and ulceration.
The clinical presentation of uncomplicated acute diverticulitis (
Option A

) is colicky abdominal pain that is relieved with flatus or a bowel movement. On physical examination, left-lower-quadrant abdominal tenderness is often present. Patients with complicated diverticulitis may present with dysuria, urinary frequency, pneumaturia, fecaluria, and recurrent urinary infection concerning for colovesical fistula. It is uncommon for patients with diverticulitis to present with rectal bleeding.
Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) (
Option B

) most commonly presents with abrupt onset of severe, periumbilical abdominal pain followed by the urge to defecate. The abdominal pain is constant, and the patient may subsequently have loose, nonbloody stools. Hematochezia occurs in a minority of cases of AMI (15%), and its presence signifies concomitant right colon ischemia. In the early course of AMI, the abdominal examination may be falsely reassuring: Despite the patient's reporting severe abdominal pain, the physical examination reveals a soft, nontender, nondistended abdomen without peritoneal signs. This is called “pain out of proportion to physical examination findings” and should immediately raise suspicion for early AMI.
Clostridioides difficile
Option C

) produces both an enterotoxin (toxin A) and a cytotoxin (toxin B) that are pathogenic. Symptomatic patients typically have watery diarrhea (rarely bloody), crampy abdominal pain, malaise, and sometimes nausea and fever. Abnormal laboratory study findings are nonspecific but can include leukocytosis, an elevated serum creatinine level, and hypoalbuminemia.

references: Oglat A, Quigley EM. Colonic ischemia: usual and unusual presentations and their management. Curr Opin Gastroenterol. 2017;33:34-40.

title: Question 213

children: A 21-year-old man is evaluated for a racing heart that began 30 minutes ago. He also has palpitations, fullness in the neck, and some anxiety. Previous short episodes of tachycardia have responded to Valsalva maneuver, but this episode has not.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg; pulse rate is 214/min. ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
A narrow-complex regular tachycardia with no obvious P waves is consistent with supraventricular tachycardia.
Adenosine is a short-acting blocker of atrioventricular node conduction and is highly effective at termination of nodal-dependent supraventricular tachycardia.
Adenosine (
Option A

) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient. He has hemodynamically stable narrow-complex tachycardia consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The rhythm is regular, and no obvious P waves are visible on his ECG. Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), which accounts for up to two thirds of SVT, is the most likely cause. Patients often report neck pulsations, which are caused by simultaneous contraction of the atria and ventricles. The ventricular rate is generally between 120/min and 220/min. Vagal maneuvers block the atrioventricular (AV) node by increasing vagal tone and can help diagnose and treat SVT. Because the patient could not terminate his tachycardia with vagal maneuvers, adenosine should be administered. Adenosine is an endogenous nucleotide that is a short-acting blocker of AV node conduction. It is highly effective at termination of nodal-dependent rhythms and can help identify the underlying cause. For example, continued atrial activity (P waves) during AV block can help identify atrial flutter and atrial tachycardia.
