Patients given adenosine should be on a cardiac monitor with a running paper rhythm strip to document the results. Before taking adenosine, patients should be warned that they may experience nausea, flushing, chest pain, or a sense of dread. Patients with bronchospastic lung disease should not receive adenosine.

AV nodal blockers (β-blockers or calcium channel blockers) are used to prevent recurrent AVNRT. In patients with recurrent AVNRT and those who do not tolerate or prefer to avoid long-term medical therapy, catheter ablation (
Option B

) should be considered. Catheter ablation of AVNRT has a high success rate, although it is associated with a 1% risk for injury to the AV node necessitating pacemaker implantation. Catheter ablation is not appropriate for the acute treatment of SVT.
Electrical cardioversion (
Option C
) is not indicated because the patient is hemodynamically stable, and pharmacologic attempts at cardioversion, such as adenosine, have not been attempted yet.
Ibutilide (
Option D
) is an FDA-approved intravenous Vaughan-Williams class III antiarrhythmic drug for pharmacologic cardioversion of atrial fibrillation. The patient has regular SVT, not atrial fibrillation.

references: Shah RL, Badhwar N. Approach to narrow complex tachycardia: non-invasive guide to interpretation and management. Heart. 2020;106:772-83.

title: Question 214

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for a chronically weak urine stream and sense of incomplete bladder emptying without fever or dysuria. He often needs to return to the toilet within 30 minutes to void a second time. He has one to two episodes of nocturia nightly.
On physical examination, temperature is normal. There is no palpable bladder distension. The prostate is diffusely enlarged, firm, and nontender without nodules.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

In the initial evaluation of patients presenting with bothersome lower urinary tract symptoms possibly attributed to benign prostatic hyperplasia, the American Urological Association (AUA) recommends clinicians take a medical history, conduct a physical examination, utilize the AUA Symptom Index/International Prostate Symptom Score to quantify symptoms, and perform a urinalysis to assess for infection and malignancy.
The most appropriate next step in management is urinalysis (
Option D

). This patient likely has benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition and the most common cause of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men. In the initial evaluation of patients presenting with bothersome LUTS possibly attributed to BPH, the American Urological Association (AUA) recommends clinicians take a medical history, conduct a physical examination, utilize the AUA Symptom Index (AUA-SI)/International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) to quantify symptoms, and perform a urinalysis. This patient has some of the obstructive LUTS (hesitancy, weak urinary stream, straining, incomplete voiding, urinary retention, and overflow incontinence) due to bladder outlet obstruction. Patients also can experience irritative LUTS, which include frequency, urgency, and nocturia. In addition, prostate enlargement is evident in this patient's physical examination. BPH symptoms can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe by using the AUA-SI/IPSS, a validated clinical survey that quantifies and stratifies patients based on their symptoms; the results of the AUA-SI/IPSS can guide therapy. Urinalysis is recommended for all patients with BPH to assess for infection (bacteria and pyuria) and malignancy (hematuria).

An increased postvoid residual volume, determined by catheterization or ultrasonography, is supportive of the presence of BPH but is not required for its diagnosis and is not indicated in this patient. A postvoid residual study (
Option A
) is reserved for patients with a history suggesting urinary retention (bladder fullness, inability to urinate, palpable bladder) and prior to contemplated surgical intervention for BPH.

Screening for prostate cancer in asymptomatic, average-risk men has been controversial, and recommendations among professional organizations continue to evolve. For men aged 55 to 69 years, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends that the decision to undergo periodic prostate-specific antigen (PSA)-based screening (
Option B

) should be an individual one and should include discussion of the potential benefits and harms of screening with their clinician. The USPSTF recommends that clinicians should not screen men who do not express a preference for screening and recommends against PSA-based screening for prostate cancer in men aged 70 years and older.
Prostate ultrasonography (
Option C

) is an effective method for measuring prostate volume or evaluating other prostate abnormalities, such as nodules. However, volume measurement by ultrasonography is not required for diagnosis of BPH, and this patient has no other indication for prostate imaging.

references: Lerner LB, McVary KT, Barry MJ, et al. Management of lower urinary tract symptoms attributed to benign prostatic hyperplasia: AUA GUIDELINE PART I-initial work-up and medical management. J Urol. 2021;206:806-817.

title: Question 215

children: A 32-year-old man is evaluated for a 4-month history of right-lower-quadrant pain and occasional diarrhea.
Examination is remarkable only for tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant. Stool is negative for
Clostridioides difficile
and enteropathogens. Colonoscopy shows superficial serpiginous ulcers and cobblestoning in the ileum and right colon. Histology shows nongranulomatous inflammation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
Induction of remission in mild Crohn disease, particularly in the ileum and right colon, may be achieved with controlled ileal release budesonide.

The tumor necrosis factor inhibitors adalimumab, infliximab, and certolizumab, either alone or in combination with a thiopurine, are recommended for the induction and maintenance of remission in moderate to severe forms of Crohn disease and for patients who have not responded to glucocorticoids.
The patient has clinical and endoscopic features of mild Crohn disease and should be treated with controlled ileal release (CIR) budesonide (
Option C

) to induce and maintain remission. Crohn disease is an inflammatory disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal system and can also cause extraintestinal manifestations. Diagnosis is based on clinical features, laboratory studies (complete blood count, C-reactive protein, fecal calprotectin), and ileocolonoscopic findings. Histology reveals patchy superficial ulcerations; unlike in ulcerative colitis, the rectum is usually unaffected. Microscopic granulomas support the diagnosis but are absent in most patients. More severe forms involve deeper layers of the bowel wall and lead to complications such as strictures and fistulas. Treatment of Crohn disease depends on its severity, location, and complications. Induction of remission in mild disease, particularly in the ileum and right colon, may be achieved with CIR budesonide, but maintenance therapy should be limited to 4 months. In more severe and extensive forms of Crohn disease, particularly those involving the left colon, systemic glucocorticoids may be used to induce remission but not to maintain it.
The tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors adalimumab (
Option A

), infliximab, and certolizumab, either alone or in combination with a thiopurine (e.g., azathioprine, mercaptopurine), are recommended for the induction and maintenance of remission in moderate to severe forms of Crohn disease and for patients who have not responded to glucocorticoids. However, it is usually unnecessary in the treatment of mild disease.
The thiopurines azathioprine (
Option B
) and mercaptopurine are also used in Crohn disease as glucocorticoid-sparing therapy but are not effective in inducing remission.
Aminosalicylates such as mesalamine (
Option D
) are effective in the treatment of mild ulcerative colitis but not Crohn disease.

references: Lichtenstein GR, Loftus EV, Isaacs KL, et al. ACG clinical guideline: management of Crohn's disease in adults. Am J Gastroenterol. 2018;113:481-517.

title: Question 216

children: A 42-year-old woman with a 2-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is evaluated for the recent onset of bilateral burning sensations in the feet. She also has coronary artery disease and first-degree atrioventricular block. Medications include metformin, liraglutide, metoprolol, and atorvastatin.
There is evidence of bilateral sensory polyneuropathy involving the feet and ankles. Deep tendon ankle reflexes are absent.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient's neuropathy?
The typical presentation of distal symmetric polyneuropathy is an ascending bilateral “stocking and glove” distribution of pain, numbness, burning, and tingling.
Duloxetine (
Option A

) is a reasonable initial option for this patient's painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy. The typical presentation of distal symmetric polyneuropathy is an ascending bilateral “stocking and glove” distribution. Damage to the small nerve fibers may result in pain, numbness, burning, and tingling and may impair light touch and temperature sensations. Damage to the large nerve fibers leads to abnormal vibration sensation and proprioception. Diminished or loss of ankle reflexes is commonly seen early with diabetic polyneuropathy. Motor weakness may occur as the polyneuropathy progresses. The goal of treatment of diabetic neuropathy is symptom control. The American Diabetes Association recommends duloxetine, pregabalin, or gabapentin as initial therapy for neuropathic pain. The American Academy of Neurology recommends tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, gabapentinoids, and sodium channel blockers. Of these agents, only pregabalin and duloxetine are FDA approved for the treatment of diabetic neuropathy. The 8% capsaicin patch is FDA approved for the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy of the feet. Opioids, tramadol, or tapentadol are not recommended. Few head-to-head comparison trials of these drugs for distal symmetric polyneuropathy exist; thus, selection must consider the potential risks and benefits associated with each drug for an individual patient. Duloxetine has fewer risks than a tricyclic antidepressant for this patient, given her cardiac history.
Electromyography (
Option B

) or nerve conduction study is not routinely required for diagnosis or treatment of patients with diabetes mellitus and a typical presentation of symmetric distal polyneuropathy. Atypical clinical features should prompt additional evaluation, including electrophysiologic testing.
Vitamin B
deficiency has been associated with long-term use of metformin and may present with peripheral neuropathy. The dose and duration of metformin therapy determine the risk for vitamin B

deficiency; 5% to 10% of patients have a diminished level after 5 years of metformin therapy. Risk is particularly increased in persons with poor nutritional intake or poor absorption (e.g., after bariatric surgery). Metformin use is not associated with folate deficiency. It is unlikely that either folate or vitamin B
deficiency is the cause of this patient's peripheral neuropathy given the short duration of metformin use; folate and vitamin B
measurement (
Option C
) is unnecessary.
Tricyclic antidepressants, such as nortriptyline (
Option D

), should be used cautiously in patients with known cardiac disease because of an association with arrhythmias, heart block, and sudden death. The patient's history of cardiac disease and first-degree atrioventricular block may increase her risk for adverse effects from nortriptyline.

references: Draznin B, Aroda VR, Bakris G, et al; American Diabetes Association Professional Practice Committee. 12. Retinopathy, neuropathy, and foot care: standards of medical care in diabetes—2022. Diabetes Care. 2022;45:S185-S194.

title: Question 217

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a crush injury resulting from dropping a wooden kitchen stool on her left foot. She is at 12 weeks' gestation in an otherwise uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no symptoms or other medical problems.
During her care in the emergency department, a routine urinalysis is obtained. The urine dipstick is positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy increases the risk for pyelonephritis and has been associated with preterm birth and low–birth-weight neonates.
During pregnancy, the safest antibiotics for the treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria are amoxicillin-clavulanate, cephalosporins, and fosfomycin.
Urine culture (
Option C

) is the most appropriate management for this patient's asymptomatic bacteriuria. Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy increases the risk for pyelonephritis and has been associated with preterm birth and low–birth-weight neonates. Therefore, pregnancy is one of the few indications for screening for bacteriuria in asymptomatic patients, and a urine culture is generally recommended at 12 to 16 weeks' gestation or at the first prenatal visit. The prevalence of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is approximately 2% to 10%. In patients with untreated bacteriuria early in pregnancy, approximately 20% to 40% will develop acute symptomatic pyelonephritis later in pregnancy.

Antibiotic therapy should be culture guided, using an antibiotic with a known safety profile in pregnancy. During pregnancy, the safest antibiotics are amoxicillin-clavulanate, cephalosporins (e.g., cephalexin, cefpodoxime), and fosfomycin. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin (
Option A
), are toxic to developing cartilage, and tetracyclines have adverse effects on fetal bone and teeth; these agents are contraindicated during pregnancy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (
Option B

) should not be used in pregnant patients near term because it may cause hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in the newborn. It is generally avoided during the first trimester because it is a folic acid antagonist and may be associated with development of fetal abnormalities.
No testing or treatment (
Option D
) is necessary for asymptomatic bacteriuria, except during pregnancy or if a patient is scheduled to undergo an invasive urologic procedure.

objective.__html: Manage asymptomatic bacteriuria in a pregnant woman.

references: Nicolle LE, Gupta K, Bradley SF, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the management of asymptomatic bacteriuria: 2019 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clin Infect Dis. 2019;68:e83-e110.

title: Question 218

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated because of anorexia and weight loss despite a regular diet and high-calorie supplements. He receives hospice care for end-stage glioblastoma. He has no difficulty chewing and swallowing. He reports no abdominal discomfort or constipation.
On examination, the abdomen is nontender with active bowel sounds.
The patient's family members ask about pharmacologic options for weight gain.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment of this patient's cachexia?

Cachexia of advanced disease cannot be significantly reversed by more aggressive or invasive methods of nutritional support, including enteral (or parenteral) nutrition, and these interventions do not improve morbidity or mortality.

Megestrol may enhance appetite and promote some weight increase but is associated with adverse effects (such as risk for thrombotic events); for those who do gain weight, neither mortality nor quality of life is improved.
This patient's current care should be continued (
Option D

). Anorexia, weight loss, and cachexia are common in advanced malignancy. Assuming potentially reversible conditions (nausea, altered taste, medication side effects, bowel obstruction, dysphagia, psychological comorbidities) have been excluded, disease-related cachexia is caused by an altered neurohormonal, inflammatory milieu that results in profound alterations in metabolism. These changes lead to decreased appetite and increased catabolism, which cause progressive weight loss. Patients often feel compelled to eat (despite discomfort) to ease distress experienced by family members and caregivers. Cachexia cannot be significantly reversed by more aggressive or invasive methods of nutritional support, including enteral (or parenteral) nutrition, and these interventions in the context of cachexia of advanced disease do not improve morbidity or mortality. Educating patients and families on the causes and pathophysiology of cachexia may help them better understand and accept the expected course of the disease and should ideally occur before anorexia and weight loss develop. Patients and families may benefit by shifting focus to social pleasures derived from eating even small quantities; maintaining quality of life should be the goal instead of gaining weight.
Cancer-related anorexia and cachexia may be due in part to the production tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α and other cytokines. Trials of TNF-α inhibitors, including infliximab (
Option A
), have failed to demonstrate improvement in food intake or body weight in patients with advanced cancer and cannot be recommended.
The role of medical marijuana (
Option B
) and its derivatives, such as dronabinol, for the treatment of cachexia in advanced disease is unclear, given the paucity of evidence of appetite stimulation and weight gain.
Megestrol (
Option C

) may enhance appetite and promote some weight increase but is associated with adverse effects (such as risk for thrombotic events), which lead to its discontinuation. For those who do gain weight, mortality does not improve, and most studies involving cachexia associated with cancer show no improved quality of life.

objective.__html: Treat cachexia in a patient with cancer.

references: Swetz KM, Kamal AH. Palliative care.

This diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion is based on a low serum osmolality and a urine osmolality that is inappropriately high relative to serum osmolality without evidence of hypovolemia.

Although free water restriction is the recommended therapy for asymptomatic patients with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, hypertonic saline is used to treat symptomatic patients.
This patient has symptomatic hypotonic hyponatremia, and a rapid increase in the serum sodium level using a 3% saline infusion (
Option D

) is indicated. This patient's presentation is consistent with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), likely resulting from his recently started antidepressant medication. This diagnosis is based on a low serum osmolality and a urine osmolality that is inappropriately high relative to serum osmolality without evidence of hypovolemia. Although free water restriction is the recommended therapy for asymptomatic patients with SIADH, hypertonic saline is used to treat symptomatic patients. A typical goal for treating symptomatic hyponatremia is to increase the serum sodium level to approximately 120 mEq/L (120 mmol/L). Evidence suggests that an increase in the serum sodium level by approximately 4 to 6 mEq/L (4-6 mmol/L) over the first 24 hours is sufficient in symptomatic patients. If the extracellular fluid osmolality rapidly normalizes in a patient with chronic hyponatremia, neuronal cell shrinkage may occur and can precipitate osmotic demyelination syndrome.
Bumetanide (
Option A

), a loop diuretic, can be used as adjunctive management of hyponatremia caused by SIADH because this agent interferes with urine concentration and causes excretion of a more dilute urine, thus increasing total water excretion. However, the rapidity of correction expected with bumetanide alone is insufficient to increase the serum sodium concentration in a symptomatic patient.
Conivaptan (
Option B
), an intravenous V
receptor antagonist, is approved to treat patients with asymptomatic isovolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. The safety of V
receptor antagonists in the management of patients with symptomatic hyponatremia has yet to be established, and 3% saline is preferred for acutely symptomatic patients.
Use of 0.9% saline (
Option C

) in patients with SIADH can result in excretion of most of the infused sodium and retention of a significant portion of the infused water, leading to positive water balance and worsening hyponatremia.

title: Question 220

children: A 75-year-old man is evaluated for a slowly growing tumor beneath his right eye that he first noticed 1 year ago. He is a retired postal worker and has had a walking route for 30 years. He typically wore a hat, a long-sleeved shirt, and trousers but did not use sunscreen protection.
The tumor is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Nodular basal cell carcinoma classically presents as a pink, pearly, or translucent dome-shaped papule with telangiectatic vessels; as the lesion grows, the central area often ulcerates, creating the characteristic rolled edge.
Superficial basal cell carcinoma appears as a pink-red patch with or without scale; it may have a slight threadlike pearly rolled border.
This lesion is most consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC), nodular type (
Option A

), which classically presents as a pink, pearly, or translucent dome-shaped papule with telangiectatic vessels. As the lesion grows, the central area often ulcerates, creating the characteristic rolled edge. An important clue to the diagnosis of BCC is a changing skin lesion, including ulceration or erosion, that spontaneously bleeds. Flecks of melanin pigment are commonly present. A biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. BCC rarely metastasizes, but it can cause significant local tissue destruction.
BCC, superficial type (
Option B

), appears as a pink-red patch with or without scale. It may have a slight threadlike pearly rolled border. It can be confused for an actinic keratosis, squamous cell carcinoma in situ, or a patch of dermatitis such as psoriasis or nummular dermatitis. Superficial BCC tends to be a persistent solitary patch that does not respond to topical glucocorticoids. Biopsy provides definitive diagnosis.
Melanoma (
Option C

) is classically a pigmented macule or plaque that is asymmetric and has irregular, notched, scalloped, or poorly defined borders. The lesion usually has shades of brown, tan, red, white, and blue-black, which makes it less likely as a diagnosis in this patient. Rarely, melanomas are not pigmented (amelanotic) and can mimic BCC, which is why a biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
Squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) (
Option D

) are hyperkeratotic, often ulcerated macules, papules, or nodules that commonly appear in areas of significant sun damage, such as the scalp, neck, and pinnae. SCCs tend to be scalier and grow more rapidly than BCCs and are occasionally tender. They lack the pearliness and telangiectasias seen in BCCs, making SCC unlikely in this patient. They are particularly common in the setting of immunosuppression. SCCs are more aggressive than BCCs and have a much higher tendency to metastasize.

references: Kim DP, Kus KJB, Ruiz E. Basal cell carcinoma review. Hematol Oncol Clin North Am. 2019;33:13-24.

title: Question 221

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated after a syncopal episode in a restaurant. He became diaphoretic and lightheaded while standing and straining while urinating in the toilet. He was unconscious for less than a minute and had no symptoms of confusion upon awakening. His only other medical illness is benign prostatic hypertrophy treated with tamsulosin.
On physical examination, vital signs, including orthostatic blood pressure measurement, and the remainder of the examination are normal. ECG is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Neurally mediated syncope includes vasovagal syncope, which is provoked by noxious stimuli, fear, stress, heat overexposure, or prolonged standing; situational syncope, which is triggered by cough, micturition, defecation, or deglutition; and carotid sinus hypersensitivity, which is sometimes experienced during head rotation, shaving, or use of a tight-fitting neck collar.
The most likely diagnosis is situational syncope (
Option C

). Neurally mediated syncope, or reflex syncope, is the most common form and is seen primarily in younger adults. The underlying syncopal mechanism, termed the neurocardiogenic or vasodepressor reflex, is a response of vasodilation, bradycardia, and systemic hypotension, which leads to transient hypoperfusion of the brain. Neurally mediated syncope includes vasovagal syncope, which is provoked by noxious stimuli, fear, stress, heat overexposure, or prolonged standing; situational syncope, which is triggered by cough, micturition, defecation, or deglutition; and carotid sinus hypersensitivity, which is sometimes experienced during head rotation, shaving, or use of a tight-fitting neck collar. Prodromal symptoms, including nausea and diaphoresis, are classically present before neurally mediated syncope, and fatigue and generalized weakness are typically present afterward. Treatment of most types of situational syncope relies heavily on avoidance or elimination of a triggering event.
Cardiovascular syncope (
Option A

) is the second most common form of syncope and is associated with increased morbidity, mortality (including sudden death), and direct traumatic injury. Cardiovascular syncopal events often occur suddenly and usually without a significant prodrome, although chest pain and palpitations may be present briefly. Causes of cardiovascular syncope include arrhythmia; coronary artery disease; and structural and obstructive disease, including aortic and pulmonary valve stenosis, obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic dissection, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary embolism. This patient's prodrome of diaphoresis while straining during urination is most compatible with situational syncope.

Orthostatic syncope is the third most common form of syncope and predominantly affects older adults. It classically occurs after changes in position and is typically associated with prodromal symptoms, such as light-headedness. A related phenomenon is postprandial hypotension (
Option B

) which is associated with a symptomatic fall in blood pressure 15 to 90 minutes after eating and is most commonly found in older individuals. Although postprandial hypotension is possible in this elderly patient who was in a restaurant, the syncopal event while straining at urination is most consistent with situational syncope.
Vasovagal syncope (
Option D
), which is provoked by noxious stimuli, fear, stress, heat overexposure, or prolonged standing, is unlikely in the absence of any of the common precipitants.

references: Shen WK, Sheldon RS, Benditt DG, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/HRS guideline for the evaluation and management of patients with syncope: executive summary: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines and the Heart Rhythm Society. Circulation. 2017;136:e25-e59.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next test?

Vitamin D deficiency may result in osteomalacia, which is characterized by diffuse bone pain, bone tenderness to palpation, and proximal muscle weakness; however, early osteomalacia may present only with low bone mass on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry and may be indistinguishable from osteoporosis without further testing.
Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by mild hypocalcemia, mild hypophosphatemia, increased alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone levels, and a decreased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level.
The most appropriate next diagnostic test is to measure this patient's serum level of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] (
Option C

). He likely has vitamin D deficiency, which is characterized by mild hypocalcemia, mild hypophosphatemia, increased alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, and a decreased serum 25(OH)D level. Vitamin D deficiency may result in osteomalacia, which is characterized by diffuse bone pain, bone tenderness to palpation, and proximal muscle weakness; however, early osteomalacia may present only with low bone mass on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) and may be indistinguishable from osteoporosis without further testing. In the evaluation of vitamin D deficiency, measurement of 25(OH)D (calcidiol) is more informative than measurement of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [1,25(OH)2 D] (calcitriol) (
Option A

) in most patients with hypocalcemia because vitamin D deficiency causes hypocalcemia and stimulates PTH secretion, which in turn stimulates renal conversion of 25(OH)D to 1,25(OH)2 D. Low dietary intake, poor absorption of vitamin D, and lack of production in the skin will result in a low serum 25(OH)D level. This serum level will also be low in patients taking phenytoin, those with nephrotic syndrome (loss of vitamin D–binding protein), and those with hepatobiliary disease. Whereas 25(OH)D has a long half-life, 1,25(OH)2 D is more short-lived and therefore not a good measure of vitamin D status. 1,25(OH)2 D levels will be low despite normal or high 25(OH)D levels in patients with renal insufficiency, deficiency of renal 1α-hydroxylase (vitamin D–dependent rickets, type 1), or hypoparathyroidism.
DEXA (
Option B

) is not the most appropriate next test. The results of DEXA scanning are likely to show low bone mineral density, and if the patient has confirmed vitamin D deficiency, he will receive supplemental vitamin D and calcium regardless of the DEXA scan result. Furthermore, DEXA scan cannot differentiate between osteoporosis and vitamin D deficiency as a cause of low bone mineral density.

The most commonly reported radiographic findings of osteomalacia due to vitamin D deficiency are reduced bone mineral density and thinning of the cortex; these findings are nonspecific and not diagnostic. Radiographic changes in vertebral bodies and the presence of Looser zones (narrow radiolucent lines) in the femoral neck or shaft are more diagnostically specific. However, measurement of 25(OH)D is the most direct method to diagnose vitamin D deficiency and is preferred to radiographic surveys (
Option D
) in the diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency.

references: Bouillon R, Carmeliet G. Vitamin D insufficiency: definition, diagnosis and management. Best Pract Res Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2018;32:669-84.

title: Question 223

children: A 48-year-old man reports intermittent right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain and nausea for the past 10 hours.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Diffuse epigastric and RUQ tenderness are present. Leukocyte count and serum amylase and lipase levels are normal. Total serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels are disproportionally increased compared to aminotransferase levels. Abdominal ultrasound shows a dilated common bile duct, gallstones, and normal gallbladder.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Symptoms of choledocholithiasis include biliary colic and jaundice due to obstruction of bile flow.
The initial imaging test of choice for choledocholithiasis is transabdominal ultrasonography.
The most likely diagnosis is choledocholithiasis (
Option C

), which is characterized by symptoms of biliary colic, including right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) or epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. Pain is typically constant but may be intermittent and typically lasts longer than 6 hours. This patient's liver chemistry test results (disproportionate increase in serum alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin compared to aminotransferase levels) support a diagnosis of bile duct obstruction. Visualization of gallstones and dilation of the common bile duct on ultrasonography support the diagnosis. The absence of fever and leukocytosis or hyperamylasemia makes a complication such as cholangitis or pancreatitis less likely. Importantly, less than 50% of patients with choledocholithiasis develop symptoms, and 20% spontaneously pass stones from the common bile duct.
Cholangitis (
Option A

) is one of the potential complications of choledocholithiasis. Cholangitis presents as a syndrome of fever, jaundice, and abdominal pain (Charcot triad) that develops as a result of stasis and infection in the biliary tract with organisms that typically ascend from the small intestine. Occasionally, sepsis arises in severe cases, leading to hypotension and altered mental status (Reynold pentad).
Although patients with cholecystitis (
Option B

) may present with similar symptoms of biliary colic, physical examination and imaging findings can be used to differentiate between the diagnoses. In cholecystitis, patients usually have fever and a positive Murphy sign (arrest of respiration on palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis, normal or very mild elevations in serum aminotransferase levels, and normal or mild hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin level <4 mg/dL [68.4 µmol/L]). Diagnosis can be made by using ultrasonography to visualize gallbladder wall thickening and/or edema and a sonographic Murphy sign. This patient's ultrasound does not show any of these findings.
The presence of a functional gallbladder disorder (
Option D

) is suggested by typical biliary pain in the absence of gallstones or structural pathology. Typical biliary pain is located in the epigastrium and/or RUQ; is intermittent; lasts at least 30 minutes; crescendos and then plateaus; is severe enough to interrupt normal activities or results in an emergency department visit; and is not relieved by bowel movements, positional changes, or acid suppression. This patient's abnormal imaging and laboratory evaluation exclude functional gallbladder disorder.

references: Lam R, Zakko A, Petrov JC, et al. Gallbladder disorders: a comprehensive review. Dis Mon. 2021;67:101130.

title: Question 224

children: A 26-year-old woman is seen for a routine wellness examination. Personal medical history and family history are unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection. She is in a 10-year monogamous sexual relationship with her partner. Pelvic examination and cervical cytology 1 year ago were normal.
Which of the following is an appropriate cervical cancer screening test to perform next?

text.__html: Cervical cytology and high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) co-test now

children: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women aged 21 to 65 years every 3 years with cytology; in women aged 30 to 65, primary high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing (preferred) or cytology combined with hrHPV testing can be performed every 5 years.
The American Cancer Society recommends initiating cervical cancer screening at age 25 years and prefers primary HPV testing every 5 years through age 65 years.
It is appropriate to perform cervical cytology in 2 years (
Option B

). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women aged 21 to 65 years every 3 years with cytology (Pap testing). In women aged 30 to 65 years who want to lengthen the screening interval, primary high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing (preferred) or cytology combined with hrHPV testing can be performed every 5 years. The FDA has approved primary hrHPV tests as well as hrHPV tests to be used in combination with cervical cytology. The two categories of tests are not interchangeable. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends against screening women younger than 21 years because screening has not been shown to reduce cervical cancer incidence or mortality. Screening can be discontinued at age 65 years in non–high-risk women with adequate prior screening, defined as three consecutive negative cytology results or two consecutive negative cytology plus HPV test results within the last 10 years, with the most recent test occurring within 5 years. In women older than 65 years with life expectancy of at least 10 years and risk factors for cervical cancer (history of abnormal Pap smears, history of a high-grade precancerous lesion, in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol, immunocompromise, previous HPV infection), continued screening should be considered. The American Cancer Society recommends initiating cervical cancer screening at age 25 years and performing primary HPV testing every 5 years through age 65 years (preferred); if primary HPV testing is not available, persons aged 25 to 65 years should be screened with cytology and hrHPV co-testing every 5 years or cytology alone every 3 years.
There is no need for this patient to undergo cervical cancer screening at this time, either through co-testing with cervical cytology and hrHPV testing (
Option A
), cervical cytology (
Option C
), or primary hrHPV testing (
Option D
). Any of these tests can be done in 2 years.

references: Curry SJ, Krist AH, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for cervical cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;320:674-86.

title: Question 225

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated for resistant hypertension. Her blood pressure remains above target despite adherence to therapeutic lifestyle changes and treatment with amlodipine, lisinopril, and chlorthalidone. She has no other medical problems.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. There is a bruit in the right epigastric region. Kidney function is normal; urinalysis is unremarkable. Catheter-based angiography of the renal arteries reveals a “string of beads” pattern involving the right renal artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Renovascular hypertension due to fibromuscular dysplasia is most commonly caused by medial fibroplasia of the renal artery; the characteristic imaging finding is the "string of beads" appearance of the involved artery.
Renal angioplasty is the treatment of choice for patients with hypertension related to fibromuscular dysplasia of the renal arteries.
Renal artery angioplasty (
Option B

) is indicated for this patient with renovascular hypertension secondary to fibromuscular dysplasia. There are two types of renovascular disease: (1) atherosclerotic renovascular disease and (2) fibromuscular dysplasia. Atherosclerotic renovascular disease usually occurs in patients aged older than 45 to 55 years, especially in those with diffuse atherosclerosis, but it also can be isolated to the kidney. Fibromuscular dysplasia is a nonatherosclerotic disorder that affects the mid and distal portions of the renal artery and usually occurs in young to middle-aged persons, particularly women (90%). Renovascular hypertension due to fibromuscular dysplasia is most commonly caused by medial fibroplasia of the renal artery. On angiography, the characteristic finding of fibromuscular dysplasia is the "string of beads" appearance of the involved artery. Hypertension usually affects patients between 15 and 30 years of age. Catheter-based renal angiography is the most accurate method to diagnose this condition. This study is indicated for patients whose clinical presentation raises strong suspicion for fibromuscular disease–related hypertension, such as those with severe resistant hypertension and high plasma renin activity. Revascularization with renal angioplasty may be performed at the same time as diagnostic angiography. The young age of many patients with fibromuscular dysplasia, such as this 32-year-old woman, reduces the risk for complications from this procedure.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a noninflammatory disorder that leads to arterial stenosis and occlusion as well as aneurysm formation and dissection in multiple arterial beds, most commonly the renal arteries. Because it is a noninflammatory condition, treatment with glucocorticoids, such as prednisone (
Option A
), will have no impact on improving arterial flow the patient's hypertension.
Clinical trials support the efficacy of adding a low-dose aldosterone receptor antagonist (spironolactone or eplerenone) (
Option C

) for treatment of resistant hypertension. However, the high likelihood of both technical success and meaningful blood pressure improvement from renal angioplasty makes drug therapy in this young patient unnecessary at this time.
Surgical revascularization (
Option D

) is not first-line treatment for this patient given the associated higher morbidity. Surgery should be reserved for patients who do not respond to renal angioplasty or who have arterial anatomy too complex for renal angioplasty.

objective.__html: Treat renovascular hypertension secondary to fibromuscular dysplasia.

references: Herrmann SM, Textor SC. Renovascular hypertension. Endocrinol Metab Clin North Am. 2019;48:765-778.

title: Question 226

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated because of a 1-month history of left shoulder pain that worsens when he brushes his hair or puts on a tee shirt.

On physical examination, there is no tenderness to palpation. There is pain on active and passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees. Drop arm testing is negative. Pain is reproduced with the empty can test. Range of motion and strength are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Sling immobilization and subacromial glucocorticoid injection

children: Most patients with nontraumatic rotator cuff disease do not require imaging studies; however, when the diagnosis is unclear or if concern exists for a rotator cuff tear, imaging of the shoulder with MRI is the preferred modality.

Initial therapy for rotator cuff tendinopathy typically includes rest, avoidance of aggravating activities, NSAIDs, and physical therapy to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles and improve flexibility.
This patient most likely has rotator cuff tendinopathy (specifically, supraspinatus tendinopathy) and would likely benefit from physical therapy (
Option B

). Rotator cuff disease is the most common cause of shoulder pain and refers to all symptomatic rotator cuff disorders, including subacromial bursitis, tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear. Risk factors for rotator cuff disease include increasing age and participation in activities that require repetitive overhead arm use. This patient has worsened pain with overhead activities, pain with active abduction, and a positive painful arc test (complete passive abduction of arm with pain between 60 and 120 degrees) and empty can test. The empty can test is a maneuver where the extended arm is passively abducted to 90° in the plane of the supraspinatus (30° anterior to the coronal plane) and internally rotated (as though pouring a glass of water onto the floor). The patient is asked to maintain the position while the examiner exerts downward force on the arm. Weakness or reproduction of pain is a positive result. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff tendinopathy involving the supraspinatus tendon, which is the most commonly involved tendon in nontraumatic rotator cuff injury. Given the patient's classic presentation and examination findings, it is appropriate to diagnose him without further testing. Initial therapy typically includes rest, avoidance of aggravating activities, NSAIDs, and physical therapy to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles and improve flexibility.
Referral for orthopedic surgery (
Option A
) would be premature prior to a trial of conservative measures for 3 to 6 months.

Most patients with nontraumatic rotator cuff disease do not require imaging studies. However, when the diagnosis is unclear or if concern exists for a rotator cuff tear, imaging of the shoulder should be obtained. MRI is the preferred imaging modality (>90% sensitivity), although ultrasonography (
Option C

), in experienced hands, is also an option. This patient has no evidence of a complete rotator cuff tear; his strength is preserved, and he has a negative drop arm test, which argue against a full-thickness tear. Therefore, imaging is unnecessary in this patient.
Neither immobilization with a sling nor subacromial glucocorticoid injections (
Option D

) would be appropriate for this patient. Immobilization with a sling should be avoided to prevent development of adhesive capsulitis. Subacromial glucocorticoid injections may provide short-term pain relief in patients with subacromial bursitis in whom other measures have failed but should be limited to one or two courses to limit complications.

references: Whittle S, Buchbinder R. In the clinic. Rotator cuff disease.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 227

children: A 71-year-old man, a retired university professor, is evaluated for a 9-month history of difficult-to-manage behaviors and slow gait. He has exhibited intermittent forgetfulness and inattention, gotten lost while driving, and had visual hallucinations. Family members report that his affect has become blunted. He has no other medical problems.
Vital signs are normal. Examination reveals mild agitation, impaired recall and figure drawing, masked face, muscle rigidity, hand tremors, and a slow gait.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Core features of dementia with Lewy bodies are parkinsonian motor features, visual hallucinations, and frequent fluctuations in attention; autonomic symptoms and REM sleep behavior disorder are common.

When dementia occurs well after the motor symptoms, it is considered Parkinson disease dementia but when dementia and motor symptoms develop within 1 to 2 years of each other, it is classified as dementia with Lewy bodies.
This patient most likely has dementia with Lewy bodies (
Option B

), the second most common cause of degenerative dementia. Core features of dementia with Lewy bodies are parkinsonian motor features, visual hallucinations, and frequent fluctuations in attention; autonomic symptoms and REM sleep behavior disorder are common. Sensitivity to neuroleptic medications also is commonly seen. When dementia occurs well after the motor symptoms, it is considered Parkinson disease dementia. When dementia and motor symptoms develop within 1 to 2 years of each other, it is classified as dementia with Lewy bodies.
Alzheimer disease (
Option A

) is predominantly characterized by a decline in memory that may be accompanied by deficits in other cognitive domains. Typical behavioral changes in the earlier stages of Alzheimer disease include irritability, anxiety, and depression. Although visual hallucinations and motor symptoms may occur in Alzheimer disease, these features generally present relatively late in the disease course. In this patient, early cognitive fluctuations and parkinsonism favor dementia with Lewy bodies over Alzheimer disease.
Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) (
Option C

) is a clinical syndrome characterized by the insidious onset of changes in behavior, personality, and executive function (behavioral variant) or language (primary progressive aphasia variant). In behavioral variant FTD, patients may exhibit hyperorality, loss of insight, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, and impaired social conduct. In this patient, early impairment of memory and visuospatial function, psychosis, cognitive fluctuations, and motor symptoms are inconsistent with FTD.
Vascular cognitive impairment (
Option D

) encompasses a category of disorders in which the causal link between cerebrovascular disease and cognitive impairment is strong. In older populations, vascular cognitive impairment is likely second only to Alzheimer disease as the most common primary cause of dementia (but not of neurodegenerative dementia). This disorder may occur concurrently with Alzheimer disease in older patients. The likelihood of vascular cognitive impairment increases with age and is associated with systemic vascular risk factors and a history of stroke (either clinically diagnosed or based on neuroimaging evidence). Two major signs of vascular cognitive impairment are early gait impairment and pseudobulbar affect (“emotional incontinence”) that can manifest as excessive crying or laughter disproportionate to the context of the situation and is abrupt in onset and discontinuation. Vascular cognitive impairment cannot explain this patient's parkinsonian motor features, visual hallucinations, blunted affect, and frequent fluctuations in attention.

references: Arvanitakis Z, Shah RC, Bennett DA. Diagnosis and management of dementia: review. JAMA. 2019;322:1589-99.

title: Question 228

children: A 21-year-old woman reports a 9-month history of recurrent episodes of anxiety, fatigue, binge eating, irritability, and difficulty concentrating at work. Symptoms are consistently worse during the last half of the menstrual cycle and resolve after menses onset. She gave birth to her first child 8 months ago. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications or supplements.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder is characterized by symptoms of mood disturbance that develop the week before menstruation, remit within a week after menstruation, and occur with most menstrual cycles.
This patient meets criteria for premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) (
Option D

), which consists of symptoms of mood disturbance that develop the week before menstruation, remit within a week after menstruation, and occur with most menstrual cycles. Diagnosis requires the presence of at least one primary symptom: mood swings, irritability or anger, feelings of hopelessness or depressed mood, and anxiety. In addition, a patient must have a total of at least five symptoms, which may also include appetite changes, decreased interest in usual activities, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of loss of control, sleep disturbance, and physical symptoms (breast tenderness, weight gain, bloating, myalgia). This patient has five PMDD symptoms that remit within a few days after onset of menstruation, and these symptoms cause clinical impairment.
Patients with adjustment disorder with depressed mood (
Option A

) may exhibit depressive symptoms in response to a stress- or trauma-related life event. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is present when symptoms can be clearly linked to an identifiable stressor, but criteria for other depressive disorders are not met. This patient does not have a clearly identifiable stressor, nor does she exhibit depressive symptoms. Her symptoms are also episodic, making adjustment disorder with depressed mood unlikely.
Peripartum depression (
Option B

) affects 7% of pregnant or postpartum women. It is characterized as major depressive disorder occurring during pregnancy or within 4 weeks after delivery. It is not considered a separate mood disorder; instead, it is a subtype of major depressive disorder with the specifier “with peripartum onset.” The cyclical nature of this patient's symptoms each month in association with menstruation and the time since the birth of her child do not support a diagnosis of peripartum depression.
Personality disorders (
Option C

) involve consistent patterns of interpersonal behavior and perceptions that are inflexible, diverge significantly from the behavioral standards of the person's culture, and cause substantial functional impairment and emotional distress. Development of these disorders usually occurs in adolescence. This patient's episodic symptoms associated with menstruation and onset after adolescence are not consistent with a personality disorder.

references: Lanza di Scalea T, Pearlstein T. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder. Med Clin North Am. 2019;103:613-628.

title: Question 229

children: A 36-year-old woman is evaluated after testing positive for human papillomavirus (HPV) genotype 16 on high-risk HPV testing. Pap smear 3 years ago was normal, as were results of all previous Pap testing since the age of 21 years. She has been in a monogamous relationship for the past 4 years. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive.
On physical examination, vital signs and pelvic examination findings are normal. Result of HIV testing is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

When cervical cancer screening is performed by screening for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) with HPV genotyping, a positive result for HPV genotype 16 or 18 should be managed by immediate referral for colposcopy with biopsy.
The most appropriate management is colposcopy (
Option C

). When cervical cancer screening is performed by screening for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) with HPV genotyping, a positive result for HPV genotype 16 or 18 should be managed by immediate referral for colposcopy with biopsy. Genotypes 16 and 18 confer high current and future risk for cervical cancer. Therefore, detection of either HPV genotype requires referral for colposcopy testing no matter the results of prior or concurrent cytology. Colposcopy provides an illuminated, magnified view of the cervix, vagina, and vulva and enhances the ability to detect premalignant and malignant lesions that can biopsied. This 36-year-old woman has completed appropriate cervical cancer screening by having high-risk HPV screening. Her screening test results are positive, with detection of HPV genotype 16, so immediate colposcopy referral is indicated.
In patients with a confirmed diagnosis of cervical cancer and who are candidates for radial hysterectomy, abdominopelvic CT (
Option A

) or whole-body PET/CT might be indicated as part of the staging process, depending on associated clinical and laboratory findings. This patient does not have an established diagnosis of cervical cancer, and imaging for the purposes of cancer staging is not indicated.
Conization of the cervix (
Option B

) entails excision of a cone-shaped wedge from the cervix that includes the transformation zone and the endocervical canal. In the diagnosis of cervical cancer, conization is performed if cancer is suspected but is not found with colposcopy-directed cervical biopsies. Consideration of conization is premature in this patient who has yet to undergo colposcopy and directed biopsy.
Pap testing (
Option D

) plays a role in cervical cancer screening algorithms but does not provide added diagnostic information for this woman with a high-risk HPV test result that is positive for genotype 16. A normal Pap result would not negate the need for immediate colposcopy referral.

objective.__html: Test for cervical cancer in a woman with a high-risk human papillomavirus genotype.

references: Fontham ETH, Wolf AMD, Church TR, et al. Cervical cancer screening for individuals at average risk: 2020 guideline update from the American Cancer Society. CA Cancer J Clin. 2020;70:321-346.

title: Question 230

children: A 55-year-old man is evaluated after a 45-minute episode of right monocular vision loss. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with chlorthalidone, metformin, liraglutide, and pravastatin.
Vital signs and neurologic examination findings are normal. Brain imaging is unremarkable. Neurovascular imaging shows 40% stenosis of the right carotid artery. ECG and echocardiogram are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
For patients with transient ischemic attack or acute ischemic stroke who are not eligible for thrombolysis or endovascular stroke therapy, antiplatelet therapy is the mainstay of acute treatment.

The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association recommends that aspirin and clopidogrel be initiated within 24 hours of symptom onset and continued for 21 days to reduce the risk for stroke for a period of 90 days; long-term aspirin monotherapy is continued after 21 days of dual antiplatelet therapy.
The most appropriate therapy is dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel (
Option A

). For patients with transient ischemic attack (TIA) or acute ischemic stroke who are not eligible for thrombolysis or endovascular stroke therapy, antiplatelet therapy is the mainstay of acute treatment. When administered either orally or rectally within 48 hours of stoke, aspirin reduces the short-term risk for recurrent stroke. Monotherapy with clopidogrel, however, has no established benefit in the acute stroke setting. Patients with TIA or minor stroke, usually defined as a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score of 5 or less, have been the focus of recent trials of antiplatelet therapy because of their high short-term risk for recurrent events. Two trials examined the role of aspirin combined with clopidogrel versus monotherapy (with either aspirin or clopidogrel) initiated within 12 to 24 hours from symptom onset in patients with TIA or minor stroke. The studies used 21 or 90 days of aspirin plus clopidogrel versus single antiplatelet agents; overall, the combination therapy produced a small but significant reduction in risk for recurrence at 90 days. The risk for hemorrhagic complications seemed to increase beyond 30 days; DAPT with duration between 30 and 90 days is commonly used in minor stroke or TIA. On the basis of these studies, the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association recommends that DAPT (aspirin and clopidogrel) be initiated within 24 hours of symptom onset and continued for 21 days to reduce the 90-day risk for stroke. Long-term aspirin monotherapy is continued after 21 days of DAPT.
Cilostazol (
Option B

) is a phosphodiesterase 3 inhibitor that results in reversible inhibition of platelet aggregation and arterial vasodilation and is commonly used to treat peripheral artery disease–related claudication. Clinical trials in Japan and China have demonstrated that cilostazol is effective for secondary stroke prevention in these populations. However, data in other ethnic groups are insufficient to permit recommendation of cilostazol to non-Asian patients. Other barriers to routine use for secondary stroke prevention include the need for twice-daily dosing, adverse effect profile, heart failure contraindication, and expense.
Acute administration of anticoagulation in ischemic stroke (
Options C, D
), regardless of whether the stroke is related to atrial fibrillation, does not reduce the short-term risk for recurrent stroke and is not indicated in a patient with TIA.

objective.__html: Treat transient ischemic attack with dual antiplatelet therapy.

references: Amarenco P. Transient ischemic attack. N Engl J Med. 2020;382:1933-1941.

title: Question 231

children: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for an 8-month history of gradually worsening erectile dysfunction. He does not have morning or spontaneous erections. Depression screening is negative. He is physically active, does not smoke cigarettes, has no other medical conditions, and takes no medications.
Physical examination findings, including vital signs and BMI, are normal. Early-morning serum testosterone level and lipid, glucose, and thyroid levels are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
First-line therapy for erectile dysfunction includes lifestyle modifications, such as weight loss, increase in physical activity, and smoking cessation.
First-line pharmacologic therapy for erectile dysfunction is a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor.
This patient should be treated with an oral phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor (PDE-5), such as tadalafil (
Option C

). The evaluation of erectile dysfunction (ED) should include medical, psychosocial, and sexual components as well as noting the presence of early-morning and nocturnal spontaneous erections, which suggest a psychological cause. Physical examination should include cardiovascular, genital, digital rectal, peripheral vascular, and neurologic evaluations. Clinicians should pay close attention to reduced testicular volume, loss of normal body hair distribution, and gynecomastia, which suggest hypogonadism. Basic laboratory evaluation includes fasting glucose, lipid, morning testosterone, and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels. Given this patient's activity level and absence of cardiovascular risks, no further assessment for safe sexual activity is necessary. Appropriate lifestyle modifications, such as weight loss if needed, should be discussed first. Referral to behavioral health also should be considered for underlying mood disorder and psychosocial/interpersonal aspects of ED. First-line drug therapy is a PDE-5 inhibitor, such as tadalafil. PDE-5 inhibitors increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate, which facilitates smooth muscle relaxation and allows inflow of blood. An adequate trial is generally deemed to include gradual escalation of the dose to the maximum, with at least six attempts of maximum-dose therapy. PDE-5 inhibitors should be avoided in patients receiving any form of nitrate therapy. There is a risk for hearing loss with their use, and a rare complication is nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy characterized by acute, monocular, painless visual loss with optic disc swelling. Concomitant use of α-blockers may result in hypotension.

Second-line therapies for ED should be reserved for men with symptoms that do not improve with lifestyle modifications or use of PDE-5 inhibitors. These include alprostadil (intraurethral administration or intracavernosal injection) (
Option A
), vacuum erection devices (
Option D
), and penile prostheses.
Experts recommend against penile revascularization (
Option B
) as a treatment for erectile dysfunction because it is rarely effective and safer, noninvasive options are available.

references: Burnett AL, Nehra A, Breau RH, et al. Erectile dysfunction: AUA guideline. J Urol. 2018;200:633-41.

title: Question 232

children: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated for asymptomatic anemia. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and amlodipine.
Blood pressure is 148/84 mm Hg. BMI is 17. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Laboratory studies:
Hemoglobin

Normal

Normal
Peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic erythrocytes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The anemia of kidney disease is usually normochromic and normocytic with a low or low-normal reticulocyte count.
Patients with even minor increases in serum creatinine levels may have reduced erythropoietin levels.
This patient most likely has anemia secondary to kidney disease (
Option B

). Anemia in kidney disease is from decreased erythropoietin production in the kidney and decreased red cell survival. The anemia of kidney disease is usually normochromic and normocytic with a low or low-normal reticulocyte count. Patients with minor increases in serum creatinine levels may have reduced erythropoietin levels. Although this patient's creatinine level is 1.5 mg/dL (132.6 µmol/L), her estimated creatinine clearance (calculated by using the abbreviated Modification of Diet in Renal Disease Study equation, based on age, creatinine level, and sex) is 46.7 mL/min, which corresponds to chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) guidelines recommend screening for anemia at least annually in patients with CKD stage 3. Before anemia is attributed to CKD, other potential causes of anemia should be eliminated. The typical evaluation includes complete blood count with erythrocyte indices, absolute reticulocyte count, serum iron level, total iron-binding capacity, percentage transferrin saturation, serum ferritin level, and serum vitamin B

level. Patients with symptomatic anemia secondary to kidney disease respond to a supplemental erythropoietin-stimulating agent (ESA); however, this treatment would not be necessary in this patient. KDIGO recommendations are to consider ESAs for patients with CKD who have hemoglobin concentrations less than 10 g/dL (100 g/L).
Anemia of inflammation (
Option A

) may cause mild normocytic anemia with decreased reticulocytes, as seen in this patient. However, anemia of inflammation is usually seen in patients with an underlying inflammatory disorder and is associated with normal or low serum iron levels, low total iron-binding capacity, and an elevated serum ferritin level, which this patient does not have.
Drug-induced hemolytic anemia (
Option C

) may be the result of immune-mediated erythrocyte destruction through different mechanisms, including inducing autoantibody formation or through a hapten or drug adsorption process. The list of medications known to cause immune-mediated hemolytic anemia is extensive, and a careful history of recent exposures is helpful. Laboratory findings include increased indirect bilirubin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and low haptoglobin levels. As long as no additional conditions that would impair erythropoiesis are present, increased reticulocytes and an elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) are noted. This patient has another reasonable cause of anemia, and neither reticulocytosis nor elevated MCV is present.
Iron deficiency (
Option D
) should be ruled out in patients with anemia of kidney disease as these conditions may coexist. This patient has normal iron study results.

objective.__html: Diagnose anemia of kidney disease in a patient with normocytic anemia.

references: Cascio MJ, DeLoughery TG. Anemia: evaluation and diagnostic tests. Med Clin North Am. 2017;101:263-84.

title: Question 233

children: A 22-year-old woman is evaluated because of nontraumatic anterior left knee pain that began after training for a triathlon competition. The pain worsens with running, squatting, climbing stairs, or sitting for an extended time.
Examination reveals pain with direct pressure to the patella and while squatting. There is no other tenderness or swelling.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Patellofemoral pain syndrome is characterized by anterior knee pain and/or stiffness that is worse with knee flexion during weight-bearing activity such as running, climbing stairs, and squatting, but pain is also worse after prolonged flexion with sitting.
Patellar pain with squatting has 91% sensitivity as a physical examination sign for patellofemoral pain syndrome.
This patient has patellofemoral pain syndrome (
Option B

). Patellofemoral pain syndrome is caused by disordered patellar tracking with knee movement. Risk factors include female sex (due to higher Q-angle in women); patellar instability; weakness of the quadriceps; and physical activities such as climbing stairs, running, and squatting. It is characterized by anterior knee pain and/or stiffness that is worse with knee flexion during weight-bearing activity such as climbing stairs, running, and squatting, but pain is also worse after prolonged flexion with sitting. On physical examination, applying pressure to the patella may reproduce pain. There is also exacerbation of pain with squatting, which has 91% sensitivity as a physical examination sign. NSAIDs may help alleviate symptoms in the acute setting but have not shown benefit in the long term. In the acute phase of injury, modification of activity and cryotherapy (ice, cold water immersion) is recommended. In the recovery phase, the most effective treatment for patellofemoral pain syndrome is physical therapy with an exercise program designed to strengthen the quadriceps, hamstrings, and gluteus muscles. Core strengthening exercises may also have benefit.
Meniscal tear (
Option A

) usually results from an acute twisting knee injury or can develop more insidiously because of chronic degeneration. Symptoms of a meniscal tear include pain, locking, catching, and grinding. Patients with acute meniscal tears are usually able to bear weight immediately. On examination, effusions, if present, are generally small to moderate in size. This patient has no symptoms or findings consistent with meniscal tear.
Pes anserine pain syndrome (also known as pes anserine bursitis) (
Option C

), common in athletes and runners, classically presents with pain localized to the proximal anteromedial tibia. On physical examination, tenderness is localized to the anteromedial aspect of the knee about 6 cm below the joint line. This finding is not present in this patient.
Tendinopathy of the quadriceps (
Option D

) or patellar tendon causes knee pain with movement, such as jumping, running, or squatting. Pain occurs superior to the patella (quadriceps tendinopathy) or distal to the patella (patellar tendinopathy) and can be reproduced with palpation of the affected area. This patient has pain directly over the patella, an unlikely presentation of quadriceps tendinopathy.

references: Willy RW, Hoglund LT, Barton CJ, et al. Patellofemoral pain. J Orthop Sports Phys Ther. 2019;49:CPG1-CPG95.

title: Question 234

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for diminished visual acuity with blurring of her central vision. She has a 22-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus that has been treated with basal and prandial insulin. She is not pregnant, and she has no other medical problems. Glucose level, lipid levels, and blood pressure are under optimal control.
Ophthalmologic testing reveals macular edema and retinal neovascularization.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

In patients with diabetic retinopathy, vision can be preserved by appropriately timed laser photocoagulation or intraocular injection of an anti–vascular endothelial growth factor agent (ranibizumab, bevacizumab, aflibercept).
Intravitreal anti–vascular endothelial growth factor agents are the preferred treatment regimen for central-involved diabetic macular edema.
Anti–vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) intravitreal injections with an agent such as bevacizumab (
Option B

) are the most appropriate next step in management. Diabetic retinopathy is a well-recognized microvascular complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus and is one of the leading causes of visual loss in adults in the United States. Diabetic retinopathy is classified as nonproliferative (with hard exudates, microaneurysms, and minor hemorrhages), which is not associated with visual decline, or as proliferative (with “cotton-wool spots” and neovascularization), which is associated with loss of vision. Changes in retinal blood flow occur after several years of diabetes. These changes cause retinal ischemia, which in turn promotes growth factors that stimulate proliferation of new blood vessels. This process leads to scarring and fibrosis. Fibrous tissue can put traction on the retina, which may cause retinal detachment with resultant vision loss. New vessels may also become more permeable and leak serum, which causes macular edema. Tight glycemic control, lipid lowering, and blood pressure reduction have been shown to decrease the incidence and progression of retinopathy. Once proliferative retinopathy is established, vision can be preserved by appropriately timed laser photocoagulation. Intraocular injection of an anti-VEGF agent (ranibizumab, bevacizumab, aflibercept) has also been shown to be an effective treatment. Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents provide a more effective treatment regimen for central-involved diabetic macular edema than monotherapy or even combination therapy with laser photocoagulation, and they are the preferred therapy.
Randomized clinical trials have detected no benefit or harm of aspirin (
Option A
) on the incidence or progression of proliferative retinopathy and visual loss.
The cytokine tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy. Although the TNF-α inhibitor infliximab (
Option C
) has been approved for treating autoimmune inflammatory disorders, it has not been approved for treating diabetic retinopathy.
Glucocorticoid intravitreal injections with an agent such as triamcinolone (
Option D

) have been associated with improvement in diabetic retinopathy. However, intravitreal injections of glucocorticoids are associated with worsening glucose control, cataracts, and other undesirable glucocorticoid-related complications and are not first-line therapy.

objective.__html: Treat diabetic retinopathy with anti–vascular endothelial growth factor.

references: American Diabetes Association. 11. Microvascular complications and foot care: standards of medical care in diabetes-2021. Diabetes Care. 2021;44:S151-S167.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is defined as the presence of obesity (BMI ≥30) and daytime arterial hypercapnia (P

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is typically diagnosed during an episode of acute-on-chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure, characterized by dyspnea and somnolence.
The most likely diagnosis is obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) (
Option D
). OHS is defined as the presence of obesity (BMI ≥30) and daytime arterial hypercapnia (P
CO

≥45 mm Hg [5.9 kPa]) in the absence of other causes of alveolar hypoventilation. The vast majority of people with OHS also have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OHS is typically diagnosed during an episode of acute-on-chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure, characterized by dyspnea and somnolence. Frequent comorbidities include heart failure and pulmonary hypertension. This patient has severe obesity (BMI >40) and an elevated carbon dioxide level (62 mm Hg [8.3 kPa]) during wakefulness, the defining characteristics of OHS. Although OHS is a diagnosis of exclusion and further evaluation is warranted, it is the most likely cause of hypercapnic respiratory failure in this patient with no history of chronic lung disease. To establish the diagnosis, evaluation should exclude other causes of hypoventilation, including COPD, restrictive chest wall deformity, severe hypothyroidism, neuromuscular disease, and central hypoventilation syndromes. Positive pressure ventilation is often effective for treatment of hypoventilation. Weight loss, possibly including bariatric surgery, is recommended.
Central sleep apnea (
Option A

) is a sleep-associated breathing disorder with decreased central respiratory drive. Patients typically present with excessive daytime sleepiness. Central sleep apnea is most commonly found in older men with other comorbid conditions, such as heart failure or opioid use. It is not a hypoventilation syndrome, as seen in this patient, and arterial blood gases generally reveal normocapnia or slight hypocapnia.
Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP) (
Option B

) is a potentially treatable autoimmune neuropathy. CIDP often presents with a progressive or relapsing symmetric proximal and distal weakness and sensory symptoms with diffuse areflexia. Its temporal course is often subacute, with progression after 8 weeks of onset. Atypical forms include multifocal asymmetric and distal symmetric variants, but respiratory failure is rare. This patient has no findings suggestive of CIDP.
Long-standing, severe COPD (
Option C
) may lead to carbon dioxide retention and hypercapnia, but COPD is less likely in this patient given the absence of risk factors and audible wheezing, cough, or sputum production.
