title: Question 236

children: A physician colleague has a change in his mood and behavior. He cannot complete hospital rounds on his patients in a reasonable amount of time and appears to have trouble making decisions. He is forgetful, has lapses of judgment, and has committed errors. When asked if something is wrong and if help is needed, the colleague becomes angry and abusive.
Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

text.__html: Ask the nursing staff if they have concerns
Search medical records for evidence of negligent care

children: Physicians have an obligation to protect the welfare of patients by reporting an impaired colleague.
The colleague's behavior should be reported to the colleague's supervisor (
Option C

). Physicians may be reluctant to report colleagues suspected of impairment because of discomfort associated with “speaking up,” fears of retaliation, and desire to protect colleagues. However, physicians have a duty to speak up because an impaired and disruptive colleague's behaviors may harm patients, negatively affect team morale, and impede learning. This physician's colleague manifests multiple behaviors suggestive of impairment, including altered mood, lapses in judgment, and changes in clinical performance. Because the physician has already directly confronted the colleague and the concerns were dismissed, the physician should report the impaired colleague to the appropriate supervisor, such as a chief of service, chief of staff, institutional or medical society assistance program, or state medical board.
Asking nursing staff if they have concerns (
Option A
) is unprofessional, delays the reporting process, and does not mitigate the responsibility of reporting the suspected impaired colleague to the proper authorities.
There is a professional and ethical responsibility to report the impaired colleague. Simply avoiding the colleague (
Option B
) and taking no further action may result in patient harm and is unethical.
Physicians should not review the medical records of patients who are not under their care (
Option D

); therefore, it is unethical to review the colleague's patient care notes for evidence of negligent care. Conducting such record reviews delays and does not remove the responsibility of reporting the suspected impaired colleague.

objective.__html: Report an impaired colleague to the appropriate authorities.

references: Sulmasy LS, Bledsoe TA; ACP Ethics, Professionalism and Human Rights Committee. American College of Physicians ethics manual: seventh edition.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 237

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated in the office for new-onset fever, diffuse rash, and worsening joint pain. She has rheumatoid arthritis. Medications are methotrexate and rituximab; her second infusion of rituximab was 7 days ago.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F). Purpura is present over the trunk and extremities. Symmetrical polyarticular synovial swelling, erythema, and warmth of the small joints of the hands and feet are present.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Serum sickness is a type III hypersensitivity reaction mediated by complement-fixing antibodies against an immunogenic region of an external agent, usually a foreign protein or drug.
The typical presentation of serum sickness is the triad of fever, rash, and arthritis that occurs 7 to 14 days after exposure to an inciting agent.
Serum sickness (
Option D

) induced by rituximab is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with new onset of fever, rash, and worsening rheumatoid arthritis. Serum sickness may mimic exacerbation of various rheumatologic conditions. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction mediated by complement-fixing antibodies against an immunogenic region of an external agent, usually a foreign protein or drug. Agents that may provoke a serum sickness–type reaction are antivenoms, antitoxins, streptokinase, several monoclonal antibodies (rituximab, infliximab), rabies vaccine, and insect venom. Similar reactions have been reported with the use of cefaclor, penicillins, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Typical symptoms are a triad of fever, rash, and arthritis that occurs 7 to 14 days after exposure, such as in this patient. Other manifestations include glomerulonephritis, elevated inflammatory markers, and hypocomplementemia. It is vital to recognize the diagnosis of serum sickness because readministration of the inciting protein/medication often leads to a more severe reaction. Treatment with systemic glucocorticoids is generally very effective at resolving a serum sickness reaction. This patient should not be rechallenged; the medication should be discontinued.
Anaphylaxis (
Option A

) is a severe reaction caused by acute mediator release into the circulation, usually triggered by IgE-linked immunologic responses to specific foods, medications, insect venom, latex, or other antigens, but sometimes occurring without an allergic trigger. The mediator release results in various clinical manifestations, including pruritus, hypotension, and tissue swelling (known as angioedema) caused by capillary leak from widespread inflammatory mediator release. Onset of symptoms may be immediately after antigen exposure or delayed, sometimes for hours or even days, although more rapid onset usually signals a more severe reaction. Fever and joint pain are not part of the presentation.
Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (
Option B

) is a severe life-threatening medication reaction. Unlike other medication reactions, the onset of symptoms is delayed, often by 2 to 6 weeks, from the time of exposure. Patients begin with fever and flulike symptoms, which are quickly followed by burning skin pain and rash. Patients typically develop a morbilliform exanthem that starts on the face and upper trunk and spreads distally. Eventually patients develop striking facial edema and redness, a hallmark of this condition. The patient's presentation of symptoms 7 days following rituximab infusion, purpura, and joint pain is not compatible with drug hypersensitivity syndrome.
In contrast to serum sickness, medication-related infusion reactions (
Option C

), such as fever, rash, myalgia, and hypotension, occur immediately during administration of the drug and are likely related to mast cell degranulation with complement activation rather than antidrug antibodies. The time course in this patient makes an infusion reaction unlikely.

references: McNamara K, Hughes OB, Strowd LC. Cutaneous drug eruptions including serum sickness-like reaction, symmetrical drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthema, and drug-induced lupus. Clin Dermatol. 2020;38:641-647.

title: Question 238

children: A 32-year-old man is hospitalized following an opioid overdose. At the scene of the overdose, he was treated by emergency medical services with intravenous naloxone. During his hospitalization, he received repeated injections of naloxone. This is his first episode of opiate overdose. He uses no other substances and has no other medical problems.
Which of the following is the most appropriate discharge medication?
Naloxone is an opioid antagonist capable of temporarily reversing life-threatening respiratory depression in opioid overdose.
Naloxone is recommended for persons at risk for opioid overdose, including those recently discharged from emergency departments after opioid overdose, and family members of at-risk patients.
This patient should be prescribed intranasal naloxone (
Option C

). Naloxone is an opioid antagonist capable of temporarily reversing life-threatening respiratory depression in opioid overdose. Naloxone is available in injectable forms and as an intranasal spray. Although injectable naloxone may be best reserved for use by trained medical personnel, intranasal naloxone can be safely used on the patient by friends and family members in the event of overdose. It is important to remember that naloxone has a very short half-life, and its antidote effects will usually wear off before the opioid effects are gone; patients should be observed for continued or recurrent signs of respiratory distress, which may require repeated dosing of naloxone. The National Institute on Drug Abuse, CDC, and U.S. Surgeon General all recommend prescribing naloxone for persons at risk, including those recently discharged from emergency departments after opioid overdose, and family members of at-risk patients.
Buprenorphine (
Option A

) is a partial opioid agonist used in the treatment and maintenance of sobriety from opioid addiction that has superior ability in reducing opioid withdrawal symptoms. Its combination with naloxone (buprenorphine-naloxone) allows for less abuse potential and respiratory depression in overdose. Buprenorphine prescription is restricted to qualified physicians who have received training and a waiver to practice medication-assisted opioid addiction therapy. Before buprenorphine is prescribed, the patient would need to be assessed for his interest in and willingness to try discontinuing opioid use and participating in addiction treatment.
Diazepam (
Option B

) is a long-acting benzodiazepine. Shorter-acting benzodiazepines such as lorazepam are the safest and most effective method to manage alcohol withdrawal. After initial dosing to control symptoms acutely, a symptom-triggered approach with standardized instruments should be used to measure the severity of withdrawal and guide treatment. The risk for opioid overdose is increased with higher doses and concurrent benzodiazepine prescription. Benzodiazepines should be avoided if at all possible in patients with opioid use disorder.
Methadone (
Option C

) is a long-acting opioid agonist and reduces opioid craving and opioid-related mortality. Only licensed opioid treatment programs or licensed inpatient hospital units are able to dispense and supervise methadone treatment for opioid use disorder. As for buprenorphine, the patient would need to be assessed for his interest in and willingness to try discontinuing opioid use and participating in addiction treatment before starting pharmacologic treatment.

objective.__html: Treat a patient at risk for opioid overdose.

references: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. Naloxone: the opioid reversal drug that saves lives. How healthcare providers and patients can better utilize this life-saving drug. December 2018. Accessed July 14, 2020.

Chloride
5.0 mEq/L (50 mmol/L)
L
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypokalemia?

Prolonged vomiting results in a low urine chloride concentration (<20 mEq/L [20 mmol/L]), reflecting gastrointestinal losses and prolonged volume contraction that leads to avid renal reabsorption of chloride with sodium.
Volume contract stimulates sodium-potassium exchange in the distal renal tubule resulting in hypokalemia.
Vomiting (
Option D

) is the most likely cause of this patient's hypokalemia. She presents with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with extracellular volume depletion. This patient's history (generalized weakness and lightheadedness), physical examination findings (orthostatic hypotension), and urine electrolyte levels are most consistent with vomiting. Vomiting results in loss of hydrogen chloride and fluid from gastric secretions, and, if persistent, results in volume contraction. Hypovolemia activates the renin-angiotensin system with an increase in sodium-hydrogen exchange and increased bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule due to increased luminal hydrogen ion and exacerbated by decreased chloride available for reabsorption with sodium. Increased aldosterone secretion stimulates sodium-potassium exchange in the distal tubule, resulting in hypokalemia. This patient's urine electrolytes reflect these physiologic changes. With volume depletion, the urine sodium concentration is generally low (<20 mEq/L [20 mmol/L]) due to the kidney's conservation of sodium. However, in this case, excess filtered bicarbonate associated with the alkalosis is excreted through the renal tubule, and sodium is lost in the urine as an obligatory cation to maintain electroneutrality; this results in increased urine sodium excretion. Because of this, the urine chloride concentration more accurately determines volume status than the urine sodium concentration in metabolic alkalosis. The urine chloride concentration is low (<20 mEq/L [20 mmol/L]), reflecting gastrointestinal losses and prolonged volume contraction that leads to avid reabsorption of chloride with sodium.
Renal potassium wasting also occurs in inherited tubular defects, including Liddle (
Option A

), Bartter, and Gitelman syndromes. In Liddle syndrome, increased sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron causes hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, and potassium wasting. This patient is volume contracted (low blood pressure and orthostatic hypotension) making Liddle syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.
Primary aldosteronism (
Option B

) is caused by either hyperplasia of both adrenal glands or a unilateral aldosterone-producing adenoma. Primary aldosteronism is a common cause of secondary hypertension, and approximately 40% or more of individuals will develop hypokalemia. This patient's low blood pressure and orthostatic hypotension make primary aldosteronism unlikely.
Type 1 (hypokalemic distal) renal tubular acidosis (
Option C

) results in impaired excretion of hydrogen ions by the distal nephron with inability to acidify urine below a pH of 6.0. Urinary potassium wasting in the setting of diminished proton secretion underlies the development of hypokalemia. Patients develop hyperchloremic (normal anion gap) metabolic acidosis, which is not seen in this patient.

objective.__html: Identify vomiting as a cause of hypokalemia.

references: Palmer BF, Clegg DJ. Physiology and pathophysiology of potassium homeostasis: core curriculum 2019. Am J Kidney Dis. 2019;74:682-695.

title: Question 240

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for painful left-sided submandibular swelling that occurs with the onset of eating. She has a 60-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and continues to smoke. She is chronically ill and has heart failure treated with furosemide, eplerenone, carvedilol, and lisinopril.
On physical examination, temperature is 36.3 °C (97.3 °F). On examination of the oral cavity, there is a firm mass within the left submandibular duct. Oral hygiene is poor.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Salivary gland stones may present as acute pain and swelling in anticipation of eating or during eating; often the pain and swelling are transient but can be persistent.

Treatment of sialadenitis is hydration and stimulation of salivary flow with warm compresses and sialagogues (sour candies or vitamin C lozenges), salivary gland massage, increased fluid intake, and improved oral hygiene.
The most likely diagnosis is a salivary gland stone (sialolithiasis) (
Option C

). The salivary glands include the major (parotid, submandibular, and sublingual) salivary glands and thousands of minor salivary glands. Decreased salivary gland flow can predispose to the formation of salivary gland stones. Risk factors include hypovolemia, use of diuretics or anticholinergic medications, smoking, chronic periodontal disease, and a history of nephrolithiasis. Salivary gland stones may present as acute pain and swelling in anticipation of eating or during eating. Often the pain and swelling are transient but can be persistent. A stone may be palpable in a major duct. Wharton duct of the submandibular gland is found along the floor of the mouth. Stensen duct of the parotid gland opens opposite the second upper molar. Treatment is hydration and stimulation of salivary flow with warm compresses and sialagogues (sour candies or vitamin C lozenges), salivary gland massage, increased fluid intake, and improved oral hygiene.
A salivary gland tumor (
Option A

) most commonly presents as a painless salivary gland mass; facial paralysis and lymphadenopathy increase concern for malignancy. Previous radiation therapy, smoking history, and viral infection (Epstein-Barr virus, HIV, human papillomavirus) are common causes. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI and tissue biopsy, typically with fine-needle aspiration, are the first steps in evaluation.
Rarely, sarcoidosis (
Option B

) can cause Heerfordt syndrome (uveoparotid fever), a combination of fever, uveitis, and parotitis with or without cranial nerve VII palsy. This can lead to sicca symptoms and can mimic Sjögren syndrome. Fever, uveitis, and parotitis are absent in this patient.
Sjögren syndrome (
Option D

) is an autoimmune exocrinopathy affecting salivary and lacrimal glands. It is more prevalent in women and commonly presents in the fourth and fifth decades. Primary Sjögren syndrome occurs in isolation; secondary Sjögren syndrome occurs in the setting of other rheumatologic diseases, most commonly rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus. The most common presentation of Sjögren syndrome is sicca, consisting of dryness of the eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and mouth (xerostomia). Patients report gritty eyes or a foreign body sensation. Oral dryness can cause caries and difficulty eating dry food. Symmetric parotid and lacrimal swelling is common, as is skin and vaginal dryness. This patient's onset of symptoms with eating and a palpable mass within the left submandibular duct are not consistent with Sjögren syndrome.

references: Ogle OE. Salivary gland diseases. Dent Clin North Am. 2020;64:87-104.

title: Question 241

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated following an episode of syncope. He was sitting at the breakfast table and suddenly, without prodromal symptoms, lost consciousness. He spontaneously revived after 2 minutes. There was no evidence of seizure activity. He has no chest pain or palpations.
Physical examination is normal without orthostatic blood pressure changes. ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the diagnosis?

In second-degree atrioventricular block, only some P waves conduct to the ventricles; Mobitz type 2 second-degree atrioventricular block is typified by intermittent nonconducted P waves with unchanging PR intervals.

Regardless of symptoms, permanent pacing is indicated for second-degree Mobitz type 2 atrioventricular (AV) block, high-grade AV block, and third-degree AV block not attributable to reversible causes.
The diagnosis is second-degree Mobitz type 2 atrioventricular (AV) block (
Option C

). In second-degree AV block, only some P waves conduct to the ventricles. In this ECG, two nonconducted P waves are seen after the third QRS complex in the bottom rhythm strip. Mobitz type 2 second-degree AV block is typified by intermittent nonconducted P waves with unchanging PR intervals. Dizziness and syncope are major symptoms. Mobitz type 2 AV block usually occurs below the AV node and has a higher risk for progression to third-degree (complete) heart block. Regardless of symptoms, permanent pacing is indicated for second-degree Mobitz type 2 AV block, high-grade AV block, and third-degree AV block not attributable to reversible causes.
Atrial fibrillation (
Option A

) is defined by the presence of disorganized atrial activity with an irregularly irregular ventricular response on ECG without preceding P waves. Although this patient does have an irregularly irregular rhythm, P waves are present before all QRS complexes but not all P waves are conducted.
Mobitz type 1 second-degree (Wenckebach) AV block is characterized electrocardiographically by a PR interval that progressively prolongs until a beat is dropped, resulting in grouped beating (
Option B

). When 2:1 block is present, Mobitz type 2 AV block cannot be distinguished from Mobitz type 1 AV block. Most patients are asymptomatic, but if the sinus rate is slow enough, it may result in lightheadedness, syncope, presyncope, angina, or heart failure. In the absence of bradycardia, Mobitz type 1 AV block may be suggested by an irregular pulse. There are few other physical examination findings.
In third-degree AV block, no P waves conduct to the ventricles (
Option D

). AV dissociation is observed on the ECG; P waves bear no relationship to the QRS complexes. Most patients with complete heart block are symptomatic. Symptoms may include fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, presyncope or syncope, and cardiac arrest.

objective.__html: Diagnose second-degree Mobitz type 2 atrioventricular block as the cause of syncope.

references: Kusumoto FM, Schoenfeld MH, Barrett C, et al. 2018 ACC/AHA/HRS guideline on the evaluation and management of patients with bradycardia and cardiac conduction delay: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines and the Heart Rhythm Society. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2019;74:e51-e156.

title: Question 242

children: A 29-year-old woman has a 9-month history of generalized body aches, poor sleep, waking unrefreshed, and fatigue. She also reports difficulty concentrating and recurrent band-like headaches. Her only other medical problem is irritable bowel syndrome. Acetaminophen and NSAIDs have provided no relief.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Examination reveals widespread muscle tenderness. Laboratory studies are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

The characteristic features of fibromyalgia are widespread chronic pain, fatigue, and sleep disorders; impaired cognitive function, mood disorders, headache, gastrointestinal symptoms, and paresthesia are common associated symptoms.
First-line therapy for fibromyalgia is nonpharmacologic, particularly aerobic exercise, as well as education and psychosocial support.
This patient has fibromyalgia, and low-impact aerobic exercise (
Option B

) is the most appropriate next step in management. The characteristic features of fibromyalgia are widespread chronic pain, fatigue, and sleep disorders. These features are frequently accompanied by impaired cognitive function; mood disorders; and other symptoms, such as headache, gastrointestinal symptoms, and paresthesia. First-line therapy is nonpharmacologic, particularly aerobic exercise, as well as education and psychosocial support. Several studies have found that low-impact cardiovascular exercise (fast walking, biking, or swimming) can reduce pain, improve function, and may improve sleep. The exercise program should be individualized based on patient preference and any underlying comorbidities. Yoga and tai chi also have shown some benefit in managing pain and dysfunction in patients with fibromyalgia. Patients should be counseled to make gradual and modest increases in the amount and duration of exercise to avoid transient increases in pain and fatigue on initiation of an exercise program. Patients with fibromyalgia should be assessed for psychosocial stressors and psychiatric illness, including a history of trauma. If such stressors or illness is present, referral for psychological care is mandatory because psychic distress may both promote and result from fibromyalgia. Cognitive behavioral therapy has shown modest benefit in reducing pain, negative mood, and disability.
Although many patients respond to nonpharmacologic therapies alone, some also benefit from medications to reduce pain and improve sleep. Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline (off label) (
Option A
), are often used as initial pharmacologic treatment. Pregabalin, duloxetine, and milnacipran are the only three FDA-approved treatment options for patients.

Studies have failed to show efficacy for the use of NSAIDs, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. There is no role for opioids or glucocorticoids, such as prednisone (
Option C
), in the management of fibromyalgia.
Tramadol (
Option D

) is a mixed opioid analgesic and weak serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Tramadol is classified as an opioid, with associated concerns of class adverse effects, including tolerance and addiction. Tramadol is not approved for fibromyalgia; if nonpharmacologic treatment does not provide sufficient relief of symptoms, other, safer and possibly more effective drugs are available.

references: Macfarlane GJ, Kronisch C, Dean LE, et al. EULAR revised recommendations for the management of fibromyalgia. Ann Rheum Dis. 2017;76:318-28.

title: Question 243

children: A 35-year-old man has right eye redness and thick, globular yellow discharge without ocular pain. The discharge rapidly accumulates after it is wiped away. He also reports that his eyelids stick together in the morning. He wears contact lenses.
Examination shows mucopurulent discharge at the lid margins and diffuse conjunctival injection of the right eye. Vision is normal.
He is instructed to stop wearing his contact lenses.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?

Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by redness and thick purulent discharge in one or, less commonly, both eyes; in the morning, the eye is “glued shut,” and discharge is thick and globular and continues throughout the day.
Bacterial conjunctivitis in adults who do not use contact lenses is commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus
species, or
Moraxella catarrhalis
and can be treated with erythromycin ointment or trimethoprim-polymyxin drops; in contact lens wearers,
Pseudomonas
is common in addition to these species, so the preferred treatment is topical fluoroquinolone therapy.
The most appropriate treatment is a topical fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin eyedrops (
Option B

), for this patient with probable bacterial conjunctivitis, a bacterial infection of the conjunctiva that causes redness and thick purulent discharge in one or, less commonly, both eyes. In the morning, the eye is “glued shut.” The discharge in bacterial conjunctivitis is thick and globular and continues throughout the day. This is unlike the discharge of viral or allergic conjunctivitis, which is typically watery during the day and does not quickly recur. Bacterial conjunctivitis in adults who do not use contact lenses is commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus
species, or
Moraxella catarrhalis
and can be treated with erythromycin ointment or trimethoprim-polymyxin drops (
Option D
). In contact lens wearers,
Pseudomonas

is common in addition to these species, so the preferred treatment is topical fluoroquinolone therapy and discontinuation of contact lens use. Of note, patients with a red eye should be evaluated for warning signs and symptoms that would prompt urgent ophthalmology referral, including pain, reduction of visual acuity, photophobia, corneal opacity, or pupillary defects. This patient does not exhibit these symptoms.

Patients with allergic conjunctivitis often have ocular discharge that is typically watery, not persistently mucopurulent as seen in this patient. Allergic conjunctivitis usually presents with itching of the eyes, and patients also may report burning or grittiness. Systemic symptoms, such as sneezing or nasal congestion, are common. Topical antihistamine eyedrops, such as cetirizine eyedrops (
Option A
), are helpful for patients who have allergic conjunctivitis but are inadequate treatment for patients with contact lens−related bacterial conjunctivitis.
Glucocorticoid eye drops, such as prednisolone (
Option C

), have no value in the treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis and are associated with many harms, including worsening of infection, corneal scarring, and perforation. Longer-term consequences may include cataracts and glaucoma.

references: Lin A, Rhee MK, Akpek EK, et al; American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Pattern Cornea and External Disease Panel. Bacterial keratitis Preferred Practice Pattern

title: Question 244

children: A 36-year-old woman has a 3-year history of irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant subtype. She has pain and loose bowel movements at least three times weekly. Her original evaluation included negative results on fecal calprotectin testing and on testing for giardiasis and celiac disease. She has had no improvement in abdominal pain despite a diet low in FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) and treatment with rifaximin, eluxadoline, alosetron, and loperamide.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea include rifaximin, eluxadoline, and alosetron; other drugs with clinical evidence include loperamide, antispasmodics, and tricyclic antidepressants.
There is little or no evidence of effectiveness of probiotics or fecal microbial transplant in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.
The most appropriate treatment is a tricyclic antidepressant (
Option D

). Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is the most common functional gastrointestinal disorder, with a prevalence of 10% to 15% in the general U.S. population. The Rome IV criteria for diagnosis of IBS require symptoms of recurrent abdominal pain at least 1 day per week for a period of 3 months, along with at least two of the following three criteria: pain related to defecation, change in stool frequency, or change in stool consistency. Although multiple supplements and prescription medications have been used to treat IBS, the body of evidence in favor of some of those treatments is, at best, modest. Patients with IBS-D may benefit from dietary restrictions, including a low-FODMAP (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) diet. Prescription medications with FDA approval for treatment of IBS-D include rifaximin, eluxadoline, and alosetron. Other medications with clinical evidence for the treatment of IBS-D include loperamide, antispasmodics, and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). This patient has tried all the aforementioned interventions except for a TCA. Based on data from several randomized trials, TCAs offer modest relief of the abdominal pain and global symptoms of IBS-D. The American Gastroenterological Association has given a conditional recommendation based on low-quality evidence for the use of TCAs in the treatment of IBS-D.
A systematic review and meta-analysis concluded that fecal microbial transplant (
Option A
) was no more effective than placebo in the treatment of IBS. Results remained disappointing whether the transplant was administered by capsule, colonoscopy, or nasojejunal tube.
A gluten-free diet (
Option B

) is recommended for patients with celiac disease. This patient tested negative for celiac disease. Although a gluten-free diet has been empirically tried and studied for IBS, evidence for its use has been inconclusive.
Routine administration of probiotics (
Option C

) is not recommended. Some studies have reported improvement in diarrhea; however, the results are inconsistent, and the improvement is modest. A systematic review and meta-analysis of probiotics in IBS found that although specific combinations of probiotics (bacteria and yeasts) with prebiotics (fiber meant to promote colonic bacterial growth), synbiotics (combination of probiotics and prebiotics), and antibiotics may possibly be beneficial, conclusive evidence was lacking.

objective.__html: Treat irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant subtype.

references: Camilleri M. Diagnosis and treatment of irritable bowel syndrome: a review. JAMA. 2021;325:865-877.

title: Question 245

children: An audit of emergency department records reveals a high percentage of inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for upper respiratory tract infections. The importance of this finding was highlighted by the recent hospitalization of an elderly woman with drug-related hypersensitivity syndrome. Additionally, a noted increase in antibiotic resistance to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole has been documented. An intervention is planned to decrease inappropriate antibiotic prescribing.
Which of following is the most appropriate quality improvement intervention?

The Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle is a quality improvement approach in which a specific change is planned and implemented on a limited scale, the results are observed, and action is taken based on what is learned.
The Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle (
Option C

) is a quality improvement approach in which a specific change is planned and implemented on a limited scale, the results are observed, and action is taken based on what is learned. The first step in a PDSA cycle in this case would be to plan an intervention that would remedy inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for upper respiratory tract infections. The Act step involves refining the intervention to achieve the ideal outcome based upon what is learned by evaluating the limited intervention. This approach to quality improvement works well in a small-scale health care environment, such as a small office, as well as in a large-scale environment, such as a hospital or health care system.
The Lean model (
Option A

) aims to maximize value and minimize waste by closely examining a system's processes and eliminating non–value-added activities within the system. Value stream mapping can be used to graphically display the steps of a process and the time required for each step, thereby highlighting process inefficiencies or areas of waste and allowing for their improvement. Lean also uses a 5S strategy (Sort, Shine, Straighten, Systemize, and Sustain) to create an organized workplace. Lean, for example, may be used to improve the time used to obtain, submit, analyze, and report the results of a laboratory test. Lean may improve efficacy of certain processes in the emergency department but is not the best model to reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing.
Mandatory physician education (
Option B

) as a stand-alone intervention for quality improvement rarely, if ever, changes physician behavior. Physician education as part of a multimodal intervention, including a PDSA cycle, is much more likely to reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing.
Six Sigma (
Option D

) is a quality improvement model that improves processes by identifying and removing causes of error and minimizing variability in patient care. The term Six Sigma is derived from statistical quality control measures in manufacturing processes and refers to a process that delivers nearly perfect production quality. The Six Sigma model achieves quality improvement by implementing several methods, including the stepwise DMAIC (Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control) process. The Define step of DMAIC involves developing the objectives of the project. In the Measure step, baseline data on the number and types of defects within the system are measured. The Analyze stage uses the data collected to determine the magnitude of the effects. The Improve step involves implementation of tools to improve the process. Finally, in the Control phase, future processes are controlled to sustain the gains. Six Sigma may be applied to complex, multistep health care processes, such as the ordering and administration of high-risk medications like chemotherapy, to decrease medication errors. Six Sigma may be too cumbersome and complex to address inappropriate antibiotic prescribing in the emergency department.

objective.__html: Implement the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle in quality improvement.

references: Johnson MC, Hulgan T, Cooke RG, et al. Operationalising outpatient antimicrobial stewardship to reduce system-wide antibiotics for acute bronchitis. BMJ Open Qual. 2021;10.

title: Question 246

children: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 2-day history of a painful rash on the right side of her body. She is receiving chemotherapy for breast cancer.

On physical examination, temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F), blood pressure is 115/62 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 78/min. A vesicular rash on an erythematous base in various stages of development is present on her right posterior chest, flank, buttock, and thigh.
Which of the following infection control precautions should be initiated?
Patients with localized zoster who are not immunocompromised can be managed with contact precautions alone.
Airborne and contact precautions are appropriate infection control measures for patients who have disseminated zoster or who have localized zoster and are immunocompromised.
Airborne and contact precautions (
Option A

) for disseminated varicella-zoster virus reactivation are necessary for this patient. Varicella-zoster virus can be transmitted from persons with zoster to susceptible hosts (i.e., those who have never had chickenpox and are not vaccinated against it), who may develop chickenpox as a result of the exposure. The virus can spread through direct contact with active lesions, which is most common with localized zoster. Localized zoster is defined as rash in one or two dermatomes (most commonly along a thoracic dermatome) that does not cross the midline. Patients with localized zoster who are not immunocompromised can be managed with contact precautions alone; a person is no longer infectious after all the lesions have crusted over. Disseminated zoster is defined as a more widespread rash involving three or more dermatomes; it may appear similar to varicella (chickenpox). Vesicles usually appear in various stages of development and generally form over 3 to 5 days before they start to dry and crust over. Immunocompromised persons (such as this patient) are at increased risk for disseminated zoster, which may involve the respiratory tract. In patients with disseminated zoster or those who are immunocompromised, the virus may be transmitted via the airborne route from infected small (≤5 microns) respiratory droplet nuclei that can remain suspended for extended periods or travel long distances on air currents. Airborne (negative-pressure room; health care personnel [HCP] wear fit-tested N95 respirators) and contact precautions (single room; gloves and gown for HCP entering room) are appropriate infection control measures for patients who have disseminated zoster or localized zoster and are immunocompromised.
Contact precautions alone (
Option B
) would be appropriate for a patient with localized varicella-zoster virus reactivation but not disseminated infection.
Contact and droplet precautions (
Option C

) are insufficient to prevent the spread of varicella-zoster infection from a person with disseminated disease. Combination contact and droplet precautions are appropriate for patients with adenovirus infection.
Droplet precautions (
Option D

) are applied for organisms that are transmitted via large (>5 microns) droplets that travel less than 3 feet on air currents (such as respiratory viruses, pertussis, and mumps). Droplet precautions are insufficient to prevent the spread of varicella-zoster infection from a person with disseminated disease.

objective.__html: Prevent disseminated varicella-zoster virus nosocomial transmission.

references: Siegel JD, Rhinehart E, Jackson M, Chiarello L, Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee. 2007 Guideline for isolation precautions: preventing transmission of infectious agents in healthcare settings. Updated December 9, 2010. Accessed June 18, 2021.

children: www.cdc.gov/hicpac/2007IP/2007isolationPrecautions.html

title: Question 247

children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 3-week history of nonradiating low back pain that worsens with activity. She reports no fever, trauma, morning stiffness, weakness, or paresthesia. She has no other medical problems.
She is afebrile. Lumbar spine range of motion is limited due to pain. There is no spine or sacroiliac joint tenderness. Straight leg raise test is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
In patients in whom low back pain cannot be attributed to a specific disease or spinal abnormality (nonspecific low back pain), routine imaging or other diagnostic testing is not recommended.
In patients with back pain, immediate MRI should be obtained when there are risk factors for spinal infection or concern for cord compression or cauda equina syndrome.
This patient with acute nonspecific low back pain does not require additional testing or imaging (
Option D

). In patients with low back pain, the history and physical examination should focus on determining the likelihood of a specific cause of pain and identifying neurologic involvement. In patients in whom low back pain cannot be attributed to a specific disease or spinal abnormality (defined as nonspecific low back pain), routine imaging or other diagnostic testing is not recommended. Such testing should be reserved for patients in whom a serious underlying condition is suspected, those with severe or progressive neurologic deficits, or patients without symptom improvement after 4 to 6 weeks of conservative management. As this patient's pain meets the definition of nonspecific low back pain, no additional imaging or testing is indicated before initiating therapy.
An elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level is a marker of inflammation, and CRP measurement (
Option A
) is indicated only if a systemic inflammatory process or infectious cause of low back pain is suspected, neither of which is suggested in this patient.

When malignancy is suspected as the cause of back pain, guidelines recommend plain radiography in addition to measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate or CRP. If results of these initial tests are negative and significant concern remains, MRI should then be obtained (
Option B

). Immediate MRI should be obtained when there are risk factors for spinal infection or concern for cord compression or cauda equina syndrome. In patients with persistent pain despite conservative measures, symptoms/signs of radiculopathy, or spinal stenosis, MRI may be considered only if the patient is a potential candidate for surgical intervention.
Radiography of the lumbar spine (
Option C
) is indicated only if fracture, degenerative arthritis, or an inflammatory process such as ankylosing spondylitis is suspected, none of which are likely diagnostic considerations in this patient.

objective.__html: Evaluate acute nonspecific low back pain.

references: Popescu A, Lee H. Neck pain and lower back pain. Med Clin North Am. 2020;104:279-292.

title: Question 248

children: A 54-year-old man is evaluated for fever and altered mental status of 12 hours' duration. He has diabetes mellitus and underwent a prostate biopsy 5 days ago.
Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0 °F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse rate is 118/min, and respiration rate is 27/min. He is confused. Extremities are cool with livedo reticularis.
Blood cultures are obtained, serum lactate is measured, and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

Guidelines support collection of blood cultures, measurement of serum lactate levels, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and initiation of intravenous crystalloid fluid in patients with hypotension or signs of hypoperfusion, all within 1 hour.

Guidelines recommend against the routine use of glucocorticoids in patients with sepsis; glucocorticoid therapy is appropriate in patients with septic shock that is refractory to adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor administration.
This patient should receive a bolus of intravenous (IV) fluids (
Option B

). Guidelines support collection of blood cultures, measurement of serum lactate levels, administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, and initiation of intravenous crystalloid fluid in patients with hypotension or signs of hypoperfusion, all within 1 hour. The goal of initial fluid resuscitation of a patient with severe sepsis or septic shock is maintaining adequate tissue perfusion. The defining features of inadequate tissue perfusion may include any of the following: low arterial or venous pressure, tachycardia, tachypnea, central venous oxygen saturation less than 70%, oliguria, acidosis, delirium, cold extremities, elevated blood lactate, and livedo reticularis.
Guidelines recommend against the routine use of glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone (
Option A

), in patients with sepsis. However, glucocorticoid therapy is appropriate in patients with septic shock that is refractory to adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor administration. This patient should not be given a glucocorticoid until he has had adequate volume resuscitation and a trial of vasopressors, if indicated.
Vasopressor therapy with norepinephrine (
Option C

) may be necessary when appropriate fluid challenge of at least 30 mL/kg of IV crystalloid fluid given within the first 3 hours of presentation fails to restore adequate tissue perfusion or during life-threatening hypotension. Vasopressor therapy should not be administered before adequate volume replacement. The Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines support using norepinephrine as first-line therapy in patients who require vasopressor support, as it increases systemic vascular resistance without compromising myocardial performance (stroke volume or cardiac output). In cases in which norepinephrine alone is insufficient, secondary agents, including epinephrine, vasopressin (
Option D
), and dobutamine, may be considered.

objective.__html: Manage sepsis in a hospitalized patient.

references: Evans L, Rhodes A, Alhazzani W, et al. Surviving Sepsis Campaign: international guidelines for management of sepsis and septic shock 2021. Crit Care Med. 2021;49:e1063-e1143.

title: Question 249

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for the gradual onset of visual impairment over a period of 6 months. She has no other symptoms, including headache, pain with eye movement, seeing halos around lights, or photopsia.

Neurologic examination is otherwise normal. Confrontation testing shows diminished vision in the temporal fields. Formal visual field testing confirms this finding and ascertains that she has normal central visual acuity.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Bitemporal hemianopsia is most commonly caused by compression of the optic chiasm due to a sellar mass.
Patients suspected of having a sellar mass should be referred for pituitary MRI with gadolinium contrast.
The most likely diagnosis is a pituitary adenoma (
Option C

) in this patient with bitemporal hemianopsia, which is most commonly caused by compression of the optic chiasm due to a sellar mass. Pituitary adenomas are the most common cause of sellar masses. The onset of the visual field defect with a sellar mass is typically gradual. Patients suspected of having a sellar mass should be referred for pituitary MRI with gadolinium contrast. MRI can differentiate between pituitary hemorrhage and a sellar mass, and it can define the relationship between the mass and surrounding tissues.
Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) (
Option A

) is a progressive chronic disease involving the central retina. Patients with early AMD are often asymptomatic, although yellow drusen may be visible underneath retinal pigment epithelium. Patients with atrophic AMD, which accounts for 80% to 90% of AMD cases, note slowly progressive vision loss over years. AMD does not cause bitemporal hemianopsia and this patient has normal central vision, excluding the diagnosis of AMD.
Multiple sclerosis (
Option B

) commonly causes optic neuritis and/or eye movement abnormalities. Optic neuritis typically presents with unilateral eye pain that is worsened with eye movements and the presence of photopsia (flashing lights) and/or visual loss affecting central vision. Eye movement abnormalities in multiple sclerosis include abnormalities of voluntary gaze and nystagmus. These abnormalities present as diplopia or oscillopsia. Multiple sclerosis does not commonly affect the optic chiasm.

A rapidly growing pituitary tumor or rapid expansion due to pituitary apoplexy (sudden hemorrhage or infarction of a pituitary adenoma) causing compression of the optic chiasm may result in complete bitemporal hemianopsia or even blindness. Pituitary apoplexy may even result in cranial nerve palsies of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI, whereas a slowly growing pituitary tumor that abuts the optic chiasm may cause minimal or no loss in peripheral vision. title: Question 250

children: A 24-year-old man is evaluated for uncontrolled seizures. The seizures started 3 years ago, occur twice weekly, and are characterized by a sense of fear followed by lip smacking and impaired awareness. He currently takes levetiracetam and previously tried valproic acid and gabapentin, administered at maximally tolerated dosages, without improvement in seizure control.
Vital signs and physical examination are normal. Brain MRI is
shown
Which of the following treatments is most likely to lead to seizure remission?

text.__html: Initiation of the modified Atkins diet

children: An MRI finding of mesial temporal lobe sclerosis and seizure phenomenology consisting of an aura of fear followed by automatism and altered awareness are consistent with right temporal lobe epilepsy.
In patients with mesial temporal sclerosis and refractory seizures, a right temporal lobectomy offers a greater than 60% probability of seizure freedom.
This patient should undergo a right temporal lobectomy (
Option B

). He has medication-refractory epilepsy, defined as the persistence of disabling seizures for longer than 1 year despite treatment with adequate doses of two or more antiepileptic drugs. An MRI finding of a T2 hyperintense (bright) lesion in the right mesial temporal lobe
shown

and seizure phenomenology consisting of an aura of fear followed by automatism and altered awareness are consistent with right temporal lobe epilepsy associated with mesial temporal sclerosis. The goal of epilepsy surgery is to remove the area of the cortex that is the epileptogenic focus. The highest rates of seizure freedom are seen in patients with known lesions, such as a low-grade tumor or vascular malformation, or with temporal lobe epilepsy associated with mesial temporal sclerosis. A right temporal lobectomy offers a greater than 60% probability of seizure freedom (and even up to 80%, depending on results of further evaluation).
The modified Atkins diet (
Option A

) or ketogenic diet is a palliative treatment that may lessen the seizure burden in patients who are not candidates for epilepsy surgery. This option rarely leads to seizure freedom and is not appropriate for this patient who has no contraindications to epilepsy surgery.
This patient's seizures have been refractory to more than two medications. The likelihood that substituting or adding a new medication, such as lamotrigine (
Option C
), to his regimen would lead to seizure remission is less than 10%.
Although vagal nerve stimulation (
Option D

) reduces seizure frequency by 50% in 50% of patients, seizure remission is not common after placement of a vagal nerve stimulator. Therefore, a right temporal lobectomy is most appropriate for this patient at this time.

objective.__html: Treat refractory temporal lobe epilepsy with surgery.
